fields.headline: Waning windfalls turn off voters
fields.standfirst: Standard Life members' rejection of the carpetbagger route has cast a shadow over the mooted conversion of Bradford & Bingley, where prospects for the anti-mutuality vote look shaky, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Bradford & Bingley's planned conversion to a bank is under threat after Standard Life members showed this week that pro-mutual voters can scupper the best-laid plans of carpetbaggers.
fields.body:
Bradford & Bingley's planned conversion to a bank is under threat after Standard Life members showed this week that pro-mutual voters can scupper the best-laid plans of carpetbaggers.

Standard Life members turned their backs on windfalls worth on average £5,000. Bradford & Bingley's 2.5m savers and borrowers, who were sent voting packs this week, will be giving up mutuality for far less. At the time of B&B's first vote last year, windfall figures of £1,000-£1,500 were bandied about. But with the stockmarket much weaker, estimates of B&B's windfalls are no higher than £815 and could be as little as £500.

Pro-mutuality campaigners say the prospective windfall is so paltry that B&B's 350,000 mortgage holders will be worse off after two or three years. Demutualised Halifax currently charges 7.74% on its variable rate, while mutual flag-bearer Nationwide Building Society charges 7.29%. On a £60,000 mortgage the Nationwide borrower saves £204 a year, while on a £100,000 home loan it is £336.

If B&B moves its mortgage rate in line with Halifax and other demutualised lenders, then the extra interest payments are likely to wipe out the benefit of the windfall soon.

The borrowers' vote will be crucial. B&B's conversion cannot go ahead unless it receives a majority of borrowers' votes in favour. It also has to win the approval of 75% of savers and at least half of its savers must vote. Votes must be in by July 12 and the result will be announced on July 17.

However, the savers' vote is likely to be much more strongly in favour of conversion, as hundreds of thousands of them are believed to be carpetbaggers with as little as £100 in their accounts. It is difficult to argue how a small decrease in their interest income will wipe out the benefit of the windfall.

But even if B&B wins 100% support from savers, the conversion will fail if 51% of the borrowers voting vote against. At last year's vote, not a proper conversion ballot but more of an opinion poll, 62% of B&B members voted for conversion - but within that figure, 60% of borrowers voted against. So B&B's conversion is not a foregone conclusion.

Joining the battle to keep B&B mutual is an all-party group of MPs led by Andrew Love, MP for Edmonton. He says: "The tremendous Standard Life result places a whole new complexion on mutuality debate. Windfalls of £5-6,000 did not attract majority support. Members took a long-term view. All the calculations show that the windfall benefit for borrowers will be exhausted after just three or four years."

Mr Love is also pressing the Treasury to revise building society rules which mean that while 75% of savers have to approve a conversion, only 50% of borrowers have to do so. "Borrowers have a larger long-term interest, so why don't they have a bigger voice? Savers are benefiting at the expense of borrowers."

However, a spokesman for B&B said: "You have to bear in mind that the average mortgage length is actually 5-7 years, and the average size is £50,000, not £100,000. What's more, borrowers will become shareholders, and therefore get dividends as well. We also have no intention of suddenly jacking up mortgage rates."

webTitle: Get ahead of the fads choosing your own shares

fields.headline: Get ahead of the fads choosing your own shares
fields.standfirst: Teri Harman seeks tips from the experts on selecting this season's top stocks
fields.trailText: Teri Harman seeks tips from the experts on selecting this season's top stocks.
fields.body:
Nobody with any sense would invest all their life savings in the stock market. But if you've got enough cash stashed in safe investments, a portfolio of your own carefully selected stocks and shares could be just what you need to add a little spice to your finances.

You can trade at the click of a mouse. Tempted? For some tips to get you started we gave three stockbrokers a notional £25,000 and asked what shares they recommending buying to produce an annual pre-tax income of around £1,000 - a yield of 4% or around twice the average on the All-Share index.

Their consensus was that now is a good time to buy shares for income. As Greig Middleton's Jim Wood-Smith said: "There are plenty of quality companies offering significantly higher returns."

So meeting our target shouldn't be a problem. Investors' love affair with dot.com and hi-tech companies, though on the wane, has led to a neglect of "old economy" stocks. Our experts all agree many of these have fallen to very attractive levels. Here are their tips and selections:

 Jim Wood-Smith at Greig Middleton

"Follow two golden rules when seeking an income from shares. First, look at the forecast dividend, rather than last year's payment _ Second, check out the company's cash flow and balance sheet - paying a dividend requires hard cash.

"It's important, even with a relatively small portfolio, to spread your risk, so I suggest investing equally across 10 stocks, all blue-chip names forecast to yield more than 4% in the coming year: BOC (chemicals), TI Group (engineering and machinery), brewers Scottish & Newcastle and Whitbread, electricity suppliers Scottish Power and Scottish & Southern Energy, banks Abbey National and Lloyds TSB and real estate specialists Land Securities."

 William Younger at Killick & Co
"To meet the income criteria set, an investor could put half their £25,000 into a fixed-interest investment which would guarantee them an income, and invest the other half in equities for income and capital growth.

"If they wanted the whole lot in stocks, I'd suggest splitting the £25,000 equally between five companies: Powergen, Tomkins, IT Group, United Utilities and Wimpey."

 Jeremy Batstone at NatWest Stockbrokers

"I would suggest relatively risk-averse income-seekers consider the corporate bond market, plus convertible and preference shares. These can be converted into ordinary shares in future to 'lock in' capital gains, but initially provide a higher income.

"My current favourites, across which I recommend spreading your £25,000 equally, are:

 Bank of Scotland. Go for the 9.25% non-cum irredeemable preference shares, which have a current gross yield of 9.5%;

 Amec, the construction company. Buy the 6.5p convertible preference shares, currently priced at around 112p, with a gross yield of about 7.19%; and

 Caradon, the international group with diverse businesses. Again buy the 7.25p convertible preference shares, which have a gross yield of 9.11%.

"Then, for ordinary shares, pick BAT (British American Tobacco), provided you have no ethical objections, Whitbread, and Scottish & Southern Energy."

fields.headline: Sun, sea, solvency
fields.trailText: The holiday season is here again and airports are filling with people desperate to escape the hum-drummery of office life, the computers that won't work, the queues for sandwiches you don't really want, the in-house soap operas of gossip and back-stabbing.
fields.body:
The holiday season is here again and airports are filling with people desperate to escape the hum-drummery of office life, the computers that won't work, the queues for sandwiches you don't really want, the in-house soap operas of gossip and back-stabbing.

But if holidays are crucial therapy, they also have an uncanny ability to make all your money disappear. Whatever your spending plans, by the time you reach the airport departure lounge your wallet will have its own vapour trail of evaporating cash.

There's something about all that spare time, the expert wheedling skills of children and the influences of too much food and drink that turns us all into travelling cash fountains, spraying money in all directions and leaving the credit cards with punishing sunburn and red wine hangover.

So what can we do to limit the damage? Travel companies and banks all offer top tips for holiday cash. But, strangely enough, these often include altruistic suggestions like letting them sell you foreign currency or buying their travel insurance.

I've assembled my own more practical list of 10 ideas for holiday money saving, drawn from bitter experience.

1. Get to the airport as late as possible so you have no spending time: you'll arrive laden with cash and a misguided sense of optimism, making you extremely vulnerable to rash spending such as buying ridiculous holiday clothes you'll never wear or deciding you need something from the Daft Travel Gadget Shop, like a hat with a built-in reading lamp.

2. Changing money: ask if your own bank will change money without charging commission, as some accounts include this as an additional benefit Ñ for instance, the gold service current account with Lloyds TSB. Consider fixed-rate fees, rather than percentage charges, for buying larger amounts of foreign currency.

3. Annual insurance: if you're a regular traveller, annual insurance policies could well save you money. Even if you're only looking for one-off travel insurance, be careful about taking a policy included with a package deal not only because it won't be the cheapest, but also because the cover could be thinner than the plot of your airport novel.

4. Children: the age at which children become paying passengers on planes is two, so schedule your holidays to maximise free flying time.

5. Credit and debit cards: if you use credit cards as international cashpoint cards, get a debit card which can be used in machines abroad. Cards with the Cirrus symbol can draw cash straight out of your current account, saving you from racking up credit card bills.

6. Airport parking: this can be the shark in the paddling pool, quite capable of eating up more of your money than your flights. Check in advance about long-term parking costs, which might be enough to make a taxi or public transport preferable.

7. Hotel phones: make sure you know the rate they charge, because they can be a rip-off. I stayed in a hotel in Yorkshire a couple of months ago that charged almost £1 a minute for calls to London.

8. Car hire: this can have an infuriating habit of becoming much more expensive than you expected. This has happened to me on several occasions, with all kinds of charges, taxes, insurance and assorted mark-ups pushing the price way above the quote given on the phone. We've taken to paying in advance by credit card, which seems to have cut down on the arguments over what we thought we'd agreed to pay.

9. Buying abroad: with sterling so strong against Euro currencies, it can be cheaper to buy goods when you arrive at your holiday destination, including bigger items such as a video camera or holiday basics that are more expensive at home, such as sun tan lotion. If you want to compare prices, check out online stores in the country you're visiting.

10. Unpaid labour: make sure you take all your holidays. The most appalling news I've heard this week was that almost two-thirds of employees fail to take their full holiday entitlement. According to recruitment company totaljobs.com, the average worker misses 3.6 days leave each year, which represents a £6bn gift to employers.

Call me a work-shy old slacker if you like, but this is madness - giving your wages to a Bigger Bonuses for the Bosses scheme. It might leave me broke, but I'm taking all my holidays. See you on the beaches. I'll be the one wearing the cap with the built-in reading lamp.

coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

webTitle: Join the race for bigger rewards

fields.headline: Join the race for bigger rewards
fields.trailText: Fancy a regular income with a near-10% return? Then consider putting your cash into one of the 57 varieties of high-income bond, mostly offered by life insurance companies and often sold through mailshots.
fields.body:
Fancy a regular income with a near-10% return? Then consider putting your cash into one of the 57 varieties of high-income bond, mostly offered by life insurance companies and often sold through mailshots.

But these bonds, attractive as the headline rate might be, need careful scrutiny because they come with a few riders - some of which could wipe out up to half your money.

High-income bonds are equity-based products that promise a fixed income of about 8% to 9% over a fixed term, typically between three and five years. After this time the capital is returned on one condition - that the chosen stock market index has not fallen by more than a pre-determined amount over that time.

It is quite a catch. A typical deal would see you penalised heavily if the stock market fell more than 25%. After this threshold, 25% would be wiped off your investment and you would lose another 2% every time the index dropped a percentage point. And this downside is often hidden in the small print.

Alan Neale, from financial adviser R J Temple, says this has never happened for as long as the bonds have been going but "it does not mean to say that it won't".

"They are for investors on the point of retirement who are in need of additional income and who can afford to accept the element of risk to their capital," he says, adding that they are best suited to those with a reasonably large investment portfolio.

fields.headline: Clobber the taxman
fields.standfirst: You can put off declaring gains from with-profits bonds for years, reports Jenne Mannion
fields.trailText: You can put off declaring gains from with-profits bonds for years.
fields.body:
With-profits bonds from life insurance companies are an attractive option for investors who want to earn higher income than they would from a building society deposit, while steering clear of the volatility associated with direct equity investments.

A with-profit bond generally requires a minimum lump-sum investment of £5,000. There is no fixed term, although there are often early-surrender penalties during the first five years. This means that with-profits bonds should be considered for longer-term investments.

Last year more than £12bn was invested in with-profits bonds in Britain.

Life assurance companies invest with-profits funds in a range of assets including equities, property, gilts and cash. The returns from the highs and lows of these investments are smoothed out by holding back some of the profits when investment conditions are particularly good, thereby building up reserves for when markets are less lucrative.

Regular withdrawals can be taken without incurring an immediate tax bill and most with-profits bonds offer a range of payment frequencies, including monthly, quarterly, half yearly or annually. The withdrawals can be stopped or started at any time to meet changing requirements.

Ian Beestin, a director at the Nottingham-based With-Profits Bond Shop, reckons with-profits bonds are most likely to appeal to those at the early stages of retirement, who have probably just received a lump sum from their pension.

Kevin Minter, financial planning manager at the Woburn Sands-based David Aaron Partnership, says with-profits bonds also appeal to taxpayers, who receive generous tax treatment thanks to the bond's life assurance base. Investors can withdraw up to 5% a year free of further tax. This is particularly advantageous for higher-rate tax payers who can defer declaring gains for 20 years, or until the bonds are sold and then pay only 18% tax on any extra amount taken each year.

Most providers offer current annual bonus rates of between 5% and 6.25% net of basic-rate tax. Virtually all providers also offer a terminal bonus, which depends upon how well the investment has performed over the term of the policy. Terminal bonuses are not guaranteed.

According to Mr Beestin, the average rate of return over five years, after charges and net of basic-rate tax on with-profits bonds, was 10.3% a year. But this high level of return is unlikely to be sustained over the next five years as interest rates and investment returns are expected to fall.

"For investors wanting a higher level of income, there are some products which enable the withdrawal of both the annual bonus and what would normally be the terminal bonus," Mr Beestin said. "This was pioneered by Legal and General and more recently CGU has introduced a similar facility."

The main disadvantage of with-profits bonds, according to Mr Minter, is that most have an early encashment penalty, which is around 5% in year one and runs down to around 1% in year five and zero thereafter.

Another disadvantage to bear in mind is the market value adjustment factor, which means that if investment conditions are poor over a period of time, the actuaries at the life companies can reduce the policy's cash-in value to be "fair" to other with-profits investors.

webTitle: How to make your money pay... and pay... and pay...

fields.headline: How to make your money pay... and pay... and pay...
fields.trailText: Investing for a monthly income needn't be a risky procedure.
fields.body:
Investing for a monthly income needn't be a risky procedure. Most building societies and banks offer accounts and bonds which pay monthly interest for those looking to supplement pay cheques or pensions in the knowledge that their savings are safe from stock market turmoil.

But rates can vary immensely, with differences far greater than any recent changes in the Bank of England base rate. Some accounts come with guarantees, offering extra protection if rates fall - but no joy if they rise.

Before you decide on a savings vehicle, have a think about how important access to your cash is to you. Instant access accounts are available but most pay a lower rate than those with notice periods.

An exception is be Bristol & West's instant access "save.it" account. The hitch is that you must operate it solely via the internet.

Otherwise, getting a higher rate will probably mean agreeing to a notice period of between 30 and 90 days.

There can be restrictions on the number of withdrawals on notice accounts. Bristol & West's Easy Life 30-day notice account limits them to six a year, while Skipton Direct 30 account has a four-withdrawals ceiling.

Monthly interest paying bonds, the other main option for risk free investing, don't usually include bonuses. They work by locking in your initial lump sum for the life of the investment - usually one, two, three or four years. The upside of this is that the rates should be slightly better - Northern Rock, for example, offers 6.85% on all its bonds, regardless of what happens to base rates.

The downside is you can't access the money until the investment matures. Stepped bonds, which offer higher rates as the bond ages, can also be good value.

Bristol & West's Easy Life 30-day notice account limits them to six a year, while Skipton Direct 30 account has a four-withdrawals ceiling. Monthly interest paying bonds, the other main option for risk free investing, don't usually include bonuses. They work by locking in your initial lump sum for the life of the investment - usually one, two, three or four years. The upside of this is that the rates should be slightly better - Northern Rock, for example, offers 6.85% on all its bonds, regardless of what happens to base rates. The downside is you can't access the money until the investment matures. Stepped bonds, which offer higher rates as the bond ages, can also be good value.

webTitle: How gene blueprint will affect insurers

fields.headline: How gene blueprint will affect insurers
fields.standfirst: Reaching a century will become commonplace as the great leap forward in genetics translates into treatment. Jill Papworth and Jessica McCallin report
fields.trailText: Reaching a century will become commonplace as the great leap forward in genetics translates into treatment.
fields.body:
As scientists this week announced that we now have the draft blueprint for human life, insurance buyers and companies are asking how this breakthrough, perhaps the greatest in scientific history, will affect our finances.

Those behind breaking the genetic code reckon their research could eventually extend our lives by 20 years - not far-fetched, as the last century saw average UK life expectancy increase by two decades.

The commonsense response is that, if we live longer, life insurance should be cheaper as the chances of a claim are cut.

But pensions will become more expensive if we all start living to 100 but still retire at 65. Pension funds depend on numbers of members dying quickly after retirement to balance out the long-lived. If we all live longer, we will need bigger funds and hence bigger contributions.

And the effect on health and critical illness insurance premiums is a double-edged sword. Health insurance should be cheaper, but the cost of new treatments may push premiums up. The longer we live the more likely we are to succumb to illnesses which need, potentially, expensive treatment.

Critical illness cover is quite a different affair. If we get the medical breakthroughs promised, the need for critical illness insurance could be reduced.

At the moment, you pay your premiums so that if sickness strikes you get a lump sum payment to cover care and loss of earnings. But if some illnesses, such as cancer, become easier and quicker to treat, we may elect to have smaller lump sums and premiums should go down accordingly.

For this to happen the human genome project must lead to medical breakthroughs. But as Bupa's Dr Virginia Warren explains, the issue is not that simple: "Many of the genes which the project has discovered will not be involved in disease or, if they are, will be involved with a handful or other genes and lifestyle and environmental factors. We will have to establish how these factors interact before we can establish the likelihood of someone getting a disease and this will take years, if not decades."

Norwich Union agrees that the project's findings will not be immediate. "This will not happen overnight. An 80-year-old is not suddenly going to live until 100. People have gradually been leading longer and healthier lives and insurance companies have been continuing to accommodate this."

Dr Adrian Bull at PPP Healthcare believes financial products will evolve rather than change overnight. "Genetic information will provide risk management so we can gauge premiums more precisely," he says.

But in the meantime, under the Association of British Insurers' (ABI) code of practice on the use of genetic test results, insurers can only ask for the results of genetic tests you have already undertaken. They are not allowed to ask you to take a genetic test. Last year the government set up the Genetics and Insur ance Committee (GAIC), to assess applications for the use of results of specified genetic tests for specified insurance purposes.

This was partly in response to consumer fears that insurers will eventually make the leap from requesting disclosure of existing genetic test results to insisting that applicants undergo genetic tests as a condition of being offered insurance.

The concern is that, as tests are developed to predict the risk of individuals developing a range of diseases in later life, insurers will make such tests compulsory in order to cherry-pick the least risky applicants. Those with genetic predispositions to chronic conditions would, at best, face considerably higher premiums for life and health-related insurance and, at worst, be uninsurable.

But the ABI insists: "We are not out to get people to go and take genetic tests. While the majority of insurers now require the disclosure of genetic tests already undertaken, to ask people to take tests would be a massive step and one we have absolutely no interest in taking."

Disclosure of health facts will still be prompted by standard medical and family history questions on insurance application forms and premiums loaded accordingly. But will there not be more discrimination if, as is predicted, tests are developed which can indicate whether people have a raised risk of common conditions such as heart attacks and strokes later in life?

John Gillot of the Genetic Interest Group, which supports those affected by genetic disorders, thinks not. "As long as insurers don't start asking people to be tested, which they say they will not, risk-factor genetics shouldn't be that significant for life insurance."

Crack the code

For copies of the ABI's Code of Practice or information sheet on Genetic Tests and Insurance, contact 020-721-67493 or www.abi.org.uk.

Other useful contacts include the Genetic Interest Group (GIG) 020-7704-3141 (www.gig.org.uk) and the UK Forum for Genetics and Insurance (UKFGI) 020-7632-2136, (www.ukfgi.org.uk).

fields.headline: Charcol managers may lose out
fields.trailText: Top branch managers at mortgage brokers John Charcol - bought for £100m by Bradford & Bingley in February - are threatening legal action which could jeopardise B&B's share value if the building society demutualises. They say they are victims of unfair management decisions.
fields.body:
Top branch managers at mortgage brokers John Charcol - bought for £100m by Bradford & Bingley in February - are threatening legal action which could jeopardise B&B's share value if the building society demutualises. They say they are victims of unfair management decisions.

Directors of the regional Charcol branches have 20% stakes in each local venture, with the B&B-controlled holding company owning the rest.

But now they say the sell-out to the building society means their efforts could be worthless. For B&B has said it intends to build up the Charcol- online brand and, more importantly, have John Charcol-labelled employees in branches.

"The local directors' equity will become worthless," says solicitor Gareth Fatchett at Birmingham firm Armstrong Neal. "They joined expecting their shares would be valuable, but only if they hit targets which will be impossible when B&B sets up in competition. My clients are concerned, so they are signalling worries for their futures and for the quality of B&B management before a flotation."

Charcol main board director Ian Darby says: "We understand the concerns of the present branch directors because we have not yet articulated the roles they will have in the wider context. We could have bought them out but we did not see the need."

Later this month, Charcol representatives will move into northern region B&B branches in a trial. Charcol is a powerful brand; some in the City suggest the group would be worth more with the Charcol label than with B&B.

webTitle: Set your sights on higher returns

fields.headline: Set your sights on higher returns
fields.standfirst: Jobs & Money looks at ways to ensure a monthly or annual cash boost - while safeguarding your future
fields.trailText: Jobs & Money looks at ways to ensure a monthly or annual cash boost - while safeguarding your future.
fields.body:
Everyone would like more income. But all too often income seekers just look for the biggest percentage and forget about the future.

The choice is enormous. There are annuity schemes which guarantee you will lose all your money - in return for a high monthly income. These are free of all risk: you know what you will get and that the capital is lost when you die.

At the other end of spectrum stand income-oriented investment trusts. Financial advisers, who rarely sell them and even less often understand them, say these are very risky. But as they offer the returns on £1,000 for an outlay of about £850, investors have a cushion.

Before choosing, savers need to analyse their needs to decide which stage they are at in their investment career:

First stage income seekers are largely comfortable with the cash that hits their bank accounts each month. Their main concern is the future, so they want their capital to grow. They expect annual pre-tax returns of around 3%.

Ideas for this group include:

 Equity income unit trusts, which pay a lowish dividend coupled with hopes of underlying fund increases - all can be included in a tax-free Isa;

 Investment trusts with an income portfolio - thanks to the typical 15% or so discount, purchasers can buy the income stream for less than its face value;

 To go for growth now but encash enough shares or units each year to meet any needs using the £7,200 annual capital gains tax exemption.

Second stage income seekers need more - often to boost a pension - but do not want to take undue risks with their underlying capital. Here a conservative target is 6% before tax.

Those in this situation could look at:

 Corporate bond unit trusts, preferably held through Isas. Many will pay out quarterly or monthly;

 Insurance-based with-profits bonds;

 Building society and bank deposits that pay monthly income;

 A portfolio of zero dividend investment trust shares which can take advantage of the CGT exemption;

 Guaranteed income bonds from life insurance companies based on gilts - these have some tax advantages.

Third stage income seekers want to maximise their income irrespective of what happens to their capital. They will typically be older people - many of whom have calculated that turning capital into income rather than leaving it in wills makes life more enjoyable and ensures inheritance tax does not eat up 40% of their estates. Here income could be in the high single figures.

Ideas include:

 Life insurance ultra-high income bonds based on stock market indices;

 Annuities - they have tax advantages outside personal pensions;

 Home income plans that unlock part of the value of a property and turn it into a regular income for life.

But whichever route income seekers choose, there is no point in hankering after that golden era 10 years ago when risk-free double-digit yields were easy to find.

Wade Pollard, a fund manager at HSBC, explains: "We could then get high yields and grow dividends by substantial percentages each year. But inflation meant dividend cheques bought the same goods or often less, despite appearing to increase.

"Now inflation is low so money buys the same goods as last year."

webTitle: Take your place in the sun

fields.headline: Take your place in the sun
fields.standfirst:
Offshore accounts are not just for the wealthy, or criminals: even lower rate taxpayers can gain, reports Liz Stuart

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Offshore accounts are not just for the wealthy, or criminals: even lower rate taxpayers can gain, reports Liz Stuart
fields.body:
The furore surrounding Lord Levy's tax payments has put the spotlight on how individuals can legally limit their tax burdens. The average, law-abiding UK punter can use offshore accounts to help with tax planning and make their investing more tax efficient, provided some caveats are taken into account.

Whatever the mythology of secret Swiss bank accounts, offshore does not spell tax evasion. Craig Wetton, chief executive of independent financial advisers Chartwell Asset Management, says: "The whole point of offshore investing is that you can defer paying tax, not avoid paying it forever. If you think that you can put the money overseas and never have to declare it, you are on to very dodgy ground. You declare these investments in the same way as any other."

In other words, on savings accounts you will have to pay the tax at some point in the future and with investment bonds you will have to pay the tax upon encashment.

Because you can roll over tax obligations, offshore accounts are used for tax planning purposes, mainly by higher rate tax payers who have already used up their tax allowances on their UK investments.

Clever planning means you can roll over your tax obligations into a year when you are not using your full capital gains tax allowance and so avoid paying capital gains tax, or if you are a higher rate income tax payer, you can defer some income tax liability until you retire, when you may fall into the basic rate payer category.

Lower rate payers can also make use of the tax advantages: you can offset your tax allowance against offshore bonds, as payouts are gross and not net as with their UK equivalents.

The best rates on £10,000 with instant access to your cash are offered by Skipton Guernsey, whose Guernsey Access account pays 6.25% gross, although there is a minimum withdrawal of £500, and Cheshire Guernsey which is offering 5.85% gross on its Offshore Access account, this time with a minimum withdrawal of £1,000. Interest is paid annually in both cases.

If you want a higher rate but will not need to get hold of your money so quickly, the Anglo Irish Bank, based on the Isle of Man, is offering 6.55% gross on its Privilege account which has a nine day notice period.

But there are potential pitfalls. Wetton says that you should stick with the familiar: "Everyone has heard of Jersey and Guernsey, but who knows where the Dutch Antilles are?

It also makes sense to go for a brand name you know from the UK high street. Most building societies and some banks have offshore divisions."

If you do want to invest further afield, you should try to pick a country which has tight financial regulation, such as Bermuda.

Halifax has two international operations, one in the Isle of Man which caters for UK-based customers and one in Jersey for ex-pat customers, the majority of whom are resident in Saudi Arabia or Spain.

David Wilkinson, business operations manager for Halifax Isle of Man, says: "Our UK customers tend to be fairly high net-worth individuals who have already exhausted their tax planning possibilities onshore." The average investment is £20,000-£30,000 and if customers chose to roll over their tax liability until the next tax year, this can save them hundreds of pounds.

And if you want to hold a dollar or euro account, the Isle of Man operation is the only part of Halifax offering this.

"These are still niche products, but people use them if they tend to travel abroad frequently, or if they work for foreign companies and are paid in dollars or simply because they want to pay the currency rate game: for the first time I can remember the US Federal Reserve rate (currently at 6.35%) is higher than UK bank base rates," says Wilkinson.

But the most effective way of putting your money offshore is to take yourself with it: spend all but 90 days of the year abroad and you will not be eligible for the UK's high rates at all.

fields.headline: Universal challenge
fields.standfirst: A new bank based in Post Offices will offer the 3.5m Britons who do not have accounts a basic service, reports Jessica McCallin
fields.trailText: Forget shopkeepers, we'll soon be a nation of bank account holders if government plans to offer banking to the socially excluded through the Post Office come to fruition.
fields.body:
Forget shopkeepers, we'll soon be a nation of bank account holders if government plans to offer banking to the socially excluded through the Post Office come to fruition.

Universal Bank will offer basic banking services to the estimated 3.5m Britons who do not have a bank account, mainly because their credit profile is not profitable enough for the high street banks. Overdrafts will not be available, but account holders will be able to write cheques, use cash withdrawal machines and gain access to reasonably priced loans.

They will also be able to set up direct debit transfers, which should mean savings on bills such as gas, telephone and electricity. People who already have bank accounts but want their state benefits paid into a different account will also be allowed to bank with Universal, pushing the number of customers the Post Office is expecting up to 4m.

The idea is rooted in the government's desire to cut its social security bill by paying benefits and pensions straight into bank accounts by 2003. The current system of paying benefits over Post Office counters costs the benefits agency £400m a year.

By automating the service, the government thinks it can shrink this bill, although it acknowledges that old habits die hard and that customers used to drawing their benefit or pension in cash over the Post Office counter must continue to have this choice.

It also forms part of a wider government rescue package for the Post Office's failing 19,000 branch network. With 94% of the UK population living within one mile of a Post Office, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said Post Offices are a crucial and trusted part of the country's fabric, providing valuable services to, among other things, isolated rural and deprived urban areas. But the network needs to modernise.

However, with income from the benefits agency cut - the Post Office estimates it will only make £200m a year by administering Universal - the network will need to find other ways of raising money. Other ideas are for the Post Office network to act as a provider of general government information to the public. Facilities for training people on the internet and using the branch network as a focal point for community e-commerce are also being mooted.

Other money raising ideas include closer partnership with commercial banks. At present, customers from Barclays, Lloyds, the Co-operative Bank and Cahoot, the Abbey National offshoot, can do basic banking transactions through the Post Office, but the organisation hopes to extend this system to other high street banks to make up its £200m shortfall. The Post Office also needs the expertise of the banks when setting up the system.

Co-operating with the Post Office would be one way for the banks to meet the obligations placed on them by the Treasury to help the socially excluded, but a spokesman for the British Bankers' Association was vague about the amount of support the Post Office can expect from banks.

"High street banks are not a monolithic whole," he said. "They have very different procedures and views on social exclusion. The devil is usually in the detail, so until formal talks are held with the banks it's hard to say which ones will want to support it."

He added, however, that not all banks see low-income people as bad customers who will never take out loans, credit cards and mortgages. Some see the possibility of growing them into profitable customers, so if these banks see the Post Office initiative as a threat, we may see heightened efforts by some commercial banks to offer accounts to the worst-off.

Universal will be jointly owned by the Post Office and the commercial banks which make a contribution. The government has hinted that it might provide some financial support but would prefer this to come from the banks. Basil Larkin, managing director of network banking at the Post Office, wants the government to pay a set amount for every account opened under the scheme.

The Post Office will draw up a business plan in the next few months and is aiming to test the new system in a limited area by the end of the year.

"High street banks are not a monolithic whole," he said. "They have very different procedures and views on social exclusion. The devil is usually in the detail, so until formal talks are held with the banks it's hard to say which ones will want to support it." He added, however, that not all banks see low-income people as bad customers who will never take out loans, credit cards and mortgages. Some see the possibility of growing them into profitable customers, so if these banks see the Post Office initiative as a threat, we may see heightened efforts by some commercial banks to offer accounts to the worst-off. Universal will be jointly owned by the Post Office and the commercial banks which make a contribution. The government has hinted that it might provide some financial support but would prefer this to come from the banks. Basil Larkin, managing director of network banking at the Post Office, wants the government to pay a set amount for every account opened under the scheme. The Post Office will draw up a business plan in the next few months and is aiming to test the new system in a limited area by the end of the year.

fields.headline: Cheerful prognosis for health sector
fields.standfirst: As the human genome project dramatically expands the frontiers of knowledge, Robin Stoddart picks the companies most likely to reap the benefits
fields.trailText: As the human genome project dramatically expands the frontiers of knowledge, Robin Stoddart picks the companies most likely to reap the benefits.
fields.body:
In sickness and in health, the share market always throws up some winners. This week it was the pharmaceutical sector that sparkled on the back of the epoch-making - or breaking - advance in gene mapping. High-level stomach troubles upset other technology issues and interest rate concerns bled most financial centres.

Along with Glaxo Wellcome and impending new partner SmithKline Beecham, earlier stage drug groups Celltech and Shire Pharmaceuticals were among the strongest performers. AstraZeneca is still piling up revenues from its ulcer treatment as the two larger groups did previously in the same field, before their patents expired. Cancer therapies and a prospective cholesterol treatment brought a strong broker's recommendation for the Swedish-UK group.

The publicity given to the resolution of the human genome chain by scientists on both sides of the Atlantic lifted several shares, most notably Nycomed Amersham on the European shore. The UK part of the Anglo-Norwegian combine started as part of the old Atomic Energy Authority's radiation offshoot and was one of the earliest and most popular privatisations.

Outside these leaders, who have every reason to wel come the increase in knowledge of how disease may stem from variations in people's genetic make-up and indications of means of prevention, smaller and newer companies have proliferated by the score, particularly in the US. Their names may give some clue to their area of expertise: sometimes the layman is none the wiser. That points up the advantage of investing in a fairly widely-based fund specialising in the area.

At least the managers are building up their knowledge and expertise and not starting from scratch with the shots in the dark that the public, even serial investors, may otherwise be making. The rise and fall of British Biotechnology a few years ago, when claims to likely breakthroughs in some crucial fields were shown to be wildly exaggerated, exposed the risks.

Famine to feast has been the recent record of the handful of investment companies specialising in the field. The change from gloom to euphoria has been nowhere so marked as in the Rothschild fund management group. Its Guernsey-based Biotechnology Investments concentrated primarily on small US companies floated in IPO (initial public offering) issues. Until the spring of last year these companies performed poorly compared with their larger brethren and Rothschild decided to withdraw from the highly specialist area.

A mooted merger with International Biotechnology Trust (IBT) consequently fell through in the same stable. BI's residual holdings were passed to 3i's Bioscience investment trust a few months ago. It has since performed well. The boom in US biotechnology issues that began a year ago multiplied IBT's asset value as the imminence of the completion of the human genome project spurred on some remarkable gains.

In the half year to February 29 IBT shares soared by 480% and the recent interim report is ebullient about new investments, while reporting on spectacular realisation and appreciation gains. Liquid assets rocketed to just over £50m from next to nothing and unrealised appreciation climbed by £200m to £225m.

Recent additions to the portfolio included Delsys Pharmaceuticals of the US, in which IBT was the lead subscriber for the development of faster and better oral drug products by the company. This month $8m was invested in a Canadian company, Inflazyme, which is developing treatments for inflammatory diseases, including asthma and arthritis.

Franco-US group ValiGen is the subject of a similar investment. In the words of chairman John Green-Armytage, who has a long record in expanding high-technology companies in electronics as well as pharmaceuticals: "ValiGen's integrated portfolio of bioinformatics, genomics and chimeraplast technologies enables the identification and validation of novel targets for both pharmaceutical and agricultural products." Impressive, if hard to follow.

The identification of other success stories in genomics in the UK will not be easy and it could be years before the real winners among smaller companies emerge. Recent gainers in the wider sector include Powderject, which is more readily comprehensible as it offers superior injection equipment. Oxford Glycosciences and Cambridge Antibody have also attracted strong support, but sales are so far small and the cash burn-up continues.

International Biotechnology will remain in the news because Millennium Partners, a break-up specialist, has called a meeting for next Friday in which it will try to secure capital repayments to shareholders.

This is because the asset value remains well above the share price in spite of recent buying and the excellent growth which has been achieved over the past nine months. IBT managers were awarded millions in performance fees as a result, although share options lapsed a year ago and the accounts were retrospectively qualified because of changes in the share capital that were not recorded after new shares had been fully converted.

A true and fair view is now given, after amendments, KPMG, the auditors confirm. There is no reason not to applaud the outstanding recent growth. Whether human engineering and longevity open up a new promised land is more questionable.

webTitle: Don't fancy chancing your capital? Consider a corporate bond fund

fields.headline: Don't fancy chancing your capital? Consider a corporate bond fund
fields.trailText: Corporate bond funds have built up a reputation for high income while not putting your capital at any great risk.
fields.body:
Corporate bond funds have built up a reputation for high income while not putting your capital at any great risk.

But as more and more bond funds crowd into the market, you have to be more careful than ever that some of the tasty yields on offer are as good as they look - and that you aren't taking more risk with your capital than you can afford.

Corporate bonds are securities issued by companies to raise money. Unlike ordinary shares, whose year-to-year dividend is unpredictable, corporate bonds pay a fixed income each year and promise to return the capital on a fixed date. In this way, bonds sit far lower down the risk ladder.

You can invest in corporate bonds individually through a stockbroker, but most brokers will be looking to buy £100,000-worth of bonds at a time.

More practical is to buy into a corporate bond fund, which spreads its money across dozens of different bonds and employs a professional fund manager to decide which ones to buy.

fields.headline: Unknown pleasures
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia Orchestra/ Leonard Slatkin
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia Orchestra/ Leonard Slatkin
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Aaron Copland may be one of the most under-appreciated composers of the 20th century. Not in terms of exposure, but in the way so much of his output remains buried beneath the blockbusting popularity of works like Billy the Kid or Rodeo. Leonard Slatkin's programme with the Philharmonia, part of the celebrations marking Copland's centenary year, was a super-abundant attempt to represent every side of Copland's creativity, and to put the historical record straight.

Connotations, written in 1962 for the opening of New York's Lincoln Center, was the least well-known and most "difficult" work in the concert. On the surface, this 20-minute orchestral essay belongs to Copland's abstract style. But in reality, Connotations is a post-romantic orchestral showpiece, complete with batteries of percussion and impassioned string lines. For all its pervasive dissonance, the shape and flow of the music are grounded in conventional idioms.

Hearing Connotations just after Appalachian Spring revealed that although Copland's oeuvre may seem to contain a schizophrenic split between abstraction and accessibility, there is a genuine continuity between all of his works. The same concern for clarity defines the orchestration of Connotations as it does the wide-open harmonies at the end of Appalachian Spring.

If there is one piece which embodies the gamut of Copland's compositional continuum, it is his settings of poems by Emily Dickinson. Responding to Dickinson's lucid imagery, Copland employed the range of his creative techniques to depict nature's glories and the inevitability of death. Soprano Barbara Bonney was ideally attuned to the vivid spirituality of the music. The Philharmonia conjured a soundworld of Mahlerian subtlety, from impetuous birds to the tread of death's carriage.

Copland's flirtation with jazz was illustrated by Michael Collins in the Clarinet Concerto, written for Benny Goodman in 1948. The opener was the Fanfare for the Common Man, while Slatkin closed with the Four Dance Episodes from Rodeo. The comforting familiarity of these pieces was fascinatingly reinterpreted by the less- celebrated riches of the other works on the programme.

fields.headline: Experiments with Elvis
fields.standfirst:
Composers Ensemble/ Michael Thomas
Almeida, London
***
fields.trailText:
Composers Ensemble/ Michael Thomas
Almeida, London
***
fields.body:
The Juliet Letters, Elvis Costello's collaboration with the Brodsky Quartet, saw a classical ensemble working in the loose, creative manner of a rock or jazz group. They made music in the studio and the lines between writing, arranging, performing and recording became blurred. That experience inspired ex-Brodsky violinist Michael Thomas to score and conduct a whole Costello-based evening with the Composers Ensemble of piano, flute, clarinet and four strings. The atmospheric Almeida provided all the signifiers of hardcore contemporary, from the rows of empty seats to the silent pauses and shuffling of hastily copied parts between numbers: no crossover nonsense here.

Hearing Costello's songs as chamber music, without the cracked varnish of the master's voice, is a surprise: with its resolutely British melodic invention and chord twists it's like Darmstadt never happened. Shaky at first, the band gained confidence throughout the evening. Thomas's nervousness vanished whenever he picked up the fiddle to augment the band or play solo (for a superb Birds Will Still Be Singing). Narrator Johnny Brown, with jet black hair, black sweater and jeans, added a punkish element to several numbers, as he ranted Costello's acerbic words (including Stalin Malone) over the intricate charts.

Thomas's arrangements covered all bases: he confessed his fear that he had "gone too far" in the virtuoso coda to Couldn't Call it Unexpected, but this was well within the compass of the performers. Playing the simple bits was more tricky.

A big surprise came when Thomas grabbed the microphone. Classical musicians do burst into song from time to time - from avant-garde chanting to the Gogmagogs' fine John Tavener piece - but you sensed that this was a rite of passage for Thomas. His vocal performances, on songs such as King of the Unknown Seas and his own Ruin, were moving and naked in a way that the ensemble wasn't. Apparently Thomas decided to do this at the last minute. It was clearly seat-of-the-pants stuff and I'm afraid it didn't always work.

But for the finale the composer, who had been listening in the audience, climbed up to sing Favourite Hour. Despite Costello's modest "I'm just another musician" demeanour, he sang his heart out before the arrangement subsided into a lengthy coda for pianist Catherine Edwards.

Super-8 images flickered on the unplastered back wall of the theatre. You could hear a pin drop. The event was an experiment, an unclassifiable, unpredictable curiosity and a rare treat for completist Elvis fans.

webTitle: Happy customers earn extra £116,000 for Nationwide chief

fields.headline: Happy customers earn extra £116,000 for Nationwide chief
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nationwide building society last night defended a £116,000 rise in the pay of its chief executive, Brian Davis, to £737,000 last year - claiming that he would earn more if the building society were a bank.
fields.body:
Nationwide building society last night defended a £116,000 rise in the pay of its chief executive, Brian Davis, to £737,000 last year - claiming that he would earn more if the building society were a bank.

The increase followed a revision in the structure of an annual bonus scheme at the start of the year.

Mr Davis' annual bonus of £164,000 was based on two performance measures - member satisfaction and efficiency - rather than profitability, while the medium-term bonus of £129,000 is based on the achievement of group performance targets over a three-year period.

In total, the executive direc tors on the board of the society were paid £2.4m in the year to April 4, up from £1.9m last year.

News of Mr Davis's pay followed the disclosure that Dino Adriano, the former chief executive of Sainsbury, received a £1.2m payoff. He also earned £546,000 that year.

Sainsbury's annual report also disclosed that none of its directors received their annual bonuses last year because they failed to achieve the performance criterion.

After a difficult period in which Sainsbury was outpaced by Tesco and Asda, the supermarket chain poached Sir Peter Davis as its new chief executive - on a lucrative and unusual three-year contract - from Prudential.

In total, the recent upheaval on the board of the supermarket group has led to payments to the ousted directorstotalling more than £3.5m.

David Bremner, the deputy chief executive, and Kevin McCarten, head of stores, received payoffs of £788,000 and £525,000 respectively following their departures. They left just days after the arrival of the new chief executive.

Rosemary Thorne, the former finance director, received £402,000 in compensation while another former director, David Clapham, was paid £486,000 for loss of office.

The group is in the process of transferring executives to one-year contracts from two, in line with industry recommendations.

fields.headline: The old men's turn
fields.standfirst:
Henry IV Part 2
Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
****
fields.trailText:
Henry IV Part 2
Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
****
fields.body:
I'd rather watch Shakespeare's two Henry IV plays than almost anything else in the canon. And Michael Attenborough's new production, part of the RSC's This England season, fully grasps the distinction between the two parts: this second play, in contrast to the invigorating first, is a prolonged meditation on time, death, age and the mutability of human affairs.

You see this most vividly in Desmond Barrit's Falstaff. A limping, white-haired, bearded figure he knows his end is near and is determined to make the most of it. But there is nothing sentimental about this Falstaff: he is predatory, parasitic and quite prepared, when Hal becomes king, to make the law his plaything. Barrit's achievement is to make you see the necessity of his rejection even while regretting it. The only quality missing was the racking awareness of his own childlessness which made Robert Stephens's Falstaff so memorable.

This production is at its best in those unforgettable scenes, the high watermark of Shakespearean realism, in Justice Shallow's Gloucestershire orchard. The rustic recruiting is very funny with Wart played as a bent-double figure who keels over at the slightest touch. Benjamin Whitrow's Shallow is a toothless local bigwig wrapped in a world of self-delusion. But my particular delight was Peter Copley's Silence, a spryly mischievous elder rolling his eyes heavenward at Shallow's Latinate pretensions and, when under the influence, breaking into song like a delirious thrush.

There are times when you feel this wide-ranging epic is cramped by the space: it seems odd that William Houston's Hal has to make his post- coronation entrance through a cluster of trees. And, good as Houston and David Troughton's spiritually anguished Henry IV are, their final bedside encounter is played as if they were addressing a public meeting rather than each other.

But, in a strong cast, Clifford Rose's poker-backed Lord Chief Justice, David Killick's militant Archbishop of York and Danielle Tilley's exceptionally fetching Doll Tearsheet all take the eye. Doll's youth stands in poignant contrast to the sense of mortality and decline that threads its way through this threnodic masterpiece.

 Until October 7. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: Cork saves day for England
fields.standfirst:
West Indies on the back foot as Stewart's gamble at the toss pays off
West Indies 267 for 9
fields.trailText:
West Indies are put on the back foot as Alec Stewart's gamble at the toss pays off
West Indies 267 for 9
fields.body:
If it can be unwise to judge a book by the lure of the cover, or an opera by the overture alone, then it pays doubly not to draw early conclusions about a game of Test cricket on the strength of the first session.

After the first hour of this 100th test at Lord's the West Indies openers were powering along at a run-a-ball rate, the England bowling carried the lustre of a tarnished pewter and catches - all of them difficult but none impossible - had been shelled like peas. England, so the chatter had it, were down and out before the game was out of its wrappers and, as they had loaded the side with seamers and stuck the opposition in, it was their own jolly fault.

Such things should be viewed in the overall context of the game though, for a test is played not over one hour but 30. Although West Indies had counter-attacked strongly and ominously in the final half an hour before bad light ended play four balls from the scheduled end, England had picked themselves up and battled back into the game, having taken eight for 105 in the second part of the day after the first two wickets had yielded 162.

West Indies will resume this morning on 267 for nine, with a ball just seven overs old and Reon King at the crease with Courtney Walsh. It ought to be a swift end first thing and a chance for the real hard graft to begin.

The England resurgence was primarily due to the bowling of Dominic Cork, who should have business cards printed: "Spectacular returns a speciality". This is his third incarnation as a test player and on his return to the fold last time, against South Africa at Edgbaston two years ago, he responded with five for 93.

He did not quite manage that yesterday, but four for 39 from 24 overs represented an excellent day's work. All his wickets came in a 17-over spell, broken only by tea, at a cost of just 23 runs.

It was Cork back somewhere near his compelling best; when his rhythm is spot on, he hits the crease hard, the ball snakes around at a lively pace, he dreams up his variations and that theatrical groin-thrusting appeal rents the air.

Supportive as ever, and providing the heartbeat of the side, was Darren Gough, who traded punches like an old pugilist and picked up four for 72, including the wickets of Brian Lara for six and Jimmy Adams for one. Gough also dismissed Franklyn Rose, and Shivnarine Chanderpaul, just when it seemed he might be snatching the game away from England once more.

The rest went wicketless, with the only other success the needless run-out of Adrian Griffith by Andy Caddick's smart pick-up and devastating throw from long-leg in the first over after lunch. Until then, the bowling had looked down and the day set fair for a large total.

Matthew Hoggard, selected in place of Robert Croft, must be pinching himself so rapidly has he been elevated through the ranks. He announced himself with a tidy first spell, beating Sherwin Campbell's bat several times in his first over.

Thereafter, though, he was ignored until Rose was into his stride. Abandoning his length, Hoggard suffered the consequences by going for 16 off his final over of the day.

Of Caddick, there is little to say except that, once again, his bowling lacked teeth and it is time he found some dentures.

West Indies got off to a flyer, with Campbell and Griffith largely untroubled except when Campbell edged Gough perilously close to Cork at third slip. Nick Knight, who should have been there, might have caught this, as well as a later chance offered by Griffith to White off Cork's bowling.

But Knight spent the day in the infield, swathed in a long sweater. A stiff back, not deemed serious, was the explanation, but clearly he was not fit at the start and is playing, presumably, because there was no alternative.

One later chance went begging when Campbell, on 35, flashed hard at Cork. Graeme Hick, at second slip, parried the low catch away with his left hand as the first slip Mike Atherton made to take it. Had even two of those chances been taken, Alec Stewart's decision to bowl first would have been vindicated.

Cork and Hoggard had already pegged the batting back in the second hour before the run-out gave them an unexpected inroad. Campbell and Wavell Hinds then added 82 for the second wicket, wrenching back the initiative, with Hinds driving handsomely in a free-flowing Sobersish left-handed way but troubled by the straight bouncer.

However shortly before tea Campbell, on 82 with a century in sight, was suckered into hooking Cork's bouncer to Hoggard, the finer of two men placed out for the shot, and the whittling process began.

The key to this was Lara who, in a fantasy match, would have graced the occasion with a century. But Gough did for him before he got going as he drove wildly. Then, in quick succession, Hinds followed caught at the wicket in similar fashion off Cork and Adams was lbw. By now Cork was bringing all the toys out of the box and, in the space of two overs, Ridley Jacobs was caught behind attempting to hook and Ambrose was smartly taken at short-leg.

fields.headline: Caddick comes five alive
fields.standfirst: West Indies shot out for smallest test total against England :   6-1 :   6-2 :   10-3 :   24-4 :   24-5 :   39-6 :   39-7 :   39-8 :   41-9 :   54-10
fields.trailText: Andy Caddick stirred from his torpor, stretched and bowled his side back into the second test at a time when all but the most unhinged English optimist would have deemed the match beyond redemption.
fields.body:
Andy Caddick stirred from his torpor, stretched and bowled his side back into the second test at a time when all but the most unhinged English optimist would have deemed the match beyond redemption.

Thirteen overs on the reel, each and every one packed with snarling, animal aggression brought him five prime West Indian wickets for 16, all wickets coming for seven runs in a one ball fewer than 10 of the overs. What had he had for tea? Rocket fuel?

For someone who recently would not have felt inclined to say boo to Julian Clary for fear of a poke in the eye, the transformation from the insipid character of the first innings was startling.

Once he followed through down the pitch to stand eyeball to eyeball with the great Ambrose - one of the few able to do so without recourse to a step-ladder - and so far has lived to tell the tale although it would have been wise to get his affairs in order last night.

Caddick's marvellous effort and similar response from Darren Gough and Dominic Cork saw West Indies, in their second innings, humbled in a fraction over two hours and inside 27 overs for just 54, the lowest score they have ever made against England and only two more than their lowest ever in Tests, the 51 made against Glenn McGrath and Jason Gillespie in Port of Spain fifteen months ago.

Only Ridley Jacobs, with 12, reached double figures yesterday. It left England eight overs to negotiate in pursuit of 188 to complete what would be an astounding win, and Mike Atherton and Mark Ramprakash duly negotiated seven balls before the light closed in and a remarkable day that had seen 21 wickets fall came to a conclusion.

Today, then, is as big as it gets, with not just the match but the entire series hanging in the balance. For two decades and more it has been the absolute belief within the West Indies side that no matter how few runs their own batsmen score the bowlers can always dismiss the opposition for fewer.

But to pull this one round the Twin Tormentors, Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh together with the young pretenders Reon King and Franklyn Rose will need to pull out all the stops. Perhaps they will draw strength from other matches in Trinidad. Against Zimbabwe earlier in the year they successfully defended 99 in the final innings but more pertinently, when they sent England packing for 46 when Atherton's 1994 tourists required 193 to win.

The latter is too much etched on the England psyche and too close in context to this game for comfort and badly needs exorcising.

Against that, Alec Stewart would be missing a trick if he did not bring to his teams attention the West Indies travails in New Zealand last winter when in Hamilton, in the very first innings of the series, Sherwin Campbell and and Adrian Griffith added 276 for the first wicket only to see the Kiwis triumph by nine wickets.

For West Indies to lose here, from 161 for one, given that memory, could set them back to where they were, while England know that the chance is now there for someone to make their name.

The same number of wickets as fell yesterday did so in a days' play against New Zealand at Edgbaston last year, but that was a different pitch.

This sort of batting carnage is less readily explained although the Lord's groundsman Mick Hunt will have been biting his fingernails to the quick. He need not worry. The surface was as dry as it could be on the first day and the although it has quickened up noticeably, the bounce has re mained true and the lateral movement from the seam certainly not excessive.

A contributory factor has been the blanket of haze, which has lent encouragement to the swing bowlers and kept the pitch fresher than it might have been under sunlight. Techniques on both sides, against the ball moving even minimal amounts at pace have been exposed, however, and West Indies towards evening yesterday were unable to cope with Caddick's rib-tickling bounce.

Not for a long time has an England short leg become such a predatory fielder and today it will be the high bounce of Walsh and Ambrose that will test the resolve of the England batsmen. Already, Campbell's 82 and Wavell Hinds' 59 made before tea on the first day, may prove to be the decisive innings of the match with no one else since reaching 30. Indeed apart from Nick Knight, who made 34 in the second innings at Edgbaston, no England batsman has reached even that in three innings this series.

Knight, should he bat today, will do so encumbered by a right index finger damaged when attempting to catch a screamer of a catch at third slip off Gough. While the evening carnage was unfolding he was in the casualty unit having an Xray which revealed " no major fracture" whatever that means.

The West Indies bowlers may well have felt they had done enough with the ball to put the game beyond reach.

At the outset, Ambrose was irresistible, probing, giving nothing away, and making inroads as Ramprakash, Michael Vaughan and Graeme Hick were drawn into error, the latter bowled leaden footed after a calculated assault on Rose's opening over that brought him four boundaries at a time when runs were like gold dust.

Untypically too, Atherton was drawn into some inept bathanging at Walsh and was caught at the wicket. Hick's riposte and a later partnership of 35 between Stewart (28) and Craig White (25) provided the only respite from the torture.

Walsh and Ambrose finished with four wickets apiece and if Ambrose deserved more then his superb partner, conceded little until Gough, premeditating, swung him lustily over the square leg fence.

The last-wicket stand Gough shared with a remarkably composed and organised Matthew Hoggard was just sufficient in the circumstances to come into the irritating category.

fields.headline: Barmby demands move to Liverpool
fields.trailText: Everton's Nick Barmby took the biggest gamble of his career yesterday by officially informing his club that he wished to join Liverpool.
fields.body:
Everton's Nick Barmby took the biggest gamble of his career yesterday by officially informing his club that he wished to join Liverpool. The Goodison manager Walter Smith immediately placed the England winger on the transfer list with an asking price of £8m.

Apart from dealing with the understandable wrath of his present club's supporters, Barmby's problem is that if Liverpool should fail to broker a deal with their near-neighbours he will be forced to sit out the remaining 12 months of his contract at Everton where, inevitably, he will be viewed as a pariah.

Although Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier is keen to lure Barmby to Anfield and has already discussed the possibility with Smith, he is unlikely to offer much in excess of £3.5m for a player who will be available on a free transfer next summer.

If Everton decide that principles, underpinned by a sense of parochial pride, should be placed before the need for hard cash, they may refuse any offer from Liverpool, thus condemning the 27-year-old Barmby to reserve-team football next season.

Liverpool may decide to offer Everton a package deal including either the striker Titi Camara or the midfielder David Thompson.

"Nick has indicated to me that he would like to move to Liverpool," said Smith yesterday. "Liverpool have already made an inquiry and we must now wait for an official approach from them.

"Nick Barmby has been transfer-listed with immediate effect. It goes without saying that we are very disappointed by this development."

Smith added: "We have done everything we can to retain this player's services. It is an impossible situation for both parties."

Although transfers between Liverpool and Everton have been common over the past 15 years, no player has moved from Goodison to Anfield since Dave Hickson crossed Stanley Park 40 years ago.

Everton will complete the £3m signing of Alessandro Pistone on a five-year deal from Newcastle United today if the Italian defender passes a medical.

fields.headline: Powell's patience saves Warwickshire
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 350
Warwickshire 218-9
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 350
Warwickshire 218-9
fields.body:
The shrill exhortations from the schoolkids in the Eric Hollies stand were welcome indeed. The gleeful whoops accompanying every boundary were heartening and touching. Their new-found heroes, though, had less cause to preen than blush. The fare they served up for much of the day was unfit for cabbages, much less kings.

In 30.5 overs before lunch these two sides combined for the princely sum of 53 runs. This on a pitch of mostly true bounce and holding so few terrors that Gloucestershire, owners of the country's meekest batting order, gleaned four batting points for the first time this season.

Things looked up after the break, albeit only to the extent that Warwickshire's top six took turns to self-combust. The exception was Michael Powell, a former England Under-18 captain whose progress rate might cause a sloth to look to its laurels. He scraped into the 20s off his 95th ball.

Yet the benefits were later apparent in what became a lone battle to avert the follow-on against an attack which was accurate if monochrome.

As one of three MJ Powells on the circuit, the Warwickshire model could hardly be blamed for feeling a bit anonymous, especially since Glamorgan's version has been attracting many plaudits. Having been dropped on one, by the time he edged to slip for 96 he had been scoreless for 38 balls and 50 minutes. There were some punchy drives and pulls to leaven the ennui yet here, glory be, was proof of a gift all too rare among contemporary county batsmen.

Dumpily built, modest of presence but infinite of patience - as he hinted in 1998 by becoming the first uncapped Bear to carry his bat for 49 years - Powell could bore for England without a tinge of embarrassment. He even moseys off towards square-leg after each ball like Chris Tavaré.

Ben Gannon was Gloucestershire's best bowler. He took five wickets through persistence if not with artistic impression. It seemed fitting on a day when substance beat style by an innings and plenty.

fields.headline: I was England's obituarist
fields.standfirst: Trevor Haylett, the journalist who wrote a coruscating attack on Kevin Keegan's England that was mistaken for the official Uefa line, wonders how all the controversy came about
fields.trailText: Trevor Haylett, the journalist who wrote a coruscating attack on Kevin Keegan's England that was mistaken for the official Uefa line, wonders how all the controversy came about
fields.body:
As a journalist, it is always a strange experience to find yourself the subject of a news story - particularly when the might of Uefa, the organiser of Euro 2000, has just come crashing down on you. Even now, I'm still not clear what I did to deserve the red card treatment and an early flight home from the tournament.

When I was recruited by Uefa to write articles for its internet site (www.euro2000.org) and other information sources, there was no suggestion that I and the other freelance journalists working alongside me should act as spokesmen, or that anything we wrote would be interpreted as an official Uefa line.

When teams were knocked out we were, however, asked to write an analysis of their tournament performance, known as an "obituary". Having worked at the England v Romania game in Charleroi, I was asked the following day by the Uefa internet staff to write England's obituary.

It was not a difficult story to write: England's limitations in that game, as in the first match against Portugal which they also lost 3-2, were badly exposed. No self-respecting journalist, asked to pen an obituary, could avoid that fact or some heavy criticism.

Halfway through the article I checked that it was OK to be strong in my words and also that it was acceptable to include my own comments. On both counts I was assured it was. When I had finished, the story was then processed in the normal way, somebody else being responsible for sub-editing the story and putting it on to the screens where it could be accessed by others.

It has been written in some newspapers that the story appeared on the official Uefa website. It did not. It was included as part of the media information service, accessible only to journalists working in the various media centres at the Euro 2000 stadia.

To the best of my recollection this service carries no Uefa logo or stamp, and my story should not therefore have been misconstrued as bearing any Uefa weight. It appeared on the service on Wednesday June 21, the day after England's demise. The British media did not immediately highlight my criticisms, and the storm surrounding them only blew up a full week later.

Originally, the story had been picked up by James Lawton in last Saturday's Independent. As part of a coruscating attack on the Football Association and its coaching department, he wrote that "the official news bulletin of Euro 2000 could not keep contempt out of its farewell to bedraggled England". When his article appeared I was congratulated by a senior member of the Uefa internet staff for "an excellent piece".

Unfortunately Uefa has since decreed that what was "an excellent piece" seven days ago is now a source of embarrassment. As I understand it Gerhard Aigner, its general secretary, was forced to field some awkward questions from English journalists last Wednesday, and I am now back at home rather than covering tomorrow's final for Uefa as originally planned.

The way it was suggested that I should leave my hotel sooner rather than later was all a bit demeaning. I had to rack my brains and reassure myself I had not been caught hurling cafe chairs at police in Brussels or Charleroi.

Now the story concerned appears on the media service with my byline and a note to say I am a journalist independent of Uefa. It is a pity Uefa did not possess the foresight to include that at the beginning.

Quite why Uefa should feel embarrassed about it is still something of a mystery. Leaving aside the question of whether my words should have been placed in an official Uefa context, why cannot one arm of the Uefa media enterprise be permitted a personality and the right to transmit sincerely held views?

It concerned me on Wednesday that a Uefa spokesman was issuing apologies to the FA at Lancaster Gate, but as the storm seemed to be abating I let it pass. And, come to that, why the English FA should be sensitive to the criticism contained in the article. I would bet my last guilder that my sentiments were little different to those aired in, I guess, every British newspaper and presumably many more across the continent as well.

Of course I leave with some regret. I was greatly looking forward to covering tomorrow's final game of a tournament which has been elevated by outstanding, attacking football. And the Uefa internet staff, David Farrelly and Adrian Harte, are good guys to spend three weeks with in a foreign land, totally dedicated and professional.

Still, at least I am able to console myself that I made it as far as the host nation. And like Dennis Bergkamp and co, I too went out on penalties.
