It was not a difficult story to write: England's limitations in that game, as in the first match against Portugal which they also lost 3-2, were badly exposed. No self-respecting journalist, asked to pen an obituary, could avoid that fact or some heavy criticism. Halfway through the article I checked that it was OK to be strong in my words and also that it was acceptable to include my own comments. On both counts I was assured it was. When I had finished, the story was then processed in the normal way, somebody else being responsible for sub-editing the story and putting it on to the screens where it could be accessed by others. It has been written in some newspapers that the story appeared on the official Uefa website. It did not. It was included as part of the media information service, accessible only to journalists working in the various media centres at the Euro 2000 stadia. To the best of my recollection this service carries no Uefa logo or stamp, and my story should not therefore have been misconstrued as bearing any Uefa weight. It appeared on the service on Wednesday June 21, the day after England's demise. The British media did not immediately highlight my criticisms, and the storm surrounding them only blew up a full week later. Originally, the story had been picked up by James Lawton in last Saturday's Independent. As part of a coruscating attack on the Football Association and its coaching department, he wrote that "the official news bulletin of Euro 2000 could not keep contempt out of its farewell to bedraggled England". When his article appeared I was congratulated by a senior member of the Uefa internet staff for "an excellent piece". Unfortunately Uefa has since decreed that what was "an excellent piece" seven days ago is now a source of embarrassment. As I understand it Gerhard Aigner, its general secretary, was forced to field some awkward questions from English journalists last Wednesday, and I am now back at home rather than covering tomorrow's final for Uefa as originally planned. The way it was suggested that I should leave my hotel sooner rather than later was all a bit demeaning. I had to rack my brains and reassure myself I had not been caught hurling cafe chairs at police in Brussels or Charleroi. Now the story concerned appears on the media service with my byline and a note to say I am a journalist independent of Uefa. It is a pity Uefa did not possess the foresight to include that at the beginning. Quite why Uefa should feel embarrassed about it is still something of a mystery. Leaving aside the question of whether my words should have been placed in an official Uefa context, why cannot one arm of the Uefa media enterprise be permitted a personality and the right to transmit sincerely held views? It concerned me on Wednesday that a Uefa spokesman was issuing apologies to the FA at Lancaster Gate, but as the storm seemed to be abating I let it pass. And, come to that, why the English FA should be sensitive to the criticism contained in the article. I would bet my last guilder that my sentiments were little different to those aired in, I guess, every British newspaper and presumably many more across the continent as well. Of course I leave with some regret. I was greatly looking forward to covering tomorrow's final game of a tournament which has been elevated by outstanding, attacking football. And the Uefa internet staff, David Farrelly and Adrian Harte, are good guys to spend three weeks with in a foreign land, totally dedicated and professional. Still, at least I am able to console myself that I made it as far as the host nation. And like Dennis Bergkamp and co, I too went out on penalties.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Dominic Cork may have enjoyed his England recall at Lord's yesterday, but 300 miles to the north his Derbyshire team were having a thoroughly miserable time at Darlington.
fields.body:
Dominic Cork may have enjoyed his England recall at Lord's yesterday, but 300 miles to the north his Derbyshire team were having a thoroughly miserable time at Darlington.

After falling for 151 on the first day, they saw Durham pile up 479 for nine, with centuries from the young Australian Simon Katich and the less consistent local lad Paul Collingwood, his first for a year. Durham's captain Nick Speak also made the most of a home game away from the Riverside, where the pitches tend to be less pleasant than the scenery, to score 78, his first half-century of a difficult summer.

Even Melvyn Betts got in on the act, following up his seven for 30 with a thumping 36-ball half-century. Steve Harmison ended unbeaten on 33 as Derbyshire's bowlers toiled for little reward - none more so than Tim Munton, who dragged his 34-year-old body through 41 overs for figures of three for 84.

Speak concedes that Durham need to beat Derbyshire, eight points and two places above them in the First Division, to have a realistic chance of avoiding relegation. But he also points out that Durham were in a similar position this time last year before embarking on a long winning run - food for thought for Kent and Hampshire, the two other counties in the bottom four.

Kent will have to conjure up something spectacular to beat Somerset after the visitors extended their first innings to 475 at Maidstone. Kent missed the England one-day all-rounder Mark Ealham, who went off the field with a back strain but hopes to be fit in time for the triangular tournament.

Hampshire also face an uphill struggle against Surrey at Southampton, despite Alan Mullally's best performance for his new county. Mullally took six for 75 but Surrey still posted 331, with 71 from Ally Brown and an unbeaten 56 by Martin Bicknell.

Promising youngsters continue to hold sway in the Second Division match at Chelmsford, with two likely sounding talents called Fraser and Tufnell bowling Middlesex into the box seat after Peter Such's five-wicket first-day haul. Essex tumbled for 136 against the combined wiles of Gus and the Cat, although Such and Mark Ilott then reduced Middlesex to 100 for four in their second innings.

There was more genuine encouragement for the future at Swansea, with Glamorgan's Darren Thomas taking five for 72 to secure a first innings lead of 22 over Worcestershire. Michael Powell's unbeaten 60 helped them extend that to 178 for the loss of three second-innings wickets, including Matthew Elliott for his second fifty of the match.

Zimbabwe cruised to a five-wicket win against Nottinghamshire at Trent Bridge, despite Guy Welton's 94. Paul Strang was the pick of the bowlers with three for 31.

Sanath Jayasuriya and Marvan Atapattu compiled the fifth-highest opening partnership in Test history to salvage some consolation from Sri Lanka's series against Pakistan. Jayasuriya hit 188 in a stand of 355 in the third Test at Kandy, with Atapattu unbeaten on 199 out of a total of 449 for five.

 Tomorrow's original deadline for Judge Edwin King's interim report into match-fixing has been put back to August 11. "The sheer volume of work involved is the cause of the delay," the King Commission secretary John Bacon said. "There are 1,143 pages of transcripts alone."

webTitle: Not a good year for the Roses

fields.headline: Not a good year for the Roses
fields.standfirst:
Yorkshire 164
Lancashire 149-5
fields.trailText:
Yorkshire 164
Lancashire 149-5
fields.body:
The crowds may now be smaller yet the Roses' fervour and individual intensity defiantly survives. Still they come, in solitary predetermined procession along Talbot Road or off the Metro - with their sandwich boxes and diverse private expectations.

"Athers" of this parish, though occupied elsewhere for the day, offered dire words about county cricket but could not have been thinking of this particular neighbourhood ritual.

Cardus yesterday gazed down sideways from his photographic frame in the press box. At times the Lancashire pair Glen Chapple and Mike Smethurst bowled with the commendable pace and direction that even evoked a sentimental sniff of Statham.

The batting alas too seldom sustained the reputation of past illustrious deeds. Fifteen wickets fell, some needlessly. Lancashire ended on 149 for five, 15 behind. Mark Chilton, until failing to deal with a lifting ball, and Graham Lloyd, bowled off his pads, built the total. So did Sourav Ganguly, with the game's only six, before going recklessly for another to be out to a wonderful, one-handed catch by Ian Fisher off James Middlebrook. The slow bowlers are having a good match.

Yorkshire were all out by the 60th over, their total still perhaps boosted a little by some indifferent fielding. There is nothing quite like a Roses match for your debut. Simon Widdup is the sixth Yorkshire player to make his first senior appearance this season; he stayed for nearly 90 minutes, not always comfortable and benefiting from occasional good fortune as he edged over slips for four. He had, however, seen his captain rapidly go to second slip, and Widdup went on to show application before pushing forward tentatively to Gary Keedy's opening delivery, to be caught easily at slip.

At 126 for two at lunch Yorkshire appeared to be more than justifying their decision to bat. Darren Lehmann was rattling along, eager to attack anything wayward. Concentration broken, he was out the first over after lunch.

It was left to Richard Blakey to give an increasingly crumbling innings some substance. He was sixth to go after a well made half-century, another victim of Keedy's left-arm perseverance. The slow bowler's three wickets must have been singularly rewarding against his native county.

Yorkshire had four players away on test duty but the batting should not have tailed away as it did. The last eight wickets fell for 38 in 22 overs.

Warren Hegg threw himself to his right to make a fine, low catch to dismiss Nathan Wood; it more than compensated for his lapse which allowed Blakey to escape on 22.

This was Anthony McGrath's first championship game of the summer. It ended quickly when he was contentiously lbw to Chapple. Neil Fairbrother's body language was eloquent when he was similarly dismissed by Middlebrook. Was there ever a Roses match bereft of controversy?

fields.headline: England find a rhythm section
fields.standfirst: Stewart's men on song, but only after the band strike up
fields.trailText: One of the great joys of carnival is its unpredictability and England tossed aside the old song sheet and did enough to suggest that the 100th Lord's Test will be an occasion to relish, writes David Hopps.
fields.body:
Live music rang around this historic ground yesterday to mark the official launch of Test cricket's Caribbean summer, but it was in the field that England began by performing all their old favourites. Gone To Ground, Whoops There It Goes Again, and I Wake Up Crying were all hammered out by lunchtime by a side that looked in need of a spot of fine tuning.

By the time that Third World, the Jamaican reggae band, launched into a rendition of Now That We've Found Love, the answer to the familiar chorus "What are we gonna do with it?" was do anything you like except toss it to an England fielder for safe keeping.

But one of the great joys of carnival is its unpredictability, its ability to change mood on a whim. From the moment that Matthew Hoggard, on his debut, clutched Sherwin Campbell's hook to his chest at long leg, England tossed aside the old song sheet and did enough to suggest that the 100th Lord's Test will be an occasion to relish.

Campbell fell to Dominic Cork, freshly restored to the England side, and one who used to don war paint by the litre in the sober days when the Lord's outfield was the province of marching bands.

Perhaps the Derbyshire captaincy has imbued a sense of responsibility. The war paint was absent; his exuberant approach to test cricket was not. Cork is a test-match natural, animated by the big occasion. As he blew aside Wavell Hinds, Ridley Jacobs and Curtly Ambrose, he was in his element.

The sight of Cork lording it was enough to sharpen Darren Gough's friendly rivalry. Gough is still bowling in a wrist watch, in defiance of one physiologist who advised that to remove it would add 4mph to his pace, enough to make him the fastest bowler in the world. "I wear a watch to tell the time," said Gough, and presumably will continue to do so until the Lord's clock goes digital.

For some reason, Edgbaston, venue for the first test of the series, was not deemed suitable for a spot of carnival, presumably because some Channel 4 publicity type had accepted the stereotype that all Brummies are miserable. By the time that England had lost by an innings, they had good cause to be.

Instead it befell Lord's to boogie on down, an idea which caused many as much amusement as if Spiritualized were performing live before the Women's Institute. (That would at least give the hecklers a bit more of a challenge.)

There is a perceived risk that in seeking out the younger audience that Channel 4 and the England and Wales Cricket Board craves, traditional spectators will become disenchanted. The risk tends to be favoured by those who remain under the misapprehension that test cricket grounds remain the sole province of Colonel and Lady Duffer.

Lord's, in any case, has hosted live music for years. John Barnes' Outswingers might not have chosen the coolest name in the business, but they housed some of England's finest jazz musicians, and played by the Grace Gates for years.

Now they have been forced to concede to Channel 4's "stellar line-up of musical artists". Not everyone approves. Some of those MCC members tapping their feet yesterday were tapping them in disgust.

webTitle: Caribbean old guard offer moral support

fields.headline: Caribbean old guard offer moral support
fields.trailText: This Test would always have been an historic one, being the 100th ever played at Lord's. For the West Indies, however, there is an even more momentous meaning to the contest, writes Donna Symmonds.
fields.body:
This Test would always have been an historic one, being the 100th ever played at Lord's. For the West Indies, however, there is an even more momentous meaning to the contest.

It was 50 years ago yesterday that West Indies finished off a famous victory here, the first time they had dominated a Test match at Lord's. Alan Rae (106 in the first innings), Clyde Walcott (168 not out in the second), Sonny Ramadhin (11 for 152) and Alf Valentine (seven for 127) were the architects.

Along with Sir Everton Weekes, who got 63 in each innings, they are all here marking this occasion with the Lord's Taverners and enjoying the turn of events in the initial exchanges. Neither that group of past West Indian players nor the present set would want to mar the celebrations with a gloomy performance.

All attempts were made to ensure that the day would be lively. All attempts must also have been made to ensure that Shivnarine Chanderpaul played.

Injured at Birmingham and not having played thereafter, and not even having had net sessions apparently, rumours and authoritative reports alike indicated that he could not lift his right arm and would be out for three weeks.

That would have meant Chanderpaul missing this Test and the first few one-dayers as well. Reports further suggested that Ramnaresh Sarwan would get his first Test play in England and the third of his career. His name was even down to come at No5 on the official scorecard.

There was no such luck for the classy young Guyanese right-hander, and lo and behold "Tiger" (Chanderpaul's sometime nickname) was included in the team after passing a fitness test. The form batsman of the tour had 373 runs from three matches. West Indies must have been keen to have him in the side.

After the opening day's play Jimmy Adams took particular care to emphasise the mantra oft-repeated by him since taking up the captaincy that the team is showing cohesion but needs to work harder and get the basics right.

Adams also stressed that partnership must continue to be the watchword for his batting line-up to support the usually reliable and relentless bowling. This continues to be West Indies' strength as their batting has been inconsistent. That may even be an understatement.

The one change made to the team from Edgbaston saw Adrian Griffiths replacing Chris Gayle as the other opener with Sherwin Campbell. That was certainly in keeping with the policy of going with the form players.

The West Indies captain was perhaps trying to guard against complacency and there did not seem to be very much of that in evidence, rather some misjudgment and loss of concentration. It happens in the best-regulated teams. The play of your opponents can have some impact too and, 50 years on, West Indies are hoping for a similar result.

webTitle: Hague promises to free councils in party U-turn

fields.headline: Hague promises to free councils in party U-turn
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday swept aside 20 years of Conservative ideology by promising to remove tight government spending controls on town halls while giving councils powers to plan communities without Whitehall interference.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday swept aside 20 years of Conservative ideology by promising to remove tight government spending controls on town halls while giving councils powers to plan communities without Whitehall interference.

In what amounted to a public apology for his party's long-running hostility towards local authorities, he threw caution to the wind and said a future Tory government would let councils set local taxes without the risk of "heavy-handed intervention".

Addressing the Local Government Association conference in Bournemouth, the Tory leader drew howls of incredulity from some delegates - many with bitter memories of the Thatcher years - by accusing Labour of "chronically centralising" by transferring power from local communities to Whitehall. Some councillors chuckled when he also admitted: "My party didn't always get things right."

Mr Hague rejected the previous Tory government's policy of capping council budgets - reserve powers are still held by Whitehall - arguing that town halls should be allowed to set council tax levels "at their discretion". He added: "I want to be able to trust local government to take serious decisions affecting local people without the risk of heavy-handed intervention from central government."

His pledge to free councils was accompanied by a commitment to wholesale reform of the planning system. Rigid national house building targets would be scrapped and councillors allowed to tailor plans to local needs, free of government control.

webTitle: England back from the dead once more

fields.headline: England back from the dead once more
fields.trailText: "Dying is an art, and like everything else, I do it exceptionally well," claimed Sylvia Plath, the American poet. But Plath only had to pull it off once. England have been doing it brilliantly for years.
fields.body:
"Dying is an art, and like everything else, I do it exceptionally well," claimed Sylvia Plath, the American poet. But Plath only had to pull it off once. England have been doing it brilliantly for years.

When it comes to the death scene, poets, actresses and damsels in distress cannot live with England. They perform almost fortnightly, often to disbelieving packed houses. Had Plath attempted it so regularly, she would have soon found herself left in an empty room, with a note inviting her to pull up the sheet at her leisure.

England's perpetual attraction is that in every death there is always a lingering hope of an amazing revival. Last night they exceeded even their own unrivalled standards. The doctors had looked in, shaken their heads and pronounced to the world that the patient was dead, then suddenly it was leaping around and imagining the impossible.

What most sums up the England cricket team in the eyes of the nation is disbelief. People wallow so long in the notion that they cannot get any worse that recoveries of this magnitude seem truly astounding. If England win this match - and it remains an enormous if - it will be a recovery to rank alongside Ian Botham's destruction of the Australians at Headingley in 1981.

After England took the last wicket, Alec Stewart, the stand-in captain, called his elated team into a ring and tried to calm them down, to restore a sense of perspective. It would have been understandable had 35,000 spectators joined the huddle. And someone had written 24 hours earlier that cricket was a grey game played by grey men on a grey day...

No one exemplifies England at their bluffest more than Darren Gough. When Gough began his test career, he passionately believed that, in his career, England could become the best team in the world. Now, as hard as he tries, he suspects he will rarely receive a better role than the hero in adversity. In diving to catch Sherwin Campbell's upper-cut to third man, the first West Indies wicket to fall, he was merely communicating that England's pride was intact, not seriously believing that they might win the match.

Even Gough's late-order batting this summer has taken on the role of spirited tomfoolery. As he hooked Courtney Walsh for six, a shot he probably settled upon with Walsh halfway down his run-up, he might have been borrowing from Shakespeare's Henry IV, advocating: "Doomsday is near, die all, die merrily."

Andrew Caddick, Gough's new-ball partner, is not the sort to pack them in at the Comedy Store. An explanation, albeit a convoluted one, can be advanced as to why Caddick bowled so badly at the start of the first innings, and so well in the second. In the first innings conditions were helpful, but expectations were drainingly high; in the second innings, conditions were still helpful, but the crowd had virtually conceded defeat, and the stress levels were minimal. It is the art of exceeding expectations.

He managed to dramatically change the mood of a few hours before. "Embarrassing," smiled the woman serving at the southern fried chicken stall. "Embarrassing," grinned the beery youth swaying a course through Jubilee Gardens. Embarrassing, embarrassing, embarrassing. Wherever one looked in mid-afternoon around a ground packed to capacity, one could only marvel at an English Test crowd's bottomless capacity to glean some sort of pleasure from abject failure.

By some twisted coincidence, an internet cricket site sought yesterday to promote a worthless new statistical study which seeks to calculate the likelihood that a match "might" have been rigged, an assessment that relies entirely on how much a side might have played above or below the norm.

If the norm mattered, cricket grounds would be empty. In 26.4 overs of the West Indies innings yesterday, a time of lurching emotions and honest endeavour, the whole thing was proved to be not only a nonsense, but a disgraceful one at that. For the sake of Test cricketers busting a gut, in success or failure, the International Cricket Council should bring in the lawyers.
fields.bodyText: "Dying is an art, and like everything else, I do it exceptionally well," claimed Sylvia Plath, the American poet. But Plath only had to pull it off once. England have been doing it brilliantly for years. When it comes to the death scene, poets, actresses and damsels in distress cannot live with England. They perform almost fortnightly, often to disbelieving packed houses. Had Plath attempted it so regularly, she would have soon found herself left in an empty room, with a note inviting her to pull up the sheet at her leisure. England's perpetual attraction is that in every death there is always a lingering hope of an amazing revival. Last night they exceeded even their own unrivalled standards. The doctors had looked in, shaken their heads and pronounced to the world that the patient was dead, then suddenly it was leaping around and imagining the impossible. What most sums up the England cricket team in the eyes of the nation is disbelief. People wallow so long in the notion that they cannot get any worse that recoveries of this magnitude seem truly astounding. If England win this match - and it remains an enormous if - it will be a recovery to rank alongside Ian Botham's destruction of the Australians at Headingley in 1981. fields.headline: Tigana bounces back
fields.standfirst: Gerry Cox on the new Fulham manager ready to re-establish his coaching credentials
fields.trailText: Gerry Cox on the new Fulham manager ready to re-establish his coaching credentials
fields.body:
Fulham could never have guessed it would be such a good time to unveil Jean Tigana as their manager, what with his native France on the verge of adding the title of European champions to that of World Cup winners.

Gallic stock has hardly been higher, certainly not since the 80s when Tigana was playing in the France midfield with Michel Platini, Alain Giresse and Luis Fernandez, Les Quatres Mousquetaires.

And from the sidelines the former Lyon and Monaco coach, 45 last week, can claim much of the credit for developing the talents of Thierry Henry, Lilian Thuram and David Trezeguet. He also turned Emmanuel Petit into an international and helped Fabien Barthez become one of the best goalkeepers in the world.

Fulham appointed him late last season after it was clear that they would miss promotion under Paul Bracewell. The new manager still speaks faltering English but it has improved in the past month and he points out that he does not need to speak perfectly to show his players what he wants them to do with the ball.

He has already brought in his team of fitness coaches, doctors and even a dentist, and in two weeks' time he will take the squad to Clairfontaine, the training camp used by France during the World Cup two years ago and again this summer.

Not many Nationwide League clubs can afford to use such facilities, but Tigana's reputation is matched by the owner Mohamed Al Fayed's financial backing.

There is, of course, a flipside to having a multimillion kitty and a salary in the region of £500,000 a year: the pressure to succeed and put Fulham where Al Fayed wants them, not only in the Premiership but among the big boys.

"My ambition is to build a side to win promotion to the Premiership this season," said Tigana. "I will bring my own experience to training, and the players' attitude to hard work is very important. We have good players here but I hope to bring in three or four signings."

Louis Saha, the France Under-21 striker who had a brief spell on loan at Newcastle two seasons ago, has already arrived from Metz for £2.1m. "He is very quick and has good technique," Tigana said, "and can follow the success of [Nicolas] Anelka and Henry." Henry was one of Tigana's charges at Monaco, and it was his sale and those of nine others, including Thuram and Petit, which prompted him to resign after four years.

"After I left Monaco I did not think I would be a manager again, but when Mr Fayed contacted me it was an interesting proposition. Kevin Keegan had been in charge here and I wanted to see why."

He watched the club's play-off push finally subside, and then saw more of them on video. "I watched 10 matches in person and another 15 on tape. I know what needs doing." He does not yet know much about Crewe, Fulham's opposition on the opening day of the season, or the rest of the First Division. When asked who were their main rivals, he said: "The other 23 teams."

He is close to signing Everton's John Collins, his former lieutenant at Monaco, and the club have confirmed that talks will continue with Aston Villa's Paul Merson.

Tigana does not think the future is bleak on this side of the Channel. "I saw your Under-21 side in Barcelona and was impressed. The system in France has been very good for helping young players develop, but I think things are changing in England now."

fields.headline: Italy expects the unexpected
fields.trailText: There is a newspaper clipping which Dino Zoff should pin up in the dressing room tomorrow. When De Telegraaf asked the Dutch public this week which semi-finalist would win Euro 2000, not a soul plumped for Italy. One or two must feel as embarrassed as Frank de Boer this morning.
fields.body:
There is a newspaper clipping which Dino Zoff should pin up in the dressing room tomorrow. When De Telegraaf asked the Dutch public this week which semi-finalist would win Euro 2000, not a soul plumped for Italy. One or two must feel as embarrassed as Frank de Boer this morning.

Seeing the occasional smile flicker across Zoff's face yesterday confirmed that anything in life is possible. The coach knows it was not only the locals who wrote him off. Three weeks ago most Italians thought the Pope was more likely to streak at the final than their team were to play in the game. "We feared not even reaching the quarter-finals," said Diego Antonelli of La Gazzetta dello Sport.

The mixture of delight, pride and disbelief was obvious among the hundred or so Italy fans gathered at the training ground here. Huge national flags were draped proudly over the barriers; even a celebratory flare was let off.

The stars of the semi-final were absent, resting rather than nursing hangovers presumably, but their understudies were cheered to the echo. Wolf whistles greeted one player's public change of shorts. The stall outside selling all things azzurri was doing good business.

A degree in Italian was hardly necessary to understand the headline in La Gazzetta yesterday: "Italia eroico miracolo". And if the players were not reaching for headache tablets, thousands at home must have been after pouring on to piazzas and jumping into cars to celebrate the victory over Holland.

"I spoke to my parents and they said there were big parties going on all through the night," said Russo Salvatore, resplendent in a Milan shirt and Italy bandana. "Now the people think we will beat France. They say that if we can win with 10 players against Holland we must beat France."

How quickly the mood has changed. Friendly defeats by Belgium and Spain, plus the injury to Christian Vieri and a perceived lack of flair, had prompted many fans to walk around wearing a Zoff-like expression. Yet when the going gets tough the Italians tend to get going.

They have been solid rather than spectacular but Zoff rejected claims that his team had been too negative and ugly. "I have to play a way which suits the characteristics of my squad," he said. "I am not a defensive coach but I have to be realistic."

Certainly there was an admirable cussedness about the defending in Amsterdam on Thursday. Francesco Toldo - some second-choice goalkeeper - was applauded in the post-match conference by the Italian media. "Holland could have played for an entire day taking shots at our goal and they would never have scored," he said.

An entire millennium more like. If France had been brought out straight after this marathon game, the man some call San Francesco - St Francis - would probably still have kept a clean sheet.

Yet Zoff was hardly beaming yesterday. He laughed when someone shouted, "I want to see you smile, Mr Zoff", and occasionally grinned unprompted, but at times it was hard to tell whether he was preparing for a final or conducting a post-mortem on a first-round exit. With Kevin Keegan there might have been a team of medics on hand in case he got overexcited. Zoff's gruff exterior means he is respected rather than loved.

"To reach the final is beyond expectations for any team in a tournament as difficult as Euro 2000," he said.

He was unperturbed by Luigi di Biagio's claims that half the team had cramp by the end of the semi-final. "I am sure the players will be able to recuperate physically and mentally. Their enthusiasm is high. But I have to see how each one is doing and feel it as well. France may be a little less collective than Holland but physically and technically they are better."

Much points to a France win. But with Zoff, a member of the team who took Euro 68 after winning a goalless semi-final against the Soviet Union on the toss of a coin, it is probably best to expect the unexpected.

webTitle: England need a quick fix, and we can afford it

fields.headline: England need a quick fix, and we can afford it
fields.standfirst: Dave Podmore on the cricket's crisis of corruption. And panda skin purses
fields.trailText: Dave Podmore on the cricket's crisis of corruption. And panda skin purses
fields.body:
Your heart has to go out to a guy who goes to the trouble of throwing a test match in order to get his missus a leather jacket for Valentine's and then gets nothing for his trouble but grief.

It seems the current Mrs Hansie Cronje's got the hump because all the worry has made her lose 13-odd pounds in weight, so the jacket's too big for her now. I don't want to sound unsympathetic to the lady, who I understand is delightfully dizzy and by no means unattractive, but it's hardly Hansie's fault if her kit don't fit.

She's bloody lucky. My fiancee would give anything to shed that kind of poundage. Unfortunately, the only thing Jacqui's likely to lose is her purse. It's been a good three weeks since it last happened so she must be due again.

The previous one, made of premium-quality panda hide with a rhino-horn clasp, I picked up on the pre-season tour of Singapore. I had to bowl three leg-side wides in a row and run myself out first ball to get it. The run-out was a cakewalk but I only managed to get one of the wides in the right place, unfortunately. Still, the bookie paid up like a good 'un. It's like taking candy from a baby out there.

I have to say, though, that Hansie let the side down with an unnecessary display of emotion at the end of his evidence. Blubbing is never the answer and wins you few friends. You'd never get Lance Klusener, say, doing that. He'd just go off and shoot 500 head of impala and get things off his chest that way. Hansie would have been far better off muttering the Lord's Prayer backwards to himself and retiring from the witness box with his dignity and good name intact.

There's been a lot of verbiage regurgitated as to why there isn't as much match-fixing in England as there is in developing countries such as Pakistan, South Africa, Australia etc. The answer is the English game's in fantastic nick financially, whereas guys on third-world incomes like Warnie and Cronje have to scrape around for the basic necessities like a leather jacket for your fiancee to go down the shops in. Not to mention having to rely for their lunch on hand-outs of dried meat outside the ground.

So, given we're so much better off, how come England aren't top of the pile? We're in a situation whereby we've got the icing but no cake. I believe the ECB should invest some of that money in bribing the oppo to take a dive. The knowledge that every time England set foot on the park they were guaranteed to win might offend the diehards but it's a sure-fire way to attract the youngsters. It would have to be arranged in complete secrecy, obviously, but that's never been a problem before for members of the ICC.

I'd recommend taking a leaf out of the County Championship book and bringing in a two-tier system for mobile phones. That way all your essential professional calls to the garage, B&Q etc show up on the bill, whereas Banjo Cassim or whoever could call you 180 times from Johannesburg and no one would be any the wiser.

And as an extra precaution Pod suggests taking a long hard look at the international umpires list. Out would go the likes of Javed Akhtar, in favour of blokes you could rely on 150% and whose credentials are beyond question. You want people with the right kind of experience donning the Happy Shopper white coat - the names Aitken and Hamilton come to mind.

Put the finances of cricket on a proper footing like this and there'd be no need to appoint the likes of Sir Paul "Bev" Condon to investigate the alleged corruption in the game. To be honest I haven't got a lot of time for the boys in blue, who as far as I can see spend far too much of their time mischief-making when they should be out catching paedophiles. Pulling me over to the hard shoulder merely for tipping a bag of Doritos up so I could get the last bits out, that was plain fascism. The A452 is a road Dave Podmore knows like the back of his hand, he doesn't need to actually see it while driving along.

I understand there are more amazing revelations to come when the match-fixing hearing resumes in Cape Town. Ali Bacher, for instance, reckons that as well as the last World Cup and the 1998 England v South Africa series, the 1981 Ashes and the second world war were fixed too.

I laughed when I first heard that but now I'm not so sure. After all, the overall losers of that latter contest (Germany) ended up with an awful lot of top quality leather jackets. Looking back it makes you wonder - was the first world war on the house as well?

fields.headline: Revenge so sweet for England
fields.trailText: Revenge for Port-of-Spain 1994 has been a long time coming. That was when Curtly Ambrose inspired West Indies to bowl England out for 46, with the type of awesome fast bowling - and rabbit-in-headlights batting - that has rarely been approached in Test cricket.
fields.body:
Revenge for Port-of-Spain 1994 has been a long time coming. That was when Curtly Ambrose inspired West Indies to bowl England out for 46, with the type of awesome fast bowling - and rabbit-in-headlights batting - that has rarely been approached in Test cricket.

Until now, that is. West Indies were bowled out so surgically that you half-thought Curtly and Courtney had stayed out there. Batsmen were ducking away from bouncers, being clonked on the gloves, giving catching practice to the slips. Even the crowd sounded more St John's Antigua than St John's Wood. But after you pinched yourself you realised it really was Cork and Gough roaring in, pinging helmets and wringing decisions from the umpires which, in one or two cases, looked a little dodgy.

Fine stuff indeed for England's five survivors of Port-of-Spain, four of them batsmen - Atherton, Stewart, Ramprakash and Hick. And then there was Caddick, who hitherto has always looked diffident against West Indies, especially in the first three innings of this series. Finally West Indies were faced with the county Caddick - the one who makes good batsmen jump and flinch, the one who shot out 105 batsmen in 1998 while the selectors were studiously looking the other way. This Caddick snarled in and shot out five big wickets for 16. And he got the big one - Lara, well caught by Cork in the gully. The last time Caddick dismissed Lara in a Test he had 375 to his name.

Although 21 wickets went down in the day, the pitch inspectors shouldn't be Lording it tomorrow. There was a lot of sideways movement, and occasionally some variable bounce, but what scuppered West Indies - and, let's not forget, England too - was accurate fast bowling right out of the top drawer. Ambrose made up for a solitary wicket at Edgbaston with four cheap wickets. Walsh was Walsh. Sensationally, England's fast men then managed to outdo them.

But before we get too carried away we must remember the last time West Indies set England a target of around 190 to win. They didn't quite make it. Er ... they were all out for 46, at Port-of-Spain, in 1994. Put that champagne on ice, barman!

Steven Lynch is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

This Caddick snarled in and shot out five big wickets for 16. And he got the big one - Lara, well caught by Cork in the gully. The last time Caddick dismissed Lara in a Test he had 375 to his name. Although 21 wickets went down in the day, the pitch inspectors shouldn't be Lording it tomorrow. There was a lot of sideways movement, and occasionally some variable bounce, but what scuppered West Indies - and, let's not forget, England too - was accurate fast bowling right out of the top drawer. Ambrose made up for a solitary wicket at Edgbaston with four cheap wickets. Walsh was Walsh. Sensationally, England's fast men then managed to outdo them. But before we get too carried away we must remember the last time West Indies set England a target of around 190 to win. They didn't quite make it. Er ... they were all out for 46, at Port-of-Spain, in 1994. Put that champagne on ice, barman! Steven Lynch is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

In Rotterdam tomorrow France and Italy will attempt to spare a largely upbeat European Championship an anticlimax following two dull thuds in the semi-finals. That is to say, the French will hope to win in something like the style to which the present tournament has become happily accustomed. The Italians will simply hope to win.

Italy emerged heroically from the second semi-final on Thursday when they defeated Holland on penalties after keeping the game goalless for two hours, despite losing Gianluca Zambrotta just past the half-hour to a second yellow card. What followed was an epic of defensive excellence, with Alessandro Nesta proving Patrick Kluivert's nemesis and Fabio Cannavaro almost as impassable while Francesco Toldo was unbeaten by two penalties in open play and saved two more in the shoot-out.

One exemplary Italian piece of resistance is enough. Euro 2000 hardly needs another and not only the French will look to Zinedine Zidane to prevent tomorrow's final turning into the bore of attrition which the match in Amsterdam became once Dutch legs tired and the disappointing Dennis Bergkamp gave way to a sluggish Clarence Seedorf.

Most neutrals would have preferred a final between France and Holland, a meeting of contrasting attacking minds, to the conflict of sword and shield now on offer. But knockout competitions seldom get what they want and too many "perfect" finals have flopped before now for anybody to be too put out by the Dutch absence.

The important thing is that the contest is settled without the need for a further shoot-out or even the spurious climax of a "golden goal" in sudden-death extra-time. The one that enabled France to beat Portugal in the other semi-final was not the result of inspired alchemy, more the alertness of the Slovak linesman who spotted Abel Xavier doing a spot of slip fielding at the near post which led to Zidane's decisive penalty.

The hysterical Portuguese protests surrounding this goal cast a long, late shadow across a European Championship which has otherwise brought out the best in the continent's mix of clearly defined styles of play. This time technique has largely triumphed over athleticism, although the extent to which France have augmented their skills with power and pace has so far been the dominating factor.

It has paid teams to be positive. A more liberal interpretation of the offside law, a total ban on challenges from behind and even the restriction on passing back to goalkeepers, which has always appeared to be a cop-out by Fifa, have encouraged sides to take risks and attack from the start instead of hanging around for half an hour to size each other up. Even Italy began by pressurising defences at the earliest opportunity. It is only now that they have reminded Euro 2000 that matches can be won without being won, by sitting tight and leaving the rest to Toldo. Yet before Thursday's triumph in the shoot-out Italian teams had had about as much success in these duels as Ben Turpin, the cross-eyed cowboy.

It is an odd denouement which sees the coaches of the losing semi-finalists, Frank Rijkaard of Holland and Portugal's Humberto Coelho, decide to step down while Kevin Keegan declares, following England's floperoo, that he will change neither his squad nor his tactics - except to tighten the string on his crossbow.

Returning home from international tournaments of this quality it is tempting to hope that some of the lessons will be absorbed by the domestic game. In Euro 2000, for example, Pierluigi Collina and the majority of his fellow referees have shown how to keep discipline and the play flowing at the same time.

Routine fouls have been punished by free-kicks without referees feeling obliged to fish for yellow cards. Writhing players who are obviously not seriously injured have been ignored, like toddlers rolling around the floor of a supermarket. Dissent, with the notable exception of the Portuguese, has been below average. Players have accepted decisions against them and got on with the business of playing.

It would be nice to think that, when the new season starts, the Premiership will have taken some note of what has been going on in Holland and Belgium; nice but not realistic. When two-thirds to three-quarters of clubs are concerned merely with avoiding relegation, the quality of the football served up in a summer tournament is unlikely to be regarded as relevant to the acquisition of a point at Sunderland in January.

Tomorrow's final, therefore, will be an end in itself and nobody's new beginning. At least the Premiership will be represented by foreign proxy in that Patrick Vieira, Emmanuel Petit and Thierry Henry of Arsenal, along with Chelsea's Marcel Desailly, will seek to help France become European champions two years after winning the World Cup.

For the French, compared with the 1998 final in Paris, this will be a role reversal. In the Stade de France Aimé Jacquet's pragmatists approached the game against Brazil expecting to have to mount a defensive operation to contain Ronaldo. Only when it became clear that Ronaldo was not himself did the French seize the initiative, with Zidane putting away two free headers.

Now it is assumed that France, with more strikers at the disposal of Roger Lemerre than were available to Jacquet, will be the main aggressors while Italy will fall back to the Nesta-Cannavaro line and defy them to find a way through. Perhaps it should be "him" rather than "them". Everyone knows the identity of the one man who can save this final from the Etruscan trough of nil-nihilism.

While Zidane is unlikely to get the sort of chances in the air which he accepted with such elan two years ago, in every other respect he is capable of bestriding tomorrow's game, no, not like a colossus, more like Gulliver in Lilliput. For, while the likes of Luigi di Biagio and Gianluca Pessotto may well attempt to tie him down, Zidane is the sort of footballer who can reduce the thickest rope to cotton thread.

Not that Italy will attempt to shackle Zidane by man-marking. He has been around in Serie A long enough for the opposition to know how futile that can be. Dino Zoff is more likely to try to isolate Zidane while denying space to the strikers and tracking down the forward runs of Vieira, Petit, Lilian Thuram and Laurent Blanc.

Youri Djorkaeff, if and when he appears, could be the card up Lemerre's sleeve. Francesco Totti may turn out to be Zoff's ace. Or it might be Alessandro del Piero. Totti's cheeky check and chip in the shoot-out against Holland recalled Antonin Panenka's decisive penalty to win the 1976 final for Czechoslovakia after their enthralling 2-2 draw with West Germany.

Certainly the Feyenoord Stadium would settle for similar excitement tomorrow. Zinedine Zidane can not only win the game for France; he can also prevent it becoming a zzzzzz.

webTitle: England can only lose in World Cup bid

fields.headline: England can only lose in World Cup bid
fields.trailText: It is beginning to look as if England's chance of hosting the 2006 World Cup is as doomed as Kevin Keegan's attempt to win the 2000 European Championship. Yet again, it would seem, burgeoning optimism is about to be confounded by cold reality, with tactical naivety not far behind.
fields.body:
It is beginning to look as if England's chance of hosting the 2006 World Cup is as doomed as Kevin Keegan's attempt to win the 2000 European Championship. Yet again, it would seem, burgeoning optimism is about to be confounded by cold reality, with tactical naivety not far behind.

Yesterday morning, less than a week before Fifa meets in Zurich to take a vote on which country will stage the next tournament but one, a leaked report from the world governing body revealed that its inspectors rated the bids of South Africa and Germany more highly than an English campaign which has cost £10m and circumnavigated the globe more times than Drake and Magellan put together.

South Africa was always the favourite once Sepp Blatter, the Fifa president, had declared that it was about time the African continent had a World Cup. England's best hope was to be put on standby should the political and social situation in South Africa deteriorate so severely in the next six years that Fifa would be forced to move the World Cup elsewhere.

Even this was a long shot considering that the 1978 tournament stayed in Argentina, along with its Peronist symbol, after the country had been taken over by a murderous junta and Mexico hosted the World Cups of 1970 and 1986 despite a massacre of protesting students and an earthquake.

For England the most galling part is that for all the lobbying and cosseting, not to mention an honest manifesto which has consistently emphasised the size, safety and comfort of the Premiership stadiums at which most of the games in 2006 would be played, its bid may not even make it past the first round of votes in Zurich, always assuming that a second is necessary; the way things are going South Africa could get the 13 votes required without the need of another ballot.

England can live with a South African victory but being edged out of second place by the Germans would leave a bitter taste accompanied by rancorous repercussions. An early glimpse of what the English reaction to such an outcome would be was provided by Alec McGivan, the organiser of the 2006 campaign, yesterday morning. He was clearly baffled by Fifa's decision to regard Germany's as the more worthy bid.

Therein, perhaps, lies the flaw in England's thinking. The cartoonist HM Bateman might have portrayed McGivan as The Man Who Thought Hosting The World Cup Was All About Nice Grounds. World Cup bids are more about global football politics than green grass.

McGivan may be an experienced operator but, compared with what he has been up against in South Africa's Danny Jordaan and Lennart Johansson, the pro-German Uefa president, he is a lightweight. Two of the best-known personalities in the world game, Sir Bobby Charlton and Sir Geoff Hurst, have given England's bid considerable kudos but you need more than a pawn and two knights to win this sort of chess game.

If England's campaign fires a blank in Zurich next week the critical Gatling guns will quickly find targets for blame. Some will argue that English hooliganism in Charleroi and Brussels during Euro 2000 and Johansson's threat to throw Keegan's team out proved to be the final straw for England's chances. Others will wonder if a nation under- going periodic bouts of xenophobia and regularly booing opposing national anthems at Wembley should ever have been considered a serious candidate in the first place.

Then there is Wembley itself, still a museum of empire and much loved on cup final day but as suitable for staging a World Cup final as travelling to the moon by flying boat. Yes, there would be a marvellous new stadium in place by 2006 but so far not one bulldozer has been moved in nor one brick been moved out. In terms of Olympic stadiums, moreover, the Germans are already leading 2-1.

Of course the heart of the matter is not about TV pictures of chair-throwing deadheads being dispersed by water cannon or the byzantine complexities of rebuilding Wembley. The truth is that, when it came to touting for the 2006 World Cup, England has always been behind the game.

The Germans began their campaign some 18 months earlier on the understanding that, having backed England's wish to stage the 1996 European Championship, they would be left to garner European support for 2006 unmolested. When England announced a rival bid the Germans cried foul and Johansson supported them.

Switching the English vote for the Fifa presidency from Johansson to Blatter in 1998 was not the Football Association's finest hour. Without European backing England has had to trawl the Third World for votes knowing that its natural sympathies lay with Africa. So it looks as though our World Cup bid will finish with neither trumps nor trumpets, just a feeling that the campaign could not make up in effort what it lacked in nous. One question will persist: was it really worth wrecking last season's FA Cup by allowing Manchester United to withdraw in order to win hypothetical brownie points from Blatter by turning up for his wretched Fifa World Club Championship?

At the moment, in football, England appear to be losing all round.

webTitle: Pupil ready to teach masters a lesson

fields.headline: Pupil ready to teach masters a lesson
fields.standfirst: Richard Williams on Zinedine Zidane, Euro 2000's star player, and the man with the inside knowledge to crack Italy's formidable defence
fields.trailText: Richard Williams on Zinedine Zidane, Euro 2000's star player, and the man with the inside knowledge to crack Italy's formidable defence
fields.body:
In a team full of leaders, he has become the patron. Zinedine Zidane may not wear the captain's armband, and he seldom bothers to say very much, but he is the man to whom his team-mates turn for inspiration - and the man to whom the rest of Europe is looking to unlock the steel doors of the Italian defence in tomorrow night's Euro 2000 final, thus fulfilling the promise of a tournament which, until this week's semi-finals, appeared to have been dedicated to inaugurating an era of attacking football.

Those who know Zizou best say that the introspection of old, the shyness of an immigrant's son from the housing projects who finds himself dining with presidents, has begun to fall away, and that he is becoming more at ease with his celebrity. But he will always be a man whose eloquence is primarily in his feet.

Last week, in a rare flight of verbal fancy, he declared: "At 28, I'm at the pinnacle of my art." It sounded a bit pompous, a bit uncharacteristic, even a bit French, and two days later he had reconsidered the matter. "Maybe that was a little excessive," he said. "Let's just say I'm at the top of my form."

Yet his performances in the tournament suggest that Zidane is still finding new ways to express himself with a football. In the first half of the quarter-final against Spain he appeared to want to play the game only with the soles of his feet, stroking the ball with the blades of his boots simply because that gave him a more intimate contact with its surface - the difference between a punch and a caress. Against Portugal in the next round he showed us another dimension, an ability to overcome double marking by setting off on long slaloms in which he seemed to be skimming across packed snow while his opponents were trying to run through sand dunes.

He is a big man, 6ft 1in and 12st 4lb, and his stooping gait can make him look ponderous, but his greatness lies in the delicacy of his touch and the subtlety of his mind. When he scored from a free-kick against Spain, he seemed to be feeling the precise texture of the ball through his boot and his stocking. When he took the "golden penalty" against Portugal he deployed the skills of a find-the-lady trickster, his eyes and his feet sending conflicting messages that hypnotised Vitor Baia into diving the wrong way. Earlier in the match he had set Bixente Lizarazu free on the left with a disguised six-foot backheel that was worth the price of admission alone.

But his displays of unearthly skill are not Zidane's only contribution to the squad. During their preparations for the tournament, while they were encamped at Bourg Saint-Maurice in the Savoy Alps, Roger Lemerre remarked: "When you see Zizou's appetite for work, his eagerness, his smile - well, that's reassuring." The coach was recognising that, unlike some superstars, Zidane is a vital ingredient in the social chemistry of a squad whose members relish their closeness so much that it seems as though as individuals they belong not to Juventus or Chelsea or Real Madrid or Arsenal but to a club called France. His special closeness is with Christophe Dugarry, a former Bordeaux team-mate with whom he shares ownership of a restaurant. To Dugarry's mother, Zizou is "the sort of brother Christophe always wanted".

Born in La Castellane, a suburb of Marseille, the son of an Algerian father, he made his first division debut with Cannes at 17 before moving to Bordeaux in 1992. On his international debut in 1994, he scored both goals in a 2-2 draw with the Czech Republic. He joined Juventus after Euro 96 and won the Italian championship in his first season. The triumph at the Stade de France in 1998 brought him the title of the world footballer of the year to go with his Légion d'Honneur ribbon.

Naturally, the two goals he scored with his head in the final against Brazil enhanced his already extraordinary status. And, as many observers have noted, when Zidane is not around, France are not the same side. Against Paraguay in the World Cup, while he was serving a one-match suspension for trampling on a Saudi player, the team found themselves desperately lacking a creative force and were facing elimination until Laurent Blanc stepped forward to score a decisive goal in extra-time. England's fans will also remember the way Zidane presented the 18-year-old Nicolas Anelka with three goals (one of them unjustly disallowed) at Wembley two winters ago.

"This is certainly a better side than the France of 1998," he said after last week's quarter-final. "We've all got another two years of experience in the best leagues in Europe. And this time we've got five forwards, all with great qualities, which we didn't have during the World Cup. We've also shown that we're adaptable - there isn't one ideal system because each match offers different characteristics, which means that all the 22 players are involved. Against the Czech Republic, for example, Youri Djorkaeff came on and scored a vital goal after he'd been criticised for his performance against Denmark. And the spirit of Christophe Dugarry is an asset to us because he's happy to play in any position and to put himself at the service of the team."

In a tournament full of technical interest, the main focus of tactical debate has been the general eclipse of the great playmaker, a majority of sides preferring to place their faith in collective movement. "I don't think the job of playmaker will disappear," Zidane offered, "because it's something that gives people a lot of pleasure. I know that many teams prefer to play without one, but for me that diminishes the spectacle."

And whatever the importance of team play, the stroke of individual genius is still the most effective way of determining the course of a football match, with the No10 shirt carrying a special significance in that respect. When Liam Brady, invited last week to comment on Zidane's qualities as a playmaker, remarked admiringly that he saw the Frenchman as "a maker of goals rather than a maker of the game", he was perhaps ignoring the fact that goals make games. Zidane may not sit deep in the manner of a Gerson or a Brady, but his hands are just as firmly on the strings.

On Wednesday night in Brussels, in the five minutes of madness between the award of the decisive penalty and the taking of the kick, Zidane went off by himself to prepare for the task of finishing the match. Even after almost two hours of high-intensity action, his mind and his body were in perfect union.

Talking of his development as a player, he has credited Juventus's fitness team - currently embroiled in a controversy over their alleged use of bodybuilding substances - with increasing his explosive power by 30%. "But most of the improvement is psychological," he said. "Italian football is the best education in the world." And tomorrow night the pupil will attempt to teach his masters a lesson.

In the first half of the quarter-final against Spain he appeared to want to play the game only with the soles of his feet, stroking the ball with the blades of his boots simply because that gave him a more intimate contact with its surface - the difference between a punch and a caress. Against Portugal in the next round he showed us another dimension, an ability to overcome double marking by setting off on long slaloms in which he seemed to be skimming across packed snow while his opponents were trying to run through sand dunes. He is a big man, 6ft 1in and 12st 4lb, and his stooping gait can make him look ponderous, but his greatness lies in the delicacy of his touch and the subtlety of his mind. When he scored from a free-kick against Spain, he seemed to be feeling the precise texture of the ball through his boot and his stocking. When he took the "golden penalty" against Portugal he deployed the skills of a find-the-lady trickster, his eyes and his feet sending conflicting messages that hypnotised Vitor Baia into diving the wrong way. Earlier in the match he had set Bixente Lizarazu free on the left with a disguised six-foot backheel that was worth the price of admission alone. But his displays of unearthly skill are not Zidane's only contribution to the squad. During their preparations for the tournament, while they were encamped at Bourg Saint-Maurice in the Savoy Alps, Roger Lemerre remarked: "When you see Zizou's appetite for work, his eagerness, his smile - well, that's reassuring." The coach was recognising that, unlike some superstars, Zidane is a vital ingredient in the social chemistry of a squad whose members relish their closeness so much that it seems as though as individuals they belong not to Juventus or Chelsea or Real Madrid or Arsenal but to a club called France. His special closeness is with Christophe Dugarry, a former Bordeaux team-mate with whom he shares ownership of a restaurant. To Dugarry's mother, Zizou is "the sort of brother Christophe always wanted". Born in La Castellane, a suburb of Marseille, the son of an Algerian father, he made his first division debut with Cannes at 17 before moving to Bordeaux in 1992. On his international debut in 1994, he scored both goals in a 2-2 draw with the Czech Republic. He joined Juventus after Euro 96 and won the Italian championship in his first season. The triumph at the Stade de France in 1998 brought him the title of the world footballer of the year to go with his Légion d'Honneur ribbon. Naturally, the two goals he scored with his head in the final against Brazil enhanced his already extraordinary status. And, as many observers have noted, when Zidane is not around, France are not the same side. Against Paraguay in the World Cup, while he was serving a one-match suspension for trampling on a Saudi player, the team found themselves desperately lacking a creative force and were facing elimination until Laurent Blanc stepped forward to score a decisive goal in extra-time. England's fans will also remember the way Zidane presented the 18-year-old Nicolas Anelka with three goals (one of them unjustly disallowed) at Wembley two winters ago. "This is certainly a better side than the France of 1998," he said after last week's quarter-final. "We've all got another two years of experience in the best leagues in Europe. And this time we've got five forwards, all with great qualities, which we didn't have during the World Cup. We've also shown that we're adaptable - there isn't one ideal system because each match offers different characteristics, which means that all the 22 players are involved. Against the Czech Republic, for example, Youri Djorkaeff came on and scored a vital goal after he'd been criticised for his performance against Denmark. And the spirit of Christophe Dugarry is an asset to us because he's happy to play in any position and to put himself at the service of the team." In a tournament full of technical interest, the main focus of tactical debate has been the general eclipse of the great playmaker, a majority of sides preferring to place their faith in collective movement. "I don't think the job of playmaker will disappear," Zidane offered, "because it's something that gives people a lot of pleasure. I know that many teams prefer to play without one, but for me that diminishes the spectacle." And whatever the importance of team play, the stroke of individual genius is still the most effective way of determining the course of a football match, with the No10 shirt carrying a special significance in that respect. When Liam Brady, invited last week to comment on Zidane's qualities as a playmaker, remarked admiringly that he saw the Frenchman as "a maker of goals rather than a maker of the game", he was perhaps ignoring the fact that goals make games. Zidane may not sit deep in the manner of a Gerson or a Brady, but his hands are just as firmly on the strings. On Wednesday night in Brussels, in the five minutes of madness between the award of the decisive penalty and the taking of the kick, Zidane went off by himself to prepare for the task of finishing the match. Even after almost two hours of high-intensity action, his mind and his body were in perfect union. Talking of his development as a player, he has credited Juventus's fitness team - currently embroiled in a controversy over their alleged use of bodybuilding substances - with increasing his explosive power by 30%. "But most of the improvement is psychological," he said. "Italian football is the best education in the world." And tomorrow night the pupil will attempt to teach his masters a lesson.

webTitle: Lobbying of peers on increase, watchdog told

fields.headline: Lobbying of peers on increase, watchdog told
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The House of Lords is becoming a major target for lobbyists, Lord Neill's investigation into reforming the peers' register of interests was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The House of Lords is becoming a major target for lobbyists, Lord Neill's investigation into reforming the peers' register of interests was told yesterday.

The former Labour home secretary, Lord Merlyn-Rees, told the committee on standards in public life that he received documents every day from organisations seeking to influence peers to support particular issues.

"The flow is enormous and there is far more lobbying than there used to be," he said. The lobbyists include many charities, voluntary organisation as well as big business interests.

He said the reformed Lords was becoming much more like the House of Commons, although the standard of inquiries by Lords committees was much higher than the work done in the Commons.

Lord Neill's committee is trying to establish whether the Lords should be brought into line with the Commons and have tougher codes of conduct with a mandatory register of interests, instead of the current voluntary arrangement. It is also examining whether a tougher code of conduct for peers is required.

The investigation into the Lords has been prompted by the government's axeing last November of more than 600 hereditary peers and the prospect of second stage reform.

Now only a rump of 92 hereditary peers remain among the 695 in the house alongside nominated life peers, law lords and bishops.

The clerk of the parliaments, Michael Davies, said he had no reason to question the current registration system for peers' interests, but certain members of the government believed it should be compulsory.

fields.headline: Facing the committee
fields.standfirst:
Westminster correspondent David Hencke, who exposes sleaze in parliament, recounts his appearance in front of the parliamentary committee on standards in public life
Committee on standards in public life
fields.trailText: Friday, 10.45am: Westminster correspondent David Hencke, who exposes sleaze in parliament, recounts his appearance in front of the parliamentary committee on standards in public life
fields.body:
It is a daunting experience giving evidence to Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life. The hearing is at a grandiose address, No1 Great George Street just off Parliament Square. It takes place in a very large imposing room, where I am faced by 11 people sat round in a horseshoe. They are the great, the good and the famous, drawn from the Lords and the Commons, industry, universities and business.

The committee is the only body in Britain which can lay down the rules dictating how the rest of the good and the not so good behave in parliament and government.

The subject - whether members of the Lords should have to register all their business interests and should be subject to a proper code of conduct - is in my view an open and shut case; but it is generating a lot of heat from the old guard in the Lords who are resisting the change.

Giving evidence is a surprisingly unpompous affair. This is partly because Lord Neill, the middle-aged, unstuffy law lord and chairman of the committee, puts everyone at ease.

Luckily, only two of the 11 members question me: veteran former Labour cabinet minister Lord Shore, and Lord Goodhart, a Liberal Democrat barrister. Nor is the line of questioning combative; it is aimed at teasing out arguments rather than expose individual wrongdoing. Indeed, the committee rules insist that witnesses should not use the hearings to raise complaints about individuals - which makes giving evidence as an investigative journalist slightly difficult. But it also gets me off the hook as I do not have to risk angering individuals.

My 35 minutes of questioning is helped by the fact that Lord Shore teases out my views on the need for a compulsory register and puts a lot of his own into it. So the questions are long - giving me time to think - and take time to answer; they include a ticklish one about examples of peers who may have broken the rules, but cannot be named.

I was helped along every line of the way in preparation for the hearing. The committee asks for a short statement two days in advance - so I can order my thoughts. They send you a line of questioning - so at least I am prepared for the areas I am likely to have to discuss.

In the end, it was Lord Neill himself who asked the final question that could have flummoxed me. Pointing out that I had made a logical case for a consistent and transparent (the posh word for openness) compulsory register in the Lords, he asked why I said that peers should also be accountable, given they were not elected; to which I replied that they had to be accountable to the public for passing legislation that affected the public.

I wondered if I had got it right. And then it was all over. Perhaps it was not so daunting after all, even it was not quite a fireside chat.

fields.headline: ICC's man with no baggage
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's gossip column today, we take a look at the cricketing credentials of ICC's new anti-corruption chief and reveal our third Do of the Week, featuring an author who struggled to sign his name
fields.trailText: Condon: the corruption buster with "no baggage"
fields.body:
Condon: the corruption buster with "no baggage"

How much does Sir Paul Condon, the ICC's new anti-corruption chief, know about cricket? Very little, it appears. Condon says he played the game at school and university and has an interest in cricket and in sport generally, but he would still be hard put to pick out leading international players accused of match-fixing in an identity parade. Even ICC admits that he has "no specific cricketing connections, or deep love or knowledge of cricket". Its spokesman adds: "Sir Paul is not a member of any club, certainly not a playing member."

Condon has hardly picked up a bat since, during his three years at Oxford University, he turned out regularly for a local club side, Woodstock - whose home ground was Blenheim Palace, the stately home. "Paul was a decent wicketkeeper and middle-order bat," says an old friend. "He's still very proud of that, but wouldn't claim ever to have been more than an enthusiastic amateur." Condon has since been to the odd game, his last being a cup final at Lord's a couple of years ago.

Even so, Condon doesn't list cricket as an interest in Who's Who, but then his entry doesn't mention any other recreations either. Those who know him say that Condon, who retired early this year as Commissioner of London's Metropolitan Police, relaxes by walking in the countryside near his Kent home. He's also an enthusiastic traveller, which may help explain the attractions of the three-year ICC appointment.

Encouragingly, Condon has a reputation as something of a puritan. One of his first actions on becoming Commissioner was to convert the infamous "Tank" bar in the Scotland Yard basement - haunt of generations of detectives - into a fitness centre. And some at ICC argue that his remoteness from the game is a plus. As one puts it: "It's not necessarily a disadvantage that he hasn't an inbred connection with cricket. He brings no baggage."

Do of the Week (the third in an occasional series)

Occasion The launch on Tuesday, June 27, of Cricket's Greatest Battles (Generation Publications, £14.99, July 1) by Nasser Hussain, Peter Baxter and Mike Brearley, at the Museum at Lord's. Baxter, producer of BBC Radio's Test Match Special, re-examines 21 of the game's most dramatic personal confrontations, ranging from Bradman against Larwood in the Bodyline series of 1932-33 to Botham versus Australia at Headingley in 1981. Hussain comments interestingly on each one, in one case (Atherton/Donald at Trent Bridge in 1998) from the other end of the pitch, while Brearley provides an overview from the perspective of a successful England captain, and practising psychoanalyst.
Format Champagne reception from 5pm to 7pm. Guests were greeted by a steel band.
Attendance 50, including Mark Ramprakash - like Hussain, he was in training gear - and Mike Gatting, whose 1987 row with Pakistan umpire Shakoor Rana is featured in the book.
Notable absentees The West Indians were invited, and the publishers particularly hoped to see Brian Lara, Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh, who all figure prominently in the text. But there was no sign of them - even though their team bus was parked almost outside.
Main surprise in book Nasser declining to discuss any of his greatest mental battles. Baxter urged him to, suggesting (among others) his 207 against Warne and co in the Edgbaston Test victory over Australia three years ago. But Nasser wasn't prepared to give away any trade secrets. He told me: "I don't really like talking about my own involvement and what goes through my head, especially while I'm still playing. Once I've stopped, I'll tell everyone what goes through my head, and what you think when you're going through good form and what you think when you're not going through good form."
Main talking point Nasser's cheerfulness despite that cracked left thumb. Not only has this forced him out of the Lord's Test and probably the entire one-day series, but it couldn't have come at a worse time for an author - although right-handed, he signs autographs with his left. With some difficulty he signed a number of books before heading off soon after six to have the thumb examined again.
Principal entertainment Speeches from Hussain, Baxter and Gerald Davies, the former Welsh rugby international who's now chairman of Generation. For someone who spoke at a few minutes' notice - he was reluctant to speak, and did so without notes - Hussain was surprisingly fluent, and amusing in a low-key way. "I won't keep you long," he began, "like one of my innings." He explained that the project had appealed to him because "when you get to the highest level, 90 per cent of the game is played in the mind". Baxter admitted that while the most recent clash in the book - Herschelle Gibbs's dropped catch off Steve Waugh in the World Cup game at Leeds - now worries him a little, he likes to think that the battles chosen were all "genuine red-blooded contests with no hint of a bookie anywhere around".

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). E-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com. For the mid-week Grapevine, featuring stories on the stars set to turn out for Malcolm Marshall, and how Brian Johnston's grandson is catching the eye, click here.
