fields.headline: Nail bomber convicted of murder
fields.standfirst:
Copeland profile
Photo gallery
Special report
Audio from outside the Old Bailey
fields.trailText: Nail bomber David Copeland, 24, an engineer from Cove, Hampshire, has received six life sentences after being found guilty of three murders in an attack on a Soho pub in April last year.
fields.body:
Nail bomber David Copeland, 24, an engineer from Cove, Hampshire, has received six life sentences after being found guilty of three murders in an attack on a Soho pub in April last year.

The jury at the Old Bailey did not accept the defence plea that Copeland was acting under diminished responsibility.

Copeland admitted causing explosions at Brixton, Brick Lane and Soho, London, over 13 days in April last year, killing three people and injuring 139.

The blast at the mainly gay Admiral Duncan pub in Soho killed Andrea Dykes, 27, who was pregnant, and friends John Light, 32 and Nik Moore, 31, from Essex.

The prosecution refused to accept Copeland's plea of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds he was suffering a mental illness - paranoid schizophrenia - which diminished his responsibility at the time.

Copeland showed no emotion as the jury of four women and eight men returned their unanimous verdicts. People in the public gallery, including victims injured in Copeland's bomb attacks, cheered and clapped.

Copeland received mandatory life sentences for each of the murders and three further life sentences for his bombings which targeted the capital's ethnic and gay communities. In a campaign that ran over three successive weekends last year, Copeland planted nailbombs in multiracial Brixton, the largely Bangladeshi community of Brick Lane and the gay quarter in Soho.

Judge Hyam told Copeland: "Nothing can excuse or justify the evil you have done and certainly not the abhorrent views which you have embraced.

"It is only too apparent from what you have said you have no feelings for those lives you have afflicted.

"The public must be protected from you and assured that if you are ever released it will not be for a very long time."

The jury deliberated for six-and-a-half hours to reach its verdict.

Copeland was led away to serve his sentence in Broadmoor high security hospital.

Victim Tommy Douglas, who lost both legs in the blast at the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho, said he was relieved that David Copeland had been convicted of murder.

"I prayed to God that he would go down for murder. He's not a human being," Mr Douglas said. "He has shown no remorse."

Gary Reid, 44, who lost a leg and suffered other injuries in the Soho blast, said victims now felt a "deep sense of relief and gratitude".

He said: "Justice has been done today. The fear, loathing, hatred and ignorance culminating in the bombings is a warning to society and the world as a whole that racism, prejudice and homophobia - and the fear of difference - is out there.

"We should all be aware of this and challenge it at every opportunity.

Copeland's father, Stephen Copeland, said after the verdict he would be considering an appeal. Mr Copeland, 51, said: "I don't know yet if there are grounds for an appeal. But I will be putting my full efforts into finding out if it is a possibility."

He said he still believed his son was substantially impaired and was left a "zombie" during the trial because he was so sedated.

Copeland's brother Jonathan said: "Dave is a very sick boy. Broadmoor is the best place for him."

webTitle: Labour spends half as much as the Tories

fields.headline: Labour spends half as much as the Tories
fields.standfirst:
Treasury tells ministers to use up capital budgets
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Treasury is putting pressure on Whitehall departments to boost spending on Britain's fraying public infrastructure after figures released yesterday showed capital expenditure by the state down 50% on the Conservative's last year in power.
fields.body:
The Treasury is putting pressure on Whitehall departments to boost spending on Britain's fraying public infrastructure after figures released yesterday showed capital expenditure by the state down 50% on the Conservative's last year in power.

Officials said the chancellor, Gordon Brown, had put the shortfall in capital expenditure high on the list of priorities for next month's comprehensive spending review after it became clear ministries were failing to spend money allocated to them.

After many years in which government spending on capital projects fell, the Treasury said that one explanation for the unexpected 32% drop in net public investment last year was that departments had become accustomed to "being starved of money". In addition, large parts of the public sector lacked the expertise to run big projects without long delays and spending overruns.

Treasury spending teams have now been told to liaise urgently with spending ministries to draw up plans for quadrupling the sums spent on public investment over the next two years.

Mr Brown had expected the long decline in public investment to end in the last financial year, when after sticking to the plans inherited from the outgoing Conservatives for his first two years, he pencilled in an increase to £5.5bn, followed by a doubling to £11bn by 2001-2002.

Figures from the office for national statistics released yesterday showed that net public expenditure after depreciation actually fell from £3.8bn to £2.6bn in 1999-2000, and was almost £3bn lower than expected.

With the government under mounting pressure from voters to improve public services, departments underspending are being allowed to carry unused parts of their capital budgets forward in the hope that the lost ground can be made up.

The failure of departments to spend all the money available left the government with an even bigger surplus - £18bn - in the public finances last year than it had been en visaging. However, other figures released by the ONS yesterday showed that the weakness of investment was being offset by the strength of consumer demand, which in turn was pushing Britain's balance of payments deeper into the red.

However, investment income fell from £4.1bn to £900m, while transfers to international institutions fell from £1bn to £800m.

Officials said the chancellor, Gordon Brown, had put the shortfall in capital expenditure high on the list of priorities for next month's comprehensive spending review after it became clear ministries were failing to spend money allocated to them. fields.headline: Bid, Bad and Barmby
fields.trailText: A BID TURNS BAD
fields.body:
A BID TURNS BAD

Earlier this morning the final nail was drilled into England's World 2006 coffin. And those doing the nailing were Fifa, who suggested in a leaked technical report that Premier League grounds weren't up to the same standard as those in South Africa and Germany. Alec McGivan, the leader of England's doomed World Cup bid, smelt a rat with a Swiss accent and a bad haircut. "Sepp Blatter is in an enormously powerful position," said McGivan while Fifa's head honcho remained silent. "I think he will live to regret the fact that he took such a partial position at the outset of the campaign."

Labouring under the delusion that there was still a campaign to be fought after McGivan had insulted the most powerful man in world football, Tony Banks addressed the annual Uefa congress this afternoon. "Uefa has a very tough decision to make," said the former Sports Minister. "You have to look at which bid gives Europe the best chance of hosting the World Cup." But before the assembled dignitaries could start dreaming of Germany, Tony continued: "We have done our sums and the only European bid which has enough support is England's."

Now the Fiver's no Einstein, but seeing as at least six of the eight Uefa delegates who hold seats on the Fifa executive are set to vote for Germany, and every one else in the world seems to be supporting South Africa, England's chances don't look too good. And not surprisingly a Fifa spokesman was quick to pour cold water on any claims of a Blatter-led conspiracy. "I can't imagine that is the case," he said. "There are about three people in this building who have seen this report. We are the civil servants and we are not against any country." The same thing can be said for the Fiver, which is why we're staying strictly neutral (and no we don't want a ride in your World Cup 2006 buggy, Bobby).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TO THE POWER OF 10

Dino Zoff sat down in front of the press today and offered them his assessment of Italy's opponents in Sunday's Euro 2000 final. "France are perhaps less of a collective force than the Dutch," he said, "but maybe technically, physically and as individuals they're stronger." A thoughtful appraisal, concurred the press. This man really knows what he's doing, they agreed. I think I'm going to offer myself to him as a slave, said one.

Yes, it's interesting what you can achieve when you stick ten men behind the ball. Only three weeks ago, the consensus was that Dino Zoff would get the boot from his job as Italian coach and replaced with someone a bit more progressive and outgoing. Now he's turned the Amsterdam arena into a "field of miracles" (and that's just the view of the Italian FA).

Now that Italy has experienced a collective memory loss not normally seen outside of the Vatican, you might have thought that Zoff can relax. Perhaps even send out an adventurous side on Sunday in the knowledge that he has already surpassed expectations. Not that it would be wise to bet on it. "France have the players to win the match," believes Arsene's Arsenal Wenger, "but Italy have frustrated many teams down the years. Holland are the latest. I just hope France are not the next."

Sobering words for all. But then, he is French.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"They [the Dutch] could have played for an entire day taking shots at our goal and they would never have scored" - Now why is Italian goalkeeper Francesco Toldo suddenly so cocky?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HANDING IN YOUR NOTICE

No matter how hard poor little Nick Barmby tries to get himself noticed in the city of Liverpool, he just can't get any attention. He's tried busking on the Mersey ferry, riding a unicycle around the Albert Dock stark naked, and walking through the city centre wearing a 'look at me and win £35' sandwich board - but to no avail. So imagine his surprise when today he found himself the talk of the town - and all the Everton midfielder had done was to stand in the immediate environs of his manager Walter Smith and some journalists and loudly announce "I want to play for Liverpool".

This clever scheme, which some seasoned observers may consider a tad disloyal, has led Barmby onto the transfer list with immediate effect. And while Gerard Houllier is interested, he is said to be unwilling to meet the £8m price tag Smith has slapped on Barmby's chubby face. "Liverpool had asked to be kept abreast of the situation and discussions will take place between the two clubs," Smith explained. "But it's not certain that agreement can be reached. Although a player may wish to go to a club, it's always difficult for clubs, especially those who are as close together as Liverpool and Everton, to reach agreement."

And agreement could be difficult, because Smith is said to favour a straight-cash deal - he'll tout the 26-year-old to Chelsea, who are prepared to stump up the full amount. But Liverpool may offer either David Thompson or Titi Camara in a player-plus-cash package, so Barmby's dream may yet come true. Of course, if nothing happens, Barmby could always play out the last year of his contract in front of home fans who are bitter rivals of the club he really wants to play for. He'd certainly get people acknowledging his presence then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle are set to complete a stunning £8m move for Belgian striker Emile Mpenza. A Schalke spokesman has confirmed that both they and Mpenza have accepted United's offer and the deal should be completed in the next few days.

Barcelona have announced that Josep Guardiola is available at just £3.9m. Outgoing president Josep Nunez has revealed that the Catalan club would be willing to let Guardiola leave because he is too old at 29.

Rangers have been linked with a move for Internazionale's Adrian Mutu, and could take the player on loan for two seasons. Inter have told Rangers that they are not interested in selling the Romanian international, but would allow the 21 year-old striker play at Ibrox for two seasons before moving back to Italy.

Aston Villa have made a £3.5m bid for Sheffield Wednesday winger Niclas Alexandersson. Everton and Coventry are also interested in the Swedish international.

Birmingham will offer cash plus Peter Ndlovu for Nottingham Forest midfielder Nigel Quashie.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers have signed Carlisle's 18-year-old defender Paul Reid. Arsenal, Liverpool and Leeds were tracking the highly-rated youngster, who was also the subject of a £200,000 bid by Motherwell.

Sheffield Wednesday have announced a £1m two-year shirt sponsorship deal worth Chupa Chups, the world's best-selling lollipop brand.

Bristol Rovers have been found guilty of failing to control their supporters after two spectators ran onto the pitch and attacked Stoke goalkeeper Gavin Ward earlier this year. The club will be docked a league point and fined £10,000 if a similar incident occurs during a one-year suspended sentence.

Aberdeen manager Ebbe Skovdahl has appointed former Clyde coach Gardner Spiers as his new number two.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)

All that football and now there's only this.

British Eurosport: The Spirit of Euro 2000 (7pm)

Ah no, there's always Eurosport.

Euro 200 Extra (8pm)

All right, all right, we get the message.

fields.headline: A thoroughly modern museum
fields.trailText: It takes a lot to inspire scientific curiosity in a non-scientific mind, but the Science Museum's new Wellcome wing manages to do just that.
fields.body:
It takes a lot to inspire scientific curiosity in a non-scientific mind, but the Science Museum's new Wellcome wing manages to do just that.

This cool blue showcase of the future opens on July 3. Although it holds our attention with techno-toys from a robodog to an IMAX theatre and a mangled racing car, the exhibition also raises awareness of issues and developments in modern science. It is up to date and intends to stay that way.

If you can't get to the display itself, the newly launched Science museum website has plenty to offer both potential visitors and young science fanatics.

Clear maps and a virtual tour of the new wing make planning a visit simple, and give users a taste of the hundreds of activities on offer. You can digitally manipulate your face shape and voice pattern and store them on your own science website, accessible only by fingerprint.

The site also encourages museum visitors to participate in a real scientific research project. The first of these will be Professor Hopkinson's study of how genes can control appearance. This investigation will use scans of volunteer museum visitors faces and DNA samples taken from their cheeks.

Teachers will find the Education page particularly useful as it provides free activities and original worksheets for children of all ages. The Hands on Science page provides a range of on-line virtual experiments and suggests safe investigations for pupils to try at home.

There is more to this site than publicity for the new wing. Well-presented pages give visitors opportunities to make their own suggestions for displays, and information about original exhibits - such as the Apollo spacecraft, and the history of fusion - is useful in its own right. All the links are excellent.

For enquiries about school visits, send an email or telephone 0207 9424776

webTitle: Did you look this good at Glastonbury?

fields.headline: Did you look this good at Glastonbury?
fields.standfirst: Is it possible to maintain sartorial standards in a field? To live rough without looking it? As the festival season kicks off,  Jess Cartner-Morley  advises on what to wear
fields.trailText: Is it possible to maintain sartorial standards in a field? To live rough without looking it? As the festival season kicks off, Jess Cartner-Morley advises on what to wear
fields.body:
I don't mean to be rude, but there was a notable absence of stylishness among festival-goers at Glastonbury last weekend. Considering you could scarcely move for hip young things pogo-ing up and down at the very cutting edge of fun, it was amazing how dreary they all looked. I mean, getting down and dirty in the festival spirit is all well and good but wearing cider-stained tie-dye is beyond the call of duty. Anyone would have thought they were frisking people at the entrance for banned substances, stripping normally well turned-out women of their nice shoes, dinky accessories and make-up bags, confiscating anything that looked like an attempt at coordination. Before festival-lovers get too offended, I'm not exempting myself from this criticism, I hasten to add: everything about festivals conspires to prevent you looking stylish.

Festivals can defeat the most determinedly elegant of people. I have plenty of friends who refuse point blank even to entertain the idea of going to one purely because they aren't prepared to look that hideous in public. And for the fashion devotee, Glastonbury is the Mount Everest of festivals, the greatest challenge - the biggest, longest, most prohibitively expensive to reach by black cab. Three days of camping, miles to walk between stages, a lack of secure places to leave your stuff and bathroom facilities that leave a lot to be desired all add up to a fashion assignment from hell.

Or is it really that hard? I can't help feeling some people just aren't trying. I mean, it wasn't even muddy. And looking a complete state on Sunday night is fair enough but on Friday lunchtime most punters already looked like they'd been living rough for months when in fact they had probably only been out of their new-edition VW Beetles for half an hour. So in order to prove it is possible to maintain sartorial standards at a festival, we sent a brave model down in this season's finest, to show that you can do the festival circuit in defiantly ungrungy style. If you balk at furry white designer boots, Chanel does lovely practical shiny pastel wellies for £130 - or do as the TV presenter dollies do and wear wellingtons when conditions force it to protect the hems of your Helmut Lang trousers from unsightly mud, but have an assistant on hand at all times with a pair of kitten heels to don whenever people are watching.

Practicality need not be forgone entirely - leave the white cashmere palazzo pants at home but take movie-star sunglasses and your most chichi bag, and be sure to add a splash of colour with an armful of backstage pass wristbands. After all, it's not a wake, it's a festival. Look festive.

fields.headline: Here's looking at you, Ken
fields.standfirst:
Is it the way he's turned out that gets the voters turning out? As Ken Livingstone officially turns mayor of London, Jess Cartner-Morley assesses his unique style

Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Is it the way he's turned out that gets the voters turning out? As Ken Livingstone officially turns mayor of London, Jess Cartner-Morley assesses his unique style
fields.body:
He is one the most photographed men of the year. His image can be spotted around London, immortalised in a cult T-shirt in the style of Che Guevara. His tireless championing of the one-suit wardrobe has become a hot topic of media speculation. Yet Ken - for London's new mayor has reached Madonna status, no surname required - is still seldom recognised for the style icon he surely is.

For all its unstudied air, the Ken look makes Martin Bell's anti-sleaze white suit look unpolitical. Ken's image is all about there being no image, no spin, no styling, a powerful political message that can hardly be entirely unconscious. The man-in-the-street's clichéd complaint of "politicians, they're all the same" is sidestepped by Ken's trademark mac-clad shuffle. Look at almost any photograph of a politician, cover the face and they are indistinguishable, unrecognisable. Ken, however, is undeniably, immediately Ken, from the slightly scuffed toes of his shoes to his woolly red scarf.

The keynote Ken outfit comprises a comfy-looking suit the colour of Rich Tea biscuits and an oversized, flappy beige raincoat, with that red woollen scarf tucked sensibly under its lapels. It is a look that gives him both individuality and familiarity - among politicians, he never quite looks one of the guys, but put him on the top deck of a bus and he blends right in. In the mayoral campaign, he wore the biscuity suit almost constantly, provoking questions as to whether it was one and the same suit, or one of a rack of identical suits. In a photo opportunity-obsessed world, the one-suit trick impressed with its disregard for the voracious appetites of the paparazzi. It also showed a winning lack of interest in fashion. (For the record, though, Ken definitely does have another suit: when the results of the election were announced, he wore a fetching newt-hued two-piece.)

The tyranny of appearance has such an iron grip on most of those in the public eye that to look careless, or clueless, in the style stakes gives the air of a true rebel. Simply by stuffing things in his pockets and ruining the line of his coat and suit, Ken marks himself out as a man of the people. Distrustful of makeovers, the public warm to the fact that, leaving aside the disappearance of the moustache, Ken's style has changed little over 20 years - the suit had a more rakish safari-meets-donkey-jacket air in the GLC days and the mac had a wider lapel, but the overall look is similar.

Then there's the scarf. Scarves have been out of fashion for men for years, but this is clearly of no interest to Ken. The scarf has particular connotations: it is this more than anything that gives him that indefinable Camden Town tapas bar, north London radical air.

Like Mick Jagger, Ken has an innate, unshakable air of devil-may-care scruffiness. The antithesis of Gwyneth Paltrow, who can't help looking groomed and shiny even in jeans, Ken could look careworn in Tom Ford's finest. One of the most intriguing things about That Suit is the fact that I'm not entirely convinced it is a suit - the jacket never quite seems to match the trousers. There is a certain sagginess about Ken's wardrobe that makes the scruffiness endearing rather than threatening; and the unflattering pale, sludgy colours he favours lend his complexion an air of bloodlessness. In contrast to the stage-managed slickness of most politicians, Ken's look is defiantly human: witness the glasses he wore when his victory was announced. Triumphant in a drawn-out, vicious battle he might be, but he was also vulnerable enough to be too tired and red-eyed for contact lenses.

This week, during the run-up to the official commencement of his term on Monday, Ken wore full morning dress to attend a black-tie event at the Guildhall celebrating the Queen Mother's 100th birthday, despite having ignored the dress code at another black-tie affair the previous week, at which he turned up in a normal suit. No-frills man of the people he might be, but snubbing the Queen Mum was a stop too far on the Clapham omnibus.

As from next week, such sartorial headaches are likely to be the least of Ken's concerns, of course: in fact, he might find it easier to bypass the issue by adopting traditional mayoral garb, complete with white stockings and gold chain. It's not very likely, though: something tells me the Ken look is here to stay.

Ken's image is all about there being no image, no spin, no styling, a powerful political message that can hardly be entirely unconscious. The man-in-the-street's clichéd complaint of "politicians, they're all the same" is sidestepped by Ken's trademark mac-clad shuffle. Look at almost any photograph of a politician, cover the face and they are indistinguishable, unrecognisable. Ken, however, is undeniably, immediately Ken, from the slightly scuffed toes of his shoes to his woolly red scarf. The keynote Ken outfit comprises a comfy-looking suit the colour of Rich Tea biscuits and an oversized, flappy beige raincoat, with that red woollen scarf tucked sensibly under its lapels. It is a look that gives him both individuality and familiarity - among politicians, he never quite looks one of the guys, but put him on the top deck of a bus and he blends right in. In the mayoral campaign, he wore the biscuity suit almost constantly, provoking questions as to whether it was one and the same suit, or one of a rack of identical suits. In a photo opportunity-obsessed world, the one-suit trick impressed with its disregard for the voracious appetites of the paparazzi. It also showed a winning lack of interest in fashion. (For the record, though, Ken definitely does have another suit: when the results of the election were announced, he wore a fetching newt-hued two-piece.) The tyranny of appearance has such an iron grip on most of those in the public eye that to look careless, or clueless, in the style stakes gives the air of a true rebel. Simply by stuffing things in his pockets and ruining the line of his coat and suit, Ken marks himself out as a man of the people. Distrustful of makeovers, the public warm to the fact that, leaving aside the disappearance of the moustache, Ken's style has changed little over 20 years - the suit had a more rakish safari-meets-donkey-jacket air in the GLC days and the mac had a wider lapel, but the overall look is similar. Then there's the scarf. Scarves have been out of fashion for men for years, but this is clearly of no interest to Ken. The scarf has particular connotations: it is this more than anything that gives him that indefinable Camden Town tapas bar, north London radical air. Like Mick Jagger, Ken has an innate, unshakable air of devil-may-care scruffiness. The antithesis of Gwyneth Paltrow, who can't help looking groomed and shiny even in jeans, Ken could look careworn in Tom Ford's finest. One of the most intriguing things about That Suit is the fact that I'm not entirely convinced it is a suit - the jacket never quite seems to match the trousers. There is a certain sagginess about Ken's wardrobe that makes the scruffiness endearing rather than threatening; and the unflattering pale, sludgy colours he favours lend his complexion an air of bloodlessness. In contrast to the stage-managed slickness of most politicians, Ken's look is defiantly human: witness the glasses he wore when his victory was announced. Triumphant in a drawn-out, vicious battle he might be, but he was also vulnerable enough to be too tired and red-eyed for contact lenses. This week, during the run-up to the official commencement of his term on Monday, Ken wore full morning dress to attend a black-tie event at the Guildhall celebrating the Queen Mother's 100th birthday, despite having ignored the dress code at another black-tie affair the previous week, at which he turned up in a normal suit. No-frills man of the people he might be, but snubbing the Queen Mum was a stop too far on the Clapham omnibus. As from next week, such sartorial headaches are likely to be the least of Ken's concerns, of course: in fact, he might find it easier to bypass the issue by adopting traditional mayoral garb, complete with white stockings and gold chain. It's not very likely, though: something tells me the Ken look is here to stay.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  designer denim
fields.trailText: Designer denim has been around since Mr Klein slipped a pair on Brooke Shields in 1978, but of late fashion has become obsessed with it. Alexander McQueen is responsible for young fashionistas ditching their Earls as they clamour to become the first to wear his coveted McQueens, launched last week. The range includes hipsters, bumsters, all-in-ones, bombers and corsets in indigo, stonewash and pleat-effect denim, from £95.
fields.body:
Designer denim has been around since Mr Klein slipped a pair on Brooke Shields in 1978, but of late fashion has become obsessed with it. Alexander McQueen is responsible for young fashionistas ditching their Earls as they clamour to become the first to wear his coveted McQueens, launched last week. The range includes hipsters, bumsters, all-in-ones, bombers and corsets in indigo, stonewash and pleat-effect denim, from £95.

All very cool but don't expect perfect edges - they're ripped, frayed and torn in all the right places. Those who prefer a clean cut should go for the 2 Jeans range by New York designer Katayone Adeli who, after realising some of her designs were a little too exclusive (up to £3,000), has priced her new jeans range at a more purse-pleasing £80-plus. As Adeli's trousers are famed for their perfect fit, we'll be waiting with bated breath for their launch at Selfridges in September.

Finally, for those who don't balk at spending £415 on a pair of jeans, try Balenciaga. Designer Nicholas Ghesquiere has created a pair of must-haves called Le Dix (available in Harvey Nichols) and is appealing to fashion insiders and stars alike with snug-cut, low-waisted jeans in four colours. Chloë Sevigny (whose judgment we trust) is rumoured to love them. And you thought denim was nothing special.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  visors
fields.trailText: More St Tropez than centre court, visors are currently making as many appearances off-court as on. Once favoured by bumbag-wearing tourists and over-sunned seventysomethings with an unhealthy appetite for towelling tracksuits, the visor is having a fashion moment with Palm Beach leisurewear the very pinnacle of chic. Gucci and Louis Vuitton lead the sport-luxe pack with heavily monogrammed visors, while milliner Stephen Jones has versions in transparent electric blue and Kangol and Stussy provide reasonably priced canvas versions.

webTitle: Ryan splits from Quaid amid Crowe rumours

fields.headline: Ryan splits from Quaid amid Crowe rumours
fields.trailText: Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid have announced they are separating after nearly 10 years of marriage
fields.body:
Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid have announced they are separating after nearly 10 years of marriage.

Their publicist, Lisa Kasteler, declined to say whether the two plan to divorce, but revealed that the separation began about six weeks ago.

Ryan, 38, who began filming the kidnap thriller Proof of Life in May, endeared herself to American movie audiences with such romantic comedies as When Harry Met Sally, Sleepless in Seattle, and You've Got Mail. Quaid, 46, starred most recently in the sci-fi time travelling tale Frequency and is known for his roles in Breaking Away, The Big Easy and Wyatt Earp.

The two met in 1987 on the set of Innerspace. They married in 1991 and have an 8-year-old son.

Meanwhile, the British tabloids are in a fever of speculation that Russell Crowe, with whom Ryan is currently filming Proof of Life in London, is 'helping' Ryan get through this difficult time.

Today's Sun quotes a friend, who says that Crowe gave Ryan "a shoulder to cry on", adding "Meg and Russell are extremely close and incredibly fond of each other."

fields.headline: Locking them up
fields.standfirst:
More public money is squandered, more chance of reform thrown away - and all to pander to Sun readers
Crime: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: More public money is squandered, more chance of reform thrown away - and all to pander to Sun readers
fields.body:
Spin is fine and dandy when the Guardian is given a nice advance story about how the government is going to save threatened post offices and create a new Universal bank. We were pleased and it was probably our turn. Yesterday, however, it was the Sun's turn. Downing Street decided to make the day of some Murdoch dirty raincoat. His story was branded "Exclusive" and headlined "Jail more yobs". Alongside a picture of the PM looking grimly manful, the piece read thus: "Tough-talking Tony Blair is to declare war on thugs - and order judges to lock up thousands more violent criminals. Mr Blair believes the courts are too soft on muggers and other street yobs - and is determined to see more of them behind bars. New figures show there are 4,000 "vacancies" in Britain's jails which the prime minister thinks should be filled with convicted thugs and hooligans. He will issue the "get tough" order during a special Downing Street crime summit on Monday."

Downing Street got two for the price of one. Turn to page six in the Sun and there is a robust denunciation of a disgraceful CBS television report claiming that Britain is a more a dangerous place than the US (if you don't count murder and rape). The point about spin is that whoever gets the tip is duty-bound to speak well of their exclusive announcement. The Sun has not been noticeably kind to prime minister or government of late so the planting of a tasty "tough on crime" story was a good hit - a fine example of the spin-master's art.

Not so. From day to day Downing Street manages the news with tips and sops, securing good publicity even in the most hostile organs. But where's the big picture? Where's the strategy? What are the core values this government wishes to project to the people? There is no coherent story to tell us who they really are and what they really stand for. Zig-zagging about, they haven't even got a plot to lose. They may imagine they can keep any number of plates up there on sticks but they can't. Spin a lot of loutish know-nothing nonsense to the forces of conservatism in the Sun and down crashes the Guardian plate. So here it comes.

Where are Blair's 4,000 prison "vacancies"? There are no empty cells dangling "to let" signs, with en suite facilities. Prisons are full to bursting with 65,000 inmates, up from 45,000 a few years ago. Prison numbers are now Jack Straw's virility symbol. He boasts in a letter to the Telegraph that it was "ludicrous" of them to suggest he was "soft on crime" since he had locked up 4,500 extra since the election. Overcrowding means 12,000 prisoners are crammed two to a cell built for one, eating their meals in a tiny room with an open communal toilet. Blair's extra 4,000 will all be doubled up, making 20,000 overcrowded prisoners with no work or treatment. Due to lack of staff and facilities the prison service this year failed to hit its already low target for giving prisoners time spent purposefully - on learning, training, drug therapy, anger management or work. Despite research showing how much good treatment can do, purposeful time hasn't improved in a decade. In Holloway prisoners spent only 10.2 hours a week on useful activity, Brixton had just over an hour a day.

Due to overcrowding, 11,000 prisoners are being kept more than 100 miles from home with no chance of family visits, one of the key ingredients that make reoffending less likely. Despite evidence showing intensive that treatments work and many work best in the community on tagging orders, 24 new prisons have been opened. It costs £16,000 a year to send a boy to Eton but £25,500 to send someone to prison for what Douglas Hurd this week denounced as "an expensive way of making bad people worse".

Yesterday prison governors expressed their shock at the prime minister's words, fearing the pre-election year would herald more and worse. Mike Newell, governor of Durham, president of the Prison Governors' Association denied there was any spare capacity. "I've got 874 prisoners this morning, 560 doubled up, half with no work, not nearly enough education or workshops for them all. Despite too many prisoners and too little money, we were beginning to get a better strategy. I'm very, very disappointed."

National crime figures are out shortly, hence the flurry of agitation. They will show burglary and car theft down, but violent crime up again, by somewhere in the low teens. Reported crime figures are notoriously unreliable, depending on many variables. There's been a push to encourage more reporting of street robbery, up by an alarming 36% in London. A third of that, though, was schoolchildren robbing other schoolchildren, often grabbing each other's mobile phones with menaces. This is horrible, frightening bullying - I know a boy who's been shaken down twice this year in Lambeth, once reported, once not. But the figures don't distinguish between that and some drugged mugger sticking a knife in an old lady's face to steal her pension money. Homicide (always reported) is a good indicator of other violence (not always reported): London has five times less murder than New York, four times less than Amsterdam. Violence increases in good times when people have more money to spend on drink, while property crime gets worse when unemployment rises.

But when it comes to politics, forget evidence, forget what works. Blair demands tougher sentences - and he will get them. The Home Office research department has a graph showing how judges adapt their sentencing habits to the prevailing political mood. Sentencing leapt up after Howard's "prison works" speech. Now it will happen again despite all the evidence showing criminals know little about the tariffs for their crimes: length of sentence doesn't deter them, but their estimate of the risk of being caught does. What does it matter? All that matters is what works in the Sun.

Downing Street's focus groups show crime now tops the list of popular concerns, overtaking the NHS which has dominated the agenda for so long: the new mega-money for the NHS seems to have made an impression. But one problem only makes way for another. Fear of crime is the real enemy, says Number 10. If so, the politicians are reaping their own whirlwind. Every time they hurl thunder bolts they miss the chance to explain what works and calm irrational fears. Every time they call for more prisons, they squander public money without reducing crime or fear. So the prime minister is holding this "summit" on Monday. He is calling in five big-city chief constables to "discuss" the already announced £20m for street crime. It will last about an hour, maybe there'll be a photo opportunity. In reality it will be another of those events whose only airy substance is in the reporting of it. All this is an example of short-term spin creating disgraceful policy, while only confusing further whatever it is they really stand for.

fields.headline: Carried away by clamour
fields.standfirst:
Facts are a better guide than focus groups
Crime: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tough-talking Tony is to tell judges to lock up more yobs. Or at least, that is what the Sun reported yesterday. The prime minister is to issue his "get tough" order at a Downing Street crime summit on Monday. Unnamed government officials were reported to be placing the blame for the rise in crime on lenient sentencers. The Sun, which usually takes a great interest in defending British sovereignty, fails to note that even under our unwritten constitution prime ministers are not allowed to instruct judges on their sentencing decisions. Indeed, Monday's crime summit is not for judges, but for chief constables.
fields.body:
Tough-talking Tony is to tell judges to lock up more yobs. Or at least, that is what the Sun reported yesterday. The prime minister is to issue his "get tough" order at a Downing Street crime summit on Monday. Unnamed government officials were reported to be placing the blame for the rise in crime on lenient sentencers. The Sun, which usually takes a great interest in defending British sovereignty, fails to note that even under our unwritten constitution prime ministers are not allowed to instruct judges on their sentencing decisions. Indeed, Monday's crime summit is not for judges, but for chief constables.

That said, ministers are clearly worried by an unfortunate concatenation of events: it began in January with the first rise in officially recorded crime in six years, followed by a firmer rise in May; later the same month, Gallup showed the Tories edging ahead of Labour in dealing with law and order; party focus groups relayed the same message; then came this month's resurrection of British football hooliganism; and finally this week's report suggesting the UK has become a more criminal society than the US.

Time to untangle these elements. The rise in crime was predictable. Indeed, it was predicted in our Society section 10 months ago by Chris Nuttall, the former head of research at the Home Office, not because of "soft" judges or "soft" ministers, but something more prosaic: the growth of the group which contains most criminals, young men aged between 16 and 25. Ministers will have been told about these projections and would have been wiser to have prepared the public. An opportunistic opposition banging away on simplistic law 'n'order themes was bound to rally the tabloids and gain in the polls. The rise in violent crime is worrying; but, the incidence of violent offences has risen in eight of the last 10 years. This is no sudden reverse. And the highest rise has been in robberies due to the theft of mobile phones, one-third of which were committed by schoolchildren against other schoolchildren. No one should condone such crimes, but they should not be confused with armed robberies.

The most important challenge facing ministers is to resist knee-jerk reactions. They have an intelligently devised, evidence-based crime-reduction strategy and should stick with it. Its key target areas have shown surprising results: domestic burglaries down by 20% since 1997 to the lowest level for 10 years; vehicle crime cut by 15%. It is time now to target robberies. The police services with the highest increases are already reordering their priorities. No one is suggesting violent offenders should not be sent to prison. Some sentences may have been too lenient, but most of these have been referred to the court of appeal.

The danger is not that the criminal justice system will ignore public concerns, but that it will react too readily. Judges cannot be instructed by ministers, but history has shown that sentencing policy is influenced by the climate which politicians create. Labour must resist the populist cause. There are spaces in the prison system, but only if inmates are doubled up in cells. It was a former Tory home secretary, Lord Hurd, who urged his own party last month to stop treating prisons like political dustbins. It was one of his Tory successors who described prisons as "an expensive way of making bad people worse". The US has little to teach us - this week's report is using outdated data - but it has demonstrated the folly of believing that "prison works". It locks away 2m people but still has four times as many murders.

fields.headline: Whittling Waterhouse
fields.standfirst:
Half-measures will not tackle child abuse
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care
fields.trailText: Fudge rules. The government has declined to endorse the whole of the Waterhouse package designed to combat child abuse. Wales is to get its independent children's commissioner - indeed, a more powerful commissioner than campaigners expected - but England is only promised a national children's rights officer, who will be in, not outside, the system. That is less complacent than it may seem. England has introduced a succession of initiatives since 1997 involving stricter inspection, tougher monitoring, local children's rights officers and helplines. There has been a big investment, £375m over three years, to ensure local action plans are introduced. And yet the words of Alison Taylor, the original Welsh whistleblower who was not believed, should haunt those who devised yesterday's response: "Child abuse is part of the spectrum of human behaviour that has occurred throughout history. It is not going to disappear."
fields.body:
Fudge rules. The government has declined to endorse the whole of the Waterhouse package designed to combat child abuse. Wales is to get its independent children's commissioner - indeed, a more powerful commissioner than campaigners expected - but England is only promised a national children's rights officer, who will be in, not outside, the system. That is less complacent than it may seem. England has introduced a succession of initiatives since 1997 involving stricter inspection, tougher monitoring, local children's rights officers and helplines. There has been a big investment, £375m over three years, to ensure local action plans are introduced. And yet the words of Alison Taylor, the original Welsh whistleblower who was not believed, should haunt those who devised yesterday's response: "Child abuse is part of the spectrum of human behaviour that has occurred throughout history. It is not going to disappear."

English campaigners had hoped for something better than this. They wanted eight regional children's rights directors, to whom children could have direct access. Instead they are offered one national children's rights officer, who will have direct access to the secretary of state, but who by definition will occupy a much more remote position than a regional director. Worse still, the rights officer's remit is confined to children in care. Yet child abuse is not restricted to the 56,000 "looked-after" children. It happens in all manner of homes and settings. That is another reason why the Waterhouse proposal for an independent children's complaints officer in every council should be included in the current care standards bill.

The North Wales Abuse Survivors organisation too was unhappy with the package. It still wants a national inquiry into child abuse. Yet that is unnecessary. Enough has been spent on inquiries. What we need to invest in is protection. The Waterhouse inquiry cost £13.5m compared to a mere £5m set aside initially for "Children First", the new childcare strategy for the principality. But one genuine grievance for the survivors is the government's response on compensation. We robbed them of their childhood, but still refuse to compensate them. Ministers, local councils and insurance companies are all indulging in pass the parcel. Let them look at Quebec, where the state government in a comparable situation accepted full responsibility.

webTitle: David Copeland: a quiet introvert, obsessed with Hitler and bombs

fields.headline: David Copeland: a quiet introvert, obsessed with Hitler and bombs
fields.standfirst: Nick Hopkins and Sarah Hall examine the events leading to the capture of London nail bomber David Copeland, who was today found guilty of the murders of Andrea Dykes, John Light and Nik Moore
fields.trailText: Nick Hopkins and Sarah Hall examine the events leading to the capture of London nail bomber David Copeland, who was today found guilty of the murders of Andrea Dykes, John Light and Nik Moore
fields.body:
David Copeland's terrifying campaign ended on a quiet night in a Hampshire town as the dead and maimed were still being counted from the wreckage of the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho.

Officers from Scotland Yard's Flying Squad knocked on the door of a house in Sunnybank Road, Cove. Copeland opened the front door, rubbed his eyes and mumbled: "Yeah, they were all down to me. I did them on my own."

Any doubts the officers had disappeared when Copeland led them to his bedroom. Two red-and-black Nazi flags were hanging on a wall, alongside a macabre collage of photos and newspaper stories. The theme was bomb blasts.

Copeland was eager to give detectives a graphic account of how he had made and planted the three devices. But there was one issue he could not explain. Why?

He was born in Isleworth on May 15, 1976. Described as introverted but not aggressive by his classmates, Copeland studied at Yateley comprehensive and passed seven GSCEs. After leaving school at 16, Copeland drifted into a few jobs, experimented with drink and drugs and had a few minor brushes with the police.

After his arrest, Copeland claimed he had been having sadistic dreams from the age of 12. He had thought about killing his classmates and had wanted to be reincarnated as an SS officer. In May 1997, he joined the British National Party. A year later, Copeland joined the National Socialist Movement. In 1998, he was prescribed anti-depressants and told his GP he was "losing his mind." Nobody doubts Copeland was suffering from some form of mental illness, but the severity of the condition was contested.

Five psychiatrists concluded he had been a paranoid schizophrenic for several years. But this was challenged by prosecutors, who were under pressure not to concede to his pleas of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

Another consultant psychiatrist concluded that Copeland did have a personality disorder but it was not serious enough for him to avoid a murder charge.

With a primed bomb taped to the inside of a sports bag, Copeland had taken a taxi to Brixton on Saturday, April 17, 1999. He left the bag on the corner of Electric Avenue. It was spotted by nearby street traders, who wondered if it was a bomb.

Just as the police arrived at 5.25pm, the device exploded. Fifty people were injured.

Detectives began scanning CCTV coverage of Brixton. The following Saturday, a second explosion took place, this time in east London.

Copeland had left a bomb in a Head holdall in Hanbury Street but it was spotted by a member of the public who called the police. "He was dialling 999 from when the device went off," said a source. Thirteen people were injured.

Four days later, police identified a man in Brixton who had been carrying a Head sports bag. The CCTV images were given to the media on Thursday.

Copeland decided to bring forward his next attack by a day. The Admiral Duncan pub was full when walked in. He left at 6.05pm and heard the explosion as he walked back to his hotel. Three people died and four needed amputations. Twenty-six people suffered serious burns, another 53 were injured.

Eighty minutes before the bomb went off, Paul Mifsud rang a police hotline to say a work colleague resembled the man caught on camera.

By 9pm, officers had Copeland's and by midnight, they were planning a raid on his house.

fields.headline: Overseas aid
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, submits our wish list to a reality check and seeks to reconcile one departmental demand with another
fields.trailText: The provision of additional money is of course subject to other demands, but the aim of putting the spend up to the United Nations target (and promising to keep it there thereafter) must be right. The other specific pledges proposed are not all within the power of one government - for instance reform of the IMF - but should certainly be launched.
fields.body:
The provision of additional money is of course subject to other demands, but the aim of putting the spend up to the United Nations target (and promising to keep it there thereafter) must be right. The other specific pledges proposed are not all within the power of one government - for instance reform of the IMF - but should certainly be launched.

However, the manifesto misses out, or at least underplays, three important dimensions. First, the microdimension of ensuring value for money in how budgets are spent; a sensitive matter especially for receiving governments. But there are greater inequalities of wealth and living standards within poor countries than within rich ones, so money has to be properly targeted to make a real difference to the people it is intended for. This needs more than good intentions. The manifesto should promise more attention to the ultimate application of the funds.

Second, the manifesto should take a wider view about the role of international aid and the sharing of wealth, one way or another, and what this country can do to mobilise the whole international community. A determined effort to take a long-term global view of the various issues, and of the parts the various participants can play, should be promised.

This should include not just the reform of the IMF, and determined efforts to make international, commercial and industrial concerns more accountable. There needs to be more coherence between separate national and international programmes and the prima donnas who run them. There is currently substantial overlap and misdirection of resources, to say nothing of excess of administrative costs. Only if the wealthy countries put their shoulder to this will anything useful happen.

Finally, coherence is required at home as well. Tensions between aid and other objectives - foreign policy, trade and defence - exist, inevitably and rightly. There must be closer and better linkages between all those involved. What is needed is a more inclusive and more transparent piece of machinery.

fields.headline: Health
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, subjects our health manifesto to a reality check
fields.trailText: The manifesto has to address tightly the value   obtained from the £40bn per annum, or thereabouts, being spent, plus whatever more is going to be provided. It is crucial to recognise that merely throwing money at the system is not of itself going to engender quality or confidence.
fields.body:
The manifesto has to address tightly the value obtained from the £40bn per annum, or thereabouts, being spent, plus whatever more is going to be provided. It is crucial to recognise that merely throwing money at the system is not of itself going to engender quality or confidence.

Is health care to be localised or centralised? There is a lot to be said for localisation and some experiments here should be promised. Such a step would integrate local authority social services more closely with health services.

Centralisation, on the other hand could be made to work, if it were broad enough (and included local authority services). The manifesto should give a pointer here. Either way patient-driven better management, specified in some detail, must be promised. The role of the private sector needs clarifying. The NHS should stay free at the point of service, of course, funded by the state, but what is the public/private mix to be at the provider end?

Public health and better living must be split off from care of the sick. The manifesto should promise a "department of the individual" dealing with healthy living, food safety, some aspects of environmental concern, and appropriate other aspects of daily living. This is not just a matter for some outpost of the cabinet office; it deserves a cabinet minister in its own right.

More money should be found for residential care and the like. But there is more to the well elderly than that and there's a very wide range of needs that this particular group has, including a pensions regime. The manifesto should discuss what these needs are and how they can be met.

fields.headline: Education
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, submits our wish list on education to a reality check
fields.trailText: Reducing maximum class sizes requires fresh teachers and more buildings. The same goes for free nursery places. But good teachers take time to recruit and train and good buildings take time to put up. A precisely-timed credible programme is needed, probably involving the private sector.
fields.body:
Reducing maximum class sizes requires fresh teachers and more buildings. The same goes for free nursery places. But good teachers take time to recruit and train and good buildings take time to put up. A precisely-timed credible programme is needed, probably involving the private sector.

Certainly the manifesto should promise to carry on supporting Ofsted, league tables and performance-related pay. But all these, in their various ways, need review. Ofsted needs to be made more accountable, league tables need to be more about added value, and the performance-pay scheme should be buttressed by credible criteria and appropriate support for teachers engaged in supernumerary activity.

The manifesto should grasp the nettle of higher education, but not at the risk of harming excellence. It should study the availability of top-class places, the access to them for people from the state sector, especially poorer ones; the system of grant maintenance; and the role of the private sector.

Finally, there are three big issues the manifesto must study. First, the use of the private sector - yes if it is right and appropriate. Second, central control versus LEAs - go for the LEAs as long as they can deliver. And third the updating of the curriculum to meet IT and the demands of the 21st century.

fields.headline: Crime and disorder
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, submits our wish list to a reality check and seeks to reconcile one departmental demand with another
fields.trailText: A programme based on a reduction of offences (and not just car-related offences) is desirable and attractive. But it is not new and to make it credible, the manifesto needs to detail what is proposed, coupled with the cost of each initiative, its impact on the public and its acceptability, and if possible its effectiveness. "Populist policies" are not necessarily wrong.  The manifesto should pick out separate elements in the current auction.
fields.body:
A programme based on a reduction of offences (and not just car-related offences) is desirable and attractive. But it is not new and to make it credible, the manifesto needs to detail what is proposed, coupled with the cost of each initiative, its impact on the public and its acceptability, and if possible its effectiveness. "Populist policies" are not necessarily wrong. The manifesto should pick out separate elements in the current auction.

The whole area involves not just long-term thinking, but also a very wide range of different agencies. The manifesto must say how it will pull together the efforts of all the different agencies.

More "bobbies on the beat", supplementing the use of constables with police-approved community patrol officers, and the regulation of the private security industry are fine. But their effectiveness needs to be sharply reviewed.

To continue to criminalise soft drugs, but alleviate the penalties looks like a halfway house, and seem unlikely to be either effective or acceptable. Many people would have trouble with the idea that judges should explain publicly their reasons for passing particular sentences and, in practice, a better way forward is likely to be an improved system of appeals.

On prisons, certainly the government should promise more, but cost constraints may tell. There is no reason why the government should not let the public sector bid to run all new prisons.

So far as asylum seekers go, clearly more effective liaison between agencies, here and abroad, is needed. Merging the commission for racial equality with the equal opportunities commission raises the question of whether the disabilities and grievances suffered by women and various minority groups - ethnic minorities, gays and so on - are sufficiently similar for a single commission to command acceptance, and whether "one size suits all" is appropriate.

Merging the commission for racial equality with the equal opportunities commission raises the question of whether the disabilities and grievances suffered by women and various minority groups - ethnic minorities, gays and so on - are sufficiently similar for a single commission to command acceptance, and whether "one size suits all" is appropriate.

fields.headline: Britain's place in the world
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin and veteran of both the Treasury and the cabinet office, is submitting our Guardian wish lists to a reality check and seeking to reconcile one departmental demand with another
fields.trailText: Many people will sign up to the ideas set out. Many others, however, will find them reminiscent of those Labour manifestos of the 1980s which did so much to keep Labour out of government. People who believe in "punching above our weight" and "flying the flag" aren't likely to be convinced by this prospectus.
fields.body:
Many people will sign up to the ideas set out. Many others, however, will find them reminiscent of those Labour manifestos of the 1980s which did so much to keep Labour out of government. People who believe in "punching above our weight" and "flying the flag" aren't likely to be convinced by this prospectus.

Ethical policies are obviously right and proper but they don't seem to have worked so far. They need to be spelt out more clearly. A move towards total nuclear disarmament, however desirable, or indeed the abolition of NATO, won't get far if people feel that it leaves this country powerless and/or second rate. More debate will be needed on both fronts.

People still believe in America. A big effort to shift our centre of gravity towards Europe, whether in terms of defence or in terms of adoption of the euro, will attract supporters, but it is unlikely to be a big vote-winner or greatly successful. The argument for abandoning America needs to be much more clearly spelt out in social, economic, and military terms.

Reform of the United Nations is necessary not just in its formal, political and voting sense, but also much more basically, by way of sheer competence and efficiency. Look at the recent shambles in Sierra Leone. If Britain is to move from the United States to the United Nations, the United Nations should be worthy of the move.

On trade, in every case, a balance has to be struck. Against the same need for a balance, a lead should be looked for in environmental affairs.

Finally, our "window on the world", the Foreign Office, needs revamping. There is room for a "department of Europe", which increasingly would be a home department, separate from a department for wider foreign affairs and interests. Such an expansive department should provide a wider coherent view of British aims and interests.

webTitle: PM proposes spot fines for hooligans

fields.headline: PM proposes spot fines for hooligans
fields.trailText: Prime Minister Tony Blair is pushing for on-the-spot £100 fines for drunken louts causing  misery in town centres.
fields.body:
Prime Minister Tony Blair is pushing for on-the-spot £100 fines for drunken louts causing misery in town centres.

But the proposal got only a guarded welcome from police, who would impose the fines, and was dismissed by the Tories as "just another headline-grabbing gimmick".

Mr Blair said drunken anti-social behaviour caused "offence and misery in too many towns and cities on too many Friday and Saturday nights".

"A thug might think twice about kicking your gate, throwing traffic cones around your street, or hurling abuse into the night sky if he thought he might get picked up by the police, taken to a cashpoint and asked to pay an on-the-spot fine of, for example, £100," the Prime Minister said in a speech to the Global Ethics Foundation in Tubingen, Germany.

"If the police want that power - and I believe they will, and the public will support it - they should get that power," he added. Mr Blair said he would suggest the idea at a crime summit in Downing Street on Monday, where he is to meet senior police officers.

The Police Federation, representing rank and file officers, said the fines might be welcome "in principle" but a spokesman added: "The proposals would have to be carefully considered in the light of the European Convention on Human Rights."

The Association of Chief Police Officers also gave a guarded response to the plans. "We share the Prime Minister's concerns that loutish behaviour should be firmly dealt with," an ACPO spokesman said. "His idea of on-the-spot fines for minor offences is an imaginative one to which we would wish to give further thought on how it could work in practice at a street level."

But shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe was scornful, saying: "With police numbers slashed by more than 2,300 and police chiefs concerned about the crisis on our streets, this is just another headline-grabbing gimmick. "If the police cannot police the streets now, how will they be able to enforce these fines effectively?"

She continued: "How much more bureaucracy and paperwork will be created, diverting the police from catching serious criminals? In announcing these fines, Tony Blair is admitting that Labour's flagship policies have failed to stem the rising tide of violence and disorder."

Barrister and civil rights campaigner Michael Mansfield QC said he was "very concerned" at the idea.

In a radio interview he said: "What you are actually asking the police force to do is to monitor social behaviour - it is Orwellian in its concept. What is going to constitute anti-social behaviour? How is a bobby on the beat going to weigh up whether it's one traffic cone or two traffic cones ... the whole thing is a nonsense."

But Mr Blair told his audience: "Bizarrely, as the law stands, the police have the power in Britain to levy on-the-spot fines for cycling on pavements and dog fouling. And yet they have to deal with drunks who get offensive and loutish and often can do nothing about it without a long, expensive process through the police station, the courts and beyond.

"It is perfectly legal for a private company to put a clamp on a car wheel and demand £100 to get it released, yet no comparable power exists for our public police force. I believe that should change."

The Prime Minister's official spokesman later said that the idea of on-the-spot fines had been developed with the Home Office and was in its early stages.

fields.headline: You bet your life
fields.standfirst: One man down, three left standing. Who will triumph as our gambling game reaches its climax?
fields.trailText: It's the last day of betting. Sean Ingle pocketed a mammoth £160 yesterday when Italy triumphed on penalties. This comes a day after Scott Murray picked up £280. If you matched all our tipsters pound for pound, you'd be £376.47 up. So if you've missed out there's one last chance.
fields.body:
It's the last day of betting. Sean Ingle pocketed a mammoth £160 yesterday when Italy triumphed on penalties. This comes a day after Scott Murray picked up £280. If you matched all our tipsters pound for pound, you'd be £376.47 up. So if you've missed out there's one last chance.

Totals so far:
Scott Murray £346.42
Sean Ingle £220.97
Mike Hodgkinson £7.08
Paul MacInnes RIP

Scott Murray

France to win in 90 minutes 11/10 (£46.42)

Despite showing what they can do against superior opposition, the Italians still haven't impressed me enough for me to bet on their upsetting the form book again. So I'm going for the conservative bet over the conservative tactical approach - France will cruise home in the manner of their World Cup victory to bring Euro 2000 to a sleepy end.

And even if this doesn't come off I'll have increased my initial purse six-fold - which is over six times better than nothing.

Sean Ingle

France to win 2-0 8/1 (£23)

Yesterday I surveyed my gambling surroundings, and saw that above me - way above me - stood the imposing figure of Scott Murray on an equally-imposing £396. It was time to close my eyes and launch the betting equivalent of an American Football style 'Hail Mary'. Incredibly, it worked - the Azzuri beat de Oranje on penalties and suddenly I was back in the game. But now I've got to do it again.

Normally I would have a safe punt on France to win, because all logic says that Italy will be tired both physically and emotionally, while Roger Lemerre's men are not only the better side, but have had an extra day to recover. But because I'm still £120 behind I'm forced to trust in Lady Luck again. It could easily be 1-0, 2-0 or 2-1, but after much contemplation I'm going for France to win 2-0. Let's just hope it comes off.

Mike Hodgkinson

Double: Emmanuel Petit first goal-scorer and France to win 2-1 100-1 (£7.08)

This is not, as you may suspect, the last throw of the dice for a desperate, broke and weeping man. It's the final piece in a carefully hatched, er, jigsaw which will deliver me the top tipster crown in style. Scott Murray, you think it's all over but it's not, my friend. You can sit on your vast pile of money, all rich and everything, but tell me this. Is it better to have bet and won than to have bet and lost? Is it?!

Be lucky.
