fields.headline: A love-hate thing
fields.trailText: Here are ten reasons, in no particular order, why I hate my job:
fields.body:
Here are ten reasons, in no particular order, why I hate my job:

1. I work non-stop for at least eight hours a day, five days a week.
2. It's utterly exhausting.
3. I can't do my job with a hangover.
4. Bumping into kids in the supermarket, especially on a Saturday or Sunday morning.
5. Dealing with rude, arrogant people who think they're the most important person on earth (I blame the parents).
6. Teachers are consistently undermined and undervalued by the government, whichever one is in charge.
7. When at work, I'm constantly (and I mean constantly) on show.
8. It sometimes gets hard to remember who the real me is - 'Miss' or 'Emily'.
9. I don't get paid enough.
10. Constantly having to talk at people who don't want to listen and really couldn't care less what I have to say.

Now here are ten reasons why I love my job:

1. Seeing people do a new and wonderful experiment for the first time - from lighting a bunsen burner in Year 7 to making slime with 12EP to studying the colours of transition metal ions in Year 12.
2. You can never (and I mean never) predict what's going to happen next.
3. People are fascinating. Think about it. The ways students interact with each other and with me are just so interesting.
4. Those moments when you know everyone in a room is listening to you and really concentrating on what you're saying. That's an amazing feeling. A real ego trip. It makes you stop still inside and wonder if you can really be that interesting.
5. Hard work pays off. You put in the effort, you get rewards (mostly).
6. Those other moments when you teach someone a new concept and they understand it and they're pleased.
7. Other moments when you feel, for one reason or another, that you've touched someone's life personally.
8. Talking a student out of a major strop. You start in a position of almost no hope - a student goes mad, shouting and swearing, threatening to hit someone and you get them sitting down, calm, smiling and maybe even apologising. That's an incredible feeling. It feels like talking a potential suicide down from the window ledge.
9. It can be hilarious. Surreal events happen everyday. Students start singing suddenly. They get into the cupboard. They have a cussing match. They ask you a bizarre question ('What does DD mean in bra sizes?'; 'Were you a hippy at school?'; 'Can you swim?'; 'Why do they make flavoured condoms?') out of the blue.
10. Moments when you feel really connected with someone. They laugh with you. They tell you something about themselves. They ask you about yourself. Suddenly it doesn't feel like a teacher-student thing but like a friendship. It's an insight into someone's mind.

You might be able to tell from all that just how strongly I feel about teaching. What I'm doing is the most fulfilling, exciting, exhilarating, remarkable job in the world.

So I thought I should use my CD-Rom entry to explain why I like it so much and to answer the question I get asked more than any other (apart from 'will you marry me?' of course). That question is - why did I give it all up to become a teacher? 'It all', for those who don't know, is an apparently amazing career in research where I would undoubtedly earn pots of money and discover a cure for cancer. But I didn't enjoy research. And I love teaching. Yes, it's hard, yes it's frustrating, difficult, challenging, tiring. It's the most difficult thing I've ever done.

But every day brings at least one small thing that makes me smile. Today it was Patrick and Ben being able to predict the formation of a new bond in a reaction. It was also having a deeply serious conversation with a stressed out member of my tutor group. I told her to have the day off (sorry, Mr Frawley) and enjoy herself and she was so relieved. That made me smile. It was also listening to Nick, Nathan and Toby's questions at Science Club. They were so interested, so keen to learn new things and understand the world. It was laughing with Ollie about him falling down the stairs and then having a quick gossip about his lovelife. It was explaining a huge chemical calculation to Sakkra and him understanding it. It was giggling in the Science office with the other teachers at lunchtime. It was being praised by Mr Frawley about my fantastic tutoring skills (doesn't happen very often!) and then being praised by Mr Hicks about a stroppy letter I'd written. It was hearing Maria giggle, watching Loskie draw, talking to Hannah about her singing, Daniel about football, Charlene about nursing, Katie about universities, Grant about his fractured wrist, Tom about his work, Adam about wormholes

I could go on and on about the good things. Lately there's also been Stephen reading in assembly, Alex deciding to do a chemistry degree, Rowland and his milky bar button obsession, Nathan and his lateslips, Amira being on time three whole days in a row, Aimee and Tammy laughing, Louise still being at Elliott, Parviz sulking when he's told off (yes that makes me laugh), Alan catching up with all the Chemistry he missed, Stacey having a fit about what I wrote in the newsletter, Mauri asking me if I was OK, finding out that Alex Perriam actually likes chemistry (you could have fooled me)

I hope you get the idea. Those are just a sample of the things that have happened with some of the sixth form in the last few weeks. I'm sorry if I've missed anyone out. It was just the first few good things of many that came into my head. I could go on for pages with positive things but you'd get bored eventually (if you're not already).

I never dreamed that I'd end up being a teacher. But I'm so incredibly pleased I am. What I wanted to get across in this was an idea of what it feels like to be a teacher and a tutor. I love my job, and, I'm afraid it's going to sound really corny, but the most important thing in it all is you lot, the students. You're what make it such a great job. You're enthusiastic, hardworking, motivated, helpful, generous, funny, and all round wonderful (most of the time). Well done! Now make me proud and make sure you live up to your potential. I'm sure you will.

fields.headline: Negativity good, hyperbole bad
fields.trailText: Imagine if 10-man England had held on for almost 90 minutes against the tournament favourites before eventually prevailing in a penalty shoot out. Their effort would have been a source of national pride, another shining example of the indefatigable English spirit in the face of adversity.
fields.body:
Imagine if 10-man England had held on for almost 90 minutes against the tournament favourites before eventually prevailing in a penalty shoot out. Their effort would have been a source of national pride, another shining example of the indefatigable English spirit in the face of adversity.

But Italy, well that's a different story. Their presence in the final is deemed an insult to the preceding three weeks of joyous, uninhibited football - England's efforts excepted of course. A tournament that has given much pleasure has finally found someone to perform the role of the bad guys. "The masters of negativity," lamented the master of hyperbole Bob Wilson.

The BBC panel were indignant, in particular Alan Hansen who either had Holland in the office sweepstake or has undergone a personality transformation of Norman Bates proportions in the last three weeks. Whatever happened to the merits of good defending Alan? Can you imagine his response if Scotland had achieved such a result? On second thoughts, let's avoid the realms of fantasy, shall we?

And how Martin O'Neill (the man who elevated playing for penalties to an art form) could keep a straight face when all this was going on, only he knows.

Barry Davies (inevitably) took exception to the Italian tactics but Davies is old school; in fact I suspect when he was at school football was in its infancy, a game played by oiks and those too effete for the rugger team.

As the game entered extra-time, Davies asked "From whence cometh the winner?" It was a reprise of his commentary from the Euro 96 semi-final between Germany and England which won him the gold medal in that year's Archaic Ye Olde English Awards.

I don't know why he bothered to ask because by that stage we all knew the match was going to penalties and that Holland were utterly inept from 12 yards out. A fact later confirmed when Jaap Stam's moon-bound effort landed in neighbouring Luxembourg.

While one has a modicum of sympathy for the Dutch, one also has a sneaky admiration for the way in which Italy played yesterday. If nothing else, a few more performances like that and football will soon rid itself some of some of the part-timers for whom football is the new drum 'n' bass and catenaccio is a drink on the menu at Starbucks.

Going back to the previous night, When Athletes Attack was a laugh. It was preceded by a specially-commissioned Euro 2000 version of the show, in which the referee and his linesman come under a barrage of verbal and physical abuse from a gang of swarthy desperadoes. That's Portugal to you and me.

fields.headline: Something fishy
fields.standfirst: Jaws takes to the high street, holey heists, medicinal mirth and a spot of flash dancing
fields.trailText: A shark in the middle of a British high street? Impossible!
fields.body:
Lone shark

Off the coast of Australia, yes. In the Pacific, the Atlantic, even the Mediterranean - all perfectly feasible. But a shark in the middle of a British high street - impossible!

Or at least such was the received wisdom until this week, when one made its presence felt in the middle of Ampthill. The first sign of trouble came when local shopkeeper Carol Shaw, 53, noticed an unsavoury stench wafting around outside her premises.

"It was a horrible, fishy smell," she recalled. "And it kept coming into the shop whenever the door was opened." Other residents noticed the odour too, which appeared to be emanating from an eight-foot long, board-covered electricity trench in the middle of the street.The council were duly called, and some workmen sent down to investigate.

"They took the boards off the trench and one of them got down into it," said one local man. "When he told us there was a shark in there we just didn't believe him." A shark it was, however - a small one, admittedly, and dead, but with razor-sharp teeth nonetheless.

How it arrived in Ampthill no-one is quite sure, although the most likely explanation is that it was dumped in the hole as a practical joke.

"There's no need for people to panic," assured one oceanographic expert. "Shark attacks are extremely rare even in tropical waters. In the middle of Bedfordshire they're practically unheard of."
Luton and Dunstable Herald and Post

Rush hour brakedown

A slow, unhurried place at the best of times, York has of late become even slower and more unhurried as a result of an extensive programme of summer roadworks which have effectively paralysed the entire city.

The roadworks, which began this week and involve the resurfacing of a series of major arterial routes, has turned the city into one enormous gridlock, especially at rush hour, when a journey of only a few hundred yards can, apparently, take anything up to an hour to complete.

"It's a nightmare," fumed one local motorist. "The other day I tried to drive down to the supermarket for some sponge cake and spent most of the afternoon sitting in a traffic jam. I've had an upset tummy since I got back from Corfu so you can imagine the state my car was in when I finally got home."

The situation has been exacerbated by a series of recently-installed traffic-calming measures which have meant that even when they do finally get moving drivers are still faced with an assault course of humps and width-restricters before they can finally get on their way.

"There are some short term difficulties," admitted a council spokesman, "But we are doing our very best to tackle them."

But one local pensioner sighed: "Even on an empty road my wife creeps along like she's in a traffic jam, so to be honest none of this has really made any difference to us."
The York Evening Press

A hole lot of trouble

Road problems of a different sort in the Midlands town of Sandwell, which is currently suffering from an epidemic of drain-cover thefts.

Over the past few weeks more than forty drain-covers have gone missing from the roads and pavements around the town, at a cost of almost £10,000 to the local council.

"This is a major problem," said local councillor Keith Davies. "Louts are stealing the covers and leaving holes that someone could fall down in the dark and break a leg. It's a highly dangerous thing to do and could cost lives."

The problem has been made worse by the fact that the covers are of a style that is no longer made, and the drains therefore have to be redrilled to accommodate new-style caps.

Fortunately to date there have been no serious injuries as a result of the disappearing manhole lids, although one man did suffer nasty scratches after swerving to avoid an open hole and falling into a display of ornamental cacti outside a local florists.

"Somebody's stolen all the loo paper from the public toilets as well," fumed one lifelong Sandwell resident. "This town isn't what it used to be."
The West Midlands Express and Star

A chuckle a day...

Hilarious goings on in Cheltenham this week with the opening of Britain's first official therapeutic Laughter Club.

The club is the brainchild of Indian Doctor Madan Kataria, who believes that regular bouts of laughing can both relieve stress and ward off a host of illnesses such as heart and lung disease. "Laughing can really improve our health," explained doctor Kataria, 44. "The only reason people do not laugh more is because they are naturally shy, and so I try to help them release that shyness."

To this end he has developed a series of group exercises designed to make people burst into spontaneous laughter, a technique that has lead to the opening of over 500 Laughter Clubs around the world.

Eleven people attended his first British session, paying £400 each for the pleasure of three-days unbridled chuckling. "It was wonderful," said one woman. "I came out feeling like a new person. It really worked."

Not everyone, however, is as convinced by Dr. Kataria's methods. "It's just a fad," said one local doctor, "Like all this aromatherapy rubbish. If you really want to guard against disease what you need is a good night's sleep and a yoghurt enema once a week."
Gloucestershire Echo

Letter of the Week

Last night I met some dear friends at the Casa Loco restaurant in Rugby, where we had an excellent meal. I then drove home down the Leicester Road and into Newton Lane, where I discovered six completely naked men dancing in the road.

I was rather surprised since the night air was extremely chilled, although I concluded that they were certainly not intending to commit a robbery since they didn't have a pocket between them.

I can only imagine that they were following the Road Safety Code: "Wear something that sticks out at night". I congratulate them on their achievement, though for my part a reflective jacket is a preferred alternative.
A Surprised Resident
Catthorpe Village
The Rugby Advertiser

fields.headline: A touch of Ducasse
fields.standfirst: This man has six Michelin stars. Many foodies consider him to be one of the finest chefs the world has ever seen. So why do the first New Yorkers to try his new American restaurant say it's 'only OK'?  Michael Ellison reports
fields.trailText: This man has six Michelin stars. Many foodies consider him to be one of the finest chefs the world has ever seen. So why do the first New Yorkers to try his new American restaurant say it's 'only OK'?
fields.body:
It is said that a gourmand could eat in a different New York City restaurant every night of the week and not make his way round the lot for nearly 48 years. Others, of a more dismal disposition, say that you would be dead before the task had been completed.

Either way, the Alain Ducasse should not be high on the list of those to visit first: not because his reputation might put you off - quite the reverse; not, perhaps, because this is the most expensive restaurant in town - Ducasse says that quality comes at a price; not even because the name might be difficult to recall.

No, the real reason to forget about it for a while is because there is an eight-and-a-half month waiting list for a seat at his table: that takes us up to next March.

New York has 17,000 restaurants but only one with a prix fixe menu set at $160 (£110), and that's the place on Central Park South that bears the name of the temperamental, bespectacled Frenchman with the high forehead. The $160 is only the start of it, of course. By the time you have added wine ($45), coffee ($5), tax ($20) and a decent tip ($42, or 20%), that comes out not far short of $500 for two.

And this is without investigating the most choice items on the wine list, such as the 1990 Petrus Bordeaux for $2,400 (£1,700) or the 1982 Chateau Lafite Rothschild at $1,100 (£775). For that bare $160 on the opening night there was, as a starter, what the menu called "a cocktail of tastes: sweet, salty, tart, bitter". Or tomatoes.

Next came Maine lobster medallion wrapped in a delicate pasta with a lightly spiced bouillon; sole filets au naturel simmered in Oregon morels; and squab pigeon breast and pastilla of thighs with glazed turnips and jus made from the bones. Those in attendance included Jocelyne Wildenstein, the socialite with the startling, surgery-induced facial features, and the television morning show anchor, Katie Couric.

The name of the restaurant is picked out in discreet lettering on the outside of the hotel, screened by blinds from the eyes of passers-by. Behind its heavy doors are renovations costing $1.5m, special stools where women may rest their handbags, jugs by Baccarat, china by Christian Le Page and, to sign for the bill, pens by Cartier, Tiffany, Mont Blanc and Gucci.

Wafting imperceptably among the 65 diners granted entry for each sitting are 55 waiters. Were this not enough, the air of exclusivity is maintained by the restricted hours: the place is open only five nights and two lunchtimes a week.

If the prices are unreasonably high, you will certainly not get Londoner Keith McNally, proprietor of the trendy downtown restaurants Balthazar and Pastis, to say so. "It's someone else's restaurant. They can do what they want."

New York has seen nothing like it for 18 months. That was when the new Daniel (Boulud) opened on the Upper East Side with what seems in retrospect to be a carelessly brief one-month waiting list. It cost $10m to set up and here, in Manhattan's most expensive tailor-made restaurant, it is possible to escape for $125. "In New York you see monuments of exellence and innovation and Daniel epitomises that," says the three-star Michelin chef, Michel Guerard. And before Daniel, the buzz was all about Le Cirque 2000.

The reviews are not yet in on Alain Ducasse: the city's professional eaters take their craft much too seriously to hasten to judgment on such a matter. But the reputation of the man who gives his name to the establishment is secure, as one might expect of the planet's only six-star Michelin chef (three for his Paris eaterie, three for Monte Carlo).

"He is one of the finest chefs and restaurateurs the world has ever seen," says the restaurant consultant, Clark Wolf, who has just launched the new Tribeca Grand's Church Lounge. "The fact that he saw the need to have a restaurant in New York I think is brilliant. New York has always liked French restaurants. Whether there are too many is a matter of personal opinion at least as long as Alan Greenspan [interest-rate-setting chairman of the Federal Reserve] says nothing."

When two or three are gathered for dinner in Manhattan, the conversation is as likely to be about the last restaurant they ate in as it is to refer to the latest movies. The Zagat's restaurant guide is displayed prominently in every bookshop; restaurant reviews are a staple of New York 1, the local 24-hour television news channel; the chef Emeril is mobbed by the studio audience when he comes out to fire-up the oven on the Food Network; the actor Richard Dreyfuss is said to have added his name to the list of those awaiting the return of $170-a-shot Kobe steaks at the Old Homestead.

Just over a year ago The New York Times food critic, Ruth Reichel, quit to take over as editor of Gourmet magazine. The speculation about the runners and riders to succeed her was unmatched. And lest anyone should doubt that the food business is a matter of life and death, a recent issue of the Village Voice carried a restaurant column that was actually about the demise of the writer's mother. "I realised that I'd lost not only my mother but my favourite dining partner," she wrote. "Sushi defeated her after a nibble and okra remained a lifelong challenge."

The pokiness of most Manhattan apartments contradicts any suspicion that this obsession with eating out is simply sheer self-indulgence, though most of Ducasse's clientele is likely to come from better-appointed quarters.

What they get on their plates is the product of a life that started on a goose, duck and vegetable farm in the Landes region of south-western France. Ducasse, who is 44, started work at 16 and by 1990 his Le Louis XV at the Hotel de Paris in Monaco had the coveted three Michelin stars. Seven years later he was awarded the other three for the Alain Ducasse in Le Parc-Westin Demeure Hotels, Paris.

Now he is not so much a chef as a culinary industry. Since last November he has opened a training centre for hoteliers and restaurateurs and, apart from New York, restaurants in Mauritius and London. Another launches in Tokyo next month. There is a series of cookbooks and a product line called Objet: Saveurs selling cutlery, cooking utensils and ovens.

"The important factor is the best quality for the best price," says M Ducasse. "But first of all is the quality and obviously you have to apply the price to the quality."

And what sort of quality do you get at the Manhattan restaurant? "So far, it's not all right," says Wolf, the consultant. "I've spoken to five people who have been at early previews and it's not perfect. The word is that it's only OK. You're supposed to do that for the plumber and the electrician." Ah well, perhaps everything will be fine by March.

Superchef: the rise and rise of Alain Ducasse

* Alain Ducasse was born in 1956 in the Landes in south-west France. His parents grew vegetables and kept the chickens, ducks and geese for which the region is famous.

* He started work in 1972 aged 16 at the Pavillon Landais in Sisteron. After a short period there his progress has been meteoric.

* In 1987 he took over as executive chef of Le Louis XV at the Hotel de Paris in Monaco. In 1990 the restaurant won the coveted three stars from Michelin, the first hotel restaurant ever to do so. At 33, it made him France's youngest three-star chef.

* Then, when his eponymous restaurant at the Hotel le Parc in Paris was also awarded three stars in 1998, he became the only chef in history to hold six Michelin stars at one time.

* His interests are not restricted to the rarified and extremely expensive realms of haute cuisine. He owns a country inn in Provence as well as a clutch of concept eateries: bar et boeuf (sea bass and beef) in Monte Carlo, Spoon, Food and Wine in Paris, and Spoon in London.

* The only one to escape from a 1984 plane crash in which five died, Ducasse knows about survival.

Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15
Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes
Cheat's kitchen
On the menu: parfait
Food on the net

fields.body:
Telephone: 020-7498 4651

Address: Sand, 156 Clapham Park Road, London SW4.

All very now, posed - er, poised - somewhere between the urban cool of Brixton and the upmarket style of Clapham Old Town. Striking interior design vies for attention with miniature TV screens showing classic movies. Full English or continental breakfasts for less than £5 per head and a fine dining menu featuring sushi, risotto, scallops and John Dory at £10 to £15 per head. Add to that demon Bloody Marys, wicked Bellinis and sundry cocktails mixed by hip yet charming staff and you get a seriously smart establishment. The downside? Its 2am licence means queues are par for the course. Booking for dinner is essential.

Telephone: 020-7627 0222
Address: Gastro, 67 Venn Street, London SW4.
No nonsense. No fuss. No frills. Gastro is a trad French eaterie opposite Clapham Picture House. Proper, unmucked about moules marinière, and lots of them; oysters in abundance; serious saucisses, terrines, ptés, etc. Slip in for a pre-movie quick bite at the instant-classic zinc-topped bar. Or lurch in after a searing movie experience and chill out at one of the rackety wooden tables over andouillettes (grilled chitterlings sausage for the uninitiated) and frites, sweet French black pudding and frites and grilled lobster (and frites). It's all a bit French, but, it's got style and purpose, like their football players.

Cheat's kitchen

Strawberry cream meringues

4 M&S meringue nests

500g strawberries

100ml whipping or double cream

2 tsp caster sugar

1 . Put strawberries into food processor with sugar. Blitz for about 15 secs until roughly chopped.

2 . Whip cream until really stiff. Fold in half of the chopped strawberries.

3 . Blob half the cream/strawberry mixture between halves of meringues and place on plate.

4 . Dollop the rest of the mixture over and around the meringue, and arrange remaining chopped stawberries at artistic intervals around the plate.
Ms L Castle, London

If you have any hints for Cheat's kitchen, send them to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

On the menu: parfait

How do you pronounce that?

"Parfay" as in "it's a parfay day".

Oh, very funny. Well, what is it?

A rich, frozen pudding made, usually, of something and cream and eggs.

Ice cream, you mean?

Don't be so coarse. A parfait is to ice cream what pté de foie gras is to meat paste.

So it's a bit refined, you mean.

And a bit more delicate, too. Chefs love a bit of parfait - nougat is very popular at the moment, although you may also have noticed prune chocolate and Armagnac, and raspberry.

Still sounds like ice cream to me.

Come to think of it, you do get a chicken liver parfait, too.

That isn't ice cream.

Nobody's parfait.

Food on the net

www.foodoo.com

An unusual one, this, set up as a forum dedicated to food as a pleasure. So there's nothing to buy, and not much to plug. It wants to be a site where chefs and other food lovers swap tips, recipes and thoughts.

Pros: Hosting pages for a number of big names - including Gordon Ramsay, Gary Rhodes and John Torode - foodoo can offer a range of impressive recipes, plus the musings of the professionals on food trends.

Cons: A risk of becoming a sounding board for chefs? Antony Worrall Thompson's exhortations to show some national pride in the Dome seem out of place here.

Coming soon: Extensive food glossary and a searchable recipe database.

webTitle: Harry Potter's magic fails to work in Canterbury

fields.headline: Harry Potter's magic fails to work in Canterbury
fields.trailText: The authorities at Canterbury cathedral have refused Warner Bros permission to use the cathedral - one of England's most beautiful and sacred monuments - in the first Harry Potter film
fields.body:
The authorities at Canterbury cathedral have refused Warner Bros permission to use the cathedral - one of England's most beautiful and sacred monuments - in the first Harry Potter film.

Warner Bros apparently offered a substantial amount of money in return for turning the Christian place of worship into the wizard school Hogwart's for Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. But the cathedral authorities were concerned by the story's "pagan" theme, with which they did not want the cathedral associated, and turned the studio down.

Undeterred, Warner Bros has announced that it is planning to release one Harry Potter film a year for the next seven years. Although there are as yet only three published novels in the series, with a fourth due next week, JK Rowling has said that she is planning seven Potter stories - one for every year her creation is learning his craft at Hogwarts.

webTitle: Battle over online rights no tea party

fields.headline: Battle over online rights no tea party
fields.standfirst: Former US correspondent Mark Tran on the second Boston Tea Party which sees freelance journalists pitted against the Boston Globe
fields.trailText: Former US correspondent Mark Tran on the second Boston Tea Party which sees freelance journalists pitted against the Boston Globe.
fields.body:
Freelancers for the Boston Globe newspaper face a stark choice. Unless they sign a controversial new contract by July 1 giving the US regional paper the right to reproduce their past and future work online, without any additional payment, they will not receive any more assignments.

The dispute pits the liberal-leaning Globe, owned by the powerful New York Times company, against some 750 freelancers who work for the paper. On June 12, freelance writers, photographers and illustrators filed suit against the Globe seeking to block what they called an unfair contract.

The paper, the largest in the New England area, insists that the agreement, which allows contributors to retain their copyright, is fairer than others in the newspaper industry.

In justifying the retroactive nature of the agreement, Richard Gulla, spokesman for the Globe told Guardian Unlimited: "We have already paid for that story, what we give freelancers is exposure in the paper and online."

This second Boston Tea Party is being watched closely by publishers and journalists in America and the outcome is likely to be used as a model elsewhere in the US and possibly abroad. The dispute comes at a time when "content is king" is a maxim in the internet explosion.

As outlets proliferate, companies need to fill their sites with material, but the issue of copyright in the internet age is proving to be a vexing issue for media companies. For the Globe, this deal with freelancers represents an attempt to keep up with the internet's enormous impact on the way information is distributed.

Boston.com is the fastest-growing site in the New York Times Digital stable. In the first quarter of 2000, its revenues in a category that includes "licence fees and database royalties" were up 11.5%, through the sale of material to database companies such as Lexis-Nexis.

The company is already licensing editorial and visual content on the internet. For $400, a third party can trail a Globe story on its own site for three months, provided that it links to the full text of the story on Boston.com. In addition, the Globe provides content to Merlin-net.com, a commercial photo archive and it recently agreed to provide material for Captivate Network, a supplier of internet content for lifts in hotels and offices.

The Times Company, which earned nearly $43m in online "fees and royalties" in the first three months of the year, is embroiled in a copyright battle of its own.

On April 6, a federal appeals court sided with Jonathan Tasini in his case against the Times. It upheld a 1999 decision that found the Times in violation of copyright law every time it reprints freelance work electronically without obtaining permission to do so. The paper has filed a motion to have the case to be heard in the Supreme Court.

The battle at the Globe began on April 5, when it sent a letter to its regular freelancers asking them to sign a contract posted on the Globe's web site. It offered freelancers the right to resell their work to other publications with one or two days delay. In exchange the paper claimed the right to market its past and future archive of freelancers' work in any conceivable electronic media, now and forever, for no additional fee.

On Monday, the freelance journalists suffered a setback when a Massachusetts state judge denied a request for an injunction that would block the Globe from enforcing its new contract on July 1. Judge Carol Ball said the journalists might have a legal case, but that an injunction would be inappropriate.

"The plaintiffs here, artists all, believe with a honest and compelling conviction that they have been wronged by the cold, cruel realities of the e-commerce business world," Judge Ball said. "It is not clear however, that the business practice at issue violates the law. The plaintiffs may ultimately have a remedy at law, but the issuance of emergency injunctive relief would be inappropriate."

After the decision, Debra Cash, a dance critic and cofounder of the Boston Globe Freelancers Association (BGFA) sent out an email to cheer up her fellow freelancers, saying that the ruling was based largely on technical grounds.

"The bad news is that the judge has not granted our request for an injunction," she wrote. "It is important to understand that this is not because our case is not strong, or because we do not have a good chance of winning."

Cash, who has denounced the Globe's proposed contract as a "rights grab", says she and her colleagues are not Luddites, but friends of the internet. She hopes the Globe will negotiate a new contract that distributes potential internet revenues more fairly. But if the Globe and its owner, the Times, try to "make this a test case, they can throw the tea into the harbour. They're not going to make a precedent of me", she said.

She claimed that many editors and other people on the Globe are sympathetic to the freelancers' position, and are hoping for a solution so they will not be forced to put out a paper without people they have relied on for years. She argued that one of the most "dangerous" things about the contract is that once somebody signs, the signature cannot be retracted.

"After that point, the Globe has resale rights to everything you have ever contributed to the paper, in all media, without compensation to you, for the full length of copyright - that is for 70 years after your death".

Useful links
Boston Globe

webTitle: An unrepentant Kohl goes on the offensive

fields.headline: An unrepentant Kohl goes on the offensive
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Helmut Kohl, the fallen giant of German politics, went on to the counter-attack yesterday. Making a long-awaited appearance before the parliamentary commission of inquiry which is looking into whether his government traded favours for illegal party donations, he insisted he was the victim of a systematic campaign to discredit him.
fields.body:
Helmut Kohl, the fallen giant of German politics, went on to the counter-attack yesterday. Making a long-awaited appearance before the parliamentary commission of inquiry which is looking into whether his government traded favours for illegal party donations, he insisted he was the victim of a systematic campaign to discredit him.

To him, the far-reaching scandal was not about his point-blank refusal to comply with a law which his own cabinet had introduced, its authors' aim was to "wipe out from history 16 successful years".

In a frequently ill-tempered appearance before the press during a break in the proceedings, Mr Kohl turned on the media, describing the journalists on two of Germany's leading publications as "idiots".

The former chancellor singled out a documentary by the state-funded ARD television channel as a prime example of the media campaign against him; it reported that his party had received DM30m (£9.6m) - claims Mr Kohl dismissed out of hand.

When a reporter addressed him as "Herr Kohl", he angrily corrected him, insisting that he be addressed as "Herr Doktor Kohl".

His opening statement to the commission was a rambling affair that lasted an hour and a quarter. Mr Kohl huffed and puffed - but failed to shake the growing edifice of evidence stacked up against him. The latest massive slab was lowered into place on Wednesday when an investigator reported that two-thirds of the data in the former chancellor's office had been erased in the days before he left power.

But Mr Kohl indignantly dismissed the suspicion underlying the inquiry. "Never in my entire life could I be bought," he said.

The former chancellor and his party officials hid from public and official scrutiny the source of millions of pounds they received, despite introducing a law during Mr Kohl's 16-year chancellorship which required the disclosure of all contributions exceeding £6,400, precisely in order to deter bribery.

Mr Kohl has admitted to personally receiving up to £640,000 between 1993 and his departure from office in 1998.

As he highlighted yesterday, it was a small amount in the context of the Christian Democratic Union's (CDU) overall funding - 2% of what the party received during that five-year period.

The only donation of which anything is known was made by an intermediary in an arms deal which had required - and been given - cabinet approval. More vehemently than ever, Mr Kohl yesterday refused to divulge the names of his other benefactors.

With a sublime indifference to the requirements of the law, the former chancellor explained that he had taken the money in cash because the donors wanted to remain anonymous and would not have contributed otherwise.

He has said that they were CDU sympathisers who wanted to support the party's work in the formerly communist East Germany following reunification.

Mr Kohl's uncompromising stance exasperated even members of his own party, which is still suffering from the consequences of the scandal; one party MP, Friedbert Pflüger, called it "unacceptable".

A member of the commission of inquiry who belongs to the former communist Party of Democratic Socialism, meanwhile, called for the former chancellor to be sent to jail.

Evelyn Kenzler said Dr Kohl should be "put into coercive detention until such time as he is willing to give the names".

fields.headline: Hostel blaze suspect charged
fields.trailText: An Australian drifter suspected of starting the blaze at a hostel that killed 15 backpackers has been charged with attempted murder - but the charges relate to the struggle during his arrest.
fields.body:
An Australian drifter suspected of starting the blaze at a hostel that killed 15 backpackers has been charged with attempted murder - but the charges relate to the struggle during his arrest.

Robert Long, 37, was charged with attempted murder and unlawful wounding at a bedside hearing in Maryborough Hospital, where he is being treated for a gunshot wound sustained during his arrest.

Long was the target of a nationwide manhunt after witnesses said they saw him near the Palace Backpackers Hostel in Childers, 195 miles north of Brisbane, shortly before fire engulfed the building.

Six backpackers from Britain, four from Australia, two from the Netherlands and one each from Ireland, South Korea and Japan died in the blaze.

It is not clear if police have interviewed Long in connection with the blaze.

Blackburn manager Graeme Souness has had his £2m bid for Middlesbrough striker Brian Deane turned down, reports the Sun.

They also report that Bradford keeper Matt Clark is set is to sign for Newcastle in a shock £1.5m move.

webTitle: Patriotic Liverpool up in arms over Gibson's blockbuster

fields.headline: Patriotic Liverpool up in arms over Gibson's blockbuster
fields.trailText: Mel Gibson's summer blockbuster The Patriot is in trouble again, and this time the protests are coming from Liverpool city council
fields.body:
Mel Gibson's summer blockbuster The Patriot is in trouble with the historians again (see our news story earlier this month).

This time, it's an entire city that's up in arms: Liverpool city council yesterday demanded an apology from Hollywood, claiming that the film misrepresents a former leading civic figure from Liverpool, Banastre Tarleton, presenting him as a ruthless British butcher who revels in bloodshed and infanticide.

A statement from the city council said that in fact, when Tarleton returned to Liverpool in 1782 after legendary exploits in the American war of independence, the church bells rang out and he was feted by admirers. He went on to represent Liverpool in parliament for more than 20 years. Not that that can be any guarantee of integrity, even 300 years ago.

Liverpool's mayor, Edwin Clein, is demanding a public apology over Hollywood's depiction of Tarleton. He claims that: "The experts agree there is no real evidence to justify this character assassination of someone who has contributed so much to Liverpool's great history."

In the film, written by Robert Rodat and directed by Roland Emmerich, Gibson plays the part of Benjamin Martin, who takes up arms against the British after Redcoats burn down his home.

The issue of Hollywood producing its own version of history depicting American celluloid heroes carrying out acts of derring-do that were really the work of the British has already prompted protests here, most noticeably in the case of the recently released U-571, as we reported.

Gibson, however, is busy defending his violent movie (which opens today in the US) on other counts. This time, it's an entire city that's up in arms: Liverpool city council yesterday demanded an apology from Hollywood, claiming that the film misrepresents a former leading civic figure from Liverpool, Banastre Tarleton, presenting him as a ruthless British butcher who revels in bloodshed and infanticide. webTitle: How Big Brothers used Orwell to fight the cold war

fields.headline: How Big Brothers used Orwell to fight the cold war
fields.trailText: A 79-page FBI dossier released on George Orwell reveals how the British author of Animal Farm and 1984 was used by both the Americans and the Russians as a key figure in the battle for ideas for two decades after his death in 1950.
fields.body:
A 79-page FBI dossier released on George Orwell reveals how the British author of Animal Farm and 1984 was used by both the Americans and the Russians as a key figure in the battle for ideas for two decades after his death in 1950.

Even before 1984 was published in 1949, US publishers sought to exploit the novel as an attack on Soviet totalitarianism by seeking the endorsement of J Edgar Hoover, the FBI chief - ironically, he was later dubbed America's Big Brother.

A decade later the Soviets used Orwell as part of a smear campaign to tell the Russian people that his satire was based on real life in America where everybody was under survellience.

In the 1960s and 1970s the US security services monitored George Orwell societies and film clubs on US campuses to make sure they were not a cover for subversive pro-socialist behaviour. His name was even linked with "Americong", a terrorist group which bombed an officers' mess at an air force base in Denver, Colorado, in 1972 in protest at the war in Vietnam.

Details of the file have been released under the US freedom of information act but 11 pages remain under wraps. FBI reports about the author have been heavily censored, even though some were delivered three years after Orwell's death.

The file, opened by Hoover himself, begins with a letter from Orwell's publishers in April 1949, saying: "We hope you might be interested in helping to call this book to the attention of the American pub lic - and thus, perhaps, helping to halt totalitarianism".

Eugene Reynal, the vice-president of the publishing firm Harcourt Brace, added: "1984 is an important book because it provides a picture of a plausible but frightening extension of present social and political trends. Orwell brings home to the reader in a story of mounting interest the horrors of a totalitarian world can and may bring to us within less than two generations."

He goes on: "The book leaves the reader with the shocked feeling that there is not single horrible feature in the world of 1984 that is not present, in embryo, today.

"It describes the process by which the last man in whom the spark of human spirit has not been totally suppressed, comes to believe, literally, that two plus two equals five."

The 1955 British-made animated version of Animal Farm thrilled the FBI, who declared that it had "hit the jackpot".

Hoover declined to endorse 1984 and he ordered files kept on the author - including book and film review cuttings. A heavily censored agent's report says that Orwell had originally been "sympathetic toward the communists but he later turned against them".

Ten years later the FBI was reporting on a " smear campaign" organised in East Berlin claiming that Orwell's satire was based on real life in America "where police survellience and investigation has surpassed the world and had no equals.

"Already today an American lives, so to speak, under a glass cover, and is viewed from all sides," said a report which was distributed across the communist world.

fields.headline: Dream final, schream final
fields.trailText: So what if Holland are out? So who wants the Dutch job? So why is Alec McGivan so angry?
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"These players are sportsmen" - France coach Roger Lemerre. Why do we bother?

THE EURO-TORIAL

So we didn't get Holland v France, the dream final the whole of Europe wanted. "Everyone will be disappointed," wailed Martin O'Neill as a dejected BBC panel whined collectively after last night's Dutch defeat. Well, please forgive us, Gary, Alan and Martin, but we didn't lose that much sleep last night.

You'll have no doubt heard over the past month that Euro 2000 really needed that dream final, that anything other than a meeting between the solid and occasionally spectacular world champions and the spectacular and occasionally solid co-hosts would have been a disaster. It was the conclusion every journalist currently claiming expenses in the lowlands seemed to reach, as well as more than a few fans. But why?

After all, every other "dream final" we've been encouraged to hope and pray for has been abject in the extreme. Remember nodding off during the 1994 World Cup final between Brazil and Italy? Or sliding down the sofa in the middle of the 1996 FA Cup final between Manchester United and Liverpool? God forbid the likes of the dour and unfancied Italians should gatecrash the party and upset the natural order.

But is an Italian presence at the denouement really so bad? The stars of the Frank De Boer circus troupe haven't exactly whipped up a creative storm during the tournament, save one blistering display against the self-destructing Yugoslavs. Italy's lacklustre performance could at least be blamed on the dismissal of the idiotic Gianluca Zambrotta - they won't be so negative in the final, no matter what an Oranje-obsessed media would have you believe.

Anyway, even if they are, would Holland have brought much more to the big event? Not on yesterday's evidence. So give the Italians a chance. If you're in a light coma by 8.30pm on Sunday night, don't take the easy option and blame the obvious fall guys: things might not have been much different anyway.

QUOTE-A-MISS-A-JOB

Scuff!

"I had one aim and that was to become European champion. I set my sights too high, we missed that chance and I will pay the consequences for the fact that we didn't achieve what we wanted to achieve" - Frank Rijkaard quits as manager of the Dutch national side minutes after his side's sorry defeat. He's rumoured to be heading for Milan

Shank!

"My only ambition is to be the coach of the Dutch national team. That is my only ambition in the game" - Louis van Gaal shamelessly throws his hat into the ring minutes after Rijkaard quits

Slap!

"Let things just float away for a while and then we'll see" - Ruud Gullit tries 'enigmatic' when asked whether he wants the vacant job

Stub!

"I am not available. To begin with you have to enjoy it, and I do not" - Johan Cruyff bucks the trend and makes damn sure of holding on to his dignity

Stam!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

You'll get a wider view of the Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com and click on the link on the left hand side. See how you score with fantasy share trading and you could win a 28" wide screen TV.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Alec McGivan, the leader of England's doomed World Cup bid, has attacked Sepp Blatter. Not with a hammer, calm down. He's had a good old rant after a leak of Fifa's technical report into the facilities of the five bidders suggested England were only in the second tier, behind Germany and South Africa.

McGiven said today: "It is one thing to praise those bids, and we accept that. But to suggest that England, after investing so much in the development of grounds, is not as ready as other two is amazing. We will take it up with Fifa."

He continued: "I find it quite incredible. We know the president of Fifa is backing South Africa, and that does not help. Here is a man overseeing the bidding process, and he is partial to one of the candidates."

Toys were then thrown out of the pram.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi folks, it's Paul Merson here. I'm here to give Karel, who's been going off the rails a bit recently, a bit of friendly advice by talking about myself at every opportunity. I find that usually helps. Now, do you want the rumours, or a seven-hour spiel about my deep-lying role at the Villa? OK, if that's the way you want it.

Nick Barmby has been placed on the transfer list after telling Everton boss Walter Smith he wants to play for Liverpool. Gerard Houllier will not meet Everton's £8m asking price, but may offer Titi Camara or David Thompson in part exchange, and I'm playing better than ever now I've got my head together.

Monaco have made a £15m bid for Chelsea striker Tore Andre Flo, and if you go to the hairdressers every day, soon enough you'll get a haircut.

Lazio have confirmed that Manchester United made a bid for Czech Republic midfielder Pavel Nedved. The offer, rumoured to be in the region of £30m, was turned down, and I'd like to take this opportunity to announce my international retirement.

Anyway, where's Kar... oh look, there's a mirror.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

Channel 4: Eurotika (12.40am)
Antoine de Caunes presents an alternative look at the sexiest goals of Euro 2000. During half-time Lolo Ferrari makes a special appearance on a lilo. At least that's what we think happens.

Eurosport: Euro 2000 Extra (5pm)
Does anyone regard another repeat of Norway v Slovenia as "extra"?

Euro 2000 Spirit (7pm)
Thought not... and I bet we're not talking single malt here either. Now where did we put Eurosport's telephone number?

fields.headline: Global struggle in rural France
fields.standfirst: More about globalisation and the World Trade Organisation
fields.trailText: The small southern French town of Millau (population 20,000) braced itself yesterday for the imminent arrival of up to 30,000 assorted ecologists, farmers and anti-capitalists who have promised to transform it, for the space of a weekend, into "Seattle-sur-Tarn".
fields.body:
The small southern French town of Millau (population 20,000) braced itself yesterday for the imminent arrival of up to 30,000 assorted ecologists, farmers and anti-capitalists who have promised to transform it, for the space of a weekend, into "Seattle-sur-Tarn".

After the violent clashes with the police which enlivened the world trade talks in the US city in November and the Davos world financial forum in January, the anti-globalisers plan a "festive protest happening" to mark today's trial of one of their unlikelier heroes, the veteran French activist and sheepfarmer José Bové.

"It's fantastic," said Mr Bové, who along with nine other members of his Peasant Confederation faces a five-year prison sentence for the symbolic and highly publicised trashing of a half-built McDonald's restaurant in Millau last August.

The ransacking, carried out under the benevolent eye of the local police, was a protest at the US decision to retaliate against a European ban on hormone-treated beef by doubling the import duties on a range of French products, including Roquefort, which Mr Bové produces on his smallholding in nearby Larzac.

"This is no longer a movement with one single idea, but lots of different movements that have united," he said. "The fight against malbouffe [junk or lousy food], multinationals and the ultra-liberal ways of the World Trade Organisation has now clearly become a planetary struggle."

The mayor of Millau has asked for 800 police officers. All the town's schools, as well as the now-notorious McDonald's, will be closed; the courthouse will be ringed by riot police; and the trial - due to start this afternoon, with a verdict on Saturday - will be relayed on outdoor screens.

Mr Bové's committee has organised a myriad events around the proceedings, hoping to turn the weekend into what one militant called a "21st century Woodstock".

Sixteen musical, theatre and circus groups will perform; African, Haitian and Salvadorean dishes will be served at dozens of "world food" stalls; cheeses and foie gras will be available at a farmers' market; and concerts are planned by the anti-racist band Noir Désir and the singer-songwriter and country-lover Francis Cabrel.

Distinguished speakers will lead 14 discussion forums on anti-globalisation and anti free-trade themes.

Determined to put globalisation in the dock in place of himself and his colleagues, Mr Bové has called 17 witnesses from small farmers' associations, economic institutes and union federations in America, Senegal, Honduras, Poland, the Philippines, India and France. He will be defended by six eminent lawyers, including Henri Leclerc, a former president of the League of Human Rights.

Experts are divided about the likely sentence: some expect a symbolic fine, others think the authorities will make an example of Mr Bové to head off further symbolic protests against multinationals.

Mr Bové says a jail sentence would surprise him. "The state would be making a big mistake, which could provoke an unexpected and dangerous situation."

Mr Bové's committee has organised a myriad events around the proceedings, hoping to turn the weekend into what one militant called a "21st century Woodstock". Sixteen musical, theatre and circus groups will perform; African, Haitian and Salvadorean dishes will be served at dozens of "world food" stalls; cheeses and foie gras will be available at a farmers' market; and concerts are planned by the anti-racist band Noir Désir and the singer-songwriter and country-lover Francis Cabrel. Distinguished speakers will lead 14 discussion forums on anti-globalisation and anti free-trade themes. Determined to put globalisation in the dock in place of himself and his colleagues, Mr Bové has called 17 witnesses from small farmers' associations, economic institutes and union federations in America, Senegal, Honduras, Poland, the Philippines, India and France. He will be defended by six eminent lawyers, including Henri Leclerc, a former president of the League of Human Rights. Experts are divided about the likely sentence: some expect a symbolic fine, others think the authorities will make an example of Mr Bové to head off further symbolic protests against multinationals. Mr Bové says a jail sentence would surprise him. "The state would be making a big mistake, which could provoke an unexpected and dangerous situation."

webTitle: Will Europe's mix 'n' match gamble work?

fields.headline: Will Europe's mix 'n' match gamble work?
fields.standfirst:
Politicians remain confident they can muddle along together despite different visions for the future. But hard choices are inevitable
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Monetary union and enlargement to the east have led to a renewed debate about the future of Europe. Visions of what Europe might look like 20 years from now - and what Britain's role in it will be - are coming thick and fast. Is it feasible for Europe to carry on as before with 25 members and a single currency? Is the answer full political integration, or a much looser arrangement that treats Europe as a free trade area but leaves most powers with national governments? Or something in between? All options can be catered for in the great game of fantasy politics.
fields.body:
Monetary union and enlargement to the east have led to a renewed debate about the future of Europe. Visions of what Europe might look like 20 years from now - and what Britain's role in it will be - are coming thick and fast. Is it feasible for Europe to carry on as before with 25 members and a single currency? Is the answer full political integration, or a much looser arrangement that treats Europe as a free trade area but leaves most powers with national governments? Or something in between? All options can be catered for in the great game of fantasy politics.

1: United States of Europe

Brussels would be the capital, Strasbourg the home of the parliament, London the financial capital. A European army under a single command structure would protect the borders and the European social model would keep the world's biggest market safe from cut-throat American-style capitalism. This is the Europe of full political integration, the option that allows the continent to rise above the petty squabbles of national governments and to punch its full weight on the world stage.

Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, is the most prominent European politician to have floated the idea of full political union, but the idea of "ever-closer union" goes back to the days when Jean Monnet and other founding fathers were putting together their blueprint in the aftermath of the second world war.

The arguments for a "European superstate" vary. For some, it is simply a question of efficiency.

At the moment, Europe is a halfway house - it has one interest rate and one exchange rate, but a host of different tax rates and no effective mechanism for redistribution.

Some of its members get involved in conflicts like that in Kosovo, but co-ordination is difficult with each capital making decisions on involvement and deployment of troops. Moreover, expansion to the east means that the current institutional framework, with national vetos in many areas of policy, will ossify.

Another group uses these arguments to cloak a visceral anti-Americanism. Since the end of the cold war, the United States has been the world's sole superpower, but Europe could fill the vacuum left by the collapse of communism. However, until it recognises that globalisation is increasingly making the medium-sized nation state obsolete, Europe will continue to dance to Washington's tune.

The chances of a superstate arriving any time soon are remote. Why? First, there are immense practical difficulties in putting together a nation out of so many disparate traditions, culture, languages, histories and economies. Poland does not have much in common with Portugal, for example. Second, many of those countries likely to join the EU in the near future have recent - and bitter - experience of de facto political union with the Soviet Union and are enjoying independent status.

Finally, European politicians show very little willingness to forego national advantage in favour of what most of them see as a utopian vision. As the wrangling over who should be the first president of the European Central Bank showed, national squabbling is likely to go on for some time to come. Politicians love squabbling. It's what they do best.

2: The special relationship

After rejecting the single currency in a referendum and following several more years of increasing isolation, Britain cuts its ties with the European Union and applies for membership of Nafta, the North American free trade agreement. Some supporters of ever closer links between the English speaking nations take the fantasy one stage further and envisage the UK as the 51st and most powerful state of the union. We have the Hollywood movies, we have the burgers, we have the shopping malls, so why not go the whole hog and have the political clout that being a state more populous and richer than California would bring?

In some ways, this scenario is the mirror image of the European superstate. Again, there is a logic to it. Britain signed up for a free trade agreement when it joined the then European Economic Community in 1973. It didn't sign up for monetary union (something explicitly ruled out by the Yes campaign in the 1975 referendum), let alone political union.

The British public will not buy the idea of "ever closer union" and while Britain would prefer to remain a member of the EU, voters would rather leave than be part of a superstate. Membership of the World Trade Organisation would give Britain many of the benefits it presently enjoys by being a part of the European Union, and it would gain even more by becoming part of Nafta, because the US has been far more successful in creating jobs than Europe.

John Redwood, sacked from the shadow cabinet by William Hague, and Conrad Black, proprietor of the Daily and Sunday Telegraphs, have floated membership of Nafta as an option, and it is also being investigated by Republicans in Congress. According to Mr Black, the White House front runner, George W Bush, is also interested.

As with full political integration, this does not seem a realistic short-term possibility. Labour and the Liberal Democrats believe the idea is barmy, and Mr Hague would be branded as a dangerous isolationist if he even hinted that Conservative opposition to the single currency was hardening into a call for withdrawal from the EU. The Americans can envisage a North Atlantic free trade agreement, but see this as involving the whole of the EU, not just Britain.

3: Europe of nation states

The Dutch stay Dutch, the French stay French, and the British stay British, but they all learn to rub along together and welcome more and more countries into the club. This is the Euro 2000 option, where every country retains its own distinct national identity, its own flag, and its own football team but within an over-arching structure that deepens and broadens Europe.

It is in the interests of Europe to co-op erate in some areas - the single market, the environment - but this will not stop national governments from seeking to shape the future of Europe in ways that benefit their own voters.

The realities of the modern world mean that power will be shared between Europe-wide institutions such as the European Central Bank. Instead of there being some federalist blueprint for a superstate in safes in Berlin, Brussels and Paris, the process will continue to be confused.

Almost every EU minister would sign up to this vision of Europe, at least in public. Given both the lack of public support in many countries for full-scale political union and the expansion process, there is no alternative but to muddle along. If it proves that monetary union will not be truly effective without fiscal union, then that bridge can be crossed when the time is ripe.

If some countries want to explore the possibilities of closer union when others do not, then they will inevitably do so. But the moves will only be successful if that is what the voters want.

The real question, however, is whether this mix 'n' match experiment will work or whether it will all collapse in the absence of a clearer idea of what Europe is for and where it is going.

To take but one example, monetary unions have in the past not been able to survive and thrive outside of political unions. At some point, hard choices look inevitable that involve issues fundamental to governance.

Everything may work out. The EU may expand its borders while simultaneously exercising more effective control from the centre in economic and defence policy, and its leaders may be able to edge down the road towards political union while carrying Europe's population with them. But nobody actually knows how this will be done. Rather like Philip Henslowe, the impresario in Shakespeare in Love who says he cannot justify his optimism that something will turn up because "it's a mystery", so Europe's politicians remain confident that they can offer everybody the best of all possible worlds. Which may turn out to be the biggest fantasy of all.

webTitle: Time for Blair to stop sitting on the euro fence

fields.headline: Time for Blair to stop sitting on the euro fence
fields.standfirst: The prime minister can no longer afford to stick his head in the sand and hope the single currency issue goes away, writes deputy financial editor Mark Milner
fields.trailText: The prime minister can no longer afford to stick his head in the sand and hope the single currency issue goes away, writes deputy financial editor Mark Milner
fields.body:
Tony Blair must be praying for a break on Europe. Abroad, France and Germany are threatening a two-speed Europe with guess who in the slow lane.

At home Britain's car industry is complaining about the strength of the pound against the euro with a subtext that Britain should sign up for the single currency.

The latest warning comes from Nissan. Unless the pound falls, the company's Sunderland plant may not get production of the new Micra. The warning itself is not new - but this time it comes from the very top of the company; Nissan president Carlos Ghosn.

The car makers' argument is straightforward enough. Much of UK production goes for export to Europe. At the current exchange rate, UK plants are at a competitive disadvantage.

That is fair enough, as far as it goes though it will be interesting to see how Nissan will balance its claims that there will be no threat to Sunderland's future with its warnings over the new Micra. Will Sunderland suddenly become competitive when it comes time for the Primera or the Almera (the two other models produced at Sunderland) to be replaced?

The chorus from the car industry raises a broader point, however. The government argues British membership of the single currency should be judged in the national interest. Gordon Brown has drawn up five economic tests that must be passed.

Such pragmatism sounds fine in theory but it appears to be underpinned by an assumption that as long as the door is left open for Britain to join the euro, everything is fine. Action - setting a referendum date or ruling British membership out for the foreseeable future - would have consequences but somehow inaction does not. That view is looking increasingly exposed.

One thing should be remembered, however. British membership of the single currency and the strength of the pound against the euro are related but they are not the same thing. Signing up for the single currency (at the right level) would curb industry's vulnerability to exchange-rate risk in the long term. But the pound may well fall without such drastic action. That at least would provide Mr Blair with the break he needs - but in the short term only.

webTitle: Blair willing to move on closer EU ties

fields.headline: Blair willing to move on closer EU ties
fields.standfirst:
Blair willing to move on closer EU integration
The European Commission: special report
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night assured the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, that Britain is willing to show greater flexibility over Franco-German plans for closer EU integration.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Potsdam and  Michael White
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night assured the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, that Britain is willing to show greater flexibility over Franco-German plans for closer EU integration.

In an effort to remain at the heart of Europe - one of his dearest ambitions - Mr Blair flew to Berlin determined to show he can punch his weight on the EU agenda despite Britain's isolation from the single currency zone.

The prime minister hinted he would offer concessions to the so-called pioneer group led by France and Germany - but not at the price of creating a formal two-speed Europe.

Before dining with Mr Schröder in Potsdam, Mr Blair again enthusiastically backed the euro "in principle".

In the upbeat atmosphere at Potsdam Mr Blair even took time to tell voters at home that they should have "a little more confidence in our own ability to shape the arguments without constantly worrying that Europe is going to turn into a conspiracy against Britain."

Yet in a pre-Berlin cabinet briefing, Mr Blair privately signalled that London will have to grant core countries more freedom to move ahead faster than he is either willing or able to, even if it creates the pioneer group suggested by the French president, Jacques Chirac.

It is a perilous balancing act, with both his divided cabinet and the Tory leader William Hague watching every move.

So, before the two centre-left leaders discussed China, Russia, China and the middle east - as well as the EU - Mr Blair sent out mixed signals about his intentions. They were just as ambiguous as the speech the French president made in Berlin on Tuesday.

In a bid to revitalise the Berlin-Paris axis Mr Chirac had ruled out a "European superstate" but also called for deeper integration and an EU constitution.

Last night Mr Blair said he had "no problem" with Mr Chirac's speech and added that an enlarged EU - from 15 to as many as 25 members - will need "reinforced cooperation".

In his remarks to the cabinet in London, Mr Blair had been more explicit. According to a Downing Street spokesman he said: "Within enlargement we are going to have a situation where there is a need for enhanced cooperation so one country could not block the sensible progress of others."

In Euro-jargon "enhanced cooperation" means changing the mechanism which requires more than half the 15 EU states to endorse an initiative, but only one to block it.

If Mr Chirac and other integrators get their way that could be cut to one-third endorsing a scheme and two states needed to exercise the veto, some UK officials think.

Curbs on the existing veto will be needed, all sides agree, to stop the EU jamming up when it gets much bigger. But it raises the spectre of the same core group agreeing on the same initiatives and creating a two-speed Europe whether London likes it or not.

fields.headline: Nissan stokes up euro row
fields.standfirst:
Blair dismisses two speed Europe fears

FT.com
Nissan UK
fields.trailText: Car giant Nissan has warned that the strong pound is threatening the future of its Sunderland plant, which employs 5,000 directly and thousands more in the supply industry.
fields.body:
Car giant Nissan has warned that the strong pound is threatening the future of its Sunderland plant, which employs 5,000 directly and thousands more in the supply industry.

The Japanese carmaker's president Carlos Ghosn told the Financial Times the factory faces its biggest threat since opening in 1986.

He revealed he was to hold meetings with the government "at the highest level" over the crisis. The talks are expected to involve Prime Minister Tony Blair and Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary.

Sunderland is the most productive car factory in Europe, but Nissan said its position was being hit by the strength of sterling against the euro. Rival firms - including Vauxhall, BMW, Honda and Toyota - have raised similar concerns.

Mr Ghosn stressed that Nissan would not close the plant, but warned that currency problems could jeopardise a potential £150 million expansion.

"How much we rely on Sunderland is at stake," he said. "We could be interested at limiting output at Sunderland and increasing output at other European plants."

Mr Ghosn said Nissan would decide by the end of the year whether to build the next generation Micra at Sunderland.

"We have important decisions to make. The logical place for Micra is Sunderland, but we cannot make a decision on this until we have some guarantees we can count on for the future."

Meanwhile, Tony Blair has insisted he has no worries about Britain being left behind in a "two-speed Europe" as he met German chancellor Gerhard Schroeder outside Berlin.

The Prime Minister was asked by reporters before his meeting in Potsdam whether he was concerned Britain was being left behind by France and Germany.

He said: "No I am not at all. On the issue of Europe I really think it is time the British media grew up." Industry experts said Nissan could switch production of the Micra to the firm's Barcelona plant or factories operated by Renault, the French carmaker, that owns 36.8% of the group.

Any decision to scale back production at Sunderland would be a severe blow to the north-east economy and would be a further setback for the motor industry, still reeling from BMW's break-up of the Rover Group and Ford's decision to end assembly at Dagenham in east London.

Mr Blair has said that a decision to hold a referendum would not be taken until after the next general election, expected next year, but Britain has expressed increasing fears about the development of a "two-speed" Europe, with France and Germany making all the decisions.

Tory leader William Hague has said he would introduce new laws, if returned to government, which would prevent the European courts from taking any further rights away from Britain without a treaty agreement.

webTitle: Pro-euro Tories will defy Hague manifesto

fields.headline: Pro-euro Tories will defy Hague manifesto
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered a serious blow to his authority last night when it emerged that a group of pro-European Tories led by Kenneth Clarke will release rebel manifestos in favour of the European single currency at the next general election.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a serious blow to his authority last night when it emerged that a group of pro-European Tories led by Kenneth Clarke will release rebel manifestos in favour of the European single currency at the next general election.

In an ironic echo of the challenge by Eurosceptic Tory MPs to John Major in 1997, the group of former ministers will declare in their election addresses that Britain should retain the option of joining the euro after the next election.

The personal manifestos, which will be distributed in the MPs' constituencies, will defy Mr Hague's hardline policy to rule out British membership of the euro throughout the next parliament.

Mr Clarke, who is publicly contemptuous of Mr Hague's position on the euro, disclosed at a recent pro-European union conference the decision of the group which includes the former ministers John Gummer, David Curry and Ian Taylor.

The former chancellor told the conference in Derby that his personal statement would be "at odds" with Mr Hague's line because his policy was a mistake which he could not support.

The rebel group is to ban use of Mr Hague's Keep the Pound logo in their election literature and to make clear that their views on the euro are far closer to Tony Blair's.

One of the rebel Tories was unapologetic last night about the decision to defy the party leadership. David Curry, who stood down from Mr Hague's shadow cabinet in 1997 in protest at his Eurosceptic policies, said that he wanted to see Britain join the euro after the next election.
