webTitle: Soft landing for castaway Elian as Cuba rolls out tattered red carpet

fields.headline: Soft landing for castaway Elian as Cuba rolls out tattered red carpet
fields.standfirst:
Prodigal child in halfway house after seven months in the US
Who's who in the Elian saga
Special report
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez has stayed in worse places. His impoverished seaside home town of Cardenas, for example, or the cramped apartment of his relatives in Little Havana, Miami.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez has stayed in worse places. His impoverished seaside home town of Cardenas, for example, or the cramped apartment of his relatives in Little Havana, Miami.

Lately, however, he has been used to much grander surroundings - a country estate in Maryland and a mansion in Washington DC. He has been to hi-tech theme parks, and travelled in motorcades and an executive jet.

So it is hard to guess what he will be making of his latest temporary home - a communist youth centre in the Havana seafront suburb of Miramar.

Unlike many of the crumbling relics around it, the centre, along with its swimming pool and patio, has been repainted and refurbished. On the other side of the wall, lies the deep blue of the Caribbean.

The centre must also be a haven of extraordinary quiet, as the Havana police have stopped traffic from entering a six-block zone around the house. Local residents were only allowed through the checkpoints yesterday on foot after a comprehensive check of their papers.

Homesick

In the final hours of Elian's exile, Fidel Castro appeared to vacillate over what to do with the nation's prodigal child. Journalists were first told that the plan to house him at Miramar had been scrapped and the whole extended Gonzalez family, now as familiar to the world as the characters of any TV soap opera, would be going back to Cardenas. This was reported to be at the request of Elian's homesick father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez.

But then, with Elian's chartered Lear jet already in the air and approaching Cuba, it was announced that Miramar would indeed be the family's immediate destination. It was perhaps deemed to be a suitable halfway house between the extraordinary affluence of the Washington elite and the hard realities of Cardenas.

According to the official Cuban press, Elian will now begin his readaptation. Closeted with a handful of his classmates from Cardenas, his teachers have been challenged to "undertake the masterful work of making him a model child".

Quite what this will mean is hard to say, although it is bound to involve an attempt to counter the propaganda of his seven-month stay in the US, during which Elian's Miami relatives portrayed Fidel Castro as a child-eating, school-milk stealing demon.

The Cuban press yesterday presented the 73-year-old leader as everyone's favourite grandfather - so concerned for Elian's wellbeing that he stayed away from the homecoming - his moment of triumph over America - so as not to overshadow the Gonzalez family's reunion at the airport.

Granma, the Communist party daily, wrote a gushing front-page report of the event, remarking on the "resplendent violet arc" of the setting sun. Even as grandmothers and old friends hugged, the newspaper noted, "we could all 'see' the presence of Fidel, mastermind of this first chapter in the broader struggle, which has freed the people - and in particular its youth and children - and of the struggle which still awaits us."

Fidel's presence was also tangible in the careful stage managing of the return. It was billed as a private family reunion, but the hugs and kisses took place in front of the cameras and about 800 children in Young Pioneer uniform singing the na tional anthem with the backing of a full military band. The airport had been closed a month earlier so that the event could be properly rehearsed.

At times the grandiosity of the occasion threatened to backfire and Elian - while smiling gamely and waving - occasionally appeared to be within one martial chorus of being overwhelmed entirely.

Yesterday, by contrast, was a day of supreme tranquillity in Elian's world. Miramar stewed in the damp heat. The villas on First Avenue, where Elian is living, resembled a row of uneven teeth: some had rotted away almost entirely but a few - mostly those being used as offices by new private and joint venture companies - had been expensively reconstructed and glistened in the sun.

The local residents insisted they were not put out at all by having their street closed to traffic by the police. Most walked everywhere anyway, and they claimed to be proud to have the world's most famous six-year-old next door.

Eugenio Almeida, sitting in the shade of a tree at a makeshift cafe established in someone's front garden, insisted that Elian should not be considered a "new" neighbour.

"This has always been his home, the whole country is his home. And that is true of this one child, Elian, or any other of the 11m Cubans," said Mr Almeida, who described himself as a writer, poet and composer. The Elian odyssey and Washington's role in bringing it to a close had led him to change his mind about President Bill Clinton and his wife Hillary, but only a little, he insisted.

Stupid

"This is the first time they are doing something reasonable, after years of stupid policies," said Mr Almeida, who went on to discuss the absurdities of the US embargo on the island. "Fidel Castro continues eating, driving. Its greatest effect is on the poor people."

As for news this week that congress was considering an end to the embargo on food and medicine, the 57-year-old was unconvinced that it would really happen.

"This has been going on 41 years," he said. "It is not going to end in a day."

Outside, the grey-uniformed policemen were working up a sweat redirecting Miramar's traffic. The world to which Elian had returned hung suspended between its grand past, its dismal present and a future that is the object of an ideological struggle. A half-mile from Elian's villa, workmen were busy reconstructing the Karl Marx theatre. And nearby colourful posters pictured idyllic scenes from a staunch Cuban ally. Below the inviting scenes, the caption read: "Zimbabwe - Africa's Paradise."

fields.headline: Time to end self regulation
fields.standfirst: The GMC should be replaced by an independent regulator says Observer health editor Anthony Browne, who argues self regulation is a con
fields.trailText: The GMC should be replaced by an independent regulator says Observer health editor Anthony Browne, who argues self regulation is a con.
fields.body:
We all know the General Medical Council's only conspicuous success in the last few years has been accumulating enemies.

Not just the patients with entirely legitimate complaints the GMC routinely refuses even to listen to. Or the relatives of people who have been butchered and even murdered by their doctor while the GMC - whose motto is 'protecting patients' - shouts over the pleas of whistleblowers that it sees nothing wrong.

Or even the government, who as the ultimate protector of patients has also now lost faith in the present GMC as self-serving and defensive.

But now even the doctors have lost confidence in the GMC, which is made up almost entirely of other doctors acting as judges on their peers. It is difficult to overstate the significance of this, and how it shows just how awful the GMC has become.

It is as though schoolchildren are demanding a teacher become tougher on them, or that poachers demand the game keeper sharpen up his act. Never before has a self-regulatory body condemned by those it self-regulates.

The GMC has tried desperately to smarten up its act over the last five years - and claims that it is now far more effective. But with not even doctors left to defend it, the case for wholesale reform of the GMC is completely unanswerable, and reformed it will be.

The Department of Health's National Plan published next month will have lots of proposals about how to tighten the GMC up.

Top runners are including more lay people - so it is not just doctors judging doctors - and making it accountable to parliament. But the cowardly department of health, while declaring the GMC is drinking in the last chance saloon, will refrain from doing the one thing it should: end self-regulation of the medical profession completely.

The nurses are all in favour of letting outsiders regulate them, but the doctors - despite hating the GMC - are still insisting on the right to judge themselves.

Alan Milburn argues that he would not want to judge a heart surgeon because he knows nothing about heart surgery. It's an old argument that completely misses the point. A lay panel of expert assessors - perhaps including former doctors - can take expert evidence from current doctors to get their view, and then make a judgement.

Juries and judges may know nothing about the subtleties of mental illness, but are expected to determine - with the help of expert witnesses - whether someone is bad or just mad.

Not everyone is as cowardly as the health secretary. His former boss, the Chancellor, swiftly ended self-regulation in the City, which had led to an endless torrent of financial scandals including the misselling of pensions.

He did not listen to all the stock-brokers special pleading about how only other stock-brokers can possibly judge what they do, and swept the whole self-serving corrupt panoply of City regulation away and replaced it with the Financial Services Authority.

In every area - whether the City, law or medicine - self regulation has proved a con on the general public, ultimately defending the indefensible.

The only way to get good regulation with the public genuinely at heart is to have an independent regulator. Alan Milburn should use this vote by the GMC as the excuse he needs to end it.

webTitle: Cow born with BSE despite controls

fields.headline: Cow born with BSE despite controls
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The attempt to consign the BSE crisis to history received a serious setback yesterday when Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, revealed that a cow born after eradication controls were introduced had been confirmed as having the disease.
fields.body:
The attempt to consign the BSE crisis to history received a serious setback yesterday when Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, revealed that a cow born after eradication controls were introduced had been confirmed as having the disease.

The cow was born on August 25 1996, 25 days after it became illegal to feed cattle remains to any animal or poultry and all stocks had been withdrawn from farms. It had been thought that the ban would prevent any further infection and the disease would rapidly die out as older dairy cattle that might still carry the infection were culled.

Tim Lobstein, co-director of the food commission, said: "Either the food controls for cattle have not been adequate or there is maternal transmission, a new form of transmission that has not been detected previously.

"Until more is known, we do not know how this cow got the disease - but it raises alarming possibilities that new methods or forms of transmission have yet to be fully appreciated by government scientists."

France, Germany and the European commission were informed of the case yesterday with assurances that the Ministry of Agriculture had ordered an investigation into how the case occurred. The government was hoping that it would not lead to further fears on the continent about the safety of British beef.

The government and farmers' leaders were quick to stress that the discovery posed no risk to food safety.

Mr Brown told the Commons that it was likely the cow had caught the disease from its mother - maternal transmission - something always thought theoretically possible but never proved. The second alternative was that contaminated feed had survived the 1996 ban and had subsequently been fed to the cow on the Dorset farm.

Sir John Krebs, chairman of the food standards agency, issued a statement saying the new case posed "no extra risk to food safety" and the cow had been slaughtered and incinerated. Its one calf had been traced and would also be slaughtered and no meat would enter the food chain.

Mr Brown told MPs that some extra BSE cases had always been expected. Computer predictions last year showed it was likely that pregnant cows already infected with BSE but not showing symptoms were likely to give birth to calves that later contracted the disease.

"An assessment assumed by the end of 2000 up to 19 cases born after August 1996 might be identified," he said.

The Consumers' Association said: "There needs to be a thorough and transparent investigation as to how the cow became infected and any implications for public health.

"This again reinforces the fact that many uncertainties still remain regarding BSE. We need to ensure that vigorous and effective controls are in place."

fields.headline: Doctors plunge into new crisis
fields.standfirst:
Angry BMA condemns regulatory body

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The future of self-regulation of doctors was in question last night after a split in the profession over reforms of its regulatory body, the General Medical Council, handed the government a trump card for its abolition and replacement by an independent, lay body.
fields.body:
The future of self-regulation of doctors was in question last night after a split in the profession over reforms of its regulatory body, the General Medical Council, handed the government a trump card for its abolition and replacement by an independent, lay body.

At the annual representative meeting of the British Medical Association in London, doctors passed an overwhelming vote of no confidence in the GMC. They were angered by its failure to protect them from being tarred by a succession of scandals over doctors, such as the gynaecologist Rodney Ledward who botched operations on women for 16 years. But underlying the motion was serious opposition to plans put forward by the GMC to revalidate all doctors - assess them to ensure that they are fit to practice every five years.

Signs of schism over the last few months came to a head yesterday in what some will regard as a last-ditch stand by doctors trying to protect their old autonomy from the New Labour-led rise of patient power.

The government has been leaning on the profession since the Bristol babies scandal several years ago, which revealed that two heart surgeons carried on operating on babies even though they should have known that their death rates were worse than at other hospitals. They and the chief executive of the United Bristol healthcare trust were disciplined by the GMC.

The Bristol case, which was followed by an inquiry which will report at the end of this year, has been used as a stick to beat the profession with by a government that wants doctors to be more accountable to their patients. Further scandals - the murdering GP Harold Shipman, Mr Ledward, and the revelations of the retention of children's organs after death - have increased the pressure.

The GMC is pushing forward a programme of reform, the centrepiece of which is revalidation. GPs have signed up to it, but increasing opposition from hospital doctors culminated yesterday in a concerted attack on the GMC itself.

The vote, by a four-to-one majority, called for radical reform of the GMC rather than its abolition. Doctors said they were angry at the slowness of the GMC in hearing disciplinary cases, its antiquated structure and its ineffectiveness in restoring public confidence after recent scandals.

A motion backing the principle of revalidation - now considered the touchstone of doctors' willingness to modernise and become accountable to patients - was overwhelmingly carried yesterday but with the caveats that the scheme must be "adequately resourced, practical and thoroughly piloted and evaluated".

Professor Stuart Horner, vice-president of the BMA, urged the conference to "be brave" and back the motion, even though he described those who originally voted for revalidation as "medical lemmings" jumping over a cliff.

"There is 5% of underperforming doctors. So you want to put 100% of them - their registration, their career, their income - at stake every five years unless they prove they are competent. So for 95% of the profession, the whole exercise is bureaucracy gone mad and a waste of time."

Peter Tomlin, speaking against, estimated the cost at £50m, which was, he said, "an obscene waste of money" for what was "primarily a public relations exercise".

Proposing the no-confidence vote, Peter Terry said the GMC was not working. "Confidence has not been lost in the medical profession but confidence has been lost in how the medical profession is regulated. The GMC has failed us. The GMC is a shambles."

There was criticism of the leadership. Andrew Hobart, chairman of the junior doctors' committee, said: "We do not want abolition of the GMC but we will not accept changes discussed and decided behind closed doors by a small cabal within the GMC."

Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultants committee, said: "It doesn't give me any pleasure to talk in support of this motion but I do believe that the GMC has lost contact and lost the confidence of the 30,000 consultants I represent. The GMC is capable of reform but the reform must be radical, it must be thorough and it must consult with the wider profession before proposals come forward."

Some doctors warned that backing the no-confidence motion could play into the government's hands and end self-regulation of the medical profession. "This is the shortest suicide note in history," said Andrew Ashworth. "The GMC does have shortcomings but it is initiating reform. You risk putting your freedom in the hands of Tony Blair and Sir Humphrey."

Afterwards, Ian Bogle, BMA chairman, said the debate showed doctors wanted the GMC to deal faster with problem doctors. "The delays that are the big problem and to some extent because of the delays it is not safe. It means that some doctors can practise when they shouldn't be able to.

"The public should be reassured that the profession recognises that there are problems and they are going to make sure those problems are ironed out."

Sir Donald Irvine, president of the GMC, said it was determined to press ahead. "Obviously I'm disappointed that it [the motion] is couched in such negative terms but I think I'm like many others in being confused about what they actually meant. We're as committed as before to the process of radical reform which is going ahead through the summer, the most important part of which is revalidation." Since the BMA had pledged to support revalidation, he said, "I look forward to their support for the kind of radicalism that we intend to deliver."

Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians and a member of the GMC's council, said: "We are relieved that the BMA has not voted to disband the GMC which would have destroyed self-regulation for doctors.

"We must now all work together and fast to reform the GMC, to involve the public much more and to create an organisation in which the public, the profession, government and parliament can have total faith."

"There is 5% of underperforming doctors. So you want to put 100% of them - their registration, their career, their income - at stake every five years unless they prove they are competent. So for 95% of the profession, the whole exercise is bureaucracy gone mad and a waste of time." Peter Tomlin, speaking against, estimated the cost at £50m, which was, he said, "an obscene waste of money" for what was "primarily a public relations exercise". Proposing the no-confidence vote, Peter Terry said the GMC was not working. "Confidence has not been lost in the medical profession but confidence has been lost in how the medical profession is regulated. The GMC has failed us. The GMC is a shambles." There was criticism of the leadership. Andrew Hobart, chairman of the junior doctors' committee, said: "We do not want abolition of the GMC but we will not accept changes discussed and decided behind closed doors by a small cabal within the GMC." Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultants committee, said: "It doesn't give me any pleasure to talk in support of this motion but I do believe that the GMC has lost contact and lost the confidence of the 30,000 consultants I represent. The GMC is capable of reform but the reform must be radical, it must be thorough and it must consult with the wider profession before proposals come forward." Some doctors warned that backing the no-confidence motion could play into the government's hands and end self-regulation of the medical profession. "This is the shortest suicide note in history," said Andrew Ashworth. "The GMC does have shortcomings but it is initiating reform. You risk putting your freedom in the hands of Tony Blair and Sir Humphrey." Afterwards, Ian Bogle, BMA chairman, said the debate showed doctors wanted the GMC to deal faster with problem doctors. "The delays that are the big problem and to some extent because of the delays it is not safe. It means that some doctors can practise when they shouldn't be able to. "The public should be reassured that the profession recognises that there are problems and they are going to make sure those problems are ironed out." Sir Donald Irvine, president of the GMC, said it was determined to press ahead. "Obviously I'm disappointed that it [the motion] is couched in such negative terms but I think I'm like many others in being confused about what they actually meant. We're as committed as before to the process of radical reform which is going ahead through the summer, the most important part of which is revalidation." Since the BMA had pledged to support revalidation, he said, "I look forward to their support for the kind of radicalism that we intend to deliver." Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians and a member of the GMC's council, said: "We are relieved that the BMA has not voted to disband the GMC which would have destroyed self-regulation for doctors. "We must now all work together and fast to reform the GMC, to involve the public much more and to create an organisation in which the public, the profession, government and parliament can have total faith."

fields.headline: Hague dilutes Tory waiting-list pledge
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague watered down a key plank of his "commonsense revolution" last night when he admitted that a Conservative government would be unable to provide every NHS patient with a guaranteed waiting time.
fields.body:
William Hague watered down a key plank of his "commonsense revolution" last night when he admitted that a Conservative government would be unable to provide every NHS patient with a guaranteed waiting time.

In language that differed from his much-vaunted "Patient's Guarantee", the Tory leader said that patients waiting for minor operations would be excluded from his pledge.

During an appearance on BBC1's Question Time, Mr Hague was asked whether patients waiting for varicose vein operations would be given a guaranteed waiting time.

He replied: "Not to begin with because we have to start with the most serious conditions. You cannot possibly guarantee everybody waiting times because the system cannot cope with it."

Mr Hague faced embarrassment when the presenter, David Dimbleby, held up a copy of the Tories' Patient's Charter, which says: "We will give every NHS patient a guaranteed waiting time based on their need for treatment."

Mr Hague said that he had not changed policy, insisting that the document made clear that the guarantee would only cover patients awaiting major operations - indeed he had signalled the shift as early as April, in a speech to the Royal College of Nursing.

"We obviously cannot do it for every operation," he said. "We will do it for the most serious operations, such as heart bypass surgery."

The Tory leader was on provocative form on last night's edition of Question Time, which was devoted entirely to him.

In an attempt to distance himself from past Tory governments, Mr Hague said that both his immediate predecessors had failed to tackle the problem of rising crime.

"The Thatcher and Major governments were slow to tackle this subject," he said. "They did plenty of other things and addressed a lot of issues, but I think they were slow to tackle this subject."

Mr Hague claimed that it was only with the arrival of Michael Howard as home secretary in 1993 that crime started to fall. "Michael Howard took a far tougher line on crime than any of his predecessors, and I think he has been vindicated," he said.

The Tory leader also took a swipe at the former deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine, a powerful critic of his European policy. Asked about Mr Heseltine's comment that he would be replaced by Michael Portillo, Mr Hague said: "Michael Heseltine is retiring. I do not have to take lessons from anyone."

webTitle: Jury considers verdict in Soho nail bomb trial

fields.headline: Jury considers verdict in Soho nail bomb trial
fields.trailText: The jury in the trial of the London nail bomber David Copeland will return to the Old Bailey today to consider whether he was suffering from a severe mental illness when he planted a device in a Soho pub which killed three friends.
fields.body:
The jury in the trial of the London nail bomber David Copeland will return to the Old Bailey today to consider whether he was suffering from a severe mental illness when he planted a device in a Soho pub which killed three friends.

Copeland, 24, an engineer's assistant from Cove, in Hampshire, has admitted causing the explosion in central London, and two others in Brixton and Brick Lane within the space of 13 days in April last year.

But the prosecution refused to accept his pleas of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility.

Nigel Sweeney QC, prosecuting, said the crown did not believe Copeland was suffering from paranoid schizophrenia at the time of the bombing campaign.

Copeland, he argued, was suffering from a lesser condition, probably a personality disorder, which meant he was guilty of murdering Andrea Dykes, 27, who was four months pregnant, John Light, 32 and Nik Moore, 31.

The three friends were drinking in the Admiral Duncan pub when the bomb went off. Seventy-nine others were hurt in the blast.

Summing up the four-week case yesterday, the judge, Michael Hyam QC told the jury that if they were sure Copeland had meant his bomb to kill or cause serious injury, then the burden of proof shifted to the defence. Copeland's lawyers had to prove that at the time he planted the bomb he was suffering from "such abnormality of mind...as to substantially impair his mental responsibility". The judge added: "If not, the defendant is guilty of murder."

Earlier, the court heard that medical witnesses who appeared for the prosecution and defence were in "complete, headlong, disagreement" over Copeland's condition.

Mr Sweeney told the court that Copeland was a homophobic Nazi who bombed London because he wanted to "stir up a racial war".

He said Copeland targeted Brixton, in south London, and Brick Lane, in the city's east end, because he knew they were areas where many black and Asian people lived.

The Soho bomb, said Mr Sweeney, was not a political statement, but a personal one. "He hated gay men, his hatred stemming from the way his parents treated him as a child."

Michael Wolkind, QC, defending, said Copeland had been suffering from a paranoid schizophrenic illness long before the bombings.

He called on psychiatrists who said Copeland had effectively turned into a robot, and that he had "religious and persecutory delusions".

webTitle: Controversial zoo owner John Aspinall dies at 74

fields.headline: Controversial zoo owner John Aspinall dies at 74
fields.trailText: The millionaire and controversial zoo owner John Aspinall died at the age of 74 yesterday after losing a three-year battle against cancer of the jaw.
fields.body:
The millionaire and controversial zoo owner John Aspinall died at the age of 74 yesterday after losing a three-year battle against cancer of the jaw.

Aspinall, a casino owner and former friend of missing peer Lord Lucan, had also secretly struggled with leukaemia.

He was a close friend of the late Sir James Goldsmith, who was a partner in the gaming clubs which helped to pay the running costs of his two loss-making zoo parks - Port Lympne and Howletts, near Canterbury. Aspinall stood as a Referendum party candidate in Folkestone and Hythe at the last general election, polling 4,188 votes against Michael Howard and also donated money to Neil Hamilton to fight his libel case.

Last night his half-brother, James Osbourne said his two wild animal parks would continue to be run by the John Aspinall Foundation "in the manner and philosophy of their founder".

The parks have been dogged by controversy after five zookeepers were killed in 20 years, three of them mauled to death by tigers. Yet Aspinall maintained his belief that keepers should be allowed to enter the enclosures where tigers roamed and bond with them.

Aspinall said his philosophy was to encourage keepers to come into close contact with potentially dangerous animals.

However, in 1980, he was forced to shoot two Siberian tigresses that killed two keepers at Howletts, and four years later a keeper was crushed to death by an Indian bull elephant in Port Lympne.

In 1994, the head keeper at Howletts was killed by a Siberian tiger. The most recent victim was Darren Cockrill, 27, who was crushed by elephant La Petite in its enclosure at Port Lympne in February.

In 1996, Aspinall won a high court case to maintain the controversial practice of keepers mingling with tigers, even though in May of that year, a boy was awarded £132,000 because his arm was ripped off by a chimpanzee at Port Lympne in 1989.

Last year he said one of the most distressing aspects of his cancer was not the way it ravaged his appearance but the fact that he could no longer mingle with his animals.

A lifelong gambler, he is said to have cleaned out the aristocracy in the 1960s and profits from this were used to fund his private passion, animals. With his first wins he bought a flat in Belgravia and built an enclosure in the garden for a tiger, two bears and a capuchin monkey.

Aspinall always had a fascination with wild animals and in 1958 he founded Howletts, a Palladian mansion standing in 70 acres bought following a substantial win. Port Lympne opened in 1973. Their success as breeding centres was well documented, with 73 gorillas and six black rhino born there.

In both, the animals have large paddocks and are fed a varied diet. There is also a premium on reducing boredom by encouraging wild behaviour.

For 20 years zoological societies dismissed Aspinall as an eccentric collector but after the breeding successes of his zoos they started queuing up to learn from him. He has more than a thousand animals with 80 successful breeding species. Unlike at other zoos there is a commitment to returning species to the wild. Last year his project in the Congo was the first to introduce captive-bred gorillas into the wild.

Aspinall also railed against overpopulation as he feared threatened animals would soon have nowhere to go. "The extinction of animals and plant species and the depletion of non-renewable resources are irremediable crimes," he said recently.

He is survived by his wife Sarah, two sons Damian and Bassa, daughter Amanda and two stepsons Jason and Amos.

fields.headline: 'Train killer' dies in prison fire
fields.standfirst: Anger at suicide of man accused of murdering British student
fields.trailText: The man suspected of murdering three women in France, including the Birmingham University student Isabel Peake, killed himself yesterday by apparently setting fire to his cell in the psychiatric wing of a Lisbon prison.
fields.body:
The man suspected of murdering three women in France, including the Birmingham University student Isabel Peake, killed himself yesterday by apparently setting fire to his cell in the psychiatric wing of a Lisbon prison.

Sid Ahmed Rezala, 21, who topped France's most-wanted list for several months last year before being arrested in Portugal, was alone when the blaze took hold in the early hours of the morning. Celsa Monata, the Portuguese prison services director, said he seemed to have died from inhaling fumes from his smouldering mattress.

"The mattress was fireproof. It didn't burn, but it produced a lot of smoke," Mr Monata said. "There were no signs of burns, so he must have died from asphyxiation."

A guard who tried to rescue Rezala could not open the door because it had been blocked with a bar from his bed. Emergency services were unable to revive Rezala, dubbed le tueur des trains in France because two of his alleged victims were killed on express trains. An autopsy was due to be performed yesterday at the Lisbon's Institute of Legal Medicine.

The justice minister, Alberto Costa, said an inquiry had been launched into the death of Rezala, who was arrested in Lisbon in January and was awaiting judgment on a final appeal against his extradition to France. He had already made several suicide attempts.

"I regret what has happened, and await the conclusions of the inquiry," Mr Costa said. "This was a known pathological case - he had been admitted to the prison's psychiatric unit and was receiving medical treatment."

The Algerian-born Frenchman was wanted for questioning over the death of Ms Peake, 20, from Barlaston, Stafford shire, whose partly clothed body was found by a railway line in central France last October. She had been on her way back to Britain for the weekend from Limoges, where she had just started an exchange year, when she was pushed from the overnight Brive-Paris train.

Police also wanted to interview Rezala over the deaths of Corinne Caillaux, 36, who was stabbed 15 times in the toilets of the Paris-Ventimiglia sleeper on December 14, and Emilie Bazin, an ex-girlfriend whose body was found soon after under a pile of coal in a cellar in the northern town of Amiens.

Ms Peake's parents, Brian and Annie, were said yester day to be distraught. Curtains were drawn at the family home and a padlock was fitted on the gates.

Rezala's death marks the end of an embarrassing saga for the French authorities. Elementary mistakes were made in the inquiry, including delays in identifying Ms Peake's body and in lifting forensic evidence from the train on which she travelled, which was cleaned before it could be examined.

Rezala, a small-time drug dealer and drifter who had a conviction for rape and had been cautioned many times for travelling without a ticket on the French rail network, was released after being held on the Swiss border in November, and later escaped capture at his parents home in Marseille because police had to wait a day for a search warrant.

After a Europe-wide manhunt, he was traced to Lisbon using a series of calls he made from his mobile and a public phone box to the mother of his three-year-old son in Amiens. Even then his fate seemed in doubt, since Portuguese law allows extradition to be refused to countries, including France, that can impose prison sentences longer than Portugal's 25-year maximum.

Public opinion was further inflamed last month after Rezala gave an interview to Le Figaro weekly magazine, allegedly admitting to the murders. He said he had killed the three women after seeing "flashes" that seemed like an "order to execute".

Describing his meeting at Limoges station with the "very sweet" Ms Peake, he said: "It was 3am and she was going to Paris. She was going to visit her boyfriend in England and she wanted to call him. She asked for my mobile phone; I lent it to her. She had a few drags of my joint. I saw that flash again."

At the time of the killings, he said, he was drinking two litres of Jack Daniels whisky a day, mixed with dope and acid. "May God help all their families and bring misery down on me," he said. "If someone had done that to someone from my family, I would have killed them, torn out their heart and eaten it."

Lawyers for the two French victims expressed anger that Rezala would never be tried, and blamed the slow pace of the Portuguese legal system.

One of Rezala's French lawyers, Jean Claude Richard, said he found it "surprising that somebody is able to set fire to his cell without being seen or heard. We are very sad that a boy of 21 has died in this way. To us, it does not mean he was guilty."

webTitle: All hands to the handshaking with Khaki Ken

fields.headline: All hands to the handshaking with Khaki Ken
fields.trailText: It was mayor's question time in the Greater London assembly yesterday. The idea is for this monthly session to be the precise opposite of prime minister's questions in the Commons - or "the palace of pain," as the GLA chairman, Trevor Phillips, called it.
fields.body:
It was mayor's question time in the Greater London assembly yesterday. The idea is for this monthly session to be the precise opposite of prime minister's questions in the Commons - or "the palace of pain," as the GLA chairman, Trevor Phillips, called it.

In fact the plan seems to be to turn the GLA into a parish council, only more relaxed. Meetings are even held in a church hall, the Emmanuel Centre in Westminster. (Norman Foster is designing a new assembly building, but that will take years, plus extra months when they find that an engineering problem makes it sway when anyone walks inside.)

Ken Livingstone turned up wearing ill-matched khakis, and sat on a rickety chair stuck on a patch of green baize. One assumed the first item of business would be the church hall restoration fund, followed by a vote of thanks for the refreshments provided by Mrs Pargiter, but it turned out to be the mayor's statement. He appealed for GLA members to turn up and greet guests at some function. "We need all hands to the handshaking," he said with a grin.

"Ah," said Mr Phillips, waspishly. "So we can try out the new handshaking techniques you've got from your friendship with the royal family. You seem to spend more time with the royal family than you do with me."

"Whooo!" went the GLA members in a collective camp Frankie Howerd spasm.

Mr Phillips perhaps felt this was a hissy fit too far, even at a parish meeting. When Ken announced that he had invented another job, he said enthusiastically: "Gosh, that's fantastic! Solving unemployment the Livingstone way!"

They all seem to like Ken, even the Tories. When he announced that Margaret Thatcher had abolished the GLC "because it was popular and successful", they all went "Whoa!", but it was a matey, "come off it, mate, and mine's a pint" sort of whoa.

John Briggs (Labour) asked whether he would let his cabinet say what they pleased about everything. What if they were in favour of fox-hunting in London? Or supported apartheid? "We need a strong mayor!"

"Well," said Ken, in that familiar, teasing, nasal drawl, "over the last 20 years I think I've had all the strong government I can use."

He also has a line in fake bombast that is meant to sound self-deprecating, but which is actually really rather bombastic. Someone asked about the quality of his staff. "If you have taken 20 years to climb to the top of the political greasy pole, as I have so successfully done, you don't do it if you have dumb-assed second-raters around you" I don't know. Tony Blair managed it.Earlier, in the Commons, I had the pleasure of listening to Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, chief executive of the Millennium Dome, give evidence to the culture committee. And it was a pleasure. His years with Disney have given him not only a fine Franco-American accent - JR Ewing meets Hercule Poirot - but a permanently happy grin, like Minnie Mouse.

And he adores the dome. "Zum zings are working, an' zum zings are not working. But at zur end of zur day, three million people lurv eet. And zur show! Ah theenk eet ees zur bes' show anywhere in zur world!" (Sorry, but he really sounds like that.)

"Zur dome 'as been a fantastic popular success. You know, eet ees weird for visitors to 'ave a Frenchman stand in front of them telling them zat ziss is zur best thing - in zur world!"

What was faintly spooky was his hair. I was standing behind him and noticed that it had been teased up into spikes, making it certain he had gone to the barber's and said: "Please, ah wan' to look exactly like Bart Simpson."
fields.bodyText: It was mayor's question time in the Greater London assembly yesterday. The idea is for this monthly session to be the precise opposite of prime minister's questions in the Commons - or "the palace of pain," as the GLA chairman, Trevor Phillips, called it. In fact the plan seems to be to turn the GLA into a parish council, only more relaxed. Meetings are even held in a church hall, the Emmanuel Centre in Westminster. (Norman Foster is designing a new assembly building, but that will take years, plus extra months when they find that an engineering problem makes it sway when anyone walks inside.) Ken Livingstone turned up wearing ill-matched khakis, and sat on a rickety chair stuck on a patch of green baize. One assumed the first item of business would be the church hall restoration fund, followed by a vote of thanks for the refreshments provided by Mrs Pargiter, but it turned out to be the mayor's statement. He appealed for GLA members to turn up and greet guests at some function. "We need all hands to the handshaking," he said with a grin. "Ah," said Mr Phillips, waspishly. "So we can try out the new handshaking techniques you've got from your friendship with the royal family. You seem to spend more time with the royal family than you do with me." "Whooo!" went the GLA members in a collective camp Frankie Howerd spasm. Mr Phillips perhaps felt this was a hissy fit too far, even at a parish meeting. When Ken announced that he had invented another job, he said enthusiastically: "Gosh, that's fantastic! Solving unemployment the Livingstone way!" They all seem to like Ken, even the Tories. When he announced that Margaret Thatcher had abolished the GLC "because it was popular and successful", they all went "Whoa!", but it was a matey, "come off it, mate, and mine's a pint" sort of whoa. John Briggs (Labour) asked whether he would let his cabinet say what they pleased about everything. What if they were in favour of fox-hunting in London? Or supported apartheid? "We need a strong mayor!" "Well," said Ken, in that familiar, teasing, nasal drawl, "over the last 20 years I think I've had all the strong government I can use." He also has a line in fake bombast that is meant to sound self-deprecating, but which is actually really rather bombastic. Someone asked about the quality of his staff. "If you have taken 20 years to climb to the top of the political greasy pole, as I have so successfully done, you don't do it if you have dumb-assed second-raters around you" I don't know. Tony Blair managed it.Earlier, in the Commons, I had the pleasure of listening to Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, chief executive of the Millennium Dome, give evidence to the culture committee. And it was a pleasure. His years with Disney have given him not only a fine Franco-American accent - JR Ewing meets Hercule Poirot - but a permanently happy grin, like Minnie Mouse. And he adores the dome. "Zum zings are working, an' zum zings are not working. But at zur end of zur day, three million people lurv eet. And zur show! Ah theenk eet ees zur bes' show anywhere in zur world!" (Sorry, but he really sounds like that.) "Zur dome 'as been a fantastic popular success. You know, eet ees weird for visitors to 'ave a Frenchman stand in front of them telling them zat ziss is zur best thing - in zur world!" What was faintly spooky was his hair. I was standing behind him and noticed that it had been teased up into spikes, making it certain he had gone to the barber's and said: "Please, ah wan' to look exactly like Bart Simpson."

webTitle: We need vigour and rigour at the heart of Europe

fields.headline: We need vigour and rigour at the heart of Europe
fields.standfirst:
New European institutions must foster an inclusive democracy
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: That Europe is "under construction" is an old conceit. President Jacques Chirac, looking forward to the French presidency in the second half of this year, invoked it earlier this week in the Reichstag when he spoke of "three great building sites" during a period of "great transition". What is less often mentioned is that this construction continues without overarching blueprints or plans, on the basis only of temporary and very partial agreements between architects, contractors, and clients - and that, in other words, it is wonderful that brick stands upon brick at all.
fields.body:
That Europe is "under construction" is an old conceit. President Jacques Chirac, looking forward to the French presidency in the second half of this year, invoked it earlier this week in the Reichstag when he spoke of "three great building sites" during a period of "great transition". What is less often mentioned is that this construction continues without overarching blueprints or plans, on the basis only of temporary and very partial agreements between architects, contractors, and clients - and that, in other words, it is wonderful that brick stands upon brick at all.

The jagged and less than wholly responsible nature of this process has been illustrated recently by the back and forth debate between French and German politicians over what should be the long term goals of the Union. Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, began it with a private speech in which he called for a European constitution, a European president, a European government, and a more representative and powerful European parliament. Various French responses culminated two days ago in Chirac's address in the Reichstag, in which he said not one word about any of these proposals, except to observe that "the face of the future of Europe is still to be drawn". But he did commend the old idea of a "pioneer group" that could go ahead more quickly with integration than other members, of which Fischer had also spoken.

What is it about this kind of exchange, between men who are in their different ways both interesting and important politicians, and which certainly concerns very critical questions, that makes many Europeans uneasy? Perhaps it is the suspicion that neither man has a sound mandate, even in their own countries, to propose or reject such fundamental changes. Perhaps it is the feeling that these ideas are not emerging as a result of lengthy and inclusive discussion within or between the two governments, but are the product of accidents of personality and the exigencies of domestic politics.

The Schröder government, after all, was regarded until quite recently as the weakest government Germany had had since the war, divided, incoherent and led by a man whose purposes were unclear even to himself. It is only the downfall of Helmut Kohl and the consequent implosion of the Christian Democrats that has made the governing coalition appear, by contrast, a relatively sound proposition. Fischer, for his part, has since the beginning spoken his mind in a way which suggested that prior consultation was not a fixed habit with him. Are we entirely sure that the government did not find itself following where Fischer led, rather than the other way round?

The weaknesses of the French government spring from an extreme case of cohabitation in which a conservative president and a socialist prime minister both have the date of the next presidential election in 2002 so firmly in mind that every aspect of policy, particularly foreign policy, where their responsibilities overlap, is a prisoner to their clashing interests. Recent splits over the Middle East have been the most obvious indication of their differences. This no doubt accounts in part for the extremely cautious nature of Chirac's speech because, even though French attitudes toward European integration are changing, there is a sceptical constituency whose votes are important. Certainly Europe is not face to face with an agreed Franco-German plan for the future, or even the beginnings of such a plan.

But it is interesting that precisely at the moment when they do not agree, France and Germany should be raising again the idea of the pioneer group, of the "hard core". Just what is this pioneer group going to pioneer when it does not agree on either the speed or direction of change? Other European countries could be forgiven for concluding that the one thing it might agree on is Franco- German primacy.

It should be said more frequently than it is that the hard core idea is a dangerous one. It ignores the wishes of a majority of EU members and of the candidate states. It misleads, when it is suggested that there could be several different "cores", according to function, when defence is the only serious other grouping. It threatens to demote the Brussels institutions, especially the commission, by setting up an alternative centre of decision making. It is in essence backward looking, for what it strives to do is to encyst the old union of the six within the new union of the 26, or however many it turns out to be.

Of course there are overwhelming arguments for flexibility as Europe enlarges, but that is not the same as an institutionalised inner group with, for instance, as Chirac says, its own secretariat. "Secretariat" is a word that should always be regarded with considerable suspicion. Nobody outside of the old six likes the hard core notion, as Tony Blair no doubt explained again to the German chancellor at their dinner last night. The candidate members, as Professor Jacques Rupnik says, regard it as an idea that seems to "be emptying enlargement". Given that anti-union sentiment is gaining ground in eastern Europe, helped on by the EU boycott of Austria, that is a worrying thought.

The Franco-German manoeuvres of recent weeks do illustrate a matter of central importance, which is that Europe's political cultures differ greatly. These differences, charted perceptively by Larry Siedentop in his new book on European democracy*, can be seen as both difficulties and as assets. France's in stinct for responsive structures that can be controlled by a sharp elite, and Germany's instinct for the careful allocation of power to different levels and units are clearly at play in these proposals. Britain's pragmatic approach, with its attachment to informal consensus, in spite of the adversarial nature of the party system, represents another choice. Other European countries have other models still.

Such cultures, as Siedentop argues, cannot be wished away, but they could be damaged by the creation of the wrong kind of European institutions. Since Europe's democratic possibilities are rooted for what may be a long time to come in these specifically national traditions, that would be disastrous. The German approach to the reform of the union, as exemplified in recent exchanges, is more democratic than that of the French, and preferable on those grounds. But it is also more thoroughgoing, and therefore less preferable on those grounds, at least to British eyes. The hard argument is over how to enhance the power of European institutions in such a way as to bring a truly European democracy into existence, rather than in a manner that will instead reduce the possibility of such a democracy ever emerging. It needs to be conducted both with more vigour and with more rigour than has so far been evident.

*Democracy in Europe by Larry Siedentop, Allen Lane

webTitle: Lost painting unearthed in Suffolk country house

fields.headline: Lost painting unearthed in Suffolk country house
fields.standfirst: National treasure 13th-century masterpiece handed to gallery
fields.trailText: A lost masterpiece, one of the few surviving works by the 13th-century Italian artist Cimabue, was handed to the National Gallery yesterday, saved for the nation as payment of £7.2m in death duties.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A lost masterpiece, one of the few surviving works by the 13th-century Italian artist Cimabue, was handed to the National Gallery yesterday, saved for the nation as payment of £7.2m in death duties.

The Virgin and Child Enthroned with Two Angels, a panel painting which is 10in by 8in, was due to be auctioned at Sotheby's next week, almost certainly for export and probably for far more than the value agreed with the government's revenue commissioners who accepted it as duty payment.

The National Gallery, with its steadily eroded acquisitions budget, could scarcely have afforded it. Neil MacGregor, the director, said that getting the painting was "thrilling, absolutely stupendous".

It was the only Cimabue believed left in private hands, and one of a handful of his works to survive anywhere. He is renowned as the father of the Renaissance, the tutor of Duccio and Giotto, but almost nothing by him is left.

Rupert Charlton-Jones, of Sotheby's, who spotted it in a routine valuation of the contents of Benacre Hall in Suffolk, said he was left weak at the knees when he guessed what it might be. Dillian Gordon, the National Gallery's early Renaissance expert, said yesterday: "I won't believe it until it's actually hanging on our walls."

Her attribution, accepted internationally by experts, has also authenticated another small panel in the Frick in New York as a Cimabue, because the style, particularly the punched decoration in the gilding, is so similar.

Cimabues have been lost in wars, floods and earthquakes. This one survived a major fire at Benacre Hall in the 1920s, when it was among piles of furniture and books dragged by the servants out of the burning house and heaped up on the lawn.

The family believes it may been bought by Sir Edward Sherlock Booth in Florence in the 19th century. The picture will go on display to the public this morning.

webTitle: Unisys warns of steep profits slide

fields.headline: Unisys warns of steep profits slide
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Unisys fell 34% yesterday after the IT company said second-quarter earnings could be less than half Wall Street's expectations. It blamed a combination of weak sales to the government and the financial sector and currency fluctuations.
fields.body:
Shares in Unisys fell 34% yesterday after the IT company said second-quarter earnings could be less than half Wall Street's expectations. It blamed a combination of weak sales to the government and the financial sector and currency fluctuations.

Unisys said it expects second-quarter earnings per share of 18 to 20 cents. Analysts had been expecting 37 cents a share, level with the results of the 1999 second quarter, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.

Lawrence Weinbach, the Unisys chairman and chief executive, last month said he expected second-quarter revenues to fall slightly compared with the a year earlier but that double-digit revenue growth would return in the second half of the year.

Yesterday the company forecast second-quarter revenues of $1.62bn to $1.65bn, down 13 to 15% from a year earlier.

The company blamed a fundamental shift of focus in the marketplace towards e-business. "It's the issue of transition, of what's going on in the marketplace," said the director of investor relations, Jim Kerr. "It is a shift to e-business away from solutions."

The shares fell $81/16 to $159/16 in early trade, making Unisys the biggest percentage loser on the New York market. The warning also hit IBM shares; it too relies heavily on sales to the government and financial sector. IBM shares were down $31/16 to $110.
Reuters

fields.headline: Singapore pay lure counters dot.coms
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Singapore's public salary earners from the prime minister downwards were offered a handsome pay increase yesterday to prevent them being lured away by tempting offers from dot.com start ups.
fields.body:
Singapore's public salary earners from the prime minister downwards were offered a handsome pay increase yesterday to prevent them being lured away by tempting offers from dot.com start ups.

Deputy prime minister Lee Hsien Loong told parliament that with the end of the Asian economic crisis, there was a real danger of top talent succumbing to the dot.com fever. Young Singaporean civil servants were "hoping to become the next Bill Gates".

Singapore has long been seen as a haven of hi-tech talent. Sir Richard Branson's Virgin group recently tied up a $1bn (£700m) deal with a Singapore Telecommunications subsidiary, Sing Tel Mobile, to provide mobile and internet services in Asia.

It is not known whether the prime minister, Goh Chok Teng, has also been tempted but his salary is going up, too. He will earn S$1.94m (£800,000) annually, more than five times the pay of Bill Clinton.

After this revision, said Mr Lee, the prime minister's salary will rank 63rd among the city state's private sector earners.

At first sight, the new salary tables do not reveal a significant rise for the prime minister. Mr Goh's basic salary of S$85,000 monthly will be increased by $300 a month.

But, like all civil servants in Singapore, Mr Goh also enjoys a 13th month bonus. The extras increase his total annual pay by 14%.

fields.headline: Appeal court overturns £115m Monsanto award
fields.standfirst: GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: Monsanto, the controversial American biotechnology company, claimed what it called an important legal victory in the United States yesterday.
fields.body:
Monsanto, the controversial American biotechnology company, claimed what it called an important legal victory in the United States yesterday.

An appeal court overturned a $174.9m (£115m) award over licensing rights in genetic engineering of seeds.

The California Court of Appeals overturned a 1998 jury award in favour of Mycogen, a seed company owned by Dow Chemical.

In the original case, Mycogen had alleged that Monsanto had refused to give it timely access to gene technology which makes some plants resistant to herbicides and other chemicals.

The appeals court also rejected the claim that Monsanto should license valuable genetically engineered material to Mycogen as part of an agreement dating back to 1989.

Dow Chemical responded to the appeal court's decision by saying that it would take the case to the California Supreme Court.

But Scarlet Foster, a spokeswoman for Monsanto, said that yesterday's decision had been "a complete win" for the company.

Monsanto was taken over by Pharmacia & Upjohn last year. Before the takeover it had developed a reputation for hard negotiating tactics over licensing and an aggressive acquisition strategy.

But its share price fell sharply as it fell foul of a consumer backlash against genetically engineered foodstuffs.

The company faces several other cases involving licensing rights for genetically modified agricultural products.

Ms Foster said yesterday: "When the first products of any hi-tech industry begin to get commercialised there are always questions to be resolved around patents."

Yesterday's appeal court decision dates back to an earlier agreement between Monsanto and Lubrizol Genetics, a company that was subsequently bought by Mycogen.

In the original trial, the jury held that Monsanto had witheld valuable information and said that it should pay damages equal to twice Mycogen's loss of future profits.

webTitle: Virtual's market battering 'goes with the territory'

fields.headline: Virtual's market battering 'goes with the territory'
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Virtual Internet slid 34% yesterday after it warned that a delayed product launch and a disappointing performance from a number of its international operations would affect full-year results.
fields.body:
Shares in Virtual Internet slid 34% yesterday after it warned that a delayed product launch and a disappointing performance from a number of its international operations would affect full-year results.

Combined with the announcement of a threefold increase in pre-tax losses to £4.2m for the half year, the shares closed down 110p at 213p on thin trading of 71,000 shares. Earlier in the year, the stock traded as high as 950p. Virtual Internet specialises in registering domain names and protecting brands online.

Chief executive Jason Drummond said he was disappointed by the market's reaction to the figures which he said had been in line with expectations. "I think this [fall] goes with the territory at the moment," he said.

"The market is very squiffy. A few thousand shares change hands and all of a sudden you've lost £30m off your market capitalisation.

"It's ironic because we're actually in the process of becoming one of the dominant global players in the area we operate in, we've got £25m in the bank and we've just recorded year on year organic turnover growth of 800%. Yet we're only valued at about two times cash."

Mr Drummond said a delay to the launch of Nomodo, an automated high-volume domain registration service, and disappointing early growth in a number of its international operations were to blame. Nomodo would be on the market imminently after the completion of final technical tests and steps had been taken to strengthen management in the US and Italy.

Despite the setbacks Mr Drummond feels Virtual's cash resources makes it a natural consolidator in the market and will look for acquisitions.

In the six months to April 30, turnover climbed from £307,304 to £2.5m but pre-tax losses grew from £1.43m to £4.25m. New customer gains during the period included Reuters, Royal Sun Alliance and Channel Four.

The company moved to the main market in April, raising £25m. It was set up by 30-year-old Mr Drummond in 1996 and he retains more than 50% of the shares.

Nomodo would be on the market imminently after the completion of final technical tests and steps had been taken to strengthen management in the US and Italy. Despite the setbacks Mr Drummond feels Virtual's cash resources makes it a natural consolidator in the market and will look for acquisitions. In the six months to April 30, turnover climbed from £307,304 to £2.5m but pre-tax losses grew from £1.43m to £4.25m. New customer gains during the period included Reuters, Royal Sun Alliance and Channel Four. The company moved to the main market in April, raising £25m. fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: M&S blocks part of claim
fields.body:
M&S blocks part of claim

Marks & Spencer yesterday blocked a large part of the £54m High Court action launched against it by clothing supplier William Baird, which was dropped after 30 years as a supplier to the high-street chain in October 1999. It claimed its services were dropped without warning.

Both companies claimed partial victory. The court refused to accept a claim on the basis of breach of contract but a secondary goodwill claim, which M&S calculates to be for £15.5m, can proceed to trial, the High Court ruled.

Pharmagene plans to float

Pharmagene, the British biotechnology company, is to list on the Stock Exchange next month in a flotation expected to value it at up to £120m. The offering is likely to raise £30m for the company, which is based in Royston, near Cambridge, and chaired by former Chiroscience chief Nowell Stebbing.

Record drop in used car prices

Second-hand car prices dropped by a record amount last month, figures out today show.

Prices for new cars also fell but, at a year-on-year decrease in May of 3.2%, the decline was not as steep as that of second-hand vehicles. Year-on year prices for used cars - the three-year-old category - fell by 19.2% last month, a record since the Alliance and Leicester Car Price Index was launched in October last year. Prices for nearly new cars - the one-year-old category - fell by 16.7% in the 12 months to May 2000.

Pay awards 'in line with prices'

Pay awards in Britain are climbing in line with the increase in prices, according to Incomes Data Services. While the bulk of settlements continue to be in the 2.5 to 3.5% range, those agreed in late May and early June were "significantly higher" than other deals recorded at the beginning of the second quarter, the research company said.

Of 104 new settlements recorded in the latest report, covering just over 1m employees, just under two-thirds gave rises of between 2.5% and 3.5%.

New funding for video firm

Video Networks, the video-on-demand company yesterday confirmed a £102m funding deal from hi-tech investment group Digital Explosion. The agreement brings the company's total backing to more than £170m and will be used to fund the roll out of Video Network's HomeChoice service.

The service was launched yesterday across the capital.

webTitle: Troubled Hamleys confirms talks with mystery bidder

fields.headline: Troubled Hamleys confirms talks with mystery bidder
fields.trailText: A mystery bidder is stalking Hamleys, the world famous toy shop which recently admitted it had suffered a "terrible" year. The company yesterday said it was in preliminary discussions, understood to be with a venture capital firm. The news sent Hamleys' shares up 3.5p to 155p, valuing the business at £32.5m.
fields.body:
A mystery bidder is stalking Hamleys, the world famous toy shop which recently admitted it had suffered a "terrible" year. The company yesterday said it was in preliminary discussions, understood to be with a venture capital firm. The news sent Hamleys' shares up 3.5p to 155p, valuing the business at £32.5m.

Any offer would be opportunistic - the company's market value is near its all-time low. Hamleys has struggled to cope with the decline of traditional toys and the increasing popularity of electronic entertainment.

Several possible bidders immediately ruled themselves out. Retail entrepreneur Philip Green, who recently took over the department stores chain BhS, told friends he had "enough toys to play with".

Jon Moulton, chief executive of the venture capitalists Alchemy Partners, "knew nothing about it. Industry sources suggested that CVC, Cinven or Schroder Ventures could be behind the approach, or a foreign firm - Hamleys' brandname is known internationally.

Richard Ratner, an analyst at stockbroker Seymour Pierce, said that Hamleys' strength was its good reputation among customers. Its prospects for expansion, however, were limited: "It's a brand which is very difficult to replicate. Attempts to open more shops haven't really worked in the past."

Mr Ratner said he believed Hamleys chairman Howard Dyer would hold out for a price close to 200p - which would value the company at £42m.

In addition to its flagship shop in Regent Street, the company has four satellite stores and a small chain operating under the name Toystack. In the 14 months to March, the group made pre-tax profits of just £27,000 from sales of £51.8m.

Hamleys was founded in 1760 by a Cornishman, William Hamley, who set up shop in Holborn selling rag dolls, tin soldiers, hoops and wooden horses. The group has been through tough times before - it was briefly forced into liquidation after the economic depression of the 1920s. Hamleys was floated on the stock market five years ago.

Mr Dyer is due to stand down this summer. Simon Burke, a former boss of Virgin Megastores, was appointed chief executive last year to turn the business around. He has refurbished the ground floor of the Regent Street store and attempted to modernise the group's product range.

However, the group's boardroom has been tense in recent months. Among the non-executive directors is Jim Hodkinson, who was recently sacked as chief executive of womenswear retailer New Look. Mr Hodkinson was told of his fate by Mr Dyer, who is also chairman of New Look.

Summer bestsellers:

Pokémon cards Japanese collectables depicting exotic monsters

Billy the Bass A stuffed fish which sings when moved

Poo-Chi A metal dog which walks around and barks

Bob the Builder Hard hats, tools and soft toys featuring the TV cartoon character

fields.headline: DoCoMo builds £6bn war chest
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: NTT DoCoMo, the mobile phone division of Japan's largest company, is building a war chest for further expansion in Europe. Executives have confirmed that the group was considering a share issue that could raise £6.5bn.
fields.body:
NTT DoCoMo, the mobile phone division of Japan's largest company, is building a war chest for further expansion in Europe. Executives have confirmed that the group was considering a share issue that could raise £6.5bn.

Kiyoyuki Tsujimura, managing director of NTT DoCoMo's global business operations, said the company wanted to expand its popular mobile internet business around the world - but he declined to say how much capital it would raise.

NTT is the world's second biggest telecom company after Vodafone AirTouch, and has the largest number of internet mobile phone users - having signed up 8m in its first year of service.

Mr Tsujimura said that the company would launch its third-generation mobile technology in commercial service in May next year.

The service would first be introduced in Japan, and then roll out to other countries, "and we are looking to tie up with companies overseas as part of our expansion," he added.

This third generation technology will enable mobile handsets to be used as pocket internet terminals, with fast access to information and services such as online shopping.

Mr Tsujimura said third generation wireless technology was a greater catalyst for expansion than any high-priced acquisitions such as Vodafone AirTouch's £119bn bid for Mannesmann.

"We don't necessarily think that kind of investment strategy is right," he said.

However, some analysts have been critical of the recent minority investments made by DoCoMo in fellow mobile groups, arguing the company has not been aggressive enough in the competitive telecommunications market.

DoCoMo snared a 19% stake in Hutchison Whampoa's telecoms group for £281m last year and recently stumped up £3.22bn for a 15% share in Dutch mobile operator KPN Telecom.

The company also has interests in Malaysia and Brazil, and recently opened an office in China.

Analysts said DoCoMo's next target could be a 15% stake in Canada's Telesystem International Wireless, which could cost about £1.37bn.

TIW successfully bid for the biggest third generation mobile phone licence in the UK, paying £4.4bn. A stake in TIW would give DoCoMo a strong foothold in the UK market.

There have also been persistent reports that DoCoMo is targeting a similar size shareholding in two other companies: VoiceStream of the US and South Korea's largest phone operator, SK Telecom.

DoCoMo's decision to build a string of shareholdings in many global mobile companies may be part of its strategy to promote a technology known as wideband code division multiple access.

If this is adopted as the global standard for third generation mobile phone networks, it will enable DoCoMo's I-mode service - which provides internet access on mobile phones - to operate internationally on other companies' third generation networks.

I-mode is considered by many specialists to be a more advanced internet mobile service than the Wireless Application Protocol and General Packet Radio Service systems which allow internet on wireless handsets in Europe.

A £6.5bn equity issue would dilute the holding of DoCoMo's main shareholder, NTT, from its present 67% level.

Industry observers believe that having such a controlling stake in the hands of the former state owned telecoms monopoly has been a key factor preventing the company from adopting a more aggressive acquisition strategy.

Building blocks in global strategy

These are some of the key building blocks in NTT DoCoMo's developing global strategy:

 $410m for 19% stake in Hutchison Telecom, the international telecom empire of Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing.

 €5bn for 15%stake in the expansionist Dutch mobile operator KPN, which has more than 8m subscribers - mainly in the Netherlands and Germany.

 $1.9bn for 15% of TIW, the Canadian mobile operator which paid £4.4bn to win a third-generation UK mobile licence.

 $5bn is the likely price for 20%of Voicestream, one of the largest US mobile operators.

 A hefty price is expected for 10-20% of SK Telecom, South Korea's largest cellular operator.

fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Refocus Recruitment agency Spring Group yesterday announced plans to transform itself into an online recruitment firm focusing on the information technology sector despite full year losses of £6.4m. The company's move into the red surprised dealers - the shares fell nearly 15p to 132.5p.
fields.body:
Refocus Recruitment agency Spring Group yesterday announced plans to transform itself into an online recruitment firm focusing on the information technology sector despite full year losses of £6.4m. The company's move into the red surprised dealers - the shares fell nearly 15p to 132.5p.

 Online The number of employers recruiting graduates on the internet has doubled over the past year, a report showed yesterday. Two out of three graduate recruiters are now hiring staff online, while nine out of 10 students in their final year of university are looking for jobs on the net. Almost half of graduate recruiters believe the quality of applications is higher via the internet than through traditional methods.

 Hat sale Computer company IBM Corp has filed with the securities and exchange commission to sell 75,000 common shares, valued at $2.6m (£1.7m), of Red Hat , the Linux operating system and software company.

fields.headline: Come Hellstrom and high water
fields.standfirst: Ericsson chief lays it on the line
fields.trailText: What are we to make of yesterday's turmoil in the telecoms sector? The cause was clear enough. Ericsson chief executive officer Kurt Hellstrom suggestion that growth in the mobile phone industry could slow because of the high cost of third generation mobile licences.
fields.body:
What are we to make of yesterday's turmoil in the telecoms sector? The cause was clear enough. Ericsson chief executive officer Kurt Hellstrom suggestion that growth in the mobile phone industry could slow because of the high cost of third generation mobile licences.

Yet worries about the costs of the 3G licences are hardly new. And Ericsson was quick to let investors know it was not going back on previous forecasts for market growth - even if yesterday's statement was driven by the stock mar ket's reaction to Mr Hellstrom rather than any reappraisal of the mobile market. Nor could what Mr Hellstrom had to say about the 3G licences be described as apocalyptic.

His cautious approach (Ericsson disputes what he said constituted a warning) cannot be shrugged off. True enough the Ericsson chief is not the first to worry about the high cost of 3G licences. But much of the previous chorus of complaint has come from those involved directly in the various auctions. They have every reason to try to talk prices down. Ericsson's self interest - though still there - is less direct. As an equipment supplier its prospects are related to the actual impact of the prices being paid on the development on the market - rather than what the service providers claim they will have.

So what are the risks? First operators that win new licences will be under pressure to roll out their networks as soon as possible but at a time when the auction process itself may have left them strapped for cash. Second, they will want to sell as many services as possible for as much as possible - or at least as much as the market will bear - only to find their customers less than willing to play that particular game.

Even so it is important to retain a sense of proportion. As Mr Hellstrom acknowledged, growth will still be quite strong. Governments are scarcely killing the goose that lays the golden eggs - merely threatening to take away some of the lustre. The trouble is that investors do not appear to have been expecting any sort of setback to their expectations.

But taxpayers are not complaining. At least not yet. Yesterday the Dutch government followed Britain's example and announced it was cancelling a planned debt auction in anticipation of the proceeds from its 3G auction.

Mixed crop

Yesterday's crop of data on the British economy was something of a mixed bag. The trade figures hardly made encouraging reading but then they have not done for some time. The strength of the pound continued to exert its baleful influence on the trade in goods, the surplus on services held up, though there was a decline in income surplus to its lowest level for almost five years which could prove worrying if that turns out to be more than a blip.

Those who believe British interest rates have peaked will draw some comfort from the gross domestic product data but there must be lingering concerns about the strength of mortgage lending and consumer credit. It may be that the lending data is exaggerating the strength of consumer demand but not everyone in the City is persuaded there is no risk of an unpleasant surprise from that quarter.

Given the federal reserve's decision to keep US rates on hold on Wednesday and with the European Central Bank apparently contemplating a quiet summer after its last rise, the MPC is likely to adopt a similarly passive line next week without having to worry that it might be sandbagged by events elsewhere.

But there was enough in the latest figures to suggest it may be premature to conclude that the next move in British rates is more likely to be down than up.

French modesty

France Telecom has been sensibly modest in its expectations over the price its internet arm Wanadoo can be expected to command. Investors have seen what has happened to shares in T-Online in Germany and Terra Networks in Spain and are not going to get carried away when Wanadoo comes to market next month.

Instead it has chosen to disappoint those who were expecting it to command between €25bn (£16bn) and €30bn. A price range of between €17bn and €20bn should be enough - even in the face of scepticism about internet valuations - to allow upside potential for those who opt for Wanadoo shares.

France Telecom will not be too worried. It is not looking to raise cash from Wanadoo. Instead it wants an acquisition currency via a public listing for the internet company. In that sense, trying to screw the highest price out of the market is hardly paramount. If sentiment towards internet stocks recovers, Wanadoo shares will rise too. If it does not then the shares will look reasonably priced. Either way France Telecom will still be able to use the stock for acquisitions.
