fields.headline: Go-ahead expected for 'erotic gherkin'
fields.trailText: Norman Foster's controversial "erotic gherkin" City tower is edging off the drawing board and on to the streets of the Square Mile.
fields.body:
Norman Foster's controversial "erotic gherkin" City tower is edging off the drawing board and on to the streets of the Square Mile.

At a crucial meeting of the Corporation of London's planning and transportation committee next Tuesday, planning officers will once again recommend that plans for the all-glass, cigar shaped tower be approved. The tower has been caught in a spat between the Baltic Exchange, the original owners of the bomb-blasted site, and new proprietors Swiss Re, the insurance firm.

According to documents released yesterday, an "environmental statement" commissioned by Swiss Re gives the building the go-ahead, concluding that the "development is not likely to have significant effects on the environment".

However, the Baltic Exchange's chief executive, Jim Buckley, this week wrote to every member of the planning committee to urge them to vote against the abolition of the grade II* listed Baltic Exchange.

fields.headline: MoD's battlefield plan reviewed
fields.trailText: The government's £1.7bn programme to provide Britain's armed forces with a digital battlefield communications system is back in the melting pot after a leading ministry of defence committee this week said ministers should consider ordering a fresh competition for the contract.
fields.body:
The government's £1.7bn programme to provide Britain's armed forces with a digital battlefield communications system is back in the melting pot after a leading ministry of defence committee this week said ministers should consider ordering a fresh competition for the contract.

The Bowman project to replace the ageing Clansman radios with 47,000 military mo bile phones, including 3,500 high capacity data radios with access to the internet, is already eight years behind schedule and the new system may not be ready to enter service until 2005.

But a recent series of highly critical reports into the conduct of last year's war in Kosovo has underlined ministers' determination to bring in a secure system of battlefield communications as soon as possible by revealing that the Clansman radios were so defective they could be overheard by the Serbs.

The MoD's equipment acquisition committee of senior officials recommended to ministers that they either proceed with the programme put forward by the Archer consortium, the preferred bidder until now, or order a new competition. fields.headline: Hopes for new Hyder offer
fields.trailText: Nomura, the Japanese bank, yesterday came under renewed pressure to raise its £401m offer for Hyder after the Welsh utility's board advised shareholders not to accept either its bid or the higher £464m offer from Western Power Distribution of the US.
fields.body:
Nomura, the Japanese bank, yesterday came under renewed pressure to raise its £401m offer for Hyder after the Welsh utility's board advised shareholders not to accept either its bid or the higher £464m offer from Western Power Distribution of the US.

The Hyder board, which had previously recommended Nomura's 260p-a-share offer, said the American offer of 300p required further clarification of regulatory issues. Shareholders should not accept either offer until these were resolved.

WPD had said that its bid was "unlikely to raise any significant competition issues" while Nomura claimed to have won 18.8% acceptances for its lower offer.

Hyder owns both Welsh Water and the electricity company Swalec. The Department of Trade and Industry has cleared the Nomura bid, and has been urged by the Welsh Assembly to "repatriate" the WPD offer from scrutiny by the European Commission and refer it to the competition commission.

Welsh politicians favour the Japanese bid because Nomura would keep Hyder intact while WPD - which is really interested in the electricity supply business - would hive off the management and operation of the water business to United Utilities.

The government has until Thursday to ask Brussels to send the WPD bid back. If it does not do so, the commission could decide the issue eight days later.

Nomura has effectively been given 60 days to raise its bid or step aside. But Mike Kinski, whom Nomura has designated as Hyder's chief executive, indicated that an increased bid could be in the offing before all regulatory issues are cleared. Last night Guy Hands, chief executive of Nomura's investment arm, said the bank sympathised with the Hyder board decision.

"It is imperative that the UK takes into consideration the views of the Welsh assembly and makes a decision on the future of Hyder as it has very serious implications for Wales," he said. "We remain strongly committed to our bid for Hyder and hope that the company's future can soon be resolved to give security to the business, its employees and consumers."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Dillinger
fields.body:
Dillinger

(Max Nosseck, 1945)

7pm, Carlton Cinema

Brutally efficient crime potboiler with excellent credentials, introducing, as Dillinger, near-mythic Hollywood hard-man Lawrence Tierney, better known as mob boss Joe from Reservoir Dogs. The movie traces John Dillinger's career from stock market trader to public enemy number one, and his gunning down outside a theatre. It's a reliably heady mix of bullets, blondes and brutality, from the days when screen gangsters actually got on with some gangstering.

Titanic

(James Cameron, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

Three hours long, costing an awesome $200m-plus, and winner of 11 Oscars, this is a blockbuster in every sense. With dizzying special effects Cameron depicts the full tragedy of the Titanic's fateful meeting with the iceberg, but the film might have sunk without trace if the romance at the centre didn't hold. But Leonardo DiCaprio as penniless chancer Jack and Kate Winslet's rich, spirited Rose are irresistible as the star-crossed lovers.

Fire In The Sky

(Robert Lieberman, 1993)

8pm, 1.40am, Sky Cinema

Intelligent, low-key sci-fi drama based on an account of kidnap by aliens hovering around the Arizona desert in 1975. DB Sweeney plays Travis Walton, who goes missing, feared murdered, then turns up claiming a close encounter of the third kind. James Garner's sceptical cop maintains a down-to-earth presence, investigating smalltown politics as much as UFOs.

My Dinner With Andre

(Louis Malle, 1981)

4.05am, FilmFour

Two blokes sitting in a plush Manhattan restaurant jawing for 100 minutes wouldn't appear to be an inspired concept, but so it proves. Written by the two leads, this has Wallace Shawn as a Greenwich Village journeyman actor questioning the more illustrious André Gregory on his world view after spending the 70s on a mystic odyssey in Tibet, the Sahara and a Polish forest. Witty, entertaining and absorbing. "It seems to be improvised, but it was written to the dot," said Malle.

fields.headline: Wake up
fields.standfirst: Coffee Republic promises more espresso bars
fields.trailText: Britain's cafe culture received a boost yesterday after the Coffee Republic chain launched an £11m share issue to fund a further 80 outlets in the next two years.
fields.body:
Britain's cafe culture received a boost yesterday after the Coffee Republic chain launched an £11m share issue to fund a further 80 outlets in the next two years.

Coffee Republic said it is now the largest espresso bar chain in Britain, with 61 outlets compared with 36 in June last year. More than 40 are in London.

The company said the net proceeds of £10.25m from the placing and open offer of 57,894,737 new ordinary shares at 19p each will fund the roll-out of new cafes. In addition, founder and chief executive Bobby Hashemi and his sister Sahar are raising about £1m for themselves.

The group reported results for the year to March 31 with a loss before and after tax, in line with the board's expectations, of £2.7m from £1.8m. Turnover was up 140% to £12.5m.

Mr Hashemi said directors believed that the results reflected the popularity of the brand and validated the company's strategy. "The performance of the company's business since the beginning of April 2000 has been in line with the board's expectations," he said.

webTitle: Who are you? What the Sainsbury's ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Sainsbury's ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: The gorgeous Jamie Oliver is finishing off a pint in a pub with his mates. He asks if they fancy a ruby (er, Essex talk for curry, that is) and arranges to meet them all back at "Pete's". Cue Jamie dashing round a nearby Sainsbury's Local, athletically tossing various curry ingredients into his trolley. We then see him doing his thing in the kitchen, chopping and bashing and shoving everything into a Magimix while his mates play on their Sony PlayStation. He emerges from the kitchen, triumphant, with his spicy creation, but his mean pals pretend they don't fancy it much. They are, of course, only joking....
fields.body:
The ad: The gorgeous Jamie Oliver is finishing off a pint in a pub with his mates. He asks if they fancy a ruby (er, Essex talk for curry, that is) and arranges to meet them all back at "Pete's". Cue Jamie dashing round a nearby Sainsbury's Local, athletically tossing various curry ingredients into his trolley. We then see him doing his thing in the kitchen, chopping and bashing and shoving everything into a Magimix while his mates play on their Sony PlayStation. He emerges from the kitchen, triumphant, with his spicy creation, but his mean pals pretend they don't fancy it much. They are, of course, only joking....

The jargon: The Naked Chef was chosen because he encompasses "everything that Sainsbury's stands for in terms of making good food accessible to all", says agency Abbott Mead Vickers. He's basically "an everyday geezer with a passion for food", they say.

Personality: Apparently over nine million people shop at Sainsbury's every week - over half the adult population - so generalisations are a bit tricky. Jamie crosses classes and demographics, appealing to everyone from 16-year-old girls to 65-year-old men (for different reasons, obviously).

Financial status: Sainsbury's sits somewhere between Waitrose, with its posh prices and snooty south-east skew, and the rest of the nation's supermarkets like Tesco and Safeway. Given that these are permanently locked in price wars, you obviously don't need to be massively rich to shop there.

Telling lifestyle detail: Er, well, the chances are you've got one of the books (Jamie's two cookery titles are at number one and two in the bestsellers list) and you watch his TV programme (when it's on).

Other relevant data: Some of the blokes in the ad are Jamie's real mates but most are actors (the agency says they couldn't get all his mates together at one time). The commercial was also shot the week before he got married, and he had to work four nights in a row till 5am. Oh, and Jamie's spicy prawn curry really is delicious and dead easy - I made it.

fields.headline: Leader of the pack
fields.standfirst: Truly great sports commentators are few and far between: David Coleman, John Motson_ and David Duffield, Eurosport's Tour de France anchor.  It's about time his genius was recognised, reckons  Toby Scott
fields.trailText: Truly great sports commentators are few and far between: David Coleman, John Motson_ and David Duffield, Eurosport's Tour de France anchor. It's about time his genius was recognised, reckons Toby Scott
fields.body:
David Duffield is a name scarcely known outside Britain's small but dedicated peloton of cycling fans, but even if you can't see the point in watching oddly-shaped men on bikes for hours on end, David has something to offer every fan of great sports commentators. Because he has to cover all of the Tour de France. On his own.

The Tour de France is the world's hardest sporting event (probably), and certainly one of the longest: 3,630 kilometres of sweaty, muscled men, with less than two pounds of body fat between them, heaving away on bicycles that may look a lot like the one you had as a kid, but actually weigh less than a paperback book. All this takes the first three weeks of July, with only a couple of rest days and a few time trials, when the cyclists ride on their own.

Eurosport usefully has a two-hour "highlights" programme each evening. And the clue to David's greatness lies in the mention of the two-hour highlights package. If the highlights take two hours (minus the numerous ad breaks for German tyres and Swedish beer-flavoured coffee, or coffee-flavoured beer, I can't tell), how long is the whole damn thing? Several hours each day is the answer. And David is there on his own, commentating on the whole thing. Imagine Murray Walker doing a whole Grand Prix on his own, without Jim Rosenthal or that guy in the pit lane to help out. Imagine David Coleman covering the entire London Marathon without Brendan Foster to cover him while he goes to the toilet. This will give you some flavour of David's task, except that he's in France and entirely dependent on someone else for the pictures we get to see, plus he has to do it every day for three weeks.

So you wind up with commentary like this: "And here we are with 150km to go across this beautiful part of France. You can just see Lance Armstrong in the yellow jersey there just having a drink. But if you look just there to the left you can see the Chateau Berbiguiere, which you may remember me talking about during the '93 tour as I stopped there for dinner and had the most delicious meal. And now we can see Jan Ulrich trying to lead a breakaway off the front, but the Linda McCartney Vegetarian Sausage team are going to try and haul them back." And so on. I'm not sure when he eats or drinks, or breathes for that matter.

He approaches this Herculean struggle with an enthusiasm and background knowledge of the sport bordering on the insane. This is no bad thing, as, to be honest, there isn't a lot to talk about during a Tour stage. Sure, there are intermediate sprints, a climb or two, maybe a breakaway, and always the sprint finish, but most of the time it's a bunch of Lycra-clad foreigners cycling along in a densely-packed blob. Yes, they take turns at the front, occasionally pick up food or drinks, and a minute later throw the empty drink bottle at the crowd. Very infrequently you can see one of them peeing into an empty drink bottle before they chuck it into a hedge.

That's more or less it, for a good half day, every day. But David isn't allowed to be quiet (I have an image of a Eurosport producer sitting there with a gun to keep him talking, except I doubt Eurosport can afford a gun. Or a producer). So he talks about the riders, their history in recent races, their teams, their sponsors, their lives. Then he talks about the tactics, the bikes, the tyres, the bearings and the valves. Then he talks about the route, the interesting and historic local towns it goes through, the local produce, how much he enjoyed eating and drinking the local produce the night before. Then he talks about what he had for breakfast, what he had for lunch, and what he might have for dinner. Then he talks again about dinner the night before. And just when you're beginning to worry that he's going to talk about his childhood or his favourite teacher from primary school, there's an intermediate sprint to drag us back to the cycling.

My favourite moment came in the coverage of the recent Giro D'Italia, when, during a particularly bucolic portion, David told us he was going to be quiet so that we could listen to the beautiful birdsong. At that point, the director switched to an overhead shot, so we had 30 seconds of helicopter noise before we rejoined the race at ground level and David picked up his commentary again.

And just when you think it couldn't get any better, Stephen Roche arrives. Stephen is the best Irish rider of all time, and is James Hunt to David's Murray Walker. His speciality is turning up during the mountain stages and criticising the riders for stopping to put a jumper on for the descent. In his day, apparently, a bin-liner or piece of cardboard sufficed.

But it's David's show, hour after beautiful hour of it, and it's all that anyone should watch in the first three weeks of July.

The Tour de France begins tomorrow

webTitle: Behind the screen: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: With Keith Cheggers baring his (almost) all for the Channel 5 cameras a few weeks ago, readers might be forgiven for asking themselves: "That's all very well. But what of our lovely Noel , he of the jumpers and swap-tastic tactics of yester-year?"
fields.body:
With Keith Cheggers baring his (almost) all for the Channel 5 cameras a few weeks ago, readers might be forgiven for asking themselves: "That's all very well. But what of our lovely Noel , he of the jumpers and swap-tastic tactics of yester-year?" Isn't it universally accepted that Mr Edmonds is top dog as far as cheesy (sorry, Keith) showbiz is concerned?

Well, you might recall that our Noel slunk innocuously back to his Devon "castle" (he tells me it's only a large house) about this time last year after a high-profile falling-out with BBC1 controller Peter Salmon. The row was all about Noel's House Party, his erstwhile Saturday night extravaganza staged from the hilariously named Crinkley Bottom.

The BBC cancelled the show, and Noel still maintains they weren't willing to pay enough for it. Whichever side's right or wrong, we care not. What's of real behind-the-scenes interest is what Noel's doing now. Charitable deeds? Well, he seems to pursue all philanthropic activity beyond the often unhelpful glare of the media. What he will go public for these days is to plug the radio group UBC - of which he owns around four per cent - which is floating on the alternative investment market this summer at a cool £30m. He's also launching a business-to-business TV channel. But the question all 1970s kids want answered is: will Noel be making a comeback on-screen?

And the answer is no. Or probably not. He'd joked about doing a late-night, nude version of Swap Shop (perhaps Channel 5 would be interested?). But Cheggers has given us enough wobbly flesh on primetime to see us through this year's silly season.

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Stoned and dethroned
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: It isn't just the planet that's shrinking. The entire fabric of history is being squashed and filleted too, as teams of egotistical "experts" scour the globe for dramatic discoveries that will put their name in lights, or at least in funds. History and archaeology have become as competitive as international sport or corporate takeover battles.
fields.body:
It isn't just the planet that's shrinking. The entire fabric of history is being squashed and filleted too, as teams of egotistical "experts" scour the globe for dramatic discoveries that will put their name in lights, or at least in funds. History and archaeology have become as competitive as international sport or corporate takeover battles.

All this became painfully apparent during the Mysteries Of Lost Empires film about Easter Island (C4). "The remotest inhabited land on earth" was invaded by a noisy and argumentative landing party of archaeologists, architects and historians who wanted to try out their own pet theories about how the islanders managed to move and position their extraordinary stone statues a millennium or two ago. Apparently 900 stone figures were erected over a 500-year period, measuring up to 30ft high and sometimes weighing 65 tons.

There are no written records to draw on, only an oral tradition, according to which the statues simply got up and walked across the island. Our 21st-century experts couldn't get the statues to replicate this feat, and instead they surmised that the figures had been tied to wooden sleds and dragged along rails made from logs.

Elbowing her way in front of the camera as often as possible was Jo Anne Van Tilburg, inventor of the log-rolling thesis. Jo Anne was keen to pontificate about the cultural import of the statues, and they way they embodied the ancestral values of the Easter Islanders; what she was really interested in was showing off in front of her peers. So when Wyoming architect Vince Lee devised what looked like a better method of moving the statues using levers instead of just dragging them, Jo Anne grew petulant. "It's a mess," she spat, indicating Vince's efforts. "That's a disaster."

Tempers frayed. People started swearing at each other. "Architects and engineers turn from impartial observers into impassioned advocates of their own theories," noted the commentary, with admirable restraint. In the end, nothing was proved, except that given enough opportunity the squabbling scientists would almost certainly imitate the fate of the Easter islanders themselves. Overpopulation had provoked war among rival clans, who each tried to acquire greater spiritual power by building more and more statues. They became so obsessed with this that they completely deforested the island and forgot to grow enough food. It was a warning from history about ego, obsession and naked ambition.

Guns And Roses (BBC1) is not a docusoap, according to its producer Helen Thomas, but she's only saying that because commissioning editors have had to accept that the docusoap genre now looks so ridiculous that even viewers have started to notice. Besides, if it wasn't a docusoap, it wouldn't have a trailer for next week's instalment tacked on the end ("...next week, an ankle injury puts Kate's future in doubt!") Guns And Roses is the umpteenth TV programme to dog the footsteps of a bunch of army recruits as they struggle against institutionalised humiliation and enforced boot-polishing, hoping to become officers. The "new" spin here is that the recruits are female.

In contrast to the grim treatment we've seen dished out to Royal Marines and paratroopers, the women have it pretty soft. True, they get shouted at a lot by Marie, the butch staff sergeant ("I'M NOT YOUR MATE, I'M YOUR STAFF SERGEANT!" she bawled at ditsy Katie Bowes-Crick), but a bit of open-air map reading and a spot of jogging scarcely resembles adequate preparation for waging war against merciless Balkan warlords. Most of the recruits seem to be posh, horsey gels seeking an amusing diversion before they settle down with a disgustingly rich City bond trader.

It's still a man's life in rally driving, judging by Foot In The Door 's film about would-be rally technicians (BBC2). Three spotty youths were being tried out by David Richards' Prodrive outfit, changing sump guards and brake callipers on Richard Burns' souped-up Subaru as it ploughed messily around Spain's Catalunya course. The film was careful not to judge any of the applicants too harshly, but Richards got straight to the point when he made his choice. "Nick, it's yours," he said, as if whipping off a protesting Elastoplast.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: It would be easier to list the instruments Hermeto Pascoal does not play. Self-taught, he's at home on piano, guitar, sax, accordion or flute.
fields.body:
It would be easier to list the instruments Hermeto Pascoal does not play. Self-taught, he's at home on piano, guitar, sax, accordion or flute. Unlike Julian Joseph's earlier Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3), this will be live next week at London's Barbican Centre. The Brazilian's best-remembered performances outside his own country are probably the 60s sessions with Miles Davis. Tracks retrieved for this tribute prove that he was also an early fusion pioneer.

Sarah Lefanu visits one of London's oddest museums in Twenty Minutes: Cabinet Of Curiosities (8.0pm, Radio 3). The Hunterian Museum at the Royal College of Surgeons, founded by an 18th-century anatomist, lost many of its original exhibits to a wartime bomb. But it still has 3,500 of the founder's specimens, including a skeleton of an Irish giant and two extinct Indian Ocean birds, ingeniously articulated for osteologic study.

webTitle: How can I break free from my emotionally unstable relatives?

fields.headline: How can I break free from my emotionally unstable relatives?
fields.body:
My father left home when I was 11 and since then my happiness has been governed by my mother's emotional state. I would often come home from school to find her in tears or drunk. As an adult I have witnessed her further crises, including years of binge drinking, a divorce, spells of agoraphobia, being unable to cope with her job and, for the past 15 years, the problems she has had looking after her own mother. But lately things have greatly improved for her - my grandmother is living happily in sheltered accommodation and mum has moved into a more easily managed bungalow. She rang recently though, and told me she had become agoraphobic again. Then my grandmother phoned in tears saying: "I think your mother is heading for a breakdown." She said she didn't want me to think it was her own fault because of the years of stress of looking after her. I am now 11 weeks pregnant having had a near miscarriage earlier on (my mother is aware). I feel I have to be selfish and distance myself from these two demanding women. To be brutal, I just want them to stop bothering me. How can I acheive this without causing them too much distress? They both talk in veiled tones about suicide. Should I stop worrying and just let them get on with it?

Make a clean break

Clearly you love your mother and grandmother but are they abusing that? Like you, my mother's emotional stability had a major impact on me. From the age of nine, I was her main confidante, mostly about her deep unhappiness and loneliness within a violent marriage. Like many children abused in this way, I ended up with what a counsellor later called "an over-developed sense of responsibility".

I loved my mother (still do) but while we also enjoyed each other's company, her manipulation gradually became the major part of our relationship. For 20 years, I persisted in trying to "fix" her life, trying to help her to become less isolated and lonely. At 29, after running out of ideas and patience with her regular breakdowns, self-pity and empty apologies, I realised she was deliberately maintaining her own misery and would always resist any improvements.

Thereafter, I saw her past behaviour in a very different light. She'd set me up several times with carefully planted suicide notes and verbal suicide threats during my teens when we lived alone together. I discovered she never gave my brothers any hint of unhappiness. My education had collapsed under the strain of carrying her, so the damage done has been far-reaching. She sabotaged any attempted discussion, refusing to take any responsibility for her own happiness and blaming anyone else she could for her problems.

I wrote to her explaining the damage done over the years by her abusive behaviour and while I loved her, I could no longer be in her life. Within two years, I had broken free of her and moved to another country. We have no contact now at all. As painful as it has been, it was the only way.
Julia McKiernan, London

Call the Samaritans

Give your mother and your grandmother the telephone number of the Samaritans. Send them birthday and Christmas cards (and presents if you want and can afford to). Visit each of them two or three times a year if you choose. Buy yourself an answering machine and screen telephone calls. Resist their emotional blackmail and enjoy your baby and the rest of your life. Good luck!
Alison Harrop, Leicestershire

Be selfish like them

You need to think of yourself and your unborn child. Your mother and grandmother should be offering emotional support and encouragement to you, not the other way around. If they have lived their lives in such negative and problematic ways it is nothing to do with you, it was their choice.

Enjoy your pregnancy, take good care of yourself and look forward to the immense pleasures and the occasional heartaches of bringing up a child, one of the most fulfilling and important jobs you will ever do.

Be selfish because that is precisely what they are.
Name and address withheld

Think of your baby

Think of what you would wish your coming child to do in similar circumstances. I don't think you would regard the imposition of life upon him or her as entitling you to lifetime care and oversight. Being disabled and in my 70s, I am not owed anything!

You may have to appear brutal. Social services and doctors may assume that you will take responsibility. Write to them saying that you are no longer willing or able to do so. They expected me, widowed, with two teenagers, to give up my job to look after my geriatric mother. I refused.

When I was a student, my girlfriend had looked after her 60-year-old, bed-ridden mother for several years. I persuaded her to call in help from the local psychiatric hospital. Within minutes of the two doctors arriving the mother was in animated conversation with them both. Later that evening, when we rang the hospital, we were told that she was already making recommendations for reorganisation of the ward. She insisted on staying on long enough to get her teeth fixed to avoid the then very modest NHS dental charges "outside", then emerged to move house, take up ballroom dancing and lead an active social life for years.

It may seem like testing to destruction, but if you repeat your mother's cycle, what will your family's future be?
Name and address withheld

Don't run to help

Distancing yourself from your mother and grandmother is by no means selfish. You deserve a chance to govern your own feelings instead of being dragged along with them as they struggle to keep their own emotions on an even keel.

Your mother in particular sounds vulnerable, and needs professional help. The pressure on you will be released if she has somebody else to help her resolve her issues.

If you feel unable to confront your mother and grandmother, there are several practical solutions for you to take control of the situation without causing hurt or upset. First, do not reinforce your mother's behaviour by cancelling plans in order to attend to her when she is being demanding or hysterical. Tell her that you will discuss her problems with her at a time which is convenient with you, or when she is less upset. She will gradually learn to become less dependent on you and will hopefully learn to to take a bit more responsibility for herself.

If the above fails, you could try setting up your phone so that the number of the incoming caller is displayed. This will allow you to answer your mothers and grandmothers calls only when you feel as though you can cope with a potentially distressing conversation.
Name and address withheld

Next week

After 25 years of an outwardly contented marriage and where neither partner has had other relationships, I find myself in love with another unattached woman and she with me. She is, and now was, one of my wife's best friends. My wife, very successful in her job (with attendant single-mindedness and fatigue), closed the bedroom door many years ago, before our much loved but mechanically conceived children (now 15, 13 and 10) were born. We are friends, rather than lovers, with sex being the one area my wife will not discuss.

I had hoped that "things would get better". I have willingly been the practical housemaker with my job taking second place. I now feel newly awake and see my future away from my wife, who has been told of the new relationship. Unamused, she tolerates it within limits while regarding her former friend as a home destroyer. A difficult atmosphere prevails. All three parties are concerned about the effects of a break-up on the children. I'm from a single parent home.

With great restraint shown, the new relationship is not yet physical although my wife does not believe this. Should I take cold showers and pull back from something that promises me much for the sake of the children? Or what?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: euro20bn price tag on Wanadoo
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: France Telecom yesterday put a market price tag of up to euro20bn (£13bn) on its internet arm, Wanadoo, well below initial expectations.
fields.body:
France Telecom yesterday put a market price tag of up to euro20bn (£13bn) on its internet arm, Wanadoo, well below initial expectations.

The price range of between euro17 and euro20 a share is seen as a "safety first" ploy given the recent disenchantment of investors about internet valuations.

The point was implicitly acknowledged by France Telecom's chairman, Michel Bon, who said yesterday: "In order that our shareholders remain loyal we have to offer them sufficient margin for upside."

At the height of the boom in internet stocks earlier this year, Wanadoo had been expected to command a market price tag of up to euro30bn and despite the recent re-evaluation of the sector, was still thought to be worth euro25bn.

"I think they are playing it safe. People are still wary of internet IPOs after the pull back we have seen in some valuations and clearly France Telecom wants this to be a suc cess," said a Paris-based analyst.

France Telecom is offering only 10% of Wanadoo shares to investors - a move which is likely to help support the price after the flotation next month - but will use its equity to make acquisitions.

Yesterday France Telecom said it was keen to establish Wanadoo among the top three European internet access providers within the next three years and was aiming to increase its subscriber base from 500,000 to 3m.

webTitle: Antfactory raises another $150m and eyes $1bn float

fields.headline: Antfactory raises another $150m and eyes $1bn float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Antfactory, the internet investment fund that specialises in supporting the online strategies of old economy companies, has raised a further $150m (£98m) in new funds and is poised to announce a number of alliances with leading stock-market listed UK companies.
fields.body:
Antfactory, the internet investment fund that specialises in supporting the online strategies of old economy companies, has raised a further $150m (£98m) in new funds and is poised to announce a number of alliances with leading stock-market listed UK companies.

The London-based company has now raised $545m in private equity over the past nine months. If the stock market's appetite for technology stocks improves, it is likely to seek a flotation later in the year valuing it at around $1bn.

Chief executive Harpal Randhawa said: "At the moment we're raising money from value added investors but flotation is always an option."

Investors in the new round include the existing shareholders Whitney & Co, Citicorp Venture Capital and CVC Capital Partners. First-time investors include Allianz Capital Partners, Moore Capital Management and Hopa, which is the controlling shareholder in Telecom Italia.

The funding was completed despite a general cooling among investors' appetite for internet investment and incubator companies.

Antfactory was founded byformer investment bankers and technology experts last year to identify ways in which new economy businesses can partner with existing companies, building on assets like their customer bases, brands and supply chains.

One of its best known investments is in Whittards, the coffee shop operator. Antfactory took a 25% stake earlier this year and is helping it to develop an ambitious global e-commerce division.

Dozens of internet invest ment and incubator companies have emerged over the past year to satisfy investor demand for technology stocks and entrepreneurs' needs for backing. Several, like New Media Spark, JellyWorks and Convergence Holdings have listed on the stock market. However, with market sentiment changing, many are now looking to consolidate with European and US firms.

Mr Randhawa insists that his firm is different. "E-commerce is a non-trivial business. Investing in two people with a good idea and a website does not constitute backing a business. You need customers and you either have to buy them or partner 0someone who has them.

"We believe you need to partner with old economy companies and leverage their brands, supply chains and customer bases. We hope to announce several major deals soon."

Antfactory currently has investments in 20 firms, of which 13 are UK-based.

fields.headline: Police eject player's father
fields.standfirst: Wimbledon 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Damir Dokic, the father of Australian Wimbledon competitor Jelena Dokic, was yesterday detained and interviewed by police after reports that he was drunk and abusive and smashed a journalist's telephone shortly after his daughter's victory on court number five.
fields.body:
Damir Dokic, the father of Australian Wimbledon competitor Jelena Dokic, was yesterday detained and interviewed by police after reports that he was drunk and abusive and smashed a journalist's telephone shortly after his daughter's victory on court number five.

Mr Dokic, who has been dubbed the "tennis father from hell" after landing himself in trouble during tournaments on previous occasions, had been drinking heavily prior to the match and was then seen walking around Wimbledon waving a cross of St George and shouting slogans.

As bemused tennis fans looked on, Mr Dokic approached the main press building where he became involved in a heated conversation with journalists.

Shouting things such as "the Women's Tennis Association are fascists and political" and "the Queen is for democracy, everything else in this country is fascist", Mr Dokic is then reported to have smashed a journalist's mobile telephone before being taken away by officers to the police room.

He was released without charge and officers escorted Mr Dokic out of the courts, but tournament organisers said that he would be free to return as he had not been charged with any offence.

Last year, Mr Dokic hit the headlines after he staged a sit-down protest in the street moments after being ejected from a tennis tournament in Birmingham in which his daughter had been playing. He was accused of barracking his daughter's opponents during matches and later accused tournament organisers of being Nazis.

It followed complaints from players about the presence of mothers in locker rooms prior to matches. Their influence over their daughters at tournaments has caused tension in locker rooms and the ban is to be extended to all the leading tennis tournaments.

The Association of Tennis Professionals, which governs the men's game, has not asked for a similar ban and its players will be allowed to have one non-playing guest in locker rooms prior to matches.

The WTA said yesterday: "We have asked all grand slam events to respect our request. Despite reports to the contrary this decision was not targeted at mothers but all non-player parties, including coaches, family and friends."

Some of the world's leading players, including Martina Hingis, who is constantly accompanied by her mother Melanie Molitor, and Anna Kournikova, whose mother Alla is an ever present in locker rooms, will be affected by the ban.

The mothers watch all their daughters' matches, travel the world with them during the season, sit in on press conferences, and have been criticised for their forceful influence over them.

Most players at Wimbledon yesterday agreed with the ban.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The US federal reserve may have managed to avoid upsetting the markets overnight, leaving the cost of American borrowing unchanged, but the pressure was still on London.
fields.body:
The US federal reserve may have managed to avoid upsetting the markets overnight, leaving the cost of American borrowing unchanged, but the pressure was still on London.

Having dipped as low as 6,221 points, the FTSE 100 index finally came to rest at 6,239, down 74.5 points.

There were declines in the telecoms sector, and in particular, British Telecom , which lost 23p to 858p - and now rests more than 40% below its peak at the turn of the year. The talk in market is all about investment bankers Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, which earlier this week bought the government's remaining 11.9m block of BT shares in a bought deal at 925p a piece.

The pressure on the stock since then has left Schroder Salomon unable to complete the institutional placing which would have completed the bought deal - and left the investment bank with a sizeable paper loss.

But elsewhere in the sector there were some substantially bigger losses, such as Cable & Wireless , which shed 72p to £10.46, Energis (down 251p at £23.75) and Colt Telecom (off 146p at £21.44). Dealers were clearly rattled by the comments from Kurt Hellstrom, head of Ericsson, who warned that growth in the mobile market would slow due to the high charges for new licences.

With the phone companies taking a bashing, traders decided to kick some other hi-tech issues. The result was 72.5p off ARM Holdings to 676.5p, while Guardian IT gave up 115p to £13 and Marconi ran back from 945p to 876p.

Against this, the Anglo-Dutch household products combine Reckitt Benckiser was supported by analysts at Deutsche Bank, who reiterated "buy" advice to their clients and slapped a price target of 850p on the shares. The market quote responded with a 39p rise to 754p.

Lower down the corporate scale, Advanced Technology , which provides technology for the remote reading of various meters, jumped 38.5p to 310p after news that it is in reverse takeover talks with a private firm called Ramar Technology.

Automotive design and engineering group Hawtal Whiting crashed from 49p to a low of 23p before finishing the day 11.5p lower at 37.5p. Followers panicked after news that it will be restating its 1999 profits figure from £2.5m to £1.2m. The company said that since the year-end figures were released in May it had emerged that some long-term contracts would be less profitable than expected. Also, the group said it was now looking at its "strategic options" - at putting itself up for sale, that is.

webTitle: Shepherds wanted to watch PPL flock

fields.headline: Shepherds wanted to watch PPL flock
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Anyone looking for a shift to a more mellow career should consider approaching PPL Therapeutics, the biotechnology company which specialises in cloning animals.
fields.body:
Anyone looking for a shift to a more mellow career should consider approaching PPL Therapeutics, the biotechnology company which specialises in cloning animals.

PPL Therapeutics has cloned so many sheep that it is advertising for shepherds. The company pays "above average agricultural rates" and the job is crucial - the group's animals need to be in peak condition so they produce plenty of milk, containing therapeutic human proteins.

The latest explosion in the group's animal population is due to research on a more precise method of genetic engineering, which allows PPL to deliver genes to a specific point on the sheep chromosome. This could mean the company can switch specific characteristics on and off and lead to the creation of bespoke, tailor-made animals.

The discovery raises a whole range of ethical questions but, as far as PPL is concerned, the aim is to grow human organs in animals - to avoid human rejection of such organs, certain animal genes need to be "knocked out".

Publicity about this development aroused investors' enthusiasm, sending PPL's shares up 13p to 179p in trading yesterday.

However, the prospect of commercially producing human organs is such a long way off that it has little bearing on the underlying investment case.

The real issue which has depressed PPL's shares for over a year is that the company desperately needs a partner to commercialise its lead product, a protein called AAT.

This is produced in the milk of transgenic sheep, and is used to treat either cystic fibrosis or a congenital defi ciency of AAT which affects about 200,000 people in Europe and the United States.

PPL needs a partner to pay for phase three trials of AAT, and for marketing of the product. The timing is tight - PPL is losing £800,000 a month and has under a year's cash left.

Chief executive Ron James has said he expected to complete a deal by mid-summer. The terms will be closely scrutinised - PPL ought to get royalties of about 15% to 18% on AAT sales but negotiations are difficult because potential partners know that the company is in a corner. Critics have suggested that the relatively small market for AAT could put off big drugs groups.

It will take at least a further 18 months to get AAT on the market. The group needs a big up-front payment - perhaps £5m - from its partner to tide it over.

Without a partner, PPL will struggle to raise any more cash on the market and the prospects for its "Dolly the sheep" technology look bleak.

fields.headline: Jazz FM
fields.trailText: Jazz FM is playing a new tune and the market likes it. Shares in the company that provides the listening for funksters in the 25-45 age bracket hade risen from 82.5p on Tuesday to 115.5p by last night.
fields.body:
Jazz FM is playing a new tune and the market likes it. Shares in the company that provides the listening for funksters in the 25-45 age bracket hade risen from 82.5p on Tuesday to 115.5p by last night.

Driving the movement is a recent deal for Jazz FM 102.2 to be broadcast on London's second digital multiplex, operated by Switchdigital. The agreement lasts 12 years but what is also exciting the City is that the deal automatically renews its London analogue license for a further seven years.

Jazz fans can now look forward to 1940s bebop, Miles Davis and Herbie Hancock, at least until 2009. Analysts say the audience is key to company's success. It is biased towards professional ABC1s and they are a dedicated bunch that advertisers love.

Around 15m people in Britain express a positive interest in jazz, the company claims, with many of them regularly attending live events. Even if this figure is a little on the high side, and it seems unlikely that quite so many people are susceptible to the sometimes acquired taste of jazz, the market is big and possibly growing.

A record label has been launched and several books published to leverage the customer base and improve brand awareness.

Use of the internet could also allow listeners to choose old favourites on a pay-per-listen basis. Radio is billed as an internet success story by most commentators who believe it can bypass restrictive franchises. The Jazz FM site has found that 85% of the visitors come from abroad.

A deal with Clear Channel International has also eased structural problems, according to brokers Williams de Broe. The US firm took a 31% stake and Jazz FM should break even in the next financial year after last year's pre-tax loss of £1.18m.

But is the station already fully valued? Williams De Broe believes the fair value of a share is 100p, but thinks they may be worth 120p assuming growth continues. Worth holding, but not gambling the record collection on.

webTitle: Europe votes for a stop in nuclear waste reprocessing

fields.headline: Europe votes for a stop in nuclear waste reprocessing
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Britain and France were told yesterday by 12 European neighbours to end reprocessing and so prevent further radioactive discharges into the sea.
fields.body:
Britain and France were told yesterday by 12 European neighbours to end reprocessing and so prevent further radioactive discharges into the sea.

The 12 to nil vote, with Britain and France abstaining, was at the Ospar convention meeting in Copenhagan, which controls pollution in the north-east Atlantic, North sea and Irish sea.

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment said the government would refuse to be bound by the decision.

Four countries, with contracts with British Nuclear Fuels to reprocess spent nuclear fuel at the Thorp plant at Sellafield in Cumbria, backed the Danish resolution. Germany, Switzerland, Sweden and Spain have no use for the plutonium and uranium that reprocessing spent fuel produces and realise storing it would be cheaper.

The original Danish proposal demanded an immediate end to reprocessing but the resolution was amended to say discharges "shall be reviewed as a matter of priority" with a view to "dry storage".

The rules of the Ospar convention mean a 75% majority is needed from the 15 member countries - achieved by the Danish resolution - to make a vote legally binding.

But the rules also state if a country votes against, or abstains, it is not legally bound by the decision.

In London, the Department of the Environment issued a statement pointing this out. "It is a point of principle that Europe does not have the right to tell us whether we can reprocess or not," it said.

BNFL was equally dismissive. It said: "Reprocessing is a commercial matter between BNFL and its customers."

UK delegates in Copenhagan tried to further water down the Danish proposal without success and issued a statement saying they were forced to abstain.

In 1998, at a meeting of the Ospar convention in Sintra, Portugal, Britain and France had agreed to cut discharges to "close to zero" by 2020.

A week ago officials published a plan of how this was to be achieved, hoping it would be enough to prevent a hostile vote in Copenhagan.

Bridget Woodman from Greenpeace said: "Even though the UK and France can rightly claim it is not legally binding it makes their position morally very difficult - they are going against the wishes of 12 neighbours who want this contamination to stop."

The government is reviewing the options for the state-owned industry having already abandoned plans to part privatise it until after the election. The company's critics and some of its own executives believe its future lies in nuclear waste management rather than reprocessing.

webTitle: Minister to take politics out of NHS mergers

fields.headline: Minister to take politics out of NHS mergers
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government is preparing an attempt to depoliticise the National Health Service by passing key decisions about hospital mergers and bed places to an independent panel of doctors, nurses, managers and patient representatives.
fields.body:
The government is preparing an attempt to depoliticise the National Health Service by passing key decisions about hospital mergers and bed places to an independent panel of doctors, nurses, managers and patient representatives.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is expected to announce today that ministers will accept recommendations from this new national hospital beds panel in all but exceptional circumstances.

He regards the move as a decentralisation of power similar to Gordon Brown's decision in 1997 to devolve control of interest rates to the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.

The scheme will be outlined by Mr Milburn in a speech to the NHS Confederation in Glasgow, preparing the way for publication of a new national plan for the health service at the end of next month.

The independent panel will be "tasked with ensuring the NHS achieves ministers' commitment for delivering more beds in the whole care system".

Downing Street sources said ministers were determined to get rid of procedures that contributed to the NHS losing 40,000 hospital beds between 1987 and 1997.

Frequently proposals for hospital closures, mergers and reorganisations encountered local objections and were referred to Whitehall for resolution.

Over the years decisions were taken on individual applications without an effective check on regional bed supply for patients in hospital and social care.

"We have had a patchwork of decisions with no national co-ordination," the source said. "The budget and radical NHS reforms in the national plan will go a long way to delivering Alan Milburn's commitment to provide more beds in the health care system."

The independent beds panel will make recommendations on all proposals for hospital reorganisations. Although it will be expected to follow government health policies and work within budgets set by the Treasury, it will be told to act independently of ministers. A third of the panel will be made up of doctors, nurses and representatives of the royal colleges. A third will be representatives of patients, and a third of high achieving health service managers.

"The panel will make recommendations to approve or reject mergers or reorganisations. The secretary of state will accept recommendations in all but most exception circumstances," the source said.

Government plans to introduce performance incentives for staff in the NHS received unexpected backing yesterday from health service managers.

Ministers want to offer extra rewards for staff achieving productivity targets, but have run into stiff resistance from doctors' and nurses' leaders.

The first encouragement for ministers to include performance incentives in the forthcoming national health plan came in a poll of about 1,000 senior managers and trust representatives at the NHS Confederation conference. About 80% supported non-pay incentives as a way of motivating staff to perform better and 69% approved of financial bonuses to reward groups of staff who were performing well. There was less support for individual pay incentives, with 45% backing performance-related pay similar to the scheme being introduced for teachers.

But the decision by nearly half the managers to entertain this idea astonished leaders of the NHS Confederation, who have been arguing against any form of financial incentives. Andrew Foster, the confederation's policy director, said staff were opposed to rewards that might bring pecuniary benefit to themselves at the expense of patient care. Experimental team bonuses to reduce sickness absence resulted in staff coming to work when they were ill.

The confederation is urging the government to stick to non-pay incentives that would offer extra training, amenities and equipment to successful health service teams. Neil McKay, NHS deputy chief executive, told the conference that new incentives were needed "at every level" for organisations, individuals and teams.

webTitle: Ballerina denies backing book linking dance pressure and anorexia

fields.headline: Ballerina denies backing book linking dance pressure and anorexia
fields.trailText: The Royal Ballet's principal ballerina, Deborah Bull, yesterday withdrew from the launch of a controversial book, which alleges young dancers are pressured into anorexia, after claiming surrounding publicity suggested she had endorsed it.
fields.body:
The Royal Ballet's principal ballerina, Deborah Bull, yesterday withdrew from the launch of a controversial book, which alleges young dancers are pressured into anorexia, after claiming surrounding publicity suggested she had endorsed it.

She said the suggestion was misrepresentative and an "abuse of her goodwill".

Ms Bull had been due to attend the launch of The Student Dancer, by the University of Hertfordshire academic and psychotherapist Julia Buckroyd, at the London Contemporary Dance School last night.

She pulled out after a university press release claimed she backed the author's call for "a radical reform of dance training", and supported the claim that current training was "too rigorous, threatening young people's health".

Last night, Ms Bull, 37, denied she had been due to attend the launch other than as a guest - despite her name ap pearing on invitations issued by the publisher, Dance World.

"As far as I was concerned, I was going, along with the rest of the dance world, to the launch of an academic book on dance training to see what it was all about. I said I would be there and, if my name on the invitation helped to get people along, that was fine.

"I was then surprised to see my name used by a university press office with which I have had no relationship at all, and to endorsing claims I have never commented on."

But the University of Hertfordshire insisted it had believed she was sympathetic to Ms Buckroyd's views.

A source close to the publishers suggested Ms Bull had been forced to withdraw because of pressure from the Royal Ballet, which yesterday refused to comment, but the ballerina said this claim was "ludicrous".

"There's absolutely no row at the Royal Ballet and I find it upsetting that they should be dragged into this," she said.

fields.headline: Yesterday day, bad day
fields.trailText: Farewell of day
fields.body:
Farewell of day

The Liberal Democrat constitutional affairs spokesman and one-time SDP leader, Robert Maclennan, is to stand down from Westminster at the next election, he announced. The former Labour minister has had an unbroken 34-year stint representing Caithness, Sutherland and latterly Easter Ross.

webTitle: Labour set for unions deal on minimum pay changes

fields.headline: Labour set for unions deal on minimum pay changes
fields.standfirst:
Manifesto conflicts remain over voting reform and asylum vouchers
More about the minimum wage
The minimum wage explained
fields.trailText: Annual rises in the minimum wage and a shake-up of the lower youth rates are set to be offered to union leaders in Labour's election manifesto.
fields.body:
Annual rises in the minimum wage and a shake-up of the lower youth rates are set to be offered to union leaders in Labour's election manifesto.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, signalled yesterday during discussions ahead of meetings next weekend that the government is prepared to beef up one of Labour's most popular policies.

Agreeing an annual review by the low pay commission and looking again at the level for younger people, possibly counting 21-year-olds as adults, could win widespread popular support.

Unions, led by Unison, want the main rate, due to go up 10p to £3.70 an hour in October, increased to £5, but Downing Street and the Treasury fear such a figure would cost jobs.

Senior Labour figures hope that a deal can be reached to avoid a confrontation, after the party leadership and the unions failed to resolve conflicts over the contents of the party's planned second term manifesto, at a meeting which was later described by the unions as frustrating and bruising.

But the party hierarchy did accept more than 200 amend ments from unions and constituencies to the six policy documents drafted by the party.

Anxious to show that the policy forum process, pioneered by Neil Kinnock and the then general secretary Larry Whitty, is producing ideas from the grassroots, the leadership claimed yesterday that the acceptance of the amendments showed that the process was working.

There were still more than 200 amendments rejected by the leadership, which are likely to be the subject of hard bargaining between now and the policy forum on July 7.

Labour sources said the amendments accepted by the policy commission included new commitments to end the commercial exploitation of women; tighter controls on arms brokers, especially in sub-Saharan Africa; and the creation of a new criminal offence for UK citizens to bribe or seek to bribe officials when overseas.

In a move that will delight overseas charity campaigners, the leadership has also accepted an amendment to give an increasing proportion of development resources to primary education.

Party sources said that further amendments would be accepted in the final round of arm twisting before the forum gathers in Exeter. The party leadership admitted that yesterday's meeting meant that it still faced big challenges from the grassroots and the unions over such issues as electoral reform, asylum seeker vouchers, the level of the exchange rate, and EU information disclosure directives to workers.

Some unions are also pushing for a restoration of the link between pensions and earnings.

The AEEU engineering union is still pressing for the Bank of England to be given a dual mandate, which would mean that its interest rate policy was designed to create jobs, as well as to lower the rate of inflation.

In a move that will be a relief to the party leadership, union sources were suggesting that they will not push hard to drop the party pledge to hold a referendum on electoral reform after the election.

The referendum pledge is seen inside Downing Street as vital to retaining good relations with the Liberal Democrats ahead of the election, and encouraging anti-Tory tactical voting.

One union source said: "As long as the leadership don't try to play silly buggers over other issues, we won't rub their noses in it over a referendum. In reality we don't think the government will hold two referendums and they will hold only one - on the single currency".

Another source said the union initially pushing the idea of dropping the referendum, the GMB, had seen its support crumble away.

The GMB still hopes that either the policy forum, or the later full conference in the autumn, will reiterate that the party will give backing in a referendum for the current first past the post system.

The Transport and General Workers Union is demanding that the leadership drop, or soften, the current system of vouchers for asylum seekers.

However, some unions are warning their colleagues not to risk a confrontation wit the leadership.

A senior source in the AEEU engineering union said: "We have a clear choice. Do we treat Tony Blair as if he is a Conservative prime minister, or do we recognise that he has delivered a lot for working people?

"The real enemy are the Tories. A year before the election, we have got to focus on that."

The source added: "The maturity of any future relationship between the party and the unions will depends on how we solve these problems."

fields.headline: Lost photo opportunity
fields.standfirst: How Prescott mislaid snaps
fields.trailText: After adjusting hair, chair and backdrop curtain, the nagging suspicion always remains that a five-minute photo booth is never the best place to highlight one's best side.
fields.body:
After adjusting hair, chair and backdrop curtain, the nagging suspicion always remains that a five-minute photo booth is never the best place to highlight one's best side.

But to go through the routine and end up with pictures that leave you looking like John Prescott ...

As the four pictures slid into the plastic tray, Sean Preece, a 32-year-old factory worker, failed to recognise himself. With the bags under the eyes, the grim set mouth and the sports jacket, he could not have looked more like the deputy prime minister if he had tried.

Yesterday the real John Prescott, hurrying past another photo booth at London's Victoria station, owned up. "It was a photo of me. I went into the booth to get a photo for a visa," he admitted. In a rush to get back to London from a constituency visit, Mr Prescott dashed from the concourse of Doncaster station, South Yorkshire, for a connecting train leaving his £2.50 snaps still being processed.

Mr Preece said the photos he found more than a year ago were too funny to bin. He took them home and pinned them up to the amusement of friends.

Mr Prescott, at Victoria yesterday to look at a new locomotive, appeared to revel in his appearance on the front page of the Sun. "Perhaps after this they should put me on page three," he said.

fields.headline: Belgrano relatives sue Britain
fields.trailText: More than 18 years after their relatives died in the chill south Atlantic, the next-of-kin of sailors on the cruiser General Belgrano are to sue Britain for sinking it during the Falklands conflict.
fields.body:
More than 18 years after their relatives died in the chill south Atlantic, the next-of-kin of sailors on the cruiser General Belgrano are to sue Britain for sinking it during the Falklands conflict.

Lawyers in the Argentinian capital, Buenos Aires, announced yesterday that they will launch a case for damages at the European court of human rights on Tuesday on the grounds that the sinking violated the Hague convention on the conduct of war.

Some 323 Argentinians died when the battleship with 1,093 men on board was sunk by a British submarine, the Conqueror, on May 2 1982 - the biggest single loss of life in the conflict.

It was credited with keeping the rest of the Argentinian navy out of the fighting, which ended with a British task force driving Argentinian invaders out of the Falklands.

It also led to a celebrated Official Secrets Act court case, in which a jury acquitted a civil servant, Clive Ponting, of passing information to an MP about the position and direction of the vessel when it was torpedoed 36 nautical miles (58 km) outside the 200-mile British-declared military exclusion zone around the Falklands.

Yesterday Tam Dalyell, the Labour MP for Linlithgow, who mounted a long campaign on the issue in the 1980s, said the aim of the then prime minster, Margaret [now Lady] Thatcher, in authorising the attack was less to safeguard the British navy than to scupper a peace initiative launched by Peru.

But the plan to sue was condemned as "utterly preposterous and absurd" by the Tory MP for Aldershot, Gerald Howarth.

"If they feel they have the right to sue us, then the British government should sue the Argentinian authorities for the injuries sustained to our troops."

In Buenos Aires, lawyer Jorge Olivera, said: "We are seeking indemnity for all the deaths".

The lawyers' written summary for the case, which has taken five years to plan, said: "At no time did the Argentine cruiser enter the exclusion zone.

"On the contrary, in the early morning hours it had set a course for the Isla de los Estados, clearly opposite of steering toward the theatre of operations."

Mr Olivera said the Argentinian government had failed to bring its own court case against Britain over the incident "because of political interests".

webTitle: Pump prices boycott would only harm motorists, says RAC

fields.headline: Pump prices boycott would only harm motorists, says RAC
fields.trailText: Organisers of a Dump the Pump protest over the price of petrol said last night they had taken their email address offline after being inundated by messages of support.
fields.body:
Organisers of a Dump the Pump protest over the price of petrol said last night they had taken their email address offline after being inundated by messages of support.

Their website, www.boycott-the-pumps.com advertising a boycott of petrol stations on Tuesday August 1 and on succeeding Mondays, had reached 82,194 hits by yesterday afternoon, fuelled by publicity in tabloid newspapers.

The protest against being "bled dry" by the government's duty on fuel is backed by the Road Haulage Association, which is campaigning on diesel duty, and opposed by environmentalists. The AA and RAC fear a boycott could backfire by driving retailers out of business.

The issue dominated exchanges between William Hague and Tony Blair in the Commons yesterday.

In south Wales, where former mining communities of the Rhondda are among the poorest in the UK, one garage in Porth has earned itself the status of the most expensive out of 70 garages listed in the AA's monthly survey. Yesterday, with unleaded and diesel at 97.8p per litre and four star at 99.9p, sales at the Q8 outlet were almost non existent.

Jason Evans, who works down the road, and whose girlfriend has a 20 mile round trip by car to her factory job, said he did not know how people could afford to use the garage. "It is just ridiculous. You very rarely see anyone go in although the traffic flow is constant all day. It is scandalous to think all the money goes to the government. Ten years ago I could fill my father's Granada for £20 - now it would cost nearly £70. It's crazy."

Approximately three quarters of the petrol price is duty and VAT, but the recent rises are due to the cost of crude oil -up from $10 a barrel in 1998 to more than $31.

The AA said a boycott might vent frustration, but would not have any economic impact; purchases would simply be put off until another day. The RAC said: "Many garages are dependent on a constant flow of customers throughout the week. If they are boycotted and go out of business, prices could go up because there would be less competition."

But the RAC spokesman said that, while recent rises were nothing to do with the government, the Chancellor had a £1.3bn windfall by way of additional VAT, and the RAC wanted a compensatory cut in fuel duties, as in Italy when the government knocked 1.5p a litre off prices a fortnight ago.

The AA's survey puts the average price of four star (super unleaded) at 88.9p a litre, or £4.04 a gallon. Some garages were yesterday reported to be charging 107p a litre. Unleaded has risen to 85p a litre compared with 73p in France, 63p in Germany, 62p in Ireland and 53p in Spain.

Environmentalists urged the government to stand firm. Friends of the Earth said: "A 1% rise in fuel prices would pay for a flat rate 70p bus fare nationwide." Transport 2000 said: "Far from being a populist campaign, cheaper petrol will mean more traffic and worse pollution."

webTitle: Flood of claims expected over rights act

fields.headline: Flood of claims expected over rights act
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act, which comes into force on October 2, is expected to trigger a barrage of court attempts to uphold rights which could previously be enforced only in the European court of human rights   in Strasbourg - and only after years of slogging through the British courts .
fields.body:
The Human Rights Act, which comes into force on October 2, is expected to trigger a barrage of court attempts to uphold rights which could previously be enforced only in the European court of human rights in Strasbourg - and only after years of slogging through the British courts .

The act will make the articles of the European convention on human rights enforceable in every court and tribunal. Not only judges but lay magistrates and tribunal members will have to put the new act into operation. A wide range of rights will be protected, including the right to life, freedom from inhuman and degrading treatment, freedom of expression, and right to a fair trial.

In deciding whether a right has been breached, courts will have to take account of Strasbourg case law, though they will not have to follow it slavishly.

Judicial review cases in the high court - like the one brought by prisoner Gavin Mellor for the right to artificially inseminate his wife - are predicted to double from 300 a year to 600. Human rights cases are expected to cost an extra £40m in legal aid.

Prisoners, most of whom qualify for legal aid, have taken a large number of cases to Strasbourg, and are expected to be one of the main groups to invoke the act.

Challenges by patients detained in mental hospitals are likely to be another fruitful source of court cases.

The act is expected to have its biggest impact in the criminal law field, as has happened in Scotland, where the convention is already incorporated into law as a result of the act which brought devolution to Scotland.

There was an outcry last February when Scottish judges ruled unlawful a key provision of the Road Traffic Act, which forces the owner of a car to say whether he was driving it at the time when an offence was committed, because it breached the privilege against self-incrimination.

"Postcode prescribing", which denies expensive drugs to patients in one part of the country but not in others, could come under challenge. The act guarantees the right to life and forbids discrimination in the exercise of that right.

Planned legislation to allow the detention of people with severe personality disorders indefinitely on the basis that they might commit a serious crime is certain to face a challenge.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, predicted this week that local authorities would face a raft of claims. Judges are already warning lawyers not to bring far-fetched human rights challenges for fear of bringing the act into disrepute.

Sex in jail The facts

Conjugal visits, allowed in some countries, are forbidden in British jails - although gay sex is rife in prisons.

There are stories of surreptitious sex during prison visits, though this must be difficult with CCTV cameras and prison guards hovering.

The only other opportunity for heterosexual sex comes if prisoners are on home leave, which may be granted on compassionate grounds - to attend a funeral or if a relative, particularly a child, is ill, for example.

Inmates of open prisons nearing release may go out daily to work, coming back at night; some may be allowed on occasion to stay at home for the night, according to a prison service spokeswoman.

fields.headline: The Dowager Lady Birdwood
fields.standfirst: Far right campaigner obsessed by racist fantasies
fields.trailText: The celebrity of the Dowager Lady Birdwood, who has died aged 87 of cancer, rested in her name. "Lady" and "Dowager" have a resonance, "Birdwood" was faintly odd, the stuff of country-house mystery. That, plus manic persistence and weird taste in spectacles, provided combustible material for a public persona ignited by fringe politics. As plain Joan Graham - Birdwood's maiden name - she would have remained just one more case history in the sturm und drang of the British far right.
fields.body:
The celebrity of the Dowager Lady Birdwood, who has died aged 87 of cancer, rested in her name. "Lady" and "Dowager" have a resonance, "Birdwood" was faintly odd, the stuff of country-house mystery. That, plus manic persistence and weird taste in spectacles, provided combustible material for a public persona ignited by fringe politics. As plain Joan Graham - Birdwood's maiden name - she would have remained just one more case history in the sturm und drang of the British far right.

In a memorably fatuous observation in 1994, Judge Henry Pownall told Birdwood he accepted that she did not intend to stir up racial hatred. "You are not a wicked old woman in that sense," he added. Birdwood had been convicted of distributing a pamphlet, which denied the holocaust, and proclaimed a Jewish conspiracy to subvert society. She had also suggested Jews drank the blood of gentile children. Judge Pownall sentenced her to a three-month suspended sentence.

Three years earlier, she had been conditionally discharged after being convicted of distributing anti-semitic literature intended to stir up racial hatred. On that occasion, Judge Capstick told her that if she continued to break the law, she would go to prison. She did not. Indeed, in 1998, the attorney-general, John Morris, declined to proceed against her on public order charges, having decided that Birdwood, by then, lacked the mental capacity to stand trial.

Her notoriety began in 1962, after the death of her husband, the second Baron Birdwood. He was a veteran of the first world war, late of the Indian army, chairman of the Anglo-German Society, fellow of the Royal Commonwealth Society and, at the end of the 1950s, a member of the British delegation to the United Nations.

The British far right, to which his widow gravitated, then attracted only sporadic media attention. But the liberal climate of the late-1960s helped Birdwood to prominence. There was, it seemed, a market for a lime-green spectacled cover version of Mary Whitehouse.

The Guardian labelled her "the sharpest thorn in the side of the permissive society". Kenneth Tynan's Oh! Calcutta! drove her to the local police station. John Bird's Council Of Love sparked a hymn-singing demonstration and an abortive blasphemy charge. But while Whitehouse was not a racist or fascist, Birdwood delved, erratically into anti-semitism, imperial racism and British fascism.

For a time a member of the Conservative party's right-wing Monday Club, she spoke at National Front meetings and, in 1974, briefly became general-secretary of the British "chapter" of the World Anti-Communist league.

In the years that followed, fascist newsworthiness was enhanced by the sight of her drifting into view amidst the boots, flags and leather jackets. In 1983, she took 69 votes in the Bermondsey byelection as an anti multi-racialism independent. At the 1992 general election, she picked up 660 votes as the British National party candidate in Dewsbury.

Her father, a singer, came from Hull, and her mother from Newcastle; she, herself, was born in Winnipeg. In the early 1920s, the family moved to Yorkshire. In London, she worked at the Royal Opera House, for a music publisher and a concert agency, and, during the war, for the armed forces entertainment organisation, Ensa. Postwar, in Germany, she became secretary to Christopher Birdwood, then working for the Red Cross. In 1954, his wife, Vere, was granted a divorce on the grounds of his adultery and Joan Graham and Lord Birdwood married.

Until recently, she continued to put out material on the various conspiracies she had identified, chronicles of wasted time.

 Joan Pollock Graham, the Dowager Lady Birdwood, racist campaigner, born May 18 1913; died June 28 2000

In a memorably fatuous observation in 1994, Judge Henry Pownall told Birdwood he accepted that she did not intend to stir up racial hatred. "You are not a wicked old woman in that sense," he added. Birdwood had been convicted of distributing a pamphlet, which denied the holocaust, and proclaimed a Jewish conspiracy to subvert society. She had also suggested Jews drank the blood of gentile children. Judge Pownall sentenced her to a three-month suspended sentence. Three years earlier, she had been conditionally discharged after being convicted of distributing anti-semitic literature intended to stir up racial hatred. On that occasion, Judge Capstick told her that if she continued to break the law, she would go to prison. She did not. Indeed, in 1998, the attorney-general, John Morris, declined to proceed against her on public order charges, having decided that Birdwood, by then, lacked the mental capacity to stand trial. Her notoriety began in 1962, after the death of her husband, the second Baron Birdwood. He was a veteran of the first world war, late of the Indian army, chairman of the Anglo-German Society, fellow of the Royal Commonwealth Society and, at the end of the 1950s, a member of the British delegation to the United Nations. The British far right, to which his widow gravitated, then attracted only sporadic media attention. But the liberal climate of the late-1960s helped Birdwood to prominence. There was, it seemed, a market for a lime-green spectacled cover version of Mary Whitehouse. The Guardian labelled her "the sharpest thorn in the side of the permissive society". Kenneth Tynan's Oh! Calcutta! drove her to the local police station. John Bird's Council Of Love sparked a hymn-singing demonstration and an abortive blasphemy charge.
