For a time a member of the Conservative party's right-wing Monday Club, she spoke at National Front meetings and, in 1974, briefly became general-secretary of the British "chapter" of the World Anti-Communist league. In the years that followed, fascist newsworthiness was enhanced by the sight of her drifting into view amidst the boots, flags and leather jackets. In 1983, she took 69 votes in the Bermondsey byelection as an anti multi-racialism independent. At the 1992 general election, she picked up 660 votes as the British National party candidate in Dewsbury. Her father, a singer, came from Hull, and her mother from Newcastle; she, herself, was born in Winnipeg. In the early 1920s, the family moved to Yorkshire. In London, she worked at the Royal Opera House, for a music publisher and a concert agency, and, during the war, for the armed forces entertainment organisation, Ensa. Postwar, in Germany, she became secretary to Christopher Birdwood, then working for the Red Cross. In 1954, his wife, Vere, was granted a divorce on the grounds of his adultery and Joan Graham and Lord Birdwood married. fields.headline: John Aspinall
fields.standfirst: Idiosyncratic millionaire gambler and zoo keeper whose contempt for humanity was matched by his love of wild animals
fields.trailText: John Aspinall, who has died aged 74, after a long battle with cancer, was perceived as either a magnificently over-lifesized English gentleman, animal lover, gambler and eccentric, or as a distinctly more sinister individual, who would have been quite content to feed his fellow human beings to his preferred species - the ferocious tigers with which he spent his life trying to "bond".
fields.body:
John Aspinall, who has died aged 74, after a long battle with cancer, was perceived as either a magnificently over-lifesized English gentleman, animal lover, gambler and eccentric, or as a distinctly more sinister individual, who would have been quite content to feed his fellow human beings to his preferred species - the ferocious tigers with which he spent his life trying to "bond".

Those in the "pro" lobby pointed to his two private zoos in Kent, Howletts and Port Lympne, which cost him around £4m a year (only about one-tenth of which was recovered by ticket sales) and had a better record of breeding endangered species than many grander and more conventional establishments. They pointed out that in the various gaming clubs he had run over the years, he had probably done more than Karl Marx to bring about the redistribution of wealth and the ruination of the rich.

Those in the "anti" lobby, who regarded James Bond's melodrama villains, Goldfinger and Dr No, as realistic characters in comparison, pointed to Aspinall's catalogue of beliefs - that the world's population would be better if culled by 2bn of the less intelligent; that Hitler was right about eugenics (though wrong about other matters); that everyone should feel himself to be a member of a tribe that was better than any other; that instinct and prejudice were more reliable guides to behaviour than reason; that, as a worshipper of the natural world, he worshipped earthquakes and plagues; and that he would glady sacrifice the life of his own children to save an endangered species.

Aspinall was not a comfortable person to be with or to contemplate, except perhaps for a small coterie of fellow gamblers and financial pirates, who presumably had a clearer idea of when he was joking. Over the years, that coterie included Sir James Goldsmith and Lord "Lucky" Lucan. Aspinall and Goldsmith were rumoured to have been among the council of war which met to consider Lucan's future the day after he had experienced some alleged difficulty with a length of lead pipe and the skull of his children's nanny.

Aspinall's world, though aspiring to the tenets of the jungle, was a hermetically sealed one of port and cigars, in which tigers, apes and gaming chips provided a self-prescribed danger and excitement in a little world surrounded, in his eyes, by the mediocre and mundane. The fact that it was usually his zoo employees rather than himself who were killed or mauled in pursuit of his theory of close "bonding" with wild animals - though he himself suffered in no small measure - was a component of the exotic equation of his life, which appeared to elude any sense of irony he may have possessed.

Both Howletts and Port Lympne seemed to attract human disaster. Aspinall's own daughter, Louise, was bitten by a tiger cub and needed 15 stitches. A boy of 10 had his arm ripped off by a chimpanzee at Port Lympne, and was awarded £132,000 in damages. Bindu, an English bull elephant, crushed a "bonding" keeper to death. The most recent victim, 27-year-old Darren Cockrill, was crushed by an elephant at Port Lympne last February.

In 1994, the local council banned the keepers from entering the tiger cages after one of their number, Trevor Smith, was killed at Howletts - Aspinall threatened to close down both zoos if the ban was enforced, and soon the keepers were back fondling the tigers. Balkash, the offending tiger, was described by Aspinall as coming from a "rather tricky line of tigers, the same line that produced Zeya, who killed two keepers 16 years ago. One tiger in 12 has this abberant streak. With humans, it is one in three."

Aspinall personally shot the tiger, and some of his detractors might not have been altogether surprised if he had been willing to shoot one in three human beings, though others saw his stance on culling the world population as the fantasising of a rich man who claimed he loved gambling precisely because it offered "excitement and despair".

It is possible that this tall, rangy man, with the public-meeting voice and the scarcely veiled contempt for most of his fellows, will be remembered for his services to gambling as much as that to wild animals. In this respect, his contribution was crucial and long-lasting.

As the 1950s came out of the grey austerity after the second world war, two phenomena intertwined: the desire of the British government to attract more foreign currency, and the desire of the rich to have a little more excitement.

Gambling was an obvious means of satisfying both these phenomena. But, at that time, it was illegal to attract rich foreign and British punters by setting up a casino in which gambling could take place for money; and there was still a strong religious and moral feeling against any relaxation of the law. Aspinall, who felt that Christianity was dull, was a man who could have been selected by destiny to bombard such an impasse.

John Victor Aspinall was born in India, ostensibly the son of Colonel Robert Aspinall, an Indian army doctor who had married a titled woman. It was years before she confessed to John that his real father had been Captain Bruce, of the Lincolns, who had had his way with her under a tamarind tree beside a lake in Uttar Pradesh after a regimental ball.

This evocative revelation did not seem to throw Aspinall. He searched out his real father in an old people's home and supported him for the rest of his life. But it may have added to a sense of the unreality of human relationships. As a boy, he had been thrown out of Rugby for inattention. Accounts of his university career vary, though the majority verdict is that he left Jesus College, Oxford, after faking illness so that he could go to the Ascot Gold Cup instead of completing his exams. He went down without a degree, but won a reputed fortune on the race. He joined the Royal Marines, but was too rebellious to gain a commission.

It was hardly a surprise when, in the 1950s, he hit on the Flashman-esque expedient of circumventing the gaming laws by running games of chance, mostly chemin de fer, at various private addresses (not covered by the law) in Mayfair and thereabouts. In 1962, when the law was relaxed - very much due to Aspinall's campaigning - he opened the Clermont Club, and profited by the losses of high rollers like Lucan, who could not afford it, and Goldsmith, who could, as well as overseas gamblers from the United States and Middle East.

In the early 1970s, Aspinall sold the Clermont for £500,000 - just before a market crash drove the gamblers away. Then, in the late 1970s, he popped up again with the Aspinall Curzon, backed by Goldsmith, and, in 1987, sold it to Peter de Savary for £90m. With about £20m of the proceeds, he established a trust to fund his two zoos.

"My friends say I'm better with my back to the wall," he once said. "I'm like an old warrior who can galvanise himself when he's threatened, but I'm pretty idle when I've got no threats."

Aspinall was probably neither hero nor villain, but simply a wildly out-of-fashion romantic, who saw himself, like everything else, in romantic terms. This did not always sit easily with the reality of his relationships. He was married first, in 1956, to Jane Gordon Hastings, by whom he had a son and daughter. They were divorced in 1966, after which he married Belinda Musker, divorcing in 1972. His third wife was Lady Sarah Courage (neé Curzon), by whom he had one son.

Aspinall sometimes spoke about the children he had "sired", romantically confusing the language of the stable with that of the jungle in which he saw himself bonding with other wild creatures. The injuries sustained indicated that the desire to bond was tragically stronger on his side than theirs.

 John Victor Aspinall, gambler and zoo keeper, born June 11 1926; died June 29 2000

webTitle: Masts for mobiles 'are not a hazard'

fields.headline: Masts for mobiles 'are not a hazard'
fields.standfirst:
Radiation emissions at affected schools well within safety levels
Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: An official report out today has dismissed widespread concern that children are subjected to high levels of radiation from mobile phone masts placed on top of school buildings.
fields.body:
An official report out today has dismissed widespread concern that children are subjected to high levels of radiation from mobile phone masts placed on top of school buildings.

Concrete roofs soak up most of the radiation emitted by the masts with only very low levels absorbed by children inside the classroom, according to the study by the national radiological protection board.

Pupils were found to face more radiation coming through the classroom window from masts more than 300 yards away than from one placed on the roof.

The publication of the report follows a groundswell of worry about the possible long-term health implications of placing radio masts near schools and hospitals.

Friends of the Earth, the Council for the Protection of Rural England and the Country Landowners Association have all fought to stop masts being put on top of hospitals, council flats and areas of outstanding national beauty.

During mounting opposition to the effects of the rapidly growing mobile phone industry, one group of parents refused to let their children go to a junior school in Kent because of fears over radiation from a mast in the grounds.

The NRPB carried out tests on 118 different points at 17 sites, including masts, known as base stations, near schools and outside offices and homes.

The tests showed the average exposure to radiation was well within safety boundaries at just 0.002% of international guidelines.

More than 25m mobile phones are in use in the UK but the figure is expected to double with the introduction of third-generation phones offering video pictures and internet options.

Masts have sprouted up across the country to keep pace with the popularity of mobile phones but the total number is unclear. Unofficial estimates have put the figure at more than 35,000.

More than 500 cash-strapped schools and dozens of hospitals and council flats have masts because of the lure of considerable rents.

But an environment committee of the Scottish parliament earlier this year recommended telecom masts should require planning permission.

Some local authorities are increasingly adopting a "precautionary principle", keeping masts away from schools, hospitals and residential areas.

Simon Mann, one of the authors of the NRPB study, said: "There has been huge public concern over exposure to radio waves from base stations, and there was a real need for someone to produce some independent data that could be held up for everyone to see.

"We chose places to investigate where people were concerned about masts but in all of them we found the levels of radiation were well within guidelines and not hazardous."

Early results of the study were passed to the Independent Expert Group on Mobile Phones, chaired by a former government chief scientific adviser, Sir William Stewart.

The group last month published a report calling for stricter planning controls on masts but stopped short of banning them from schools.

Residents groups and councillors had complained they found it difficult to prevent the masts being put up.

The NRPB called for a systematic study to examine thousands of locations across the UK and supported the Stewart report's recommendation that a database of masts should be established.

The debate over masts follows vigorous scientific debate and inquiries into the safety of the mobile phones themselves.

Sir William's inquiry found no evidence that mobiles damaged human health and no evidence they did not. Sir William said the widespread use of mobiles by children should be discouraged, but left it to parents to make an "informed choice".

fields.headline: Race against time
fields.standfirst:
The European Union's new directive will enforce the principle of equal treatment regardless of ethnic origin
The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Even the most optimistic Euro-MPs have been surprised at how fast the European Union turned aspiration into reality: a new race equality directive has been approved by the European parliament and passed unanimously by the council of ministers that will compel member states to rewrite their laws by the end of 2002. For the United Kingdom, which already has a race relations statutes, the directive will still provoke major reforms.
fields.body:
Even the most optimistic Euro-MPs have been surprised at how fast the European Union turned aspiration into reality: a new race equality directive has been approved by the European parliament and passed unanimously by the council of ministers that will compel member states to rewrite their laws by the end of 2002. For the United Kingdom, which already has a race relations statutes, the directive will still provoke major reforms.

In an EU where most countries have no compre hensive race legislation, the new directive enforces the principle of equal treatment irrespective of ethnic origin. European involvement in this area is based on article 13 of the Amsterdam Treaty of June 1997, allowing "appropriate action to combat discrimination based on sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation".

The directive outlaws both direct and indirect discrimination. Practices that are apparently neutral but disadvantage those of a particular ethnic origin will be banned. Incitement to discriminate is to be treated as equivalent to actual discrimination.

EU members will be obliged to ensure that their domestic law complies. Statutes must be put in place that ensure equal treatment in both public and private sectors, including social security and health, as well as in the sup ply of goods and services, such as housing.

One aspect of the directive has attracted particular controversy. This is the "burden of proof" requirement: if an individual establishes that racial discrimination has taken place, it will be for the alleged discriminator to disprove this. Business in the UK has expressed concern that this may increase the number of cases brought. Some claim that it will make for a "complainants' charter".

Yet this change in the burden of proof is needed. Often the evidence in such cases is held by the alleged discriminator alone, perhaps in personnel files. EU countries have already agreed parallel changes in the burden of proof in cases of gender discrimination, to be implemented by July 2001.

The directive's aim is not that all EU states have the same anti-discriminatory instruments. It is rather to guarantee a minimum stan dard of treatment. National race relations bodies along the lines of the UK's Commission for Racial Equality (CRE), will be charged with monitoring and supporting the measure. Governments will have to report on how the directive is being applied and include the opinions of voluntary bodies working in the race area.

The effect of the equal treatment directive will vary from country to country. The Race Relations Act here already includes many of the required provisions. But the CRE reckons harassment and indirect discrimination will have been redefined in law. The scope of the act will have to be extended to protect access to jobs and involvement in workplace organisations. The race bill now before parliament is extending the scope of the CRE to cover prisons and the police, perhaps even the immigration service as well. (The chart is a reminder of one aspect of the race equality agenda in the UK - the big increase is partly a result of more effective measurement of racial incidents by the police.) The directive means there will be further changes in the law, for example to allow organisations to bring proceedings on behalf of individual complainants.

Even more dramatic will be the directive's impact on other countries. In Germany the constitution can be invoked by individuals in court cases alleging discrimination, but there is no specific race legislation. The French constitution and civil and labour codes mention race. Politicians have been discussing new anti-discrimination proposals; the directive now gives them a comprehensive framework.

Austria, the focus of debate in recent months after the far-right Freedom party led by Jörg Haider became a partner in the ruling coalition (Mr Haider having since stood down), has no general anti-discrimination law and its constitution has no reference to "race". It is a measure of the importance of the directive that the government, Freedom party included, will have to implement a race relations act.

The EU's southern members are interesting, too. The Portuguese, who during their presidency of the EU have been leading the debate, have no constitutional provision on race, though Portuguese labour law prohibits dismissal on grounds of race or ethnic origin. Portugal's institutional architecture includes the office of high commissioner for immigration and ethnic minorities.

The constitution of Greece states that all Greeks are equal before the law, but civil and labour law entirely omit any protection against discrimination on the grounds of race. Netherlands law offers a comprehensive framework around equal opportunities and race and probably comes closest among EU members to the UK. The Dutch 1994 Equal Treatment Act explicitly mentions race, nationality and race discrimination - yet even the Netherlands will not be immune from the directive's effects.

There is no doubt that buried in the various European constitutions there are commitments to equal treatment, but they are vague and inexplicit. The new directive will bring consistency to the way all EU citizens are treated, whatever their race or origin.

Claude Moraes is a Labour MEP and former member of the Commission on Racial Equality

Austria, the focus of debate in recent months after the far-right Freedom party led by Jörg Haider became a partner in the ruling coalition (Mr Haider having since stood down), has no general anti-discrimination law and its constitution has no reference to "race". It is a measure of the importance of the directive that the government, Freedom party included, will have to implement a race relations act. The EU's southern members are interesting, too. The Portuguese, who during their presidency of the EU have been leading the debate, have no constitutional provision on race, though Portuguese labour law prohibits dismissal on grounds of race or ethnic origin. Portugal's institutional architecture includes the office of high commissioner for immigration and ethnic minorities. The constitution of Greece states that all Greeks are equal before the law, but civil and labour law entirely omit any protection against discrimination on the grounds of race. Netherlands law offers a comprehensive framework around equal opportunities and race and probably comes closest among EU members to the UK. The Dutch 1994 Equal Treatment Act explicitly mentions race, nationality and race discrimination - yet even the Netherlands will not be immune from the directive's effects. There is no doubt that buried in the various European constitutions there are commitments to equal treatment, but they are vague and inexplicit. The new directive will bring consistency to the way all EU citizens are treated, whatever their race or origin. Claude Moraes is a Labour MEP and former member of the Commission on Racial Equality cmoraes@europarl.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Harry Potter, what of him?
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: As a highbrow social commentator with a track-record for controversy, I am often asked to write outspoken think-pieces condemning things that have yet to be noticed by lesser columnists. There aren't many journalists who are prepared to brave the wrath of millions - but if you want someone to put their head above the parapet, you know where to find me.
fields.body:
As a highbrow social commentator with a track-record for controversy, I am often asked to write outspoken think-pieces condemning things that have yet to be noticed by lesser columnists. There aren't many journalists who are prepared to brave the wrath of millions - but if you want someone to put their head above the parapet, you know where to find me.

Take the past six months, for instance. In January, I wrote a long piece condemning the number of long pieces there had been about the Spice Girls ("How many more forests will be cut down before we have grown tired of long pieces about the Spice Girls?"). In February, I wrote a brave front-page for the Observer Review condemning our dumbed-down obsession with supermodels ("I defy anyone to suggest that Kate Moss is on an intellectual par with my good friend Professor Dawkin. . . Do we as a society really want to look at underweight, scantily-clad girls rather than study recent developments in the field of science?"). The Observer put its full weight behind the piece, illustrating it with full colour photographs of Kate Moss, Jerry Hall, Eva Herzi-gova, Naomi Campbell and up-and-coming superwaif Jackie Spritzer.

In March, I created an outcry when I put my head on the block of public opinion to lambast The Simpsons. I was one of the first critics to notice that they were not a real family at all, but to all intents and purposes a cartoon. "Are we not in danger of dumbing down?" I asked in the Sunday Times. The article is now regarded as a milestone: 25,000 readers responded to the accompanying offer of a cut-price Simpson's video box set. In April, I stuck my neck out again, becoming the first commentator of the year to condemn spring as "surely one of the most overrated and dumbed-down of our seasons. One day sunny, the next day drizzly - why can't it make up its tiny little mind?". And in May, I placed my intellect at the service of all those readers of the Independent on Sunday who were sick to death of reading about Gwyneth Paltrow, penning a 3,000 word attack on her ("sorry, guys, but isn't it about time we recognised her for what she is - an actress, for god's sake?").

So now it's June, and I'm constructing my third major attack in as many months on the new Harry Potter book. As the justly proud author of such underrated children's cult classics as the Fluffy the Dolphin series (now out of print), I am in a good position to judge JK Rowling's worthless potboilers from an unbiased position. I may brave the wrath of millions by daring to say so, but it doesn't take a high-minded killjoy to worry what these books are doing to the literary taste of millions of young readers. I only wish the marketing men had got behind my Fluffy the Dolphin series, because then our future as a nation of intelligent young readers would be assured.

Good luck, say I, to Joanne Rowling, who with the help of the marketing men has made a fortune conservatively estimated at £15m. I'm very happy for her, very happy, I really couldn't be happier. After all, it's not her fault that my own far more daring venture into gritty realism (Fluffy the Dolphin Shivers in a Damp Council Block, 1998) and its moving sequel (Fluffy the Dolphin Takes Shit Ecstasy and Pegs It, 1999) failed to get the weight of the marketing men behind them and thus failed to gain a huge popular following.

But what I do object to is a pedestrian, ungrammatical, repetitive prose style which Ms Rowling has and these are among those things which I object to, especially when they are pedestrian and ungrammatical. And repetitive. And the suspense in the Potter books is minimal, which makes it all the more depressing that children hang on to their every word, as if desperate to know what happens next. Personally, I prefer long, difficult, grown-up books, preferably without pictures, about heavyweight topics, if possible written in Anglo Saxon, or at very least translated from the German. It is a terrible indictment of our world that I am now five times as knowledgeable as children a fifth of my age. And why did she not set the Potter series in the real world, a world with which millions of young readers could identify and enjoy in exactly the way they would have enjoyed my books if only they had read them?

If I had written Harry Potter, the hero would have been a girl, possibly with learning difficulties, the setting would not have been a private boarding school but an embattled secondary modern battling against problems such as anorexia and child abuse, and it would not have been about magic and witches but about inner-city deprivation. And my Potter books would have proved far more popular than Rowling's - which, from what I hear, would have made her very jealous indeed.

fields.headline: The art of pressing buttons
fields.standfirst:
It's easier to promote the symbolism of race and gender politics than get to grips with class issues
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: What has Mo Mowlam got in common with Robert Mugabe? Even less than usual this week - apart from an unusually large number of acquaintances who know how to load an Armalite rifle in the dark. The Cabinet Office minister is famously counter-intuitive and her renewed attack on the over-blown privileges of the royal family must fall into that category, albeit not for the reasons savagely denounced in the Daily Mail.
fields.body:
What has Mo Mowlam got in common with Robert Mugabe? Even less than usual this week - apart from an unusually large number of acquaintances who know how to load an Armalite rifle in the dark. The Cabinet Office minister is famously counter-intuitive and her renewed attack on the over-blown privileges of the royal family must fall into that category, albeit not for the reasons savagely denounced in the Daily Mail.

After all, it is hardly surprising that she suggested they move into less grand digs and hinted at her own not-so-closet republicanism. Ms Mowlam said it all six years ago when the Mail reacted with equally proprietorial outrage: it dislikes anyone but the Mail exploiting the Windsors for political gain or profit. What is more, the royals have taken her advice, quietly modernising in all sorts of ways. It may increase their survival chances if they avoid over-irritating their increasingly undeferential "subjects" in what has long been a crowned republic.

What is more interesting is that a New Labour minister should indulge in class politics in 2000, even in such a mild form. Half the cabinet is probably republican in instinct, but it is not done to say so, as Tony Blair's ardent monarchism makes plain.

Mr Mugabe better represented the zeitgeist this week when he attacked Zimbabwe's white farmers because they are white. All former colonial powers feel vaguely guilty about the past (perhaps not Japan), it is a good button to press; but the former Marxist guerrilla leader could hardly attack the tobacco farmers as an economic elite since he has kept his regime afloat by awarding his Zanu-PF and army chums similar perks, at the expense of his increasingly disappointed urban working class.

Sounds familiar? Well yes. Since free market economics won its branch of the cold war its precepts have been so widely embraced beyond the United States that the political analysis - not to mention rhetoric - which long sustained leftwing parties throughout the industrialised world (plus Zanu-PF) has rapidly atrophied.

Into the rhetorical vacuum have come the politics of race and gender. So much so that Thatcher's children (people who grew up in the 80s and 90s) are bewildered or embarrassed by talk of conflicting interests and struggle between competing economic groups and classes.

Inside the "big tent", the theory goes, everyone is wired and enjoys their own bit of cyberspace. The striking thing about race and gender is that they are much more easily reconciled with markets than the old politics of class. They are highly susceptible to fashionable versions of meritocracy.

All those clever women, clever Asian entrepreneurs and Jesuit or Anglican-educated Guyanans (ex-choirboy David Lammy MP took his seat this week) fit into the globalised economy very nicely. It needs their brains! Anti-slavery campaigners in Britain 200 years ago and, later, in the US took the point. America's "new south" is built on the insight.

But that leaves a lot of people behind, people who are harder to accommodate. Palestinians are a good example. The politics of the Holocaust, evident in growing numbers of Holocaust museums in Europe and the US, do not simply pay lip service to the horrors of the past, they help sustain the politics of the present.

It is impossible to walk through Washington's Holocaust Museum, for example, without being aware both of the racial savagery it records and of the fact that the United States sustained its own brutal apartheid during the same period. That 30s park bench on display - stamped "Jews Only" - could also have been in Alabama. But that might have been too uncomfortable for the US capital, too close to home. The burgeoning Holocaust phenomenon serves to help keep American Jewry out of the melting pot, to bind it closer to faith and kin, closer to Israel, than might otherwise be possible. History, as always, is harnessed to contemporary needs.

So with the rest of us. Labour politicians find it easier to engage in the symbolism of racial and gender injustice than mix it in class politics. Sexuality too. Even that doughty class warrior, John Prescott, will turn up (Mo too) for this weekend's Gay and Lesbian Pride celebrations. Once it would have been the Durham Miners' Gala.

Many Labour politicians are uneasily aware of this. Gordon Brown's welfare-to- work campaigns, for instance, rest on the earnest need to include the socially excluded, what we used to call the poor. Flexible labour markets need their labour too, albeit at £3.50 an hour.

It is not that New Labour does not hanker after the old certainties of class warfare, it is just that they are uneasy. The drive to end hunting with dogs is best understood as a bit of furtive toff-bashing, but is dressed up as animal welfare. Chancellor Brown's ill-judged foray into the Oxbridge selection process may reflect this unease. Labour's policies for funding higher education have not made it easier for Britain's Laura Spences. But, as someone said of the third way's Bill Clinton, the left may get the rhetoric, but the right gets the decisions.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
Close students of Her Majesty's press may be grateful for some background about the item here on Wednesday, concerning the Sunday People's "exclusive" on three England footballers' alleged "porn video". This report was much like the one in the News of the World, but for the addition of photos and quotes from blonde "Michelle", anguished at having been "duped" into appearing in the film. All very Ben Bradlee, then . . . until it transpires that "Michelle" was crime reporter Lucy Panton (recognised at once by NoW hacks, despite having her head in her hands). The Pulitzer committee will want to know that People editor Neil Wallis thought he'd bought the story from Max Clifford when last Thursday he went to Royal Ascot (very man of the People) - and, failing to confirm the deal, was gazumped at the last by the NoW. Furious at this injustice, the People's crack executive team decided to run the story anyway with "Michelle" and some strong inside information (let's hope no confidentiality agreement was breached there) and continued to run it despite a post-first edition warning call from the NoW. We hope this helps the Pulitzer committee make its deliberations.

While this may not be the time to put down the deposit on Neil Wallis's gold watch, it does seem a good moment to recall his previous appearance here. It was Neil who, during the 1999 UK Press Gazette awards, stormed the stage and seized the microphone to deliver an important keynote address about the bias against tabloid papers. With such quiet yet convincing moral authority did he speak that we were chastened that night. You will imagine, then, the crippling sense of betrayal today.

The Diary Book of the Month for July is Under No Illusion, the autobiography of that mirthful magician Paul Daniels (Blake Publishing, £16.99). Beneath the British price on the inside cover, incidentally, is $26 - and how wise to include it, for if ever a British performer's reminiscences were primed to sweep through the American market, these are they. Certainly, Paul's disputation on page 5 as to his failure to see what is offensive about the word "nigger" ("The question is never about your colour or creed," observes this underrated thinker, "it is about whether I like you or not."), may appeal in some of the southern states such as Alabama. More soon.

A red hot favourite for Most Amusing Press Release arrives from Maxima Group plc, announcing fraud-prevention clinics for business people. "In just two years, Maxima has investigated corporate frauds for an impressive list of clients worldwide," it explains, "and has helped recover assets totalling $1bn (made up figure - could we conjure up a more authentic one? Journalists are impressed by such nonsense)." Indeed we are, and we ring to say so. "Mm. Well, we've amended it to 'something over £50m'," says Tim Stephens. That's down from £600m? "Yes. Look," says Tim, with opportunistic elan, "will you be able to highlight the seminars? They're in a good cause." A pleasure. The fees from the clinics (worth, ooh, at least £750m) in late July, go to the NSPCC.
Details at www.maximag.co.uk.

It is hard to express my sadness at the withdrawal from the front line of my old friend Alastair Campbell, propagandist in chief to Robert Maxwell, Neil Kinnock, Mr Tony Blair and . . . well, time will tell who's next. People have tended to misunderstand our working relationship. On hearing Ali describe me as "that f****** c***", they have missed the affectionate, joshing tone bubbling away merrily beneath the snarl - and no one was more confused about this affection than the Downing Street press office. Now Ali has retired to a crucial "strategic planning role", we hope to find some route to rapprochement with his successor Godric Smith.

webTitle: Lifer fights Straw's ban on fathering baby

fields.headline: Lifer fights Straw's ban on fathering baby
fields.standfirst: QC attacks 'paternalism' by home secretary as killer launches battle for right to artificial insemination of woman who married him in jail
fields.trailText: A prisoner serving life for murdering a pensioner yesterday launched an unprecedented high court battle, funded by legal aid, for the right to have his wife artificially inseminated with his sperm.
fields.body:
A prisoner serving life for murdering a pensioner yesterday launched an unprecedented high court battle, funded by legal aid, for the right to have his wife artificially inseminated with his sperm.

Gavin Mellor, 29, and his wife "desperately" wanted to start a family and feared it might be too late if they waited for his release from a life sentence, his QC, David Pannick, told Mr Justice Forbes at the high court in London.

Mr Pannick asked the judge to quash an "unjustifiably paternalistic" decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to refuse the request. Mr Straw wrongly questioned whether the prisoner's marriage was stable enough for a child, said the QC.

Mr Pannick said: "We say the home secretary has many onerous responsibilities, but whether Mr and Mrs Mellor should bring a child into the world is a matter for them and not a matter for the secretary of state."

The judge reserved his judgment after hearing arguments on both sides and said he hoped to give his decision in a few weeks' time.

Mellor was given a mandatory life sentence in January 1994 for the killing of George Sims, a 71-year-old grandfather, who was attacked as he walked home from a working men's club in Crewe, Cheshire.

Mellor met Tracey McColl, now 25, while she was working as an administration officer at Gartree prison in Leicestershire in January 1997. She later told a newspaper how she and Mellor, who has one child from a previous relationship, regularly had sex in jail.

She resigned from the prison service to marry Mellor, now at Nottingham prison, in July 1997.

His request to be allowed to donate sperm was first refused in November 1998 in a prison service letter which expressed concern about whether the marriage would remain stable once he was released.

Mr Pannick said the Home Office, in refusing the request, had asked itself a question it had no right to ask, which was: "How stable is this marriage - and would it ever be in the interests of the child to have a father in prison?"

He added: "We say English law recognises that prisoners enjoy all civil rights except those expressly removed, or removed by necessary implication."

Mellor claimed the right to inseminate his wife under article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights, the right to private and family life, and article 12, the right to marry and found a family. Mr Pannick urged the judge to bear in mind that the refusal "will also impose a substantial detriment on Mrs Mellor, who undoubtedly retains all of her civil rights". As a mandatory life prisoner, there was no guarantee that he would ever be released. If he was, his wife might be too old by that time. The earliest date he could be released on licence was in 2006.

Dinah Rose, for the home secretary, said the decision not to allow Mellor access to the facilities for artificial insemination, and the policy applied by the Home Office, "are not irrational but entirely legitimate". There was no right, under the European convention or in common law, to access facilities for artificial insemination.

Ms Rose said the decision, taken in 1998, was not a "once and for all" decision. If there was a change in circumstances it could be reconsidered.

Ms Rose said that if the matter was, as Mr Pannick contended, "none of the home secretary's business", he would have no power to refuse a request from a prisoner "with a history of sexually abusing his own children to conceive more children while he was in prison convicted of those offences".

The home secretary's policy was necessary to maintain public confidence in the criminal justice system and was both lawful and rational, she added.

Mr Pannick said: "We say the home secretary has many onerous responsibilities, but whether Mr and Mrs Mellor should bring a child into the world is a matter for them and not a matter for the secretary of state." The judge reserved his judgment after hearing arguments on both sides and said he hoped to give his decision in a few weeks' time. Mellor was given a mandatory life sentence in January 1994 for the killing of George Sims, a 71-year-old grandfather, who was attacked as he walked home from a working men's club in Crewe, Cheshire. Mellor met Tracey McColl, now 25, while she was working as an administration officer at Gartree prison in Leicestershire in January 1997. She later told a newspaper how she and Mellor, who has one child from a previous relationship, regularly had sex in jail. She resigned from the prison service to marry Mellor, now at Nottingham prison, in July 1997. His request to be allowed to donate sperm was first refused in November 1998 in a prison service letter which expressed concern about whether the marriage would remain stable once he was released. Mr Pannick said the Home Office, in refusing the request, had asked itself a question it had no right to ask, which was: "How stable is this marriage - and would it ever be in the interests of the child to have a father in prison?" He added: "We say English law recognises that prisoners enjoy all civil rights except those expressly removed, or removed by necessary implication." Mellor claimed the right to inseminate his wife under article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights, the right to private and family life, and article 12, the right to marry and found a family. Mr Pannick urged the judge to bear in mind that the refusal "will also impose a substantial detriment on Mrs Mellor, who undoubtedly retains all of her civil rights". As a mandatory life prisoner, there was no guarantee that he would ever be released. If he was, his wife might be too old by that time. The earliest date he could be released on licence was in 2006. Dinah Rose, for the home secretary, said the decision not to allow Mellor access to the facilities for artificial insemination, and the policy applied by the Home Office, "are not irrational but entirely legitimate". There was no right, under the European convention or in common law, to access facilities for artificial insemination. Ms Rose said the decision, taken in 1998, was not a "once and for all" decision. If there was a change in circumstances it could be reconsidered. Ms Rose said that if the matter was, as Mr Pannick contended, "none of the home secretary's business", he would have no power to refuse a request from a prisoner "with a history of sexually abusing his own children to conceive more children while he was in prison convicted of those offences". The home secretary's policy was necessary to maintain public confidence in the criminal justice system and was both lawful and rational, she added.

fields.headline: S Africa backs Lawrences
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: The parents of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence yesterday won the backing of the South African high commissioner in their battle for compensation from Scotland Yard.
fields.body:
The parents of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence yesterday won the backing of the South African high commissioner in their battle for compensation from Scotland Yard.

Doreen and Neville Lawrence are suing police over their bungled investigation into the 1993 racist murder. Both sides have been in protracted negotiations about the amount and Scotland Yard want the case thrown out.

Mrs Lawrence yesterday presented the former South African president Nelson Mandela with a lifetime achievement award at the South African high commission in London.

After the ceremony the high commissioner, Cheryl Carolus, called for a settlement that was acceptable to the Lawrences. She said: "We would like to see a resolution and would like to have a resolution where the Lawrence family will feel that their own personal grief has been addressed and that Stephen's spirit has been honoured in a manner that it ought to ... and in a manner which holds out fresh hope for people of colour in Britain and around the world.

The Lawrences believe that a meeting with Mr Mandela in 1993, two months after Stephen's murder, was crucial and led to police arresting the five prime suspects for the killing, for which no one has been convicted.

Ms Carolus said Mr Mandela was still monitoring developments in the Lawrences' six-year struggle for justice.

"Mr Mandela has been in touch with my office, [asking] where the case is, he has taken a really keen interest and is following it."

Presenting Mr Mandela with the ethnic multicultural media award for lifetime achievement, Mrs Lawrence said that his intervention in the case in 1993 had been vital.

She told him: "I hold you very dear to my heart. Back in 1993, just after my son was killed, you were the only one of any stature who recognised the plight of my family and spoke out."

She said that if they had not met in 1993 an inquiry into the murder would not have taken place.

Lawyers acting for the Lawrences have issued writs for damages totalling £500,000 against the Metropolitan police and 26 officers, including the former commissioner, Sir Paul Condon.

Mr Mandela, 81, said there was an increasing bond between the people of South Africa and Britain. "When we see Doreen Lawrence we recognise our collective fate and our determination to stamp out racism wherever we find it," he said.

After receiving his award Mr Mandela said: "I'm sure that I can speak for all South Africans, black and white, that this award is recognition of their struggle for peace and democracy in our country."

fields.headline: Answering back
fields.standfirst: Even the courteous are learning to heckle
fields.trailText: People sometimes say William Hague would have made a truly great politician - in 1870. His whole style belongs to a different era. So of all today's politicians, he should be better equipped than most to deal with that oldest of irritants: the heckler. As it happens, he did not get too rough a ride at yesterday's Local Government Association conference in Bournemouth. They had already given what is fast becoming known as the WI treatment to the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, but artfully, he sought to pre-empt any attack by telling his audience that "unlike some others, I know the difference between a slow hand-clap and a round of applause". Still, he was not spared completely. They were happy enough as he promised to implement some of their longest-held wishes, including greater local discretion over how many houses get built and in what style. But when he said the Conservatives had a good record of backing local government, they simply laughed in his face.

As it happens, he did not get too rough a ride at yesterday's Local Government Association conference in Bournemouth. They had already given what is fast becoming known as the WI treatment to the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, but artfully, he sought to pre-empt any attack by telling his audience that "unlike some others, I know the difference between a slow hand-clap and a round of applause". Still, he was not spared completely. They were happy enough as he promised to implement some of their longest-held wishes, including greater local discretion over how many houses get built and in what style. But when he said the Conservatives had a good record of backing local government, they simply laughed in his face.

That is worrying for Mr Hague. It suggests that, for all his efforts to sing a new tune on public services - promising more support for hospitals, schools and councils - he will always run into a credibility problem: people still do not trust the Conservatives. But boos and hisses have a message for other politicians too. As Ms Armstrong and Tony Blair can attest, audiences are getting bolder. Deference is out. The old public meetings were often raucous - but selective groups like the Women's Institute tended to be much more polite. No longer. What explains the change? The answer might lie in the death of the public meeting itself. These days there's no outlet for dissent except for a good throaty heckle at a respectable do like the one in Bournemouth. And without public meetings to serve as a training ground, politicians rarely know how to deal with barracking when they get it. Most just freeze. Unless, like Mr Hague, they happen to have been born in the 1830s.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In Class Notes, Education, page 3, June 27, we said that 18,000 teachers would not receive computers under the government's computers for teachers scheme. In fact the 27,000 eligible teachers who applied received their equipment, but there were delays in reimbursing them. Michael Wills, the minister responsible, announced that anyone waiting longer than 30 days would receive an additional £15 payment for inconvenience.
fields.body:
In Class Notes, Education, page 3, June 27, we said that 18,000 teachers would not receive computers under the government's computers for teachers scheme. In fact the 27,000 eligible teachers who applied received their equipment, but there were delays in reimbursing them. Michael Wills, the minister responsible, announced that anyone waiting longer than 30 days would receive an additional £15 payment for inconvenience.

 Hans Küng appeared without his umlaut again in a column on page 20, yesterday. It is Guardian style to use all the accents that the German and French languages require.

 Near homophone corner, page 18, yesterday, where we spoke of "a licence for anally-retentive, insular, naval-gazing pretentiousness of the most unbearable order".

fields.headline: The lessons from Harare
fields.trailText: Your coverage of Zanu-PF's victories in the rural areas failed to focus on the most relevant factor (Why Mugabe owes a debt to rural voters, June 28). In each election the party has stressed that the vote is not secret. Voters are told that any wavering of support will lead to beatings and murders and the community being deprived of state handouts such as drought relief, which Mugabe has always presented as his personal gift. The intimidation, through the mobs of Zanu-PF youth, Hunzvi's "war veterans" and the network of local officials, did not allow any challenge to the beliefs and fears of the people.
fields.body:
Your coverage of Zanu-PF's victories in the rural areas failed to focus on the most relevant factor (Why Mugabe owes a debt to rural voters, June 28). In each election the party has stressed that the vote is not secret. Voters are told that any wavering of support will lead to beatings and murders and the community being deprived of state handouts such as drought relief, which Mugabe has always presented as his personal gift. The intimidation, through the mobs of Zanu-PF youth, Hunzvi's "war veterans" and the network of local officials, did not allow any challenge to the beliefs and fears of the people.

In those areas close to towns, where democratic re-education was possible, the MDC was victorious. The opposition's success in rural and "high density" township areas around Harare, argues against any "residual emotional support" for Zanu-PF.
Kevin Walsh
Bicester, Oxon

 The land issue in Zimbabwe could create an opportunity for the women of Zimbabwe to get back the rights taken from them in April 1999, when the supreme court determined that customary law took precedence over modern law and international treaties, and that women could not inherit or own land. Increasing numbers of women, especially those widowed as a result of Aids, have been made destitute by this denial of their human rights. The land issue was discussed intensively at Beijing and women's rights to inherit, own and control land were agreed by the Zimbabwean delegation at the recent Beijing+5 UN special session in New York.

In its endeavours to help Zimbabwe reduce poverty and restore economic stability, the international community should not forget the role and rights of women farmers. Margaret Owen
Empowering Widows in Development

 Your reports on Zimbabwe's elections and Uganda's referendum are instructive (Ugandans go the president's way, June 29). The Zimbabwe election was about a democratic choice between two parties; the Ugandan referendum is about legitimising the absence of democratic choice. Yet while you acknowledge the leniency of the west in accepting the absence of legal opposition in Uganda, you repeat the falsehood that Museveni is "a benign leader".

Reporting of the Kanungu massacre briefly lifted the lid on poverty and social breakdown in rural areas. Less publicised is the drought and famine in Karamoja and the associated cattle raiding into surrounding areas. Museveni's "solutions" include the use of helicopter gunships against cattle raiders. Throughout his 14 years he has failed to resolve the civil war in the north. Despite this he has had the resources for military adventures in Rwanda and the Congo.

Uganda needs a legal opposition to enable alternative political forces to develop. It is the west's support for Museveni that prevents this.
George Heron
Manchester george@parksway.demon.co.uk

 Zimbabwe's election has received blanket coverage in the British media. In contrast, I have seen little coverage of the Mexican elections which, next Sunday, may well mark the end of the oldest dominant party in the world - the PRI, which has ruled the country since 1929, and whose candidate is unprecedentedly running neck-and-neck with his chief opposition rival. Mexico is the 11th biggest economy in the world and a major recipient of British capital (vastly more than Zimbabwe). But I guess never having been part of the empire takes a long time to live down.
Alan Knight
Latin American Centre, Oxford

fields.headline: StillElite@ Oxford.com
fields.trailText: You report that Oxford's vice-chancellor has written to its alumni in the latest issue of the university's official magazine, Oxford Today, regretting that the recent row over the admission of Lorna Spence may have set back the university's alleged efforts to open up admissions to a wider range of UK school students (Backlash fears in Oxford elitism row, June 29).
fields.body:
You report that Oxford's vice-chancellor has written to its alumni in the latest issue of the university's official magazine, Oxford Today, regretting that the recent row over the admission of Lorna Spence may have set back the university's alleged efforts to open up admissions to a wider range of UK school students (Backlash fears in Oxford elitism row, June 29).

And yet the whole of the back cover of the same issue of Oxford Today is taken up with an advert for a company called Oxbridgejobs.com. Under the heading "Exclusively yours" the ad boasts that it "is a brand new recruitment service, exclusive to current and former students of Oxford and Cambridge Universities. Deliberately elite, [we] offer client companies a unique gateway to the most prestigious academic community in the world."

I wonder how many alumni feel as I do that it is morally repugnant for such a company to have been set up, apparently seeking to formalise the old boy network and bring it into the dot.com age? And what was the university thinking about in accepting this company's advertising for its official magazine, thereby seeming to endorse an initiative which must subvert equal opportunity for all school and university students, wherever they were educated? Does the right hand know what the left hand is doing as far as Oxford University is concerned?
Prof Patrick Dunleavy
Milton Keynes patrick@dunleavy.u-net.co

fields.headline: We nuke those greenhouse gases
fields.trailText: Nuclear energy in the UK is not "twice as costly" as other sources (Power failure, G2, June 28). The most modern nuclear power stations generate electricity at less than 2p a unit - fully competitive in today's modern electricity market. This includes provision for full decommissioning and other external costs.
fields.body:
Nuclear energy in the UK is not "twice as costly" as other sources (Power failure, G2, June 28). The most modern nuclear power stations generate electricity at less than 2p a unit - fully competitive in today's modern electricity market. This includes provision for full decommissioning and other external costs.

The entire article manages to discuss energy policy without even acknowledging the serious environmental threat of climate change now facing our planet. These dangers have been underlined just this month with the publication of the Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution's report, Energy - the future climate. This acknowledges nuclear's key role in the UK's electricity supply and environmental performance, stating that it is "the main source of carbon-free energy at present".

Andy Beckett attempts to dismiss the central part nuclear energy plays curbing Britain's greenhouse gas emissions in one sentence, stating that it is a "sly claim". The truth is that each year, nuclear energy in the UK saves the emission of about 65m tonnes of CO2. The awesome challenge of climate change requires a serious debate about the future of nuclear energy in the UK, as part of a balanced and diverse energy policy.
Ray Hall
Chairman, British Nuclear Industry Forum

 Your report appeared at the same time as a new report in Sweden by the International Project for Sustainable Energy Paths, predicting that all nuclear power plants in Europe could be phased out by the year 2020. It mean dozens of atomic communities would face the stark reality confronting Bradwell today.

Valerie Mainwood is right to stress the legacy of radioac tive detritus left behind when power generation stops. Atomic mauselia are destined to litter the land as monuments to a failed experiment.

When I did research around Bradwell for a book (The International Politics of Nuclear Waste, published by Macmillans in 1991), I found that concern over nuclear waste was non-existent when Bradwell was planned in the mid-1950s. A nuclear boffin told the local Essex County Standard (November 18 1955) "methods of dealing with radioactive waste [are] so well-known in all the countries of the world that there is no hazard attached to the disposal of them." Another told the same paper on 11 May 1956: "They in Bradwell were the guinea pigs for England and they might feel proud to be selected for the honour."
Dr David Lowry
Stoneleigh, Surrey dlowryrmb@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Toxic claim
fields.trailText: The UK is not a "dumping ground" for waste Channel Islands to dispose of toxic waste on mainland, June 24). UK policy is to encourage the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man to build their own facilities to be as self-sufficient as possible in waste disposal. But in the case of small quantities of specific wastes which these countries cannot reasonably be expected to deal with in an environmentally sound manner, the UK is prepared to accept them given that we have the necessary treatment facilities which meet tough environmental standards.
fields.body:
The UK is not a "dumping ground" for waste Channel Islands to dispose of toxic waste on mainland, June 24). UK policy is to encourage the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man to build their own facilities to be as self-sufficient as possible in waste disposal. But in the case of small quantities of specific wastes which these countries cannot reasonably be expected to deal with in an environmentally sound manner, the UK is prepared to accept them given that we have the necessary treatment facilities which meet tough environmental standards.

You claim there is a new agreement with the Isle of Man. This is not so. Agreements have existed since 1996 to permit the import of limited quantities of hazardous waste for disposal. The UK does not and will not accept domestic waste at all from the Isle of Man for disposal since the island is able to deal with such waste itself. Any proposed exports to the UK would be refused.

Michael Meacher
Minister for the environment

fields.headline: Tree scandal takes the bloom off Zion's dream
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The earth was pulled from under a cherished ritual of Jewish childhood yesterday - almost literally - when the Jewish National Fund admitted that pine saplings planted in a Jerusalem forest had been uprooted and left to die.
fields.body:
The earth was pulled from under a cherished ritual of Jewish childhood yesterday - almost literally - when the Jewish National Fund admitted that pine saplings planted in a Jerusalem forest had been uprooted and left to die.

For generations, Jewish children around the world have donated their pocket money to buy stamps to be pasted in the shape of a tree, earning a certificate on completion that their sapling is part of the Zionist project of making the desert bloom.

Dozens of tour groups make a weekly pilgrimage, paying $10 to kneel in the dirt and plant their own tree to a background of songs, prayers and other ceremonies in JNF forests around Israel, as have visiting presidents and prime ministers.

But yesterday Yehiel Leket, co-chairman of the JNF, which owns more than 90% of the land in Israel, admitted that saplings planted by visitors in a forest near the Jerusalem suburb of Ein Kerem suburb were ripped out moments later to make way for the next group of tourists on a similar mission. He claimed that it was an isolated incident.

"It is a few saplings in a new site. Altogether we plant in Israel 2.5m trees every year. I completely deny the allegation that this is a systematic practice by the JNF. What is the sense of risking our credibility by taking out saplings? We can prove that every tree planted by a tourist still exists."

The tree scandal was unearthed by the Ma'ariv newspaper. Its reporters visited the Ein Kerem forest on June 25 and found a plot of withered saplings, each tethered to a sign reading: "I planted a tree in Israel."

One day later, when the reporters returned, the plot was bare but for a few forlorn holes, and they discovered sackloads of uprooted saplings littered around the area.

Ma'ariv said the plot had been planted as a memorial by the family of an American teenager, Assaf Green, who died aged 16.

Mr Leket said the JNF was conducting an internal investigation. "We will punish those responsible very severely, and we hope to convince the public abroad and in Israel that the JNF has credibility, and that nothing wrong has been done in terms of policy, and in terms of the respect we pay to individual donors."

He denied the newspaper's allegation that the JNF was systematically uprooting saplings, for which it pays a nominal sum, and pocketing the bulk of the $10 donations.

The JNF raises about $10m (£6.6m) in donations every year from Jews living abroad who plant trees in Israel. A JNF pamphlet for visitors to Israel says: "Planting a tree in the land of the Bible gives the tourist an opportunity to leave his personal, green mark on the nation's vista."

Although the organisation has been criticised in Jewish fundraising circles for high overheads and for clinging to the notion that Israel needs to keep expanding its forests, it is a venerable institution.

At the annual meeting in Jerusalem yesterday of the Jewish Agency, the most important yearly gathering of world Jewish community leaders, people were struggling to come to terms with the report.

"I cannot believe it," said Bobi Klotz, a delegate from New York.

"It is very difficult for me to even process this. I just can not believe that the JNF would do that. I think it is a very reputable organisation."

Others said they would make sure Jewish children were not disillusioned by the affair.

"I would say there is vandalism everywhere," said Rabbi Daniel Allen, executive vice-chairman of the United Israel Appeal. "Let us go plant another tree. That is what I would tell them."

webTitle: Trading insults on Hague's Nafta plan

fields.headline: Trading insults on Hague's Nafta plan
fields.trailText: Any rational examination shows that Senator Gramm's suggestion, enthusiastically supported by many in the Conservative party, that Britain should join Nafta is ludicrous (Foreign Office memo dismisses Hague's 'barmy' plan to join American trade area, June 28). The achievements of the Gatt (now WTO), which Gramm praises for its success in eliminating barriers to trade, makes such a leap of faith unnecessary. Average tariffs on industrial goods between the US and the EU have plummeted because of successive Gatt tariff-cutting rounds since the war. Trade between the UK and Nafta is far less hindered than Gramm and the Conservatives find it convenient to suggest.
fields.body:
Any rational examination shows that Senator Gramm's suggestion, enthusiastically supported by many in the Conservative party, that Britain should join Nafta is ludicrous (Foreign Office memo dismisses Hague's 'barmy' plan to join American trade area, June 28). The achievements of the Gatt (now WTO), which Gramm praises for its success in eliminating barriers to trade, makes such a leap of faith unnecessary. Average tariffs on industrial goods between the US and the EU have plummeted because of successive Gatt tariff-cutting rounds since the war. Trade between the UK and Nafta is far less hindered than Gramm and the Conservatives find it convenient to suggest.

Only 17% of Britain's total trade in goods and services is with Nafta, compared to 53% destined for the European Union. If present Nafta tariffs on British goods were eliminated, we would gain around £1.2bn. However, by losing tariff-free access to the EU market, we would incur £4.7bn of extra costs. A net loss of £3.5bn for British business. The economic case could not be clearer. It would be self-defeating in the extreme.

Both Senator Gramm and William Hague's Conservative party wish to dislodge the UK from its place in the EU and replace it with a transatlantic pipe dream. Yet it is highly doubtful that any US administration would welcome a free floating UK drifting in the political waters somewhere south of Greenland. Nick Clegg MEP
Liberal Democrat trade spokesman nclegg@europarl.eu.int

 I am researching Britain's "Nafta option" for a pamphlet to be published in September by Action Centre for Europe. Your articles foreshadowing Gramm's visit overrate the importance of the senate committee, which has no powers to conclude trade agreements with Britain or anyone else. The power to initiate or negotiate international treaties is a presidential prerogative.

One trade economist at a major think tank in Washington described this issue to me as "at best, business of the fourth-order". Most important policymakers in the US probably remain unaware of the suggestion. Moreover, those who are concerned about security and defence issues would view this idea as threatening to Nato.
Desmond Butler
London

fields.headline: I thought of it first
fields.trailText:
Fifteen years ago I started to advocate the bulk transfer of water by canal. My idea was consistently dismissed as unworkable. I eventually gave up and recently destroyed all my correspondence in despair. Now you report (Canals to solve south's water shortage, June 28) that British Waterways has come up with this amazing innovation.
Wing Cdr Derek Martin
Medmenham, Bucks

 Jim White appears to have got mixed up between lads' magazine Loaded and men's magazine FHM (RIP the lad, G2, June 29). It is the former, associated with the excesses of the 90s, that is in decline, according to the magazine industry ABC figures; the latter continues to grow, as is evidenced by its most recent issue selling 900,000 copies.
Barry McIlheney
Global brand director, FHM

 Oh, Mo - how refreshing for truth and honesty to be on display, if only fleetingly, in a sea of political double talk (Mowlam apology, June 29). Agree with you or not (I do), this is why the public love you so. Long may you reign.
LR Smith
Horsham, West Sussex

 If Buckingham Palace is vacated by its occupants, would this be an appropriate pied a terre for Mayor Ken?
Dr William Hipperson
Lindfield, W Sussex

 Thanks for the recent free publicity (Letters, June 29). It was not until I chose the trading name 13 years ago that I discovered only one in 10 people knows the proverb.
Sue Merriman
The Parsnip Buttery, Wolverhampton
SueParsnip@aol.com

 "Too many births ...because of the eclipse" (G2, June 27): it was dark for only a couple of minutes, somewhat contradicting the survey crediting British sex with lasting over 20 minutes.
Andy Coombe
Dartmouth, Devon

webTitle: Minister's pledge on child abuse scandal

fields.headline: Minister's pledge on child abuse scandal
fields.standfirst:
More about the Wales child abuse scandal
The issue explained: Children in care
fields.trailText: The health minister, John Hutton, promised yesterday to learn from the north Wales child abuse scandal.
fields.body:
The health minister, John Hutton, promised yesterday to learn from the north Wales child abuse scandal.

"This government is determined to ensure everything than can be done is done to protect children," he said in response to the report by Sir Ronald Waterhouse QC which followed a three-year inquiry into children's homes in Gwynedd and Clwyd between 1974 and 1990.

Mr Hutton said nine of Sir Ronald's recommendations were matters for the Welsh assembly: "Of the remaining 63, we agree with the spirit of each and every one."

The Association of Directors of Social Services welcomed the report but said the problems would not be fully resolved without adequate recources. Abuse victims and their lawyers condemned it.

"I am very disappointed," said Steve Messham for North Wales Abuse Survivors. "The tribunal made us relive the abuse we had suffered, but for what? We have had no help, support, counselling or compensation."

Sir Ronald heard evidence from 240 victims. His report mentions, but does not always name, 200 abusers, alleged abusers and care workers who failed to protect their charges.

He recommended changes in care provision, a Welsh commissioner to look after children's needs, ways for staff to blow the whistle on abuse, and a children's complaints officer for every local council.

Mr Hutton said reforms had been introduced in a £375m initiative, and two legislative bills would be introduced.

fields.headline: Press in Fiji taken hostage
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Tensions in Fiji's political standoff increased yesterday when gunmen forcibly held 16 journalists inside the parliamentary complex where 27 members of the deposed government are being kept hostage.
fields.body:
Tensions in Fiji's political standoff increased yesterday when gunmen forcibly held 16 journalists inside the parliamentary complex where 27 members of the deposed government are being kept hostage.

The reporters - nine from abroad and seven from Fiji - were released after being held for more than an hour. But the incident caused alarm that the rebels, led by failed businessman George Speight, might try to take more hostages.

"I think it actually marks a dangerous escalation in this business because clearly George has cut out press conferences as an option," said Michael Field, a reporter who was among those held.

Earlier yesterday, the army announced that it would cordon off the parliament compound in an effort to further isolate the hostage-takers.

Officials also said they were considering cutting off supplies, water, electricity, and telephone lines to the gunmen, but there was no evidence that any of those measures had been put into effect.
AP

fields.headline: 'Myth' of aspirin and the heart
fields.standfirst: Study raises fear of more harm than good for some
fields.trailText: Aspirin, the supposedly benign wonder drug taken by many men who fear heart attacks, may actually harm some of those most at risk, researchers warn today.
fields.body:
Aspirin, the supposedly benign wonder drug taken by many men who fear heart attacks, may actually harm some of those most at risk, researchers warn today.

For more than 50 years, doctors have recommended aspirin with increasing confidence to reduce the risk of heart attacks by dissolving dangerous blood clots.

But the results of a study, published today in the British Medical Journal, suggest that in men with high blood pressure - among those most susceptible to heart attacks - aspirin does more harm than good.

In a seven-year research programme involving over 5,000 British men aged between 45 and 69, it was found that men with high blood pressure were unlikely to get heart disease protection from aspirin but risked potentially serious internal bleeding.

Even men with low blood pressure might suffer more harm than good from the drug. The British Heart Foundation said the survey was a powerful warning to those who had no symptoms of heart disease but took daily doses of aspirin in the belief it would ward off a heart attack or stroke, rather than taking exercise and cutting out fatty foods.

The survey showed that aspirin-poppers who had not had their blood pressure checked by their GP were at particular risk, the BHF said.

"I know people who have been self-prescribing aspirin for years and years in the belief it will stop them having coronary heart disease. But the best way is to cut out fatty foods," said BHF spokeswoman Gaynor Dewsnap.

"People think that they can have a sedentary lifestyle, eat lots of chips, take an aspirin and everything will be all right."

Overall, the aspirin-takers in the study had 20% fewer strokes, heart attacks and deaths from heart failure.

But the research team's leader, Prof Tom Meade, said this was not good enough to outweigh the risks of bleeding.

"Although aspirin does reduce the risk of a first heart at tack the effect is not large," he said. "Even low doses of aspirin may cause bleeding, which is sometimes serious. However, most people who have previously had a heart attack should take aspirin as the benefits for them are much greater."

Most patients who have had heart attacks are now advised to take 75 mg of aspirin a day, equivalent to a quarter of a tablet.

Aspirin was launched as a painkiller by the German firm Bayer in 1899, although a precursor substance, found in willow leaves and bark, was known to the Greek physician Hippocrates as far back as 200 BC.

In 1948, a California doctor noticed the link between aspirin and reduced heart disease, and started recommending "an aspirin a day" to patients and colleagues.

The drug's reputation as a shield against heart disease grew from there, although it was not until 1982 that the British pharmacologist John Vane discovered how it actually worked, winning him the Nobel Prize for Medicine.

fields.headline: Austria accepts EU rights monitors
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria has grudgingly accepted plans for European Union "wise men" to monitor its human rights performance, as a prelude to lifting, probably early next year, the punitive sanctions imposed when the far-right Freedom party was taken into the coalition government earlier this year.
fields.body:
Austria has grudgingly accepted plans for European Union "wise men" to monitor its human rights performance, as a prelude to lifting, probably early next year, the punitive sanctions imposed when the far-right Freedom party was taken into the coalition government earlier this year.

Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel said last night that he would accept the plan proposed by Portugal to check whether the coalition was abiding by "common European values".

But he berated the 14 other EU governments for failing to set a date to lift the sanctions.

Portugal worked against the clock to reach an agreement before its six-month tenure of the EU presidency ends tonight. France, far more hardline on Austria, takes over tomorrow.

Sanctions will continue while the three wise men monitor Austria's respect for "the rights of minorities, refugees and immigrants" and "the evolution of the nature [of the Freedom party]", a Portuguese statement said.

It is widely assumed that the sanctions will be lifted in January, when Sweden takes over the EU helm.

Mr Schüssel said Austria's continuing diplomatic isolation was "a dead-end street", but called the Portuguese proposal "progress which we recognise".

The European court of human rights in Strasbourg, which is not part of the EU, agreed to appoint three judges to report to the 14.

Diplomats hope the scheme will be enough to head off Austria's threat to delay the reforms needed before the EU can expand and to ask its people to condemn their EU partners in a referendum.

The French far-right leader Jean Marie Le Pen attacked the monitoring decision as "scandalous", saying EU governments were "trying to claim a prerogative which was never agreed upon in any European treaty - that is, to censor a people's opinion".
