fields.headline: 500 missing on spice islands' ship
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: A ship overloaded with almost 500 people, many fleeing sectarian violence in the Molucca islands - the Indonesian spice islands - was missing, presumed sunk yesterday.
fields.body:
A ship overloaded with almost 500 people, many fleeing sectarian violence in the Molucca islands - the Indonesian spice islands - was missing, presumed sunk yesterday.

The Indonesian national search and rescue agency said the wooden-hulled Cahaya Bahari made a distress call in stormy weather. Radio contact was lost after the captain said the vessel was taking on water in heavy seas.Port officials said it had gone down.

Rescue ships were reported to have reached the search area, 40 miles east of Siau island and 1,450 miles north-east of the capital, Jakarta, but were being hampered by the bad weather.

The ship was licensed to carry only about 250 people, an official said. Of the 492 on board, 290 were refugees from Duma, a Christian village where more than 100 people were killed 11 days ago in fighting with Muslim raiders. The ship also carried 186 normal passengers and 16 crew.

It left Tobelo on Halmahera, the main island in North Molucca province, on Wednesday afternoon for Manado, the capital of North Sulawesi province.

Shipping disasters are frequent in Indonesia, where maritime standards are lax and poorly maintained ships are often overloaded with passengers and cargo.

Meanwhile, sniper fire and bomb blasts shook Ambon, the capital of the Moluccas, but the fighting between Muslims and Christians abated as the state of emergency imposed four days ago took hold.

Frightened residents took shelter in abandoned houses and makeshift camps while hundreds of soldiers patrolled the streets.

"We're praying that it is all over," said Erik Mahale, a local journalist. "Everything was quiet through the night except for a few explosions and rifle fire."

At least 71 people have been killed in Ambon since the attack on Duma.

Despite the violence easing, international relief organisations said it was still too dangerous to deliver food, drinking water and medicines to the tens of thousands of refugees and hospitals in Ambon. Philip Havet of Médecins sans Frontières said: "It's not possible to move around the city. There are barricades everywhere. But the hospitals really need help. Their supplies are quickly running out."

President Abdurrahman Wahid declared a civil emergency on Monday to give the security forces greater powers to crack down on sectarian gangs. Soldiers had been accused of doing little, and of actively taking sides.

On Wednesday the Pope called for peace and urged the Indonesian government to do more to end the violence, in which almost 3,000 people of both faiths have died in the past 18 months. AP

Despite the violence easing, international relief organisations said it was still too dangerous to deliver food, drinking water and medicines to the tens of thousands of refugees and hospitals in Ambon. Philip Havet of Médecins sans Frontières said: "It's not possible to move around the city. There are barricades everywhere. But the hospitals really need help. Their supplies are quickly running out." President Abdurrahman Wahid declared a civil emergency on Monday to give the security forces greater powers to crack down on sectarian gangs. Soldiers had been accused of doing little, and of actively taking sides. On Wednesday the Pope called for peace and urged the Indonesian government to do more to end the violence, in which almost 3,000 people of both faiths have died in the past 18 months. AP

webTitle: Exile ends for scourge of Suharto

fields.headline: Exile ends for scourge of Suharto
fields.standfirst:
The Briton who campaigned for human rights returns after 30 years Campaigner's pilgrimage to Indonesia three decades after prison ordeal
Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The only Briton to endure the horror of being a political prisoner in Indonesia during the Suharto regime returned to Jakarta yesterday for the first time in almost 30 years.
fields.body:
The only Briton to endure the horror of being a political prisoner in Indonesia during the Suharto regime returned to Jakarta yesterday for the first time in almost 30 years.

But for Carmel Budiardjo, 75, who was imprisoned without trial from 1968 to 1971 on suspicion of being a communist, the four-week visit will be anything but a nostalgic trip down memory lane.

"This is an opportunity for me to see the people that I have been working with for so long via remote communication," she said.

Since her release she has run an unrelenting campaign on a shoestring budget from her home in Thornton Heath, Surrey, against human rights abuses by General Suharto's regime. Until recently she was on an immigration blacklist that prohibited her from visiting Indonesia.

"I've learnt the importance of human rights through bitter personal experience," Ms Budiardjo said, glossing over her three-year physical and psychological ordeal. "I had no formal training but knew that something had to be done.

"I felt a very strong commitment to people I'd left behind in prison. I'd been treated favourably because I was English. I felt I had let them down."

So, despite signing a document on her release in which she promised not to participate in any anti-Indonesian activities, Ms Budiardjo soon began campaigning for the release of the remaining tens of thousands of political prisoners.

Among them was her husband, Suwando Budiardjo. They met in Prague in 1948 when she was an activist with the leftwing International Union of Students and he was on a scholarship to study political science.

They married two years later, despite much family opposition because he was Muslim and she Jewish, and settled in Indonesia in 1952 with their baby daughter, Tari.

While her husband worked as a civil servant, Ms Budiardjo became a researcher at the foreign ministry. She was involved in various leftwing academic associations but never joined the Indonesian Communist party.

Mr Budiardjo had previously been detained and released as part of the massive anti-communist purge by Gen Suharto after an attempted army coup in 1965 was blamed on communists.

He was detained again when Carmel was arrested in September 1968, simply because he accompanied her to the military post. This time he was not released for 10 years. Their marriage did not survive the protracted separation.

On her return to Britain, Ms Budiardjo formed Tapol (a contraction of two Indonesian words meaning political prisoner) in 1973 to raise awareness in Britain of Indonesian human rights abuses.

But when Gen Suharto invaded East Timor in 1975 and news started filtering out of Irian Jaya, the Indonesian half of New Guinea, of massive military oppression there in the mid-70s, she said the infant organisation was "soon doing much more than just campaigning for political prisoners".

Tapol also expanded from its British base to become more international in scope, and became known as the Indonesia Human Rights Campaign. Both it and Ms Budiardjo have won several awards for their work.

Even though Indonesia opened up enormously after the fall of Gen Suharto in May 1998, Ms Budiardjo did not end her campaigning.

"The way things are going, an international organisation like Tapol has a very important role to play," she said. "If the calls for justice are not handled properly then international pressure has to be brought to bear."

Indonesian prosecutors are currently looking into numerous brutal incidents committed during the Suharto years in addition to investigating the former president for allegedly embezzling tens of billions of pounds.

"What I'm afraid about is that the military is trying to strike back," Ms Budiardjo said. "The big question is whether the men who should be brought to justice - ie the generals - will let all these investigations go ahead."

webTitle: Novel airship design reaches for the sky

fields.headline: Novel airship design reaches for the sky
fields.trailText: Like an unusually beautiful slug, the world's latest airship performed a gentle but limited ballet yesterday outside the hangars which once housed its ill-starred predecessor, the R101.
fields.body:
Like an unusually beautiful slug, the world's latest airship performed a gentle but limited ballet yesterday outside the hangars which once housed its ill-starred predecessor, the R101.

Powered by a novel combination of hovercraft and aeroplane engines, the prototype SkyKitten whirred and wobbled in a vast marquee, after crowds of onlookers made a full-scale test flight too risky.

Clad in material including flakjacket bullet-proofing, the 50ft dirigible hopes to reverse the accident-strewn history of aviation's least successful - but most persistent - invention. The prototype has already floated for trials of up to a mile, leading to production of a commercial model eight times the size.

"We're using at least four new concepts in airship technology and they are all work ing well together," said Roger Munk, 53, whose Airship Technologies company plans a range of the new "hoverships" from the Kitten to a 1,000-tonne SkyCat. An enormous transporter, capable of carrying 1,500 people or 880 Ford Mondeos, the Cat would be the largest aircraft ever to fly.

The Kitten's more modest range, from a 15-tonne version to a 1,000-tonner, has attracted interest from charities working in developing countries, thanks to its potential carrying capacity and an ability to land almost anywhere. Mr Munk, who has designed and built small airships for 30 years, has fitted hovercraft engines for take-off and, more significantly, to allow the Kitten to grip the ground with reverse thrust.

As the prototype wobbled gracefully at Cardington airfield, near Bedford, Mr Munk said: "She's working beautifully. The great thing is that her shape and the hovercraft engines get over the problem of payload."

Previous large airships, including the disastrous Hindenburg which crashed in flames in Chicago in 1937, had to be secured by ground crews of up to 200 to prevent their buoyancy lifting the craft sky high during unloading.

Airship Technologies has already received one order for a 15-tonne version, depending on successful trials, and is trial-marketing the proposed 200-tonne payload version at £66m.

The hovercraft pioneer Martin Stevens, who has retired to the Isle of Wight, came back to work as consultant to the project, overcoming initial doubts about what "sounded like a screwball idea".

Airships are enjoying a modest revival. The industry's greatest problem has been fears of a second Hindenburg catastrophe. But the replacement of hydrogen with non-flammable helium has made disaster much less likely.

Mr Munk's previous company Airship Industries, which built 25 Skyship 500 and 600 models, went under eight years ago with the collapse of the companies of its Australian backer Alan Bond. But Mr Munk said: "There is an obvious and very big gap in the freight market between sea freight and air freight, which airships have the potential to fill."

fields.headline: Stadium looks for sponsors
fields.trailText: Cardiff's Millennium Stadium is looking for a commercial sponsor to help pay off some of its debts.
fields.body:
Cardiff's Millennium Stadium is looking for a commercial sponsor to help pay off some of its debts.

The proposal to allow a private sector enterprise to append its name to the 72,500-capacity venue could raise up to £20m for the stadium's owner, the Welsh Rugby Union, which needs to find nearly £12m to pay off creditors this year.

But the move may cause friction with officials at the millennium commission and among diehard rugby fans still mourning the loss of Cardiff Arms Park, knocked down to make way for the new jewel in Wales's sporting crown.

Max Boyce, comic and rugby fanatic, suggested yesterday that rugby supporters could chip in to help the WRU out of its difficulties.

A WRU spokesman said yesterday that proposals to sell the name were contained in the union's original business plan for the £126m stadium. Discussions had already taken place with a number of companies. He said the union had no choice but to find commercial backing if it was to make the venture financially viable.

The millennium commission said yesterday that lottery players had contributed £46m towards the cost of building the stadium.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Divers recover henge stone
fields.body:
Divers recover henge stone

Divers and salvage ships yesterday recovered a three-tonne Pembrokeshire bluestone lying in 50ft of water off the coast of west Wales.

The stone had been lost while being transported between two replica Stone Age boats, but will shortly continue by sea and land to Wiltshire, to demonstrate how Stonehenge was built 4,000 years ago.

Gas meters to read themselves

Estimated bills and meter readers are to become a thing of the past for British Gas customers.

It is to test new technology in north London and Manchester that will send information to a central billing computer by means of a small transmitter attached to the meter.

Methodists keep drink ban

The Methodist Conference in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, yesterday voted unanimously to retain rules forbidding consumption of alcohol, but agreed other denominations could use alcoholic wine if celebrating communion in one of its churches.

For the first time women were elected as president and vice president from June next year: the Rev Dr Christina Le Moignan and Mrs Ann Leck.

College room for improvement

Undergraduates at Corpus Christi, Cambridge, are opposing a scheme whereby they will be awarded a choice of accommodation in college according to their success in end of year exams.

Academically, Corpus Christi is 17th out of 23 colleges. Senior tutor Christopher Kelly said: "We need to improve results."

No truck with witchcraft

Canterbury cathedral has rejected a request from Warner Bros in Hollywood to portray its gothic building as a school of witchcraft and wizardry for a film of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.

A cathedral spokesman said: "Certain Christians have said they feel there are elements in the book which do not fit in with Christianity, and we are sensitive to those feelings even if some may not agree with them."

fields.headline: 35-year sneezing fit blamed on muesli
fields.trailText: A man who sneezed continually for 35 years has finally been cured.
fields.body:
A man who sneezed continually for 35 years has finally been cured.

Patrick Webster saw more than 60 doctors and went to three different hospitals after sneezing hundreds of times a day only to be told they had no idea what was causing the problem.

The 52-year-old former civil servant is considering suing his local health authority after discovering he is allergic to his breakfast, after being told he had no allergies.

Scientists in York have revealed that Mr Webster, from Bournemouth, who prepares his own muesli every morning, is allergic to oats.

Mr Webster began sneezing when he was just 17 and says he sneezed several hundred times a day all year round.

"I was so desperate to sort it out that I took six months off work and ended up in three different hospitals. I had skin tests for allergies but they were negative, so the doctors would not give me any other allergy test."

For 20 years, he took steroids in a vain attempt to beat the sneezes. Finally, tests by York Nutritional Laboratory revealed "a moderate reaction" to oats and egg yolk. As soon as he stopped eating his muesli, the sneezing stopped.
Press Association

webTitle: Russia dying of drink and despair

fields.headline: Russia dying of drink and despair
fields.trailText: On a scorching June day by the seaside in northern Russia, the murky brown waters and sandy beaches of the White Sea echo to the happy sound of splashing children.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Onega, northern Russia
fields.body:
On a scorching June day by the seaside in northern Russia, the murky brown waters and sandy beaches of the White Sea echo to the happy sound of splashing children.

It is the best time of year in this decaying little port town that is a centre of the Russian timber and paper industry. Here in the far north, the sun never sets for much of June during the White Sea's "White Nights".

It's the outdoor party season. But if the paddling toddlers and flirting teenagers are oblivious to the dangers of bathing in these heavily polluted waters, the odds are stacked against half of them reaching the age of retirement in a society in the throes of a full-blown demographic and public health crisis.

Russia is sick. And President Vladimir Putin knows it. When he stands before both houses of parliament in Moscow, probably next week, to unveil for the first time his vision of where he wants to take his country, the president will vow to "resurrect the strong and prosperous Russian family", according to leaks of his draft speech.

The "resurrection" will take a while. Increasing numbers of Russian women do not want to have babies. In the decade since communism collapsed, the birth rate in Russia has halved. A quarter of women of child-bearing age surveyed in an opinion poll said they had no intention of becoming mothers. The medical journal, Meditsinskaya Gazeta, reported last month that only one baby in 10 was born healthy in Russia.

"Pregnancy and child-bearing are about 10 times more dangerous for a Russian mother than, for example, a woman in Germany," says Dr Mikko Vienonen, head of the World Health Organisation in Russia.

While the birth rate slumps, mortality rates are soaring, particularly among males who, according to Dr Vienonen, can now expect to live to the age of 59, 14 years less than west European men.

"Russia is facing a demographic crisis unprecedented in a developed country in peacetime," says Dr Vienonen. A male in his 30s is three times as likely to die in Russia as in western Europe.

Among the reasons for the filth on the Onega beaches is the effluent pouring into the sea from the town's factory which produces industrial spirit. But output from the plant is also pilfered and sold at a fraction of the price of the local vodka, leaving the men of the town blind-drunk much of the time and killing them off by the hundred.

"The general drunkenness is a disaster, particularly in the villages where there is no work," says an Onega policeman. "The menfolk are drunk all day every day. And it's spirit. The death rate is terrible."

If vodka is the bane of the Russian woman's existence, it is also the big killer of Russian men, largely responsible for the shrinkage of the population by more than three million in recent years.

Poisoning from alcohol was to blame for 7% of deaths last year among males aged 20-55. In the first four months of this year, death from drink has soared 43% over the same period last year, according to the state statistics committee.

A three-year study by the International Family Research Institute in Moscow found that among male deaths in that age group, two-thirds died drunk. Alcohol also plays a huge role in suicide, now the third biggest killer of middle-aged men, in road accidents, heart disease, and violent deaths.

After a weekend of non-stop bingeing, the study found, deaths from alcoholic poisoning climb on Mondays. "As long as a bottle of vodka costs as much as a kilo of apples, milk is more expensive than beer, and a packet of cigarettes is cheaper than chewing gum, any country would have a demographic crisis," says Dr Vienonen.

Data from the state statistics committee paint the grimmest picture of what some say is a country in the grip of national psycho-social depression. Deaths outstripped births by a factor of almost two-to-one in the first four months of this year, cutting the population of 145.5m by almost 300,000.

On average there were 146 suicides a day. The murder rate, 108 a day, was around four times the rate in the US and almost 20 times that in England and Wales.

Such shocking figures illustrate the challenges confronting Mr Putin in his promise to restore Russian dignity, "greatness", and to nurse in Russian children "the spirit of victory that typifies our people". By contrast, politicians and experts are muttering apocalyptically not about victory, but about loss, defeat, and threats to Russia's very existence.

The former mayor of Moscow, Gavriil Popov, terms the demographic crisis a "Russian holocaust". Alevtina Aparina, a member of the duma (parliament) and social policy expert, describes government neglect of the issue as "genocide against our own people". Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the writer, has urged that "saving the people" be the bottom line of a new Russian "national idea".

On current trends - and all the experts say the trends cannot be reversed in the short-term - Russia's population will shrink by one third to 100m by 2025. Birth rates are also low in the West, but there they are coupled with expanding ageing populations, whereas Russia is seized by "hypermortality".

"We've reached a watershed," said Nikolay Gerasimenko, chairman of parliament's health committee. "It is time to ask whether the Russian nation will continue to exist. Even if the authorities were to begin to implement policies beneficial to population growth, decline will continue for another several years."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Subway gas killer to hang
fields.body:
Subway gas killer to hang

The leading hit man of the cult responsible for the fatal 1995 gas attack on the Tokyo subway was sentenced to hang yesterday.

Yasuo Hayashi, 42, was one of five cult members who released sarin gas on rush-hour trains, killing 12 people and leaving thousands of others feeling sick.

He was also found guilty of carrying out other murders and acts of intimidation. Jonathan Watts, Tokyo

Clunk, click is the new chic

The Braathens airline in Norway has hit an unexpected safety problem. Seat belts on its aircraft are vanishing in the name of fashion.

fields.headline: Police 'dispose' of Honduran street kids
fields.trailText: More than 300 street children and youths have been murdered in Honduras in the past two-and-a-half years as part of a "social cleansing" programme, according to a new survey published this week.
fields.body:
More than 300 street children and youths have been murdered in Honduras in the past two-and-a-half years as part of a "social cleansing" programme, according to a new survey published this week.

Calls are being made to the United Nations high commissioner for human rights to press the Honduran government to investigate the killings and punish those responsible.

Members of the police and the security services are involved in many of the killings, according to the report. Similar killings of street children and "undesirables" have occurred in Brazil but until now it was not known how widespread such murders were in Honduras.

It is suggested that police officers and members of the military dispose of the children because they are believed to be responsible for some of the large numbers of petty crimes carried out in cities like Tegucigalpa and San Pedro Sula.

"Shockingly, the statistics for the first five months of this year indicate an increase in murders of children under the age of 15," said the report by Casa Alianza, the group that works with Mexican and Central American children from its base in San Jose, Costa Rica.

"In 1999, 15 children under the age of 15 were murdered. However, as of May 31 this year, 13 children under 15 have been murdered and we fear that the list may not be exhaustive."

Researchers working for the legal offices of Casa Alianza in Honduras documented 302 murders of street children and youths from the beginning of January 1998 until the end of May this year. Of the victims, 55% were under the age of 18 and 93% were male.

Most of the murders go unpunished with the killers listed as "unknown" in 74% of the cases. The majority of the killings took place in the departments of Cortes and Francisco Morazon.

Police or members of the security forces have been proven to be involved in 36 murders. Casa Alianza claimed to have had no response from the minister for public security, Elizabeth Chiaz Sierra, to their requests for action.

Bruce Harris, the British-born executive director of Casa Alianza, said this week: "The Honduran authorities have the information on these murders yet have not been capable of prosecuting those responsible."

Mr Harris called for an investigation to be carried out by Asma Jahangea, the UN special rapporteur on arbitrary and extrajudicial executions. He also wants UN human rights commissioner Mary Robinson to intervene and bring world attention to the issue.

Honduras is a signatory to the UN convention on the rights of the child which stipulates under article 19 that member states are obliged to "protect children from all forms of mental and physical violence, injuries or abuse".

There is growing concern about the number of abandoned children now living on the streets in Central America. A UN report on children in Guatemala published earlier this year found that there were between 1,500 and 5,000 street children, mainly living in Guatemala City.

"The main sources of income for these children are robbery, prostitution or begging and it is estimated that as many as 90% of the street children engage in substance abuse, for example inhaling shoe glue or paint thinner," said the report.

webTitle: Mexicans wonder: do we dare oust the PRI?

fields.headline: Mexicans wonder: do we dare oust the PRI?
fields.standfirst: After decades of patronage politics, the ruling party is vulnerable for the first time as Mexico picks a president
fields.trailText: This weekend brings something new for the voters of Mexico. Never before have they gone to the polling stations in the knowledge that the Institutional Revolutionary Party might actually lose the presidency it has held for 71 years.
fields.body:
This weekend brings something new for the voters of Mexico. Never before have they gone to the polling stations in the knowledge that the Institutional Revolutionary Party might actually lose the presidency it has held for 71 years.

The last opinion surveys ahead of Sunday's election show the PRI candidate, Francisco Labastida, just a whisker ahead of the opposition challenger, Vicente Fox of the centre-right National Action Party, the PAN.

If the polls are right about the tiny margin between the two men, great importance attaches to the decisions made on election day by the 15% of voters who told the pollsters they were still undecided.

Also crucial could be those intending to vote for leftwinger Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the Democratic Revolution Party, the PRD, who lies a distant third in the opinion surveys. He has repeatedly refused to agree to an alliance with Mr Fox.

Right up to the moment when campaigning ended by law on Wednesday, Mr Fox was courting and cajoling PRD supporters. If he ends up losing because Mr Cardenas draws away anti-PRI votes, Mr Fox declared, "history will be a very severe judge of Cuauhtemoc".

Character attacks

Very few commentators are willing to call the outcome - not least because no one is sure how truthful people have been with the pollsters. Carlos Elizondo of the think-tank Cide said the imponderables included: "What the undecided voters will do; how many people lied because they were afraid to say they were voting against the PRI, or ashamed to say that they would; where it might rain and who that would affect."

For the last two months the PRI has primed its unparalleled electoral machine to call in the votes all over the country. It has also set about trying to ruin the reputation of Mr Fox.

Assisted by an increasing bias against the challenger in the media, the PRI has portrayed Mr Fox as an unpatriotic liar and closet authoritarian, as well as hinting at mental instability and impotence.

The election, said another political analyst, Alfonso Zarate, is going to be a test pitting the apparatus of the PRI against people's general exasperation with this party. And it will test the "marketing that made Fox into a plausible candidate".

Mr Fox, a former Coca-Cola executive who stands 6ft 6in in his favourite boots, is putting his faith in a tough-guy image, a campaign slogan proclaiming, "we have already won," and those ardent pleas to Cardenas followers to abandon the veteran politician on his third doomed bid for the presidency.

Election day will not necessarily end the cliff-hanger. A tight win by Mr Labastida would probably be contested by Mr Fox.

Organised by a genuinely independent electoral body for the first time, this is a ballot where blatant fraud will be difficult. But the poll's fairness has already been questioned by international and national observers who say there is evidence of pre-election day irregularities favouring the governing party.

These include mass donations in impoverished areas of building materials, bicycles and even washing machines, on the understanding that the recipients vote for the party. Federal anti-poverty programmes have been aggressively used to promote the PRI, and state sector workers have reported pressure to campaign for Mr Labastida, or risk their jobs.

"If Vicente Fox thinks there was fraud he's going to raise a lot of hell," said Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, one of the challenger's closest advisers who is tipped as his likely foreign minister.

PRI speakers have also been trying to frighten people by saying that the opposition, if it won, would plunge the country into chaos. Mr Aguilar Zinser countered: "We are not hostages of their stability, we are promoters of democracy, and if they fail to deliver democracy they fail to sustain stability. And if the international community sees it otherwise, tough."

Few clues on issues

But even Mr Aguilar Zinser conceded that it was difficult to tell if Mexicans would be in the mood for a post-poll protest aimed at forcing an annulment. "If we don't have the support, then we will not do it, or we will do it badly."

Also unpredictable is the reaction of the PRI if Mr Labastida loses. The party's own tradition of dirty tricks could make it hard to cry fraud credibly, but even if its rival gets a clear win, a septuagenarian political edifice built on clientalism and patronage does not disappear overnight.

Most economic analysts, however, predict that the country will avoid a crisis. The private sector seems confident that whoever becomes president will abide by the macro-economic othodoxy championed by the outgoing administration of President Ernesto Zedillo. Forty per cent of the country's 100m people are still in poverty, but the budget deficit and inflation have been brought under control.

Aside from the likelihood that economic management will continue to be cautious, there are few clues to how either candidate would handle other major issues. This is because the campaign has been fought almost exclusively on Mr Fox's character on the one hand, and on the other whether it can be healthy for the PRI to stay longer in the presidency.

Little of substance, for instance, has been said by the contenders about the conflict in the southern state of Chiapas, still simmering five years after the Zapatista rebels staged a brief but dramatic uprising in the name of indigenous rights.

Both candidates have promised to try to end the stalemate between the federal government and the Zapatistas, but neither has specified how. Mr Fox has dropped his earlier boast that he could settle this issue in 15 minutes.

The Zapatistas, led by Subcomandante Marcos, have pledged not to interfere with the setting up of polling stations in their areas of influence, while declaring a preference for the doomed PRD.

Conservative challenger with leftish fans

Vicente Fox's candidacy is a threat to the PRI because he has broadened his appeal beyond his centre-right party, the PAN, moving away from his own conservative Catholicism to build a movement around the single issue of change.

For this he owes much to two prominent leftwingers who joined his inner circle: Adolfo Aguilar Zinser , a senator and academic, and the author Jorge Castaneda . At national level, "this is the first time in Mexican history that power might be transferred through the ballot box. This has never occurred: not recently, not a long time ago, not never," says Mr Castaneda, who insists that Mr Fox is now firmly in the centre.

Mr Aguilar Zinser likes to portray his candidate as an adventurer jumping the PRI's perilous traps: "Mr Fox is the Indiana Jones of Mexican politics. A road exists that theoretically leads to the alternation of power.However, as you proceed the road gets narrower, the bridges collapse, the weather gets very bad and there are seductive temptations on the way. There has never been anyone in Mexican politics before able to cope with all of that."

If he reaches his goal, the senator argues, Mr Fox's acceptability with the right will guarantee a smooth transition .

The closest comparison to the present situation was election night 12 years ago, when early results showed gains for the opposition candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas. The lead was reversed after the government-controlled electoral computer system collapsed.

fields.headline: Real life horror
fields.standfirst: Joe Berlinger made a gruesome documentary about a satanic murder, then found himself hired to direct a fake one - the sequel to The Blair Witch Project
fields.trailText: Joe Berlinger made a gruesome documentary about a satanic murder, then found himself hired to direct a fake one - the sequel to The Blair Witch Project
fields.body:
On May 6, 1993, the bodies of three eight-year-old boys were found in Robin Hood Hills Park in West Memphis, Arkansas. They had been raped, tortured and mutilated - one of the boys' penises had the skin removed - before bleeding to death. There was no blood at the crime scene, no murder weapons found, and no footprints or any other physical evidence usually associated with such crime.

A month later, a five-hour undocumented interrogation by Arkansas police produced a statement from a 17-year-old boy with an IQ of 79, Jesse Miskelly Jr, that he had watched Damien Echols, 18, and Jason Baldwin, 16, ritually rape, mutilate and murder the boys as part of a Satanist ceremony. Miskelly Jr later retracted his statement, and despite a lack of physical evidence that linked any of the boys to the crime, the three were found guilty.

The only witnesses were two small girls who claimed to have overheard Echols boasting about killing the children. Crucial forensic evidence that might have acquitted Echols, Baldwin and Miskelly had been lost or overlooked by Arkansas police. Echols is facing death by lethal injection and Baldwin and Miskelly are serving life sentences without parole.

Soon after the success of their documentary Brother's Keeper, film-maker Joe Berlinger and his working partner Bruce Sinofsky read a report in the New York Times about three devil-worshipping teens who had killed three boys.

"It was at the time of the Jamie Bulger case," says Berlinger, "and I was fascinated by the idea that young people could be so alienated as to do something so evil. The idea was to make a portrait of disaffected youth, rather like a real-life River's Edge. I had read all the reports and assumed that the three boys were guilty, but later found out how local journalists had just talked to the families of the victims and discovered how much prejudice there is in Arkansas, which is real Bible Belt - mention the devil and everybody runs for cover.

"The first time I saw Damien in court, I had already imbued him with this sense of evil, and I remember thinking, 'Ooh, look at that spooky guy'. Two weeks later we interviewed him for the film, and he was intelligent, articulate, sympathetic, very narcissistic - a teenager who didn't understand the jam he was in.

"As I found out more about the story, nothing added up. The police weren't doing their job. I remember feeling very embarrassed that I had fallen victim to the hype surrounding [Damien] and realised that was how the community was reacting. There was a lazy media around the case who felt it easier to feed the Damien monster than do any real probing; a Bible-thumping part of the world with a literal belief in the idea of heaven and hell; and a crime so horrific that the community needed closure as soon as possible."

In terms of standard legal procedure, the trial was a farce. The strongest argument, and a theme that runs through the film, is that Damien was considered guilty because he wore black, listened to Metallica, had a vague knowledge of witchcraft and the Wicca religion that governs it and was articulate and curious in an inarticulate, closed-minded world.

"Damien Echols in New York or LA would be one among a thousand, and would most likely have been acquitted in those parts of the country," says Berlinger. "But in Arkansas he was guilty because of the way he looked."

The entire trial hung on the Miskelly confession, but it could not be used in a second trial for Echols and Baldwin because Miskelly would not agree to substantiate it. "There was a ceremonial change of venue for Echols' and Baldwin's trial to 100 miles away from West Memphis to ensure the jury wasn't biased, but that's a joke in this day and age," says Berlinger. "The local papers printed Miskelly's confession a few days before the trial, so the jury were already decided."

Few people could watch the film and not strongly suspect that a miscarriage of justice had taken place. But with such a subject there is a moral question as to how the material should be presented.

"A documentary is necessarily subjective, and we've been criticised for adding music and trying to give it a narrative, but it's structured around what we thought happened. You can't have absolute, objective truth when you're dealing with a subject like this, but you can aim to be emotionally truthful. The most important truth is that there are far too many questions surrounding the case to put this guy to death."

Berlinger returned to the case in a recent film, Paradise Lost 2: Revelations. For him, the Damien Echols affair has been a professional choice that turned into an ethical one. "We certainly didn't have a great social agenda when we made the first film. It was originally intended as a portrait of a subculture. But on the second film we were on a quest to find justice. The whole thing was emotionally draining: I had just become a father when we started shooting, and I was looking at photographs of the mutilated boys all day before going home to my little girl at night. The last thing I wanted to do was a sequel, which is rarely creatively satisfying, but we wanted to see justice. It's ironic that I'm now working on the sequel to The Blair Witch Project."

From documenting a horrific saga of a modern-day witch-hunt to making a follow-up to the most celebrated horror movie of recent times may seem a strange move. "Film-making is film-making," explains Berlinger of his decision. "I'm critical of anyone who wants to ghettoise it into documentary or fiction, and I've always considered myself a film-maker-storyteller first and a journalist second.

"In documentary you can't put words in people's mouths but you're very conscious of dramatic structure and a certain shooting style while needing to stick to what's truthful. So the transmission to features isn't such a big deal - it's a different way of working, but the director of a movie is hired to give a vision, to be the keeper of a flame. It's just odd that it's Blair Witch, which was a faked documentary anyway."

Berlinger was hired at the behest of Artisan Entertainment's studio executives who had seen the Paradise Lost documentary and admired it; he was also suggested by Blair Witch's directors Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez, who had based much of their celebrated website on the one for Paradise Lost.

"I was called up to pitch an idea to Artisan, but I think they already had me in mind," says Berlinger. "It was Thanksgiving, and I was sent three scripts. I passed on all of them as they were too similar to the first film. Lightning never strikes twice, and I had no intention of being the guy who killed the franchise. So Artisan asked me what I'd do with the subject. I wrote a script over a weekend, and by mid-February we were in production."

Berlinger isn't at liberty to say much about the film, but a few clues have emerged. There are five central characters who get lost in the woods, three men and two women, one of whom is a Wiccan and upset at the way witches have been portrayed in the first film. The title is suffixed "Book of Shadows", after the Wiccan book of incantations and spells. The group is involved in searching for traces of Rustin Parr who murdered seven children in the 40s.

There is no doubt that Berlinger is bringing his own ideas to the project. Taking on the sequel to a successful film is, of course, a dangerous business, but Berlinger is confident. "Blair Witch did three things well that I aim to keep," he says. "Firstly, it blurred the lines of fiction and reality, and I'm hoping to do that in an original and innovative way. Secondly, it had a psychological unravelling of the characters, as things start out light-hearted and get more and more serious. Thirdly, it was goreless - what you didn't see evoked fear. I've used a little more visuals to heighten the scares, but still created a movie without much blood."

The director of the most chilling documentary of recent times looks set to go his own way with Book of Shadows. "It couldn't follow in the first movie's footsteps, but it had to have enough mythology so that the Blair Witch fans get something out of it. My favourite childhood film series was Planet of the Apes - they were all connected, but each one didn't depend on the previous movie. That's my plan. But I think it's scary as hell, and a few people are going to be surprised."

 Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills is screening at 12.10am, tomorrow, on FilmFour.

 Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows is due for release on October 27.

Few people could watch the film and not strongly suspect that a miscarriage of justice had taken place. But with such a subject there is a moral question as to how the material should be presented. "A documentary is necessarily subjective, and we've been criticised for adding music and trying to give it a narrative, but it's structured around what we thought happened. You can't have absolute, objective truth when you're dealing with a subject like this, but you can aim to be emotionally truthful. The most important truth is that there are far too many questions surrounding the case to put this guy to death." Berlinger returned to the case in a recent film, Paradise Lost 2: Revelations. For him, the Damien Echols affair has been a professional choice that turned into an ethical one. "We certainly didn't have a great social agenda when we made the first film. It was originally intended as a portrait of a subculture. But on the second film we were on a quest to find justice. The whole thing was emotionally draining: I had just become a father when we started shooting, and I was looking at photographs of the mutilated boys all day before going home to my little girl at night. The last thing I wanted to do was a sequel, which is rarely creatively satisfying, but we wanted to see justice. It's ironic that I'm now working on the sequel to The Blair Witch Project." From documenting a horrific saga of a modern-day witch-hunt to making a follow-up to the most celebrated horror movie of recent times may seem a strange move. "Film-making is film-making," explains Berlinger of his decision. "I'm critical of anyone who wants to ghettoise it into documentary or fiction, and I've always considered myself a film-maker-storyteller first and a journalist second. "In documentary you can't put words in people's mouths but you're very conscious of dramatic structure and a certain shooting style while needing to stick to what's truthful. So the transmission to features isn't such a big deal - it's a different way of working, but the director of a movie is hired to give a vision, to be the keeper of a flame. It's just odd that it's Blair Witch, which was a faked documentary anyway." Berlinger was hired at the behest of Artisan Entertainment's studio executives who had seen the Paradise Lost documentary and admired it; he was also suggested by Blair Witch's directors Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sanchez, who had based much of their celebrated website on the one for Paradise Lost. "I was called up to pitch an idea to Artisan, but I think they already had me in mind," says Berlinger. "It was Thanksgiving, and I was sent three scripts. I passed on all of them as they were too similar to the first film. Lightning never strikes twice, and I had no intention of being the guy who killed the franchise. So Artisan asked me what I'd do with the subject. I wrote a script over a weekend, and by mid-February we were in production." Berlinger isn't at liberty to say much about the film, but a few clues have emerged. There are five central characters who get lost in the woods, three men and two women, one of whom is a Wiccan and upset at the way witches have been portrayed in the first film. The title is suffixed "Book of Shadows", after the Wiccan book of incantations and spells. The group is involved in searching for traces of Rustin Parr who murdered seven children in the 40s. There is no doubt that Berlinger is bringing his own ideas to the project. Taking on the sequel to a successful film is, of course, a dangerous business, but Berlinger is confident. "Blair Witch did three things well that I aim to keep," he says. "Firstly, it blurred the lines of fiction and reality, and I'm hoping to do that in an original and innovative way. Secondly, it had a psychological unravelling of the characters, as things start out light-hearted and get more and more serious. Thirdly, it was goreless - what you didn't see evoked fear. I've used a little more visuals to heighten the scares, but still created a movie without much blood." The director of the most chilling documentary of recent times looks set to go his own way with Book of Shadows. "It couldn't follow in the first movie's footsteps, but it had to have enough mythology so that the Blair Witch fans get something out of it. My favourite childhood film series was Planet of the Apes - they were all connected, but each one didn't depend on the previous movie. That's my plan. But I think it's scary as hell, and a few people are going to be surprised."  Paradise Lost: The Child Murders at Robin Hood Hills is screening at 12.10am, tomorrow, on FilmFour.  Blair Witch 2: Book of Shadows is due for release on October 27.

fields.headline: Hunger and the junta
fields.standfirst: Brazilian film didn't just survive under dictatorship. It thrived. Peter Lennon on the power of Cinema Novo
fields.trailText: Brazilian film didn't just survive under dictatorship. It thrived. Peter Lennon on the power of Cinema Novo
fields.body:
In 1963, Nelson Pereira dos Santos, already an established director in Brazil, made a film called Barren Lives. It was a kind of Brazilian Grapes of Wrath, set in the north-east of the country and made for $25,000. The same year, that region, notorious for oppressive landowners and destitute peasants, was the setting for The Guns, by Ruy Guerra, a tale of murderous landowners. A year later Glauber Rocha's Black God, White Devil. The latter, described as "a frenzied parable of desperation", poetically exposed the pitiful agrarian situation in the north-east.

The world was now alerted to a powerful new film movement: Cinema Novo. Dos Santos is recognised as its father; Rocha gave it its slogan: "the aesthetics of hunger". In 1969, Rocha introduced western filmgoers to the figure of the cangaceiro, the avenging social bandit, in Antonio das Mortes.

Cinema Novo was fiercely committed to righting the wrongs of society. Maturing during the term of the progressive President Goulart, within two years Cinema Novo faced obliteration following the military coup of April 1964, which introduced 21 years of military dictatorship. Barren Lives was banned; Rocha was arrested, though Black God, White Devil, critically acclaimed at Cannes, gave him some measure of temporary immunity.

In the teeth of dictatorship, Cinema Novo began to deal with urban problems. The Big City (1966) by Carlos Diegues, described the plight of rural migrants to the capital. Rocha made Land in Anguish, shot, as many of the films were, by cinematographer Luis Carlos Barreto. Land in Anguish was an allegorical treatment of a theme repeated by others: the ambiguous role of middle-class intellectuals. The central figure is a corrupt politician continually switching sides. It was smuggled to Cannes and won the International Critics' prize.

Dos Santos made Hunger for Love (1968), a bitter analysis of the failed Brazilian revolution expressed by a wife-swapping couple.

The movement proved to possess an astonishing vitality, with the directors displaying a capacity to change style as the occasion - and military repression - demanded. If European audiences detected a pretentiousness at times in the heavy use of allegory and myth, it was no affectation: this was often the only means by which the directors could outwit censors.

An internal military coup in December 1968 brought with it a new dictator, General Médici, and Cinema Novo entered its cannibalistic/tropicalist phase. In 1971 Dos Santos made what is regarded as a masterwork of subversion: the delirious How Tasty Was My Little Frenchman, a metaphor for the cultural genocide European colonists inflicted on the Americas. Ironically, while it survived the military censorship, it was banned at Cannes for excessive nudity.

There are extraordinary contradictions in the survival of Cinema Novo. It was the military regime that created, in 1966, a National Film Institute and Embrafilme - which provided state funding. Carlos Diegues was one of the beneficiaries of the military government's desire that the cinema should commemorate the 150th anniversary of the country.

John King, film historian and lecturer in Latin American culture at Warwick University, writes in his book Magical Reels that the government gave massive credits for historical films but that Diegues' 1977 film Xica da Silva, for example, was characterised by "carnivalesque subversion... [and] represented history against the grain of the nationalist, triumphalist desires of the government".

In this period Brazilian film production was protected by a quota; every foreign feature had to have a homemade short shown with it. But by another irony it was the first elected civilian president who destroyed the industry. In 1990, Fernando Collor de Mello abolished Embrafilme. No film was produced that year, or the next, from a high of 103 a year.

Dos Passos was still a force, though, and Hector Babenco had won a Cannes prize in 1986 for the star (William Hurt) of his Kiss of the Spider Woman. A former minister of the treasury, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, became president in 1994 and took the country in a new direction, with privatisation of state companies and a liberal economic policy. Film-makers now depend largely on private businesses taking advantage of generous tax breaks for film investment.

Delivered to the not-so-tender mercies of the market, could anything of the spirit of Cinema Novo survive? The late 90s were not without successes. The most notable was Walter Salles's Central Station. The story of a tough old lady who crosses Brazil with a little boy to help him find his father, it won the Berlin Golden Bear, and leading lady Fernanda Montenegro a Silver Bear.

John King believes "the younger film-makers have moved out of the overtly political into something that is more psychological, often expressing frustration. There is a sense of them knowing what the tradition is but keeping a distance from it and reinventing it. They are rather sardonic about the messianic bandits of the 60s. But there is some very stylish new work."

Writing in 1998, critic and film editor Inácio Araújo expressed apprehension: "Before, producers attempted to make art. Today, the key word is product. What is being asked for... are Brazilian films capable of competing with American films under the same conditions." But Araújo sees hope in the work of Tata Amaral, whose 1996 A Starry Sky is the story of a young hairdresser who wants to go to Miami to change her life; and in Beto Brant's stylish thriller, Belly Up. These films, he says, show that young film-makers still "choose", as he puts it, "to take risks and place their passions above convenience".

Considered the star of the younger directors, Walter Salles, is shooting a new film in Brazil. His Central Station won over 50 international awards, so he has less difficulty raising finance. Speaking from location, Salles says he has transferred Bitter April, a story by Albanian author Ismail Kadare, to the Brazilian north-east. "It is," he says, "a libertarian tale of individual values in a world where violence and barbarism grow geometrically."

He believes Brazilian cinema faces a new challenge. "In the 60s, the enemy was easily recognisable: the military, official ramifications, religious order and so on. Now, the structural problems are not very different from what they were in the 60s but the enemies are less palpable: the neo-liberal order, manipulation of political parties."

He sees racism as a continuing problem. "Tele-novelas here show an apparent harmony but this harmony only exists because one group is submissive to the other."

As for the problem of creating a counterweight to north American cultural colonisation, he says: "On the one hand I believe that what in the 60s was called 'cultural imperialism' is still a reality. On the other hand, I believe new technologies will somehow democratise the access of more film-makers to our medium. My brother shot a documentary recently in the slums and at one point he realised that a young girl of 20, with a digital camera, was shooting the same police raid. The possibility for her to shoot that scene would not have existed a few years ago. In this sense I am optimistic about the possibility of new film-makers appearing, although I am not nearly as optimistic about the possibility of showing those images on the large screens."

 Cinema Novo and Beyond opens on July 1 at the NFT, London (box office: 020-7928 3232); Brazilian Cinema in the 90s runs from July 15-23 at the Barbican, London (020-7638 8891). An updated edition of John King's Magical Reels is published by Verso in September.

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: Witness Protection | Anywhere But Here | Blue Streak
fields.trailText: Witness Protection | Anywhere But Here | Blue Streak
fields.body:
Witness Protection
Rental
High Fliers Cert 15
****

America's witness protection programme crops up from time to time - in GoodFellas, briefly, and My Blue Heaven, clumsily. But this is the first film I've seen put it at the centre of the action. Director Richard Pearce concentrates on the process of re-orientation and evaluation, "a re-adjustment of expectations" as Forest Whitaker, the patient agent in charge of operations, puts it, and turns in a surprisingly moving film, shot in sombre colours with acerbic dialogue.

It's the anatomy of a family at the point of maximum strain, trying to come to terms with an unknown life that will be very different to the one they know. Tom Sizemore, usually a reliable, hulking support actor, gets a rare lead role as the middle-level mobster with a 16-count indictment for extortion and racketeering who has to face a disintegrating family. He's been a bit of an absentee father whose life now depends on his resentful nearest and dearest. Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio is his smart but brittle wife. The couple have a teenage son and a small daughter ("So if we play make-believe, the bad man won't find us?" is how she understands it).

The film, which takes place almost exclusively in the halfway house between the old life and the new, takes a sombre, documentary approach which works well, and a sub-plot adds to the growing tension: who set up Sizemore for the botched hit that starts the film? Could it have been one of his own family? Made for HBO, home of that other unconventional mob family, the Sopranos.

Anywhere But Here
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 15
***

Fairly standard mother-and-daughter stuff enlivened by a flamboyant turn from Susan Sarandon, who insists on removing her 14-year-old daughter, Natalie Portman, from home in humdrum Wisconsin to follow her dreams in Beverly Hills. It's a small-scale, intimate drama, typically for director Wayne Wang, taken from Mona Simpson's book.

The plot takes tragic and comic turns, largely occasioned by the mood swings of Sarandon's character. She's likeable and exasperating, and we're invited to see her through the eyes of her daughter, who has an occasional voiceover role. Portman, who has more than a hint of AbFab's Saffy, is dragged to auditions to fulfil her mother's ambitions for her to be an actress, when she really just wants to go to college. (Appropriately Portman, recently a Star Wars princess, is now off to Harvard and knocking stardom on the head for a few years.)

Blue Streak
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 12
*

Will Smith's old Bad Boys partner Martin Lawrence is currently getting jiggy with the box office in Big Momma's House. Blue Streak pretty much re-treads his old mentor Eddie Murphy's Beverly Hills Cop days, using a well-worn plot about a con who comes out of jail to find that the place where he stashed the loot (an enormous diamond) has been built on and now houses a police station.

Lawrence is likeable enough - and he has to be because he's hardly ever off-screen - but this is one of those "comedy vehicles" which assumes star power will see it through. There are some funny moments early on as our hero tries to break into the cop shop as a ludicrous-looking pizza man and executes a weirdly comic and energetic breakdance, but once Lawrence becomes a criminal pretending to be a cop and then a pretend cop pretending to be a pretend criminal, the film becomes a wearisome farrago with a plot that wouldn't fool the average six-year-old.

It's particularly dispiriting, when Eddie Murphy has just played his funniest part in years in Bowfinger, to see this kind of sloppy big-budget mess turned out in the name of comedy with some good actors (William Forsythe and Rushmore's Luke Wilson) totally wasted. I liked Lawrence's use of a police megaphone though: "This is the LAPD. We got guns and shit."

fields.headline: Mad about Marlene
fields.standfirst: The high cheekbones, the halo of blonde curls, the voice like a petulant throb... Marlene Dietrich was more than a sex goddess. She was a serpentine vixen who glowed in her movies like a full moon. Michael Atkinson unravels her raw allure
fields.trailText: The high cheekbones, the halo of blonde curls, the voice like a petulant throb... Marlene Dietrich was more than a sex goddess. She was a serpentine vixen who glowed in her movies like a full moon. Michael Atkinson unravels her raw allure
fields.body:
Marlene Dietrich was one of the most fabulously, absurdly beautiful actresses of the Hollywood Golden Age and, arguably, its most contrived - manufactured from soft lighting, make-up, dental work and stylised visuals. Perhaps it was this combination that made her second only to Garbo in terms of raw allure and the capacity for seducing a movie camera.

It's easy to gaze upon her and wonder whether she was even verifiably human, her eyes were that cat-shaped, her cheekbones that high, her skin that sheeny. But true Dietrich fans - and I have counted myself one since I was 11 and saw Shanghai Express for the first time - are also made ardent by the halo of loose blonde curls that surrounds her sharp, alien gorgeousness; the meaty, petulant throb in her voice (rarely, in those first films, ever rising above a murmur); the womanly warmth in those eyes; the affectionate angle of her crooked, lipsticked smirk.

Dietrich wasn't just a sex goddess - she was an enrapturing cataract of contradictions, a female ideal made flesh. To watch her in one of her Josef von Sternberg-directed films of the 30s is to see movies become the illumination of our dreams.

Hollywood in the 30s was full of beautiful immigrants, of whom Garbo was the most famous (without being the most popular, by a long shot), and all imports, from Hedy Lamarr to Charles Boyer to Ingrid Bergman, had their looks, personas, biographies and often their names rehabilitated by the studio publicity mills.

Dietrich, though, was a special case: no one in the history of movies had their on-screen life so tightly controlled as Dietrich did in her first years in La La Land. The controller was the Brooklyn-born von Sternberg, with whom Dietrich undoubtedly had some kind of intimate relationship, the precise nature of which we'll never know. Those films - Morocco (1930), Dishonoured (1931), Shanghai Express (1932), Blonde Venus (1932), The Scarlet Empress (1934) and The Devil Is a Woman (1935) - are masterpieces of vapour, shadow and lust, and in them Dietrich glows like a full moon.

Already a reputable auteur in Hollywood, von Sternberg came into his own as a master of stylised opulence, heartbreaking kitsch and visual form (after seeing Morroco, which was shot in California, the Moroccan emir reputedly asked the director when he had visited Africa with his cameras); and Dietrich was, for those five years, the centre of his cyclone.

Never has an actress been attended to so meticulously as Dietrich was by von Sternberg. As a result it is as though she's not "acting" but following the lead of the man behind the camera in a sexualised ballet. When von Sternberg was watching, Dietrich radiated. Her performances are like breathless renditions of a silent song, and her visual presence, which is what von Sternberg knew was 99% of what she was to us, is an end in itself. Often a film stops dead to look at her as she basks in its attention. There's no pretence of realism; they both knew they were constructing sublime, ridiculous sandcastles.

It really all started for both of them with The Blue Angel (1930), which von Sternberg went to Germany to direct, and which transformed Dietrich from middling German ingénue and cabaret act to a worldwide star. But The Blue Angel is asymptomatic; designed and shot like a gritty German Kammerspielfilm, it is like the work of another director. Indeed, the Josef-Marlene relationship probably started between it and the journey later that year to the sunny Paramount lot in Burbank for the making of Morocco.

In The Blue Angel, Dietrich is plump, painted crudely and rarely seen in close-up, a far cry from the serpentine vixen she would become once she and von Sternberg had the Hollywood machine at their disposal. (When, exactly, she had her molars removed to sink her cheeks in further is anyone's guess.)

An indisputably great film, The Blue Angel is a tough-skinned morality tale in which Dietrich (as a heartless dance-hall tramp) carelessly ruins the lives of men foolish enough to want her. This paradigm would not return for Dietrich and von Sternberg until their last film, The Devil Is a Woman. Between The Blue Angel and Morocco, Dietrich became the camera's fixation and she deepened into an iconic womanhood, saddened and wearied by her experiences with men.

She was nearly 30 when Morocco was released and, though she appeared timeless, her character had the unmistakable substance of a grown woman. (How odd - and rare - that quality seems today.) The plots of such films are classic silliness: in some exotic locale, world-weary Marlene would, against her best instincts, fall for a legionnaire or spy or soldier and sacrifice herself for him. These were exercises in amour fou, in which even the most experienced woman on the globe (and in Shanghai Express Dietrich was the all-knowing queen of demi-mondaines) could become a selfless martyr to romance.

As such, the von Sternberg films have aged into a fecund campiness, though as with many things deemed hilarious with the passing of time, there's a crazy, misty beauty to those films that cannot be laughed away: Morocco's sweaty evensong; Dishonoured's dry mockery of the Mata Hari legend (taken too seriously a year later in Garbo's Mata Hari); the berserk imagery of Blonde Venus (Dietrich in a gorilla suit and blonde afro wig) sutured to a tear-jerking scenario; Shanghai Express's lavishly faux exoticism; The Scarlet Empress's phallic expressionism; The Devil is a Woman's veil-draped lustiness. The silky scrim of cigarette smoke was the axiom of the films.

Without von Sternberg's obsessive presence and visual adoration, Dietrich never resonated in quite the same way again; she lost the hypnotising mixture of carnality, mystery and kindness that von Sternberg conjured. Outside von Sternberg's mini-worlds, she was merely ravishing, charming and game for anything.

The Dietrich season at the National Film Theatre, which starts tomorrow, begins with the von Sternberg classics (after a few rarely seen 1929 German silents, The Woman Men Yearn For and I Kiss Your Hand Madame), then surveys her subsequent voyage into more or less typical Hollywood genre movies.

Frank Borzage's Desire (1936) plops Dietrich down delicately into a jewel-thief/romance bit of screwball, pairing her with her Morocco co-star Gary Cooper. Richard Boleslawski's The Garden of Allah (1936) is the kind of picture in which you can feel Dietrich hunger for the perversity and adoration of von Sternberg. Instead, she seems lost in sanctimony, though it is also one of the 30s' loveliest colour films, and insanely melodramatic.

Jacques Feyder's Knight Without Armour (1937) fares better, with Robert Donat helping out Dietrich's Russian countess during the Red October of 1917. By the time of Destry Rides Again (1939) and The Flame of New Orleans (1941) Dietrich had become domesticated, playing inexplicably Teutonic-accented saloon floozies in comic westerns that took pains to bring the zeppelin of her legend crashing to earth.

She survived for decades in Hollywood playing ageing variations on the wayward German woman glowering at the world, culminating in her fake gypsy fortune-teller in Orson Welles' Touch of Evil (1958).

In the real world, Dietrich fared somewhat better - or worse, depending on how you look at it - becoming so reclusive in her old age that she insisted her old friend (and Judgment at Nuremberg co-star) Maximilian Schell could not photograph her for his 1984 documentary Marlene.

Dietrich lived in the cheap seats of cultural memory as a gay icon, both as a bisexual (she wore men's tuxedos as early as 1930, and in Morocco she kissed a woman deep on the lips for no better reason than to outrage the censors) and as a middle-aged, cigarette-hoarse nightclub star easily imitated by drag queens. It's a grotesque injustice, given the fierce glamour of those early films, and Dietrich's slow-boiling presence in them. She was the quintessential cinematic woman, as beautiful as could be withstood by mortal man, and well aware that all we know of her is what could be photographed. The rest was irrelevant.

 The Marlene Dietrich season is at the NFT July 1-30. Box office: 020 7928 3232.

fields.headline: A fanfare for filth
fields.trailText: A fanfare for filth
fields.body:
Whenever I meet someone who doesn't consider 1980's Caddyshack to be a pinnacle, an apogee, an Everest among vulgar American comedies, I find I must immediately reconsider the terms of our relationship. If they also find Bob Clark's egregious, excrescent 1981 sex-farce Porky's to be tasteless and lavatorial, then I won't even have them in the house. Out! Go on, get off my lawn.

Caddyshack was written by a master laureate of American vulgarity, Doug Kenney, editor of Harvard Lampoon and founding editor of National Lampoon, which in the early 70s was the funniest magazine in America. Its covers featured men pointing guns at sad-eyed basset hounds and saying "Buy this magazine or we shoot the dog," or a cutie dressed as Santa purring, "Buy this magazine and I'll show you my tits!" At Harvard Lampoon Kenney coauthored Bored of the Rings, a satire for Tolkien-phobics, featuring Dildo Draggins; and among his most memorable pieces from National Lampoon was the story First Blowjob.

Only in his 30s, he was intensely nostalgic for his halcyon bachelorhood in the suburbs and at college. First he wrote Animal House, then Caddyshack. Then he did tons of coke, forgot to cash lots of huge cheques, and either jumped or fell off a cliff in Hawaii in 1982. People mourn Belushi. Better to mourn Doug Kenney.

But he left his monuments, including this review of Caddyshack in Monthly Film Bulletin, the humourless likes of which I pray will never come back to haunt me twenty years hence: "There are jests about vomiting and nose-picking, while the most elaborate gag sequence involves a chocolate bar falling into a swimming pool and being mistaken for a turd... a sustained exercise in tiresomeness."

Until those last five words, I thought I was reading a rave review, one guaranteed to have me grabbing my coat and running to the picture house. Bill Murray, having drained and scrubbed the aforementioned pool, picks up what the audience already knows is only a candy bar, sniffs at it cautiously, then sinks his teeth into it and chews away happily, to the horror of the country club's assembled brass. Genius. You stick to your rhyming dictionary, MFB, and keep your nice clean hands off my shit-jokes.

Back then you could occasionally enjoy this sort of scatological stuff at the movies in America, but it was entirely absent from the public realm and from television. America has only recently lost its prudery and censorious cast of mind. It was only two years ago that TV scriptwriters were finally permitted to use the 70-year-old term "scumbag" (to understand its offensive original meaning, remove the "S").

Twenty years ago things were much worse than now. The set of Susan Harris's great sitcom Soap used to be visited by a network Standards Executive whose job it was to ensure that Katherine Helmond's cleavage remained decent at all times. I remember seeing Blake Edwards' 10 in a network-censored version in 1982. All the rude words were gone. Except for one. Dudley Moore, after enduring humiliation, injury and dejection, locks himself out of his own house and screams a word the station's bluenoses were obviously unfamiliar with: "Bollocks!" O, to hear it said so far from Albion was such untrammelled sweet delight...

America came late to tasteless jokes and toilet humour (the British, by contrast, built an empire on them), but in the last few years they've taken to it like ducks to water. But that's not to say it wasn't always there. Just listen to tapes of the old Friars' Club Roasts, at which celebs from the 40s till the present day have inventively insulted their colleagues in the raunchiest terms imaginable.

For instance, Milton Berle on King of the One-Liners Henny Youngman ("the funniest man since... John Houseman!"): "Here's a guy so generous he'll go out, get two blowjobs, come back and give you one of them." But this was in darkened, smoky nightclubs, not under the bright klieg lights of the movie set or the TV studio.

Well, things change, and if one thing accelerated the long overdue vulgarisation of American civic culture, it was the traumatic process of learning what the president got up to with Monica Lewinsky, and more importantly, what he got into her and what he did to that dress. National tolerance levels were ratcheted way up as pre-schoolers learned about dirty words and cigar-related sexual delinquency from precisely the same idiot-box whose executives had striven so long and hard to maintain their innocence.

Across the land, infants looked up from their bowls of Fruit Loops and Wheaties and asked: "Mommy, what's a blowjob?" No one missed a single tawdry detail and in metaphorical terms, some of that semen ended up migrating from Monica's dress to Cameron Diaz's hair in Peter and Bobby Farrelly's There's Something About Mary.

Other signs of the thaw include Austin Powers' literally shit-eating grin ("Nutty!") in The Spy Who Shagged Me, the pastry-based erotic idyll in American Pie, the foul-mouthed tykes of South Park: Bigger, Longer & Uncut, and the Farrelly brothers, whose latest comedy, Me, Myself & Irene topped the box office this weekend, with a fat $28m in receipts.

Jim Carrey plays a split-personality Rhode Island state policeman ("he's nuttier than squirrel-turds!") whose two personalities, mild Charlie and unbuttoned id-monster Hank, go to war with each other for the affections of Renee Zellweger's Irene. It's a little stiffer and less warm-hearted than Mary and, next to the very game and spirited Diaz, the bland, whey-faced Zellweger comes across as a bit of a pudding.

No matter, because besides an extravagantly funny performance from Carrey, there are excrement-jokes galore, and that's what we're after. There are also black midgets, albinos called Whitey, gigantic, anatomically precise dildos, cow-strangulations, "playing the back nine", outrageous sexism (Hank's endearments include "Candypants", "Cheese-Tits" and "my little pussy-fart"), and three huge black teenagers, all geniuses, whose every utterance contains a bracing obscenity. This is where the genially dirty-minded legacy of Doug Kenney has come home to roost - or to crap on our heads, depending on your degree of prudishness.
